HEADLINE: The Coach in Chief

 BODY:
The campaign is ticking by and the alarm meter among the Democratic faithful is ticking up. What happened to the Vice President Al Gore who made the smashing convention speech in Los Angeles and seemed ready to snatch Florida away from Gov. George W. Bush? How did the Democrats' Great Debater manage to let Mr. Bush slip-slide away with generalities about leadership and Beltway bickering? Finally, is it time to send out an S O S to the most restless lame duck in modern presidential campaign history?
No one who has watched Bill Clinton over the past five days can doubt that he is ready to carry the battle to the Republicans. In addressing Congressional Democrats in Washington last week and at a rally for Hillary Rodham Clinton on Long Island on Sunday, he defended his administration's record. But he also sounded like a debating coach dictating lines to a struggling student, in this case his vice president. "They're wrong. We're right. You've got to fight," Mr. Clinton said. "We tried it our way. We tried it their way. Our way is better." 
 Mr. Gore, for his part, faces both a generic and a specific problem. Vice presidents as different as Richard Nixon, Hubert Humphrey and George H. W. Bush have faced the general problem of stepping out of the shadow of large, and in some cases flawed, figures. Mr. Gore's special problem is that his senior partner's main achievement -- the best economic record in modern times -- ought to be a highly marketable political advantage. But when Mr. Gore dwells on Mr. Clinton's record, he plays into two main themes of the Bush campaign. Those are that Mr. Bush will bring a loftier standard of personal behavior to the Oval Office and that, in the long view, character is more important than experience.
From the standpoint of the Bush campaign, the more prominence for Mr. Clinton the better. Bush strategists had hoped all along to run against the president's personal reputation rather than Mr. Gore's policies. They profess to welcome a more prominent role for Mr. Clinton and see his direct attacks on Mr. Bush as actually adding to the governor's stature by elevating him to the presidential plateau.
Mr. Gore's not inconsiderable ego also played a role in the construction of the tactical box in which he finds himself. Since midway in the second term he has been hoping to run as the candidate who could deliver Clintonism without all that Arkansas-Lewinsky-Lincoln-Bedroom baggage. Now as his fellow Democrats are getting jumpy and talking about Mr. Clinton as an unused campaign resource, Mr. Gore needs to have the discipline to stick to the plan implicit in his convention declaration that "I stand here tonight as my own man."
Adding a series of joint appearances with Mr. Clinton now would carry the whiff of panic, especially given the convincing reports in The Times about the level of antipathy between the two men and their families. Mr. Clinton can and should be of use in targeted appearances to push Democratic turnout in places where he would be an unalloyed asset. Louisiana, where minority turnout is critical, and the tightening race in California come to mind.
But the president ought to discipline his tendency to upstage and undercut Mr. Gore with speeches in which the subtext is, "Hey, Al, here's how you make the case." Although Mr. Bush is holding a small, steady lead, neither candidate has closed the deal with the swing voters. Moreover, the decisive opinion shifts could come very late. Mr. Gore's best strategy is to remain the star of his campaign, no matter how loudly Mr. Clinton clears his throat and taps his foot. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1219 words

HEADLINE: Report Faults Laws for Slowing Growth of Unions

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
Marie Sylvain, a longtime nursing home worker, was so upset about her low wages and workload -- feeding, washing, dressing and changing linens for 14 patients each shift -- that she decided to lead a unionization drive.
But her employer soon fired her, and the organizing drive quickly fizzled as her 70 co-workers feared that they would also be dismissed if they pushed for a union. 
 That was four and a half years ago. Today, Ms. Sylvain voices intense frustration that, because of extended legal appeals, she has still not been reinstated even though a judge ruled nearly three years ago that her firing violated the National Labor Relations Act, which prohibits employers from firing or penalizing workers for supporting a union.
Ms. Sylvain's dismissal made her one of thousands of workers who are fired, demoted or otherwise punished each year for backing a union. A recent study of National Labor Relations Board data showed that from 1992 to 1997, employers fired or punished more than 125,000 workers for supporting a union.
Numerous academic studies showed that it frequently took three to five years for fired workers to be reinstated, delays that union leaders said often caused organizing drives to die at a time when the labor movement was seeking to add hundreds of thousands of members and reverse its decades-long decline.
"U.S. labor law is stacked against employees who wish to organize a union, allowing employers to intimidate and coerce workers not to unionize," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
But some experts said unions were having trouble attracting members, not because of firings and delays by the labor board, but because of economic changes, especially the shift from manufacturing to services.
"Job growth is coming where unions are historically weak," said Leo Troy, a labor economist at Rutgers University. "The economy is leaving unions behind. Employer behavior is virtually irrelevant to labor's decline. Employer behavior is an easy scapegoat."
The concern about obstacles to organizing is one reason labor is supporting Vice President Al Gore in the presidential race despite differences with him over trade. In numerous appearances at union conventions, Mr. Gore has vowed to push for changes that would make it easier for unions to organize.
"Vice President Gore has been the most outspoken champion of the freedom to join a union since Franklin Delano Roosevelt," Mr. Sweeney said.
A recent report by Human Rights Watch concluded that because of systematic violations by employers and long delays in obtaining legal redress, the United States was essentially violating international agreements guaranteeing the rights of workers to form unions.
"Most people view these issues as just a labor-management dispute," said Lance Compa, a Cornell University labor relations professor who wrote the Human Rights Watch report, "but we think the focus should be that there is a right of freedom of association recognized under international law, and that right is being widely denied in the United States."
In the 1950's, several hundred workers suffered reprisals each year for backing a union, according to National Labor Relations Board data. But Charles Morris, a professor emeritus at Southern Methodist University, said that by the late 1990's, employers carried out reprisals against more than 20,000 union supporters each year. He also found that 1 out of 18 workers involved in unionization drives faced some type of punishment for supporting the union.
Ms. Sylvain said her firing frightened other workers from backing a union at Palm Gardens nursing home.
"They say, 'Look what happened to Marie,' " said Ms. Sylvain, who said she was paid $6.50 an hour at the nursing home and needed food stamps and Medicaid to support herself and two children. "The law gives you something with one hand, and then it takes it away with the other."
But business groups argued that after eight years under President Clinton, the nation's enforcement was stacked against management, not unions.
"Back in the 1950's, unions were fat and happy and represented 35 percent of the labor force," said Randy Johnson, vice president for labor policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
"Now that they represent just 9 percent of private-sector workers," Mr. Johnson said, "they're blaming the law for their problems. They're trying to create a straw man instead of looking at the more logical explanation that the message unions have for workers isn't selling."
Many labor experts said the penalties that employers faced for firing union supporters were so modest that it made economic sense for companies to flout the law.
When the National Labor Relations Board ruled that Ernest Duval and six other fired workers should be reinstated five years after a nursing home in Palm Beach, Fla., fired them for leading a unionization drive, the labor board concluded that he was owed $1,800 in back pay. The award was modest because federal law requires employers to pay the wages workers missed after their dismissal, minus whatever they earned in other jobs they took after being fired.
The Human Rights Watch report said: "An employer determined to get rid of a union activist knows that all that awaits, after years of litigation if the employer persists in appeals, is a reinstatement order the worker is likely to decline and a modest back-pay award. For many employers, it is a small price to pay to destroy a workers' organizing effort by firing its leaders."
Mr. Compa said: "Firing is the single most potent anti-union weapon. The upshot is many employers can achieve their goal of remaining union-free by breaking the law."
 Vice President Gore has yet to spell out how he would change labor laws to make it easier to form unions. Also looking for ways to discourage illegal firings, Ralph Nader, the Green Party presidential candidate, has proposed that improperly fired union supporters receive punitive damages and lawyers' fees. Gov. George W. Bush, who has long clashed with unions, has not called for making it easier for workers to unionize.
Labor leaders said that as long as the Republicans controlled Congress, it would be difficult to enact laws making it easier to form unions. But, these leaders said, some steps could be taken under existing law, among them having the labor board's lawyers seek more injunctions that would quickly reinstate wrongly fired workers. That would allow the terminated employee to remain on the job during appeals.
Ms. Sylvain said she wished a court could have ordered her back to work while her case was appealed. In January 1998, 21 months after she was fired, an administrative law judge ruled that the nursing home had fired her illegally and that she should be reinstated. The judge found that the nursing home had concocted a story for firing by saying she took time off without filling out the required vacation forms.
In March 1999, the National Labor Relations Board in Washington affirmed that decision, but the nursing home appealed. On Oct. 5, a federal appeals court affirmed the labor board and ruled that Ms. Sylvain should be reinstated.
She is still not back on the job because the labor board has yet to negotiate her reinstatement with her the nursing home.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Although a judge ruled in 1998 that Marie Sylvain was fired for trying to organize a Miami nursing home, she is still waiting to return to work. (Andrew Itkoff for The New York Times)

COMPANY: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH CORNELL UNIVERSITY PRESS (50%); HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH (59%); HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH (59%); NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD (56%); NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD (56%);

HEADLINE: Tentative Pact Is Reached In Actor Strike

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23

 BODY:
A nearly six-month strike by thousands of actors who appear in television commercials was tentatively resolved today, ending a bitter labor dispute that involved issues ranging from pay in commercials on cable programs to advertisements on the Internet.
The walkout was the longest and one of the most fractious talent strikes in the history of Hollywood. It raised issues and set the stage, in some ways, for a far bigger labor confrontation planned next summer against film studios and television networks by actors as well as writers. Studios and networks are already in high gear making films and television shows before the threatened strike could shut down the entire entertainment industry. 
 In agreeing to end the strike, the advertisers settled several demands made by the two unions representing the actors. One of the demands was a near doubling over three years in the maximum flat fees paid to actors in commercials on cable television.
The advertisers also dropped their resistance to recognizing the jurisdiction of the unions for commercials that run on the Internet.
Representatives of two unions, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, announced the tentative end of the strike against advertisers following prolonged talks at the Millennium Hotel in Manhattan. The boards of both unions are set to endorse the agreement on Saturday, and the full memberships will vote shortly after that. A Screen Actors Guild official said that commercial actors could be working again as early as next week.
"All of us realize that for our common good it was time to end this strike," said William Daniels, an actor who is president of the Screen Actors Guild. Anywhere from 5,000 to 10,000 actors who earn a significant portion of their incomes making commercials were affected by the strike, which received financial support in recent months from such millionaire stars as Harrison Ford, Nicolas Cage, Helen Hunt, Kevin Spacey, Eddie Murphy and Bruce Willis. About 40 percent of the striking commercial actors live in New York, the Screen Actors Guild said.
At stake in the strike, which began May 1, were several issues. One of them was the rate of pay for actors who make commercials for cable programs. Actors, as well as writers, have long insisted that they had accepted less money for cable advertisements to help the cable industry establish itself. In recent years, though, the actors felt that now-profitable and lucrative cable stations were essentially exploiting them.
Under the agreement, actors would be paid a steady increase of fees for commercials on cable television. The deal stipulates that an actor's fees climb from a maximum of $1,360 in the first year of the contract to $1,706 in the second year and $2,460 in the third year. These maximum amounts are paid to an actor every quarter if an advertisement appears during that time. Currently actors making commercials receive a maximum $1,014 each quarter.
Another issue involved the unions' insistence that they have jurisdiction over ads using actors on the Internet. "Frankly, they wanted to cut us out by not granting us jurisdiction for commercials to be made on the Internet," said Greg Krizman, a spokesman for the Screen Actors Guild. "Depending whom you talk to, that's potentially the fastest point of growth for the ad industry."
The advertisers seem to have bowed to the unions on the Internet issue. Ira M. Shepard, a Washington lawyer who was chief negotiator for the advertisers, said that "we hammered out a fair compromise so the union would have limited jurisdiction in the future over commercials made exclusively for the Internet." He said that it was still unclear to what degree the Net would be used in employing actors to advertise products.
The strike had a definite impact on the economy of Los Angeles, where many of the commercials are filmed. Jack Kyser, chief economist at the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit group, estimated direct financial losses of about $125 million. Moreover, there was an additional business loss of $103 million because the strike also affected such businesses as catering.
There had been speculation recently that the strike would be settled during this round of talks, which began in New York on Thursday. The Screen Actors Guild was under increasing pressure to resolve the strike, partly because of heightened restiveness by actors toward the union's leadership.
The impact of the strike was visible and audible because familiar faces and voices were honoring the picket lines and not making commercials. For instance, Anheuser-Busch had planned to produce more commercials in the popular "Whassup!" series for Budweiser beer, but the actors who play the friends in the spots would not work during the strike, so during the Olympics and baseball playoffs the company reran old spots in the series. Coca-Cola had planned to start running a new campaign for Diet Coke, carrying the theme "Live it up. Drink it down," but had to postpone the introduction of the commercials.
And Burger King was hampered in producing new spots because Kathleen Turner, who has been the voice in the chain's current campaign, honored the strike; a replacement voice was required.
Watching high-profile TV shows like the Olympics, baseball playoffs, N.F.L. games, it seemed there were fewer new commercials and more spots were being rerun over and over, perhaps because of limited output of new spots with union talent.
During the strike, however, the Joint Policy Committee on Broadcast Talent Union Relations, as the coalition of advertisers and agencies negotiating with the unions is known, disseminated data that showed production was "virtually unimpeded," as the committee described it, by the strike. Many commercials were shot with nonunion talent, while others were moved to Canada or Mexico or overseas to shoot.
The commercial strike, the longest in the history of actors' unions, had a public side to it as well. The striking actors recently asked consumers to begin boycotting three products made by one of the big advertisers, the Procter & Gamble Company, in an effort to apply pressure to the advertisers and agencies. Forty-four cast members of two soap operas produced by P.& G., "As the World Turns" and "Guiding Light," sent a letter to Alan G. Lafley, the company's president and chief executive, urging him to help bring a "speedy resolution" to the strike.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Gore's Stump Speech: A Clear Choice, With Clear Visions for the Future

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of a speech by Vice President Al Gore on Saturday night at Martin Luther King High School in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times:
What a crowd in Philadelphia! Whooooo! This is amazing! Thank you for being here, Mayor John Street. You told me you'd throw a good party. Philadelphia knows how to throw a good party. Live from Philadelphia! It's Saturday night! 
 I want to thank Bob Brady, your great congressman and party chair. And Congressman Chaka Fattah. Thank you. They do a great job. I want to thank Auditor General Bob Casey Jr. back here. Thank you, Bob. I want to acknowledge our secretary of labor, Alexis Herman, who's around here somewhere. I want you to know my national campaign chairman -- person -- the best ever, Donna Brazile. She's probably organizing right now.
I want to ask you to join with me in a very special welcome and then join with me in making sure we elect him as the next senator from Pennsylvania, Ron Klink.
Tina Tartaglione, our state party chair, thank you, and all the distinguished guests who are here. John Myers, state representative. I want to thank the Martin Luther King band and choir. Thank you all for doing a great job. It's great to be in a school named after one of my heroes. Tomorrow morning I will fly out of Philadelphia to Dallas, Tex., where I will speak to a large gathering with Coretta Scott King. And I'll be speaking about justice and values. And this evening I want to talk to you about the choice that we face in this election on Nov. 7.
Seventeen days from now, Pennsylvania will decide who the next president of the United States will be. Seventeen days from now, Philadelphia will decide what Pennsylvania decides. Seventeen days from now, the people in this room will decide what Philadelphia decides.
The choice is very clear. The contrast is very stark. We have a choice between two candidates. But it's not about me or Governor Bush. It is about you and your family and your city and your future. Prosperity is on the ballot Nov. 7. Education and health care are on the ballot. Social Security is on the ballot. The environment is on the ballot. The future of your family is on the ballot Nov. 7.
The other side is trying to convince this country that we were a lot better off eight years ago than we are today. (Boos.) That was my reaction also. They want to go back to the kind of policies that we had eight years ago.
Let me tell you, we've got a lot of work left to do, but we have made some progress in the last eight years because we've turned the biggest deficits that they left us into the biggest surpluses. Instead of repeat recessions, we've seen a tripling of the stock market. Instead of high unemployment, we have the lowest African-American unemployment ever measured, the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured, 22 million new jobs and the strongest economy in the 224-year history of the United States of America. That's progress! But it's not good enough. I'm not satisfied. You ain't seen nothing yet!
 
A Vision of the Future
I see a future in which our prosperity is continued and everybody participates. Nobody is left behind. More jobs. Balance the budget every year, pay down the debt every year. I want to completely eliminate the national debt early in the next decade so it's not on the shoulders of these children.
I think it's time to invest in health care and education and the environment and middle-class tax cuts for the people who most need tax cuts and retirement security. I will put Social Security and Medicare in a lockbox and veto anything that takes money out of it.
Now let me tell you what the other side has proposed. They have proposed a tax cut for the very wealthy, a very big tax cut for the wealthy that gives almost half of the benefits to the top 1 percent. In the debates just concluded, the moderator, Jim Lehrer, asked Governor Bush whether or not it was true what I was saying about his massive tax cuts for the wealthy and whether or not it benefits the top 1 percent so much and Governor Bush's answer was, "Of course it does." Does that represent the wrong priority for America? Of course it does! Is that the wrong choice for our future? Of course it is.
He proposes -- and his own numbers show this -- to spend more money on a tax cut for the top 1 percent than all of the new money that he proposes to spend on education and health care and national defense combined. You have an opportunity between now and November the 7th to put your feelings into action, to put your beliefs on the street, to put your wishes into the form of votes on the part of your neighbors and friends. This is the closest election since John Kennedy won the presidency in 1960 by one vote per precinct. I want to ask every single person here to get me one more vote per precinct between now and November the 7th. And then some!
The other side, my opponent, has proposed to take a trillion dollars out of the Social Security trust fund, and he has promised it to two different groups of people. He's promised it to young people for savings and investment, and then he's promised the same trillion dollars to seniors to prevent any cuts in benefits. Now, I know that one and one equals two. I know that the only way to describe a promise to give the same one trillion dollars to two different groups of people is to say, what kind of math is that? Fuzzy math! Fuzzy math! Fuzzy math!
His own chief economist, when confronted with what he said in the debate about Social Security, said, "I don't know why the governor said what he said." Now, if his own economist can't explain what he said, how can the rest of America figure it out? Fuzzy math! If the proposal, according to the best economist, causes the bankruptcy of Social Security, then that is a consequence that is unacceptable for our country.
But my friends, we have got to put our beliefs in motion. We have got to get people out to the voting booth. We have got to get people encouraged to vote in large numbers because the future of our country is at stake.
Here's what I believe. I believe that we need to have an economic policy that puts people first, that has fiscal responsibility to keep the economy growing strongly, to make sure that we include everyone. For example, I'm for raising the minimum wage a dollar an hour for those who most need help. I'm for investing in the priorities that are most important to people. Where health care is concerned, we have to start taking the medical decisions away from the H.M.O.'s and give them back to the doctors and the nurses and the health care professionals. And it is time to recognize that seniors, especially those on fixed incomes, are having trouble choosing those between their medicine and their meals, choosing between some medicines and other prescriptions. It is time for a prescription drug benefit for all seniors under the Medicare program. I'm for it; my opponent is not.
 
'The Challenge of Equality'
I believe it is time to address the challenge of equality. We need an equal day's pay for an equal day's work for women in this country. We need a Supreme Court that reflects our values in this country. We need to pass the Employment Non-Discrimination Act in this country. We need to pass a hate-crimes law in America. We need to enforce the civil rights laws in America.
We need a commitment to our nation's schools to make them the best in the world. With smaller classes. More one-on-one time. And I want to give every middle-class family a tax deduction for college tuition of $10,000 a year. I believe it's time to recognize that we've all got to hang together. We've all got to stay together and vote together and organize together. And I believe it is time for men and women in the workplace to have the right to organize without it being undermined. That means that I'm for a law to get rid of permanent striker replacement in America.
Now, when we talk about the importance of staying together, we also have to understand how that applies to our nation as a whole. We must resolve that never again will we allow people to divide us along the lines of race or ethnicity or religion or any of those distinctions like gender, or who your partner is. We need to have a commitment to fairness.
Now, my friends, this election is up to you. It's a question of the economy, it's a question of values. You know that it's right to help parents and strengthen families. You know parents need more tools to protect their children against the cultural pollution that threatens the values that they want in their families. You know that we need after-school programs for the youngsters who are tempted to get in trouble after school. You know that we need more child care, affordable child care and help for stay-at-home parents also.
Now, finally, here is what it comes down to. We have got to recognize that our values have to be put into action at election time. I believe that we need to fight for clean air and clean water and against global warming and for an environment that's good for our children. I believe it's time to make every school gun-free and violence-free and drug-free.
 
The Importance of Passion
But finally, I want to ask each and every one of you not only for your vote and for your support, but for your enthusiasm and something more. I want to ask you for something that's difficult for you to give, something that people hardly ever give anymore. I want you to open your hearts and allow yourselves to genuinely believe that we can do the right thing in America and be the better for it, that we can have campaign finance reform, that we can turn out the vote.
Now, when I talk about turning out the vote, I'm extremely aware that Philadelphia can make up the margin in the entire Keystone State of Pennsylvania. I'm keenly aware that that turnout depends upon each and every one of you. So here's what I'm asking. When you go home after this rally, and when you encounter your neighbors and your friends during the next 17 days, I want you to arm yourselves with the issues and the arguments about why our priorities are good for the country and the other side would take us on a right-wing U-turn back to the economic problems of the past.
But then I want you to arm yourself with something else -- and that is the passion of your belief, the strength of your conviction, the steel of your determination, the passion of your feelings about the future. When you encounter someone who says it doesn't make any difference who appoints the next three justices of the Supreme Court, when you encounter someone who says it doesn't make any difference what kind of economic priorities we have in America, when you encounter someone who says they don't even think they're going to take the time to vote, what I want you to do is not just give them the facts, I want you to give them the feeling. I want you to give them a piece of your mind, and then your whole heart. I want you to tell them how much you care.
My friends, sometimes the people who have the strongest ideals and the best hearts convince themselves they need to stay at arm's length from the political process. Maybe they're afraid their hearts will be broken, maybe they're afraid they'll be disappointed, let down or disillusioned. I'm telling you. I've said this before but I'll say it again. I may not always be the most exciting politician, like John Street or Chaka Fattah or Bob Brady, but I will work for you every single day, I'll fight for your families and I'll never let you down.
I know this. I know one thing about the job of president. It is the only position in the Constitution that is filled by someone who is given the responsibility to fight not just for one group, not just for one state or district, not just for the wealthy or the well-connected or the powerful, not just for the top 1 percent. A president who does the job right has to be willing to fight for all of the people, especially you, especially those who most need a champion. I'm running for president because I want to fight for you. I want to fight for your family. I want to fight for Philadelphia. For Pennsylvania! For the future of the United States of America. God bless you. I need your help.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: AN ILLINOIS RACE;
Attacked From Right, but That's Nothing New

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: ROCK ISLAND, Ill.

 BODY:
Republicans here say the liberalism of Lane Evans, the Democratic congressman who has represented the district for 18 years, scarcely fits this farm-and-factory region of northwestern Illinois.
It is a claim they have made for nine elections and are pressing again this year as Mr. Evans seeks a 10th term. As in the last two races, they have nominated Mark Baker, a former television newscaster, in hopes of unseating the congressman and helping to confound Democratic efforts to wrest control of the House. 
 "This district looks like it ought to be a tossup," said Jim Winship, a political science professor at Augustana College here. "But the Republicans have just not been able to crack it."
The Rock Island-Moline area, home to the tractor maker Deere & Company, was once known as the Detroit of the Farm Belt, a center of good-paying assembly-line jobs protected by strong unions, especially the United Automobile Workers. That blue-collar foundation remains the source of the Democratic strength here in the 17th Congressional District, although the number of U.A.W. jobs has been declining since the mid 1980's, when a big International Harvester plant shut down and other agricultural equipment makers, including Deere, were hit hard by the farm recession.
The Republican hopes lie in the district's small towns and rural stretches and in the more affluent parts of East Moline, home to many of the area's white-collar workers.
Mr. Baker, the Republican challenger, has sought to highlight social issues, noting Mr. Evans's support for abortion rights and gay rights and his opposition to a constitutional amendment that would allow Congress to ban flag-burning.
"Those just aren't the value systems in western Illinois," Mr. Baker said as he greeted factory workers in the small city of Sterling. "And that's what's going to bring him down."
Mr. Evans replies that after 18 years in Congress, he is familiar to the voters.
"If it were true," he said of the accusation that he is too liberal for his constituents, "it would have caused me to lose my job."
The son of two Rock Islanders -- a firefighter and a nurse -- Mr. Evans said he needed no lectures about the district's mores. "I'm born and raised here," he said. "I know the values of people here."
In fact, this is not a district that has historically been driven by sharply conservative views, even among Republicans. The last Republican to represent it was Thomas F. Railsback, a moderate who as a member of the House Judiciary Committee voted to recommend the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon.
In any event, there is little confusion about where the candidates stand, judging from two dozen interviews on the sidewalks of the district.
To Don Walker, a 53-year-old construction worker, Mr. Evans deserves support because he has been loyal to unions.
"He sides with the working people," Mr. Walker said as he filled his pickup truck with gasoline. "Wages are definitely up. Everybody who wants to work is working."
But to Phil Rocker, a 72-year-old farmer, Mr. Evans's support for unions is a bit too automatic.
"He's 100 percent for the unions, no matter what the issue is," Mr. Rocker said. "I don't have anything against Evans as a person. It's just that he's so liberal, and I tend to be a little more on the conservative side."
But much of the talk in this campaign has centered on entirely local issues like the odors emanating from waste lagoons at huge hog-confinement operations, and the debate on whether to build another bridge over the Mississippi River.
"The economy has come back a lot from the hard times of the 80's," Professor Winship said. "It's a much more diversified region than it used to be. And riverboat gambling has provided a lot of jobs."
The district is more than 94 percent white, and its population nearly 40 percent rural. In the last two presidential elections, the voters here sided with Bill Clinton, who defeated Bob Dole by 13 points in 1996. The last two Congressional races have been much closer, with Mr. Evans winning 52 percent of the vote against Mr. Baker in each.
A peripheral issue in the race this year has been the health of Mr. Evans, who has Parkinson's disease. Evans backers say Mr. Baker's frequent references to his own high level of energy is a not-so-subtle reminder to voters of the congressman's condition.
Mr. Evans has run advertisements talking about his case of Parkinson's, which he says does not interfere with his duties but does make him more understanding of the challenges faced by people with illnesses.
To a voter like Debbie Schweska, Mr. Evans's condition makes him even more appealing, as a politician who understands the difficulties of the underdog.
"You've got these Republicans who are harping about the marriage tax," said Ms. Schweska, who works in a convenience store. "Give me a break. Let's talk about the people who are really struggling, like the moms on welfare who don't get a nickel in child support."

HEADLINE: Yemeni Supply Firm Emerges as a Focus of Inquiry Into Ship Attack

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ADEN, Yemen, Oct. 23

 BODY:
As the destroyer Cole rounded the Cape of Aden 12 days ago and followed a pilot boat to its berth in Aden harbor, its arrival set off a flurry of activity at a ramshackle suite of offices near the port.
Under lazy fans that cool the second-story walk-up on Ali Mohsen al-Meraisi Street, named for a 1960's soccer player who was Aden's equivalent of Mickey Mantle, shirt-sleeved shipping clerks at a small family-owned firm prepared to provide chandlering services to the Cole. 
 Behind a fading sign declaring "Al Mansoob for Ship Supply and General Trade," the company's owners proudly declare that their chandlering operations have made the company "King of the Sea" in these parts, though for the last 30 years this once crucial and proud port has been a backwater, and it may soon sink back into near-obscurity.
Chandlering involves resupplying vessels with everything from paint and rope to fuel and fresh food and water, as well as clearing garbage and otherwise preparing ships to set to sea again. The Cole was a customer because Al Mansoob had the chandlering contract for all United States Navy ships, which started using Aden in 1999 to refuel ships moving between the Mediterranean and the Persian Gulf and the Far East.
That meant that at least some of the staff at Al Mansoob's offices knew at least 48 hours in advance about the Cole's progress through the Suez Canal and into the Red Sea, that the ship was a guided-missile destroyer and that its arrival here would be the signal for a small flotilla of service boats, including at least two from Al Mansoob, to move around it like pilot fish.
One of the two Mansoob boats was a barge sent to unload garbage. Another, according to Yemeni investigators, took at least one employee from Al Mansoob out to the ship, where he was when the bombing occurred that killed 17 sailors and 2 men on a skiff carrying the explosives. Thus Al Mansoob immediately became the focus of investigators after the Cole was attacked. Many of Al Mansoob's 35 employees, including the general manager, Ahmed al-Mansoob, and the man believed to have been aboard the Cole, Hussain Bakhateer, were detained by the Yemenis for questioning, although all but Mr. Bakhateer were later released.
Now, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, working with Yemeni investigators, has determined that the bombers' skiff was not part of the service flotilla, having approached the Navy ship from a different direction, a remote boat ramp six miles to the west across the Bay of Aden.
These discoveries appear to have prompted the investigators to review, if not abandon, earlier theories that the refueling operation was infiltrated by the bombers, perhaps with the connivance of the other service vessels, or part of some conspiracy in which the resupply operation was used as a decoy to allow the attack craft to slide alongside the Cole.
But while the F.B.I. is following up a cascade of discoveries last week -- the boat ramp, an abandoned four-wheel-drive vehicle and a boat trailer believed to have been used by the bombers and five safe houses in Aden where the bombers may have prepared the boat and the bomb and tested an outboard motor -- Al Mansoob and its staff remain under the spotlight. Now, Yemeni investigators say, the focus is on determining whether the chandlering operation could have been used to gather intelligence about the Cole's docking plans or to time the attack so that it meshed unobtrusively with the service operation.
Beyond that, longer-range inquiries by the F.B.I., the Navy and the Senate Armed Services Committee, which opened its own hearings in Washington last week, seem certain to focus on Al Mansoob as they seek to assess how thoroughly the Navy prepared its refueling operations.
Inquiries made by reporters here and statements by Pentagon officials suggest that the firm's security was loose enough that determined conspirators might have had little trouble compromising it.
Before the Cole was attacked, Mr. Mansoob, the general manager, had boasted that the Navy contract was pure gold. His reasoning, other chandlering agents recall, was that the Navy's seal of approval would entrench a dominance that the company had enjoyed since the distant days when Aden was a stopover for steamer passengers heading to and from British India and other destinations in the Far East.
But now, the Navy contract looks as though it could turn into something more like lead for the company and for the port of Aden if the inquiry leads the Navy to conclude that refueling there will end.
British, French and other foreign navies that have occasionally brought their ships here for service would be likely to follow the American lead. "If Yemen is really going to begin moving economically, it's going to need a full recovery in Aden port," one of the American officials involved in assessing Aden's suitability before the 1999 contract was let said today at a briefing for reporters. "And if there's no confidence in this port, international shipping will not come in -- it's that simple."
Before Yemeni investigators turned up the heat on the company, other reporters had conversations with Addullah al-Khalqi, the marketing manager, who said that most of Al Mansoob's employees were family members and that none had been checked for past involvement with criminal or terrorist activities. When asked why not, Mr. Khalqi replied, "We believe their word."
Pentagon officials have said security checks for employees of Yemeni companies or other intrusive efforts to make sure that port operations were not vulnerable to infiltration impossible, given Yemeni concerns about sovereignty.
The officials have been quoted as saying that any foolproof measures to secure the port would have required "militarizing" it.
But leaving security to the Yemenis meant, in effect, that the Navy was relying on a government with a shaky record in dealing with terrorist groups. Although the American Embassy has praised the government for its efforts to crack down in the last two years, Washington has often been sharply critical about the government's laxity in allowing the issuing of false passports to terrorists, or leaving controls at the Aden port so lax that they could pass unhindered in and out of Yemen.
Navy and embassy officials here have refused to detail what security arrangements, if any, were made to secure a perimeter around the Cole, saying such operational matters are not made public. One unanswered question has been whether the Navy posted picket boats in the harbor to warn off intruding boats. Since the attack on the Cole, a large inflatable Navy boat, 50 to 60 feet long with heavy machine guns mounted fore and aft and a crew of 15 to 20 sailors in helmets and flak jackets, has mounted a round-the-clock patrol around the Cole.

HEADLINE: Chairman of Lucent Is Ousted by Board After Profit Erosion

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
The board of Lucent Technologies has ousted its chairman and chief executive, Richard A. McGinn, in a move to curb the earnings erosion that threatens to undermine Lucent, the world's largest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment.
Lucent's board replaced Mr. McGinn, who only two weeks ago insisted that he had no plans to leave the company, with Henry Schacht, who served as Lucent's first chairman and chief executive for 18 months after it was spun off from AT&T in 1996. The board took action Sunday night, and the company announced the change yesterday morning. 
 To take the post, Mr. Schacht, 66, resigned as chairman of Avaya Inc., a manufacturer of office communications equipment that itself was spun off from Lucent earlier this year. He plans to remain on the Avaya board as he serves as Lucent's interim head while it conducts a search for another chief executive.
Mr. McGinn was Lucent's president under Mr. Schacht. But during Mr. McGinn's three-year tenure as chief executive, Lucent went from a fast-growing Wall Street darling to a source of concern among many investors after it did not meet optimistic growth promises.
Each financial quarter this year, the company has had to warn that earnings would be lower than analysts had expected -- a string that was extended yesterday, when Lucent warned that not only earnings, but revenue, would decline in the quarter that ends in December.
After the stock market's close yesterday, Lucent said revenue for the first quarter of fiscal 2001, which ends in December, would decline by about 7 percent from $7.9 billion in the period a year earlier, while earnings from operations would break even at about $1.08 billion.
The company said the revised expectations reflected difficulties it had had in rolling out a new generation of optical networking equipment that allowed large amounts of digital information to be transmitted using a single wavelength of light.
Lucent's stock has declined by 72 percent from a high of $79.58 only 10 months ago. The company's shares fell 56 cents, to $22.06 yesterday. With 5.3 million shareholders, Lucent is among the most widely held stocks in the United States.
"It's been a frustrating, rocky road," said John Waterman, managing director of Rittenhouse Financial Services, a Philadelphia investment manager with more than seven million Lucent shares in its portfolio. "The need for fresh blood is essential."
Lucent also reported financial results yesterday for its fiscal fourth quarter, which ended Sept. 30. In keeping with a previous warning, Lucent reported a loss of $225 million, or 13 cents a share, including a loss for discontinued operations.
Excluding costs for acquisitions, earnings from continuing operations were $600 million, or 18 cents a share, down from $768 million, or 24 cents a share, while revenue increased 14.6 percent, to $9.4 billion in the quarter.
Earnings declined after the company set aside funds to cover potentially questionable debts from clients that borrowed money to acquire Lucent's products. In addition, sales of voice switches and fiber optic equipment were not as robust the company had hoped.
In a conference call with investors, Lucent also attributed the earnings decline to an unexpected shortfall of approximately $2 billion in revenue from contracts with two clients, one in the United States and the other abroad. The company did not provide the names of the clients.
"We are clearly disappointed in our results," said Mr. Schacht, Lucent's new chief executive.
If anything, Lucent's woes highlight an old-economy technology company focused previously on voice telephone calls and PC-centric practices that has struggled to make the transition to the new economy's emphasis on data exchanges and Internet-centric activities.
Part of Lucent's problems may derive from a failure to deliver products developed by the company's Bell Labs research division to customers in a nimble and efficient way, analysts said.
"Smaller competitors are nibbling away at Lucent's chair," said Greg Geiling, an analyst at J. P. Morgan. "Psychologically, it's had a devastating effect, so some catalyst is needed to stem defections."
At Lucent, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J. and has 126,000 employees, staff turnover has reached 20 percent this year. It has becoming increasingly clear that Lucent has languished while companies in the fiber optics arena, like Nortel Networks of Canada and the Ciena Corporation, and makers of the router boxes that handle Internet traffic, most notably Cisco Systems and Juniper Networks, have raced ahead.
It was uncertain late yesterday from which industry or company Lucent might seek to recruit a new chief executive. But analysts said candidates would most likely come from competitors that are familiar with Lucent's business.
In the meantime, the company's management did not rule out layoffs for some of the company's work force as part of a company overhaul, said Deborah Hopkins, the company's chief financial officer.
"I am personally grateful for Rich McGinn's contributions to the business," Mr. Schacht wrote in a letter to Lucent employees. "However, the board felt a different set of skills was required at this point in the company's life."
Mr. McGinn was not available for comment.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: ON THE STUMP -- THE SPEECH;
Gore Sharpens His Message in Campaign's Frenetic Closing Days

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22

 BODY:
With the clock ticking to Election Day, Vice President Al Gore's stump speech has taken on a new urgency.
Gone are his leisurely strolls down memory lane; long absent is the once standard story of his father showing him slave chains in an old house in Tennessee. Gone is the fascination with suburban sprawl and traffic jams and lost luggage at airports, the focus on the hassles of daily life that threatened to turn the presidential campaign into a contest for the local zoning board. And, now that the three official debates are over and Mr. Gore has emerged in a weaker position than when he went into them, gone is his constant clamor for two or three debates a week. Gone too are the jokes, if not the humor. 
 Mr. Gore is now focused almost single-mindedly on what he calls "the big choices": Social Security, Medicare, health care, education and the economy. He has boiled his message down to its essence, a math problem, basically, that in his view has only one right answer: Mr. Gore would use the budget surplus responsibly, with discipline, while Gov. George W. Bush would squander it and drive the nation to ruin.
"Prosperity itself is on the ballot," Mr. Gore declares now in his most succinct argument for his candidacy. Coupled with this is a phrase that Governor Bush used against him in their first debate and that Mr. Gore has appropriated with great glee. "Fuzzy math!" Mr. Gore often shouts as he picks apart Mr. Bush's proposals for a tax cut and privatizing part of Social Security. "Fuzzy math!" To the disciplined Mr. Gore, this is a huge failing, and it seems to stick in his craw that Mr. Bush used it against him first.
The new urgency was evident here on Saturday night, in a high school gymnasium so stuffy that the formal Mr. Gore rolled up his shirt sleeves and mopped his face with a white handkerchief as he delivered in a crisp 18 minutes the essentials of his message. The crowd of several hundred people was cheering most of the time and the acoustics were terrible, circumstances that forced the often wordy Mr. Gore to cut short his tendencies to overinstruct an audience and speak in run-on sentences.
The larger circumstances -- Governor Bush's tiny lead in the polls, the nearness of Election Day, the demands on his dwindling time -- also forced him into a more direct message, leaving behind the desultory ramble through the high points of his parents' careers to a sharp and urgent plea for help on the eve of the closest presidential race in 40 years.
This often happens over the course of a long campaign, although few have seemed as long as this one. A candidate spends the primary season introducing himself, uses his convention to define his themes and presses those themes through the fall. For Mr. Gore, this was a lengthy process that included a bitter primary battle against a left-leaning challenger, former Senator Bill Bradley, who forced the vice president to take more liberal positions than he might otherwise have.
For Mr. Gore, the process has highlighted his search for both an identity and a message. His changing stump speech is a manifestation of that search.
All year Mr. Gore has been trying to sort out how to take credit for the economy without bragging and without casting himself as President Clinton's eclipsed No. 2. He lays out the facts as he has all year, saying: "We've turned the biggest deficits into the biggest surpluses. Instead of triple-dip recessions, we've seen a tripling of the stock market. Instead of high unemployment, we have the lowest African-American unemployment ever measured, the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured, 22 million new jobs and the strongest economy in the 224-year history of the United States of America."
But now he adds a twist designed to separate himself from Mr. Clinton and propel his candidacy into the future instead of the past: "But I'm not satisfied," he bellows. "You ain't seen nothing yet!"
Mr. Gore has also dropped most references to himself. After months of "introducing" himself to the public, Mr. Gore is spending these final frantic weeks insisting that the race is about issues, not about personality. "This is not about me and it's not about Governor Bush," he says in nearly every speech. "It is about you and your family."
As Mr. Gore emerged from his vice presidential shell, he was forced into a public search for a personal narrative to explain who he was and where he came from. For months, he dwelled on stories about his parents, whose up-from-the-hollers grit seemed more inspirational than the facts of Mr. Gore's own life, in which the drama was internal and the journey abstract.
He talked about climbing Mount Rainier with his son, an arduous experience that he translated on the campaign trail into vague thoughts about scanning the horizon. Another staple was a line from the movie, "Grand Canyon," in which a character says, "It's not supposed to be this way." Mr. Gore often quoted Gandhi, saying, "You must become the change you wish to see in the world." Another favorite was a line from the Spanish poet Antonio Machado: "Traveler, there is no path. You make your path as you travel."
These expressions were supposed to provide a glimpse into the sensitive side of Mr. Gore. But they added up to an existential question mark rather than a rationale for why he should be president.
In these final urgent days, the elaborate scaffolding that Mr. Gore had constructed to help build his identity has fallen away. Now, he relates only essential biographical facts that serve a direct purpose.
He went to Vietnam, i.e., he did not pull strings to avoid the war. He was a journalist, i.e., he has not spent his entire life in a blue suit in Washington. He has been married for 30 years and has four children, i.e., he is a devoted family man who will spare the nation any Clintonian lapses.
Distancing himself from Mr. Clinton is a subtext of Mr. Gore's speech. He almost never mentions the president's name, but evokes him nonetheless by promising: "I won't always be the most exciting politician, but I will work hard for you every single day, and I will never let you down."
What Mr. Gore has kept in his speech and what he has discarded is a response in part to changing political realities. In the primaries, for example, he would say that Mr. Bradley had not been a good Democrat. (Mr. Gore complained that Mr. Bradley "quit" the Senate after the Republicans took over and considered challenging the incumbent Democratic president, Mr. Clinton, in 1996.) Now that he is trying to win over independents and moderate Republicans, Mr. Gore tells audiences that he himself had a reputation in Congress as someone who worked across party lines. With this in mind, he has toned down the raging populism of early September. While he remains an advocate of abortion rights, he has begun to speak of seeking "common ground" with abortion opponents.
The changing stump speech is also a reflection of what has worked and what has not. Mr. Gore has stopped branding Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal a "risky tax scheme," a phrase his top advisers concluded sounded too cliched and too harsh. He has also given up his promise for "revolutionary change" in education, a concept that left audiences more puzzled than energized. But he has not abandoned his assertion that "we need to make education our No. 1 priority."
His biggest applause line now is one he hit on in late summer. "I will make college affordable" with a tax credit. And his most enduring are these: "It's time to treat teachers like the professionals they are," and "It's time to take the medical decisions away from the bean counters who sit behind computer terminals and play God."
Since "Saturday Night Live" made fun of him after the first debate for using the arcane word "lockbox" to describe where he would put the Social Security trust fund, Mr. Gore has been more self-conscious about the word. "Use whatever word you want," he will say, but he will often fall back on lockbox.
Topics that once loomed large have vanished altogether. He used to talk at length about gun control, pledging to make an issue of Mr. Bush's having signed a bill to allow gun owners to carry concealed weapons to church. But pro-gun commercials in hunter-heavy swing states like Pennsylvania and Michigan have forced him to scale back. Now, as he did in the debates, Mr. Gore emphasizes that he does not want to take firearms away from sportsmen.
In Philadelphia, his only reference to guns was that he wanted schools to be "gun-free" and "violence-free."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Political Consultants Thrive in Cash-Rich Politics

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
When Peter Fenn became a media political consultant 20 years ago, he said he was motivated more by a love of politics than a love of money.
But he got both. Mr. Fenn's gold-plated client list now includes Vice President Al Gore, leaders of Congress, heads of state and deep-pocketed interest groups. He just moved into fancy new Washington offices, and he counsels students at nearby George Washington University that while he is "not one of the folks with yachts and houses in six different places," political consulting can pay off intellectually -- and financially. 
 No more so than right now. With fund-raising records being shattered and with airwaves flooded with advertisements from candidates and interest groups, the November election is turning into a bonanza for political consultants. For all the hand-wringing about the high cost of politics, one group has little reason to complain: the pollsters, media buyers, television stations, direct mail houses, Web masters and telemarketers receiving all this money.
"It's coming down in buckets," said Phil Noble, president of Politics OnLine, an Internet firm.
Political consultants are more accustomed to toiling for low wages on shoestring campaigns and supplementing campaign work with other jobs. But this year, some consultants say their revenues have doubled since the last election, and others say consultants on big national campaigns will see million-dollar paychecks. "Winner's bonuses" of $20,000 to $30,000 are being offered to some consultants on top of their regular fees if their candidate wins.
Perhaps not surprisingly, the number of political consultants has tripled in 10 years, according to Political Resources, the trade directory.
On television, political commercials are creating a windfall for broadcasters, according to a report by the brokerage firm Paine Webber, which estimates that a record $1 billion will be spent on political commercials -- $350 million more than the firm estimated just a few months ago. Politics now ranks No. 3 in overall commercials after autos and retailing.
"Whatever office, whatever level of government, candidates are spending serious money on campaigns," said Larry Makinson, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics. "And it winds up going to these consultants. These guys are like systems analysts in a software company -- they are in the right place at the right time, and an awful lot of them will get wealthy in this election."
Technology and money have combined to create opportunities for political consultants that never existed before. For instance, Hank Sheinkopf, a pollster in the last Clinton campaign, has found that even a county commissioner candidate in Indiana can afford to hire him. And there are whole new lines of business. For instance, telemarketers, like Winning Connections, based in Washington, tap into computer data banks to call 500,000 targeted voters in three days. Or people like Michael Connell, manager of the Bush campaign Internet strategy, represent new types of consulting.
Much attention is focused, of course, on the presidential campaign and high-profile races like the one between Representative Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton. But the universe of potential clients is much larger. There are 513,200 elected offices in the United States, from senator to sheriff. While it is difficult to determine how many offices are up for grabs this November, Campaigns and Elections, a trade publication, estimates that $14 billion will be spent in the current four-year election cycle by candidates, parties and interest groups.
For the most part, political consultants are generally paid a flat fee by the campaign, although payments to media buyers can vary with the amount of advertisements placed.
"The system is awash in money," said Gary Nordlinger, who heads a media consulting firm he founded 25 years ago. "Political parties are spending more, the soft money is stunning, and it doesn't stop there. You have all these interest groups spending money -- pro-choice, right-to-life, business groups and unions. Television stations are laughing all the way to the bank."
The growth in spending is coming about for many reasons. Campaign contributions are breaking all records, an offshoot of a good economy and a breakdown in campaign finance laws, causing a political inflation to set in. For instance, in 1996, a hot Congressional race might cost around $500,000; by 1998, it jumped to $800,000 or more.
Now, candidates in hot Congressional races are spending $1 million, with soft-dollar spending from parties and interest groups adding $1 million to $2 million more to the per-candidate tab, consultants say. As of last June 30, Congressional candidates raised $653 million, according to the Federal Election Commission. And that number does not include the even greater dollars being spent on Congressional races by the parties and interest groups.
"Why is it different?" said Joseph Napolitan, a political consultant on more than 100 federal campaigns. "It's because people are finding more loopholes in campaign finance laws than you find in a piece of Swiss cheese, and they are just driving through them. The hundreds of millions raised through soft money and by interest groups are providing work for people in my business."
In the presidential race, Mr. Gore and Gov. George W. Bush each have $67.56 million in federal campaign matching funds -- as well as $298 million total in soft dollars from the two parties. In last spring's presidential primaries the top 13 candidates spent a total of $446.4 million.
Then there are state ballot proposals which, in states like California, can create enough business to support a cottage industry of consultants. A total of $150 million was spent on 20 California ballot proposals last March, and the same amount is expected to be spent this November. Big growth areas for consultants are campaigns by various interest groups, like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. From a consultant's perspective, issue work has the advantage of not having a candidate to deal with.
"You don't have candidates yelling at you because their wife said you made them look goofy," Mr. Noble, of Politics OnLine, said. "For consultants, this is low maintenance, high price tag."
New technologies, too, have made campaigns more scientific, more sophisticated and, of course, more costly. Web masters never existed before; now they are a campaign staple. Computer databases enable direct-mail houses and telemarketers to identify voters by sex, voting frequency, income and age. Once polls took several days to tally. Now they are instantaneous, increasing the appetite for more.
"Campaigns are like arms races," said Trevor Potter, a Washington lawyer and former Federal Election commissioner. "You didn't know you needed another battleship until the other country had one."
Nowhere is this more evident than in local and statehouse races.
"What's really changed is the down-ballot stuff," said James Spencer, a director of Winning Directions, a San Francisco direct-mail company that will send out 44 million pieces of campaign mail. "It's driven by competition. Your opponent will use all the professional tools. If you don't use those tools, you won't have a prayer."
In 1998, $1.4 billion was spent on statehouse races, according to the National Institute on Money in State Politics, which expects that number to be easily exceeded this year. It costs $75,000 for an average state Senate race -- rising to $600,000 in California or $400,000 in Texas -- and $30,000 for a statehouse race, rising to $200,000 in other states.
Take Iowa, where Jamie Van Fossen, a Republican state legislator is running for re-election. His first campaign in 1994 was a grass-roots effort manned by volunteers addressing mailings from his basement.
This time, he has a budget of $50,000 and a more sophisticated plan: sending out direct mailings to voters picked by a computer. He has scheduled a first round of polls and may follow it up with tracking polls, and he has three commercials set to run on CNBC and CNN.
"The more competitive the race," Mr. Van Fossen said, "the more you need to do."
It is almost a rule of thumb that television consumes about half a candidate's budget -- from the presidency on down. And with media consultants getting a percentage of the costs of every advertisement they place -- 5 percent to 15 percent of the advertisement buy -- rising media costs mean rising consultant's pay.
"There are layers of greed everywhere," said Mr. Makinson, of the Center for Responsive Politics. "Political consultants are putting pressure on candidates to raise money to pay their bills."
But media consultants point the finger at broadcasters who are raising rates as the election draws near. Federal law requires that candidates get lower rates than commercial advertisers, but even this preferential rate is rising in the last weeks of the campaign. Moreover, commercials from the growing number of interest groups are charged top-dollar prices.
Mr. Fenn, the media consultant, said one West Coast interest group that paid $900 for a spot during the 11 p.m. news in September is now being charged $2,000; another that paid $600 for a slot on the Sunday 11 p.m. news last month is being charged $1,800. This has left Mr. Fenn fuming.
"The campaign has become the Mercedes protection program for television stations," he said.
Because of such rising costs, even Mr. Napolitan, the veteran consultant, says he scratches his head -- especially in Congressional races.
"I don't understand why someone would spent $2 million to get elected to a $125,000 a year job," he said. "But they do it all the time."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
GORE PUTS FOCUS ON SMALLER STATES ONCE SEEN AS SAFE

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: EVERETT, Wash., Oct. 23

 BODY:
At a time when Vice President Al Gore should be scrapping for votes in large swing states like Ohio and Michigan, he is devoting virtually his entire week to campaigning in smaller states that he should be able to ignore -- even his home state, Tennessee.
Mr. Gore's schedule, only two weeks before the Nov. 7 election, is the ultimate reflection of the down-to-the-wire campaign and the way factors as disparate as Mr. Gore's personality and Ralph Nader's candidacy are playing havoc with the electoral map. 
 Mr. Gore, the Democratic nominee, will have campaigned in 11 states by the end of a week that began on Sunday afternoon in New Mexico and winds up on Friday in Pennsylvania. All 11 were won by President Clinton and Mr. Gore in 1992 and 1996, with the Democrats winning most by comfortable margins, often by double digits.
The itinerary, which mirrors his advertising strategy, takes him to five states -- including Oregon and Washington today -- that were won not only by Mr. Clinton but also by Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee in 1988. Mr. Dukakis carried only 10 states that year.
The campaign swing includes West Virginia, which has voted Republican only twice since 1960. And Mr. Gore will spend part of both Tuesday and Wednesday campaigning in Tennessee, where he has not lost a race in a political career that dates to 1976. His Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, also plans to campaign in Tennessee on Tuesday.
The vice president's struggle to solidify his geographic base stems from several factors, political analysts said. Some are national, like his inability to reassure voters about his credibility and amiability, and the lingering tendency of some voters to associate Mr. Gore with a scandal-ridden White House. Others are more localized, including demographic changes in some states and the strength of Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate, in places like the Pacific Northwest and Wisconsin.
In times of peace and prosperity, said Thomas E. Mann, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, "one would have expected more of what we saw after Labor Day, when he opened up leads in these states."
"Even though they weren't huge leads," Mr. Mann said, "they seemed substantial enough to allow him to turn his attention and resources elsewhere."
Mr. Gore does seem to enjoy substantial leads in California and New York, and his postconvention travel to those states has largely been limited to fund-raising and television tapings. He has also forced Mr. Bush to compete in Florida, where Mr. Bush's brother is governor.
But while campaigning in closely contested Oregon and Washington in the last two days, Mr. Gore has been forced to reach out to the disaffected Democrats who form the core of Mr. Nader's base. At rallies in Portland, Ore., on Sunday night and here today, he devoted more time than usual to promoting his environmental record, a critical issue for the Green Party.
"I will fight to protect the environment with all my heart and soul," Mr. Gore told supporters here in an open airport hangar. In Portland last night, Mr. Gore vowed to "protect ancient forests" and to "block new roads and timber sales in our roadless forests and ancient forest areas."
Part of his strategy to reclaim Nader supporters rests on raising fears about a Bush presidency.
"My opponent in his state of Texas put a lobbyist for the chemical companies in charge of enforcing the environmental laws there," Mr. Gore said today. "On his watch, Texas has sunk down to 50th out of all 50 in industrial pollution, the worst state for industrial pollution, with the smoggiest city, Houston, and over all the smoggiest state."
Mr. Gore was even more explicit when reporters aboard Air Force Two asked him about Mr. Nader.
"I will stack my environmental record against anyone, including him," he said.
Mr. Gore added that it was not his task to convince Americans that a vote for Mr. Nader was a vote for Mr. Bush. "That may be true," he said, "but my task is to convince them to vote enthusiastically for me and for what I represent."
Mr. Gore's allies in the Northwest say it is vital to win back perhaps half of Mr. Nader's supporters.
"The Nader factor is huge in Oregon," said Representative Darlene Hooley, Democrat of Oregon. "It's at 8 percent and has stayed at 8 percent, and that's why the vice president's spending time here."
Representative Jim McDermott, a Democrat who represents a Seattle district, said Mr. Gore would probably not have to campaign in Washington at this point were it not for Mr. Nader. "Gore has to get his base out in states like this," Mr. McDermott said, "and when you add in factors like Nader it throws in a few points."
But other Democratic leaders said Mr. Gore was still not receiving credit for the prosperity enjoyed during the Clinton administration, and they attributed his troubles to personality and style.
Speaking at Sunday's rally in Portland, that city's Democratic congressman, David Wu, acknowledged that "if I was choosing someone to have a cold beer with or go fishing with, the other fellow might be O.K."
In an interview today, Mr. Wu said that "sometimes the vice president's delivery has gotten in the way of his message."
"The vice president, in a small group, one on one, is incredibly funny, he's charming, he's knowledgeable," Mr. Wu said. "We need to free Al Gore, let Al Gore be Al Gore."
Mr. Gore was certainly in full voice today, feeling energized, aides said, by positive signs in several recent polls. He pledged to continue to speak in detail about issues until the final hours of the campaign.
"Fifteen days is a long time if your objective is to hold the ball and run out the clock," Mr. Gore said. "Fifteen days is a long time if you are trying to hide behind tracking polls and not engage in the issues because the people disagree with you on the issues. That's the dilemma that my opponent faces in the next 15 days."
Part of Mr. Gore's plan is to hold camera-friendly "kitchen table" discussions with citizens who can help him promote his policy proposals. He began today, sitting down for tea in Portland with Heather Howitt, 32, the founder of Oregon Chai, a manufacturer of herbal tea.
When Mr. Gore asked Ms. Howitt to discuss the impact of the economy on her business, she responded on cue: "The economy has been awesome the last eight years."
Mr. Gore replied, "You don't want to let that get away, right?"

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Lazio Focuses on Upstate

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:

This is a new 30-second commercial that the Lazio campaign plans to begin broadcasting.
 
PRODUCER -- The Murphy Pintak Gautier Hudome Agency. 

ON THE SCREEN -- As the commercial opens, Rick A. Lazio is shaking hands with sports fans in Buffalo Bills jerseys. The male announcer declares that Mr. Lazio "has listened to upstate." Mr. Lazio is shown at events and giving a speech. He walks down a shopping street in Skaneateles, near Syracuse, dressed casually in a denim shirt and dark jacket, speaking directly to the camera. The commercial ends with Mr. Lazio seated at a restaurant counter with other diners.
 
THE SCRIPT -- ANNOUNCER: "Rick Lazio. He's listened to upstate and he's ready to fight for us." Mr. Lazio: "I grew up in New York, the son of a shop owner. My background taught me what we need. I've planned, for upstate, to give billions in tax relief to create real jobs, right here."
 
Announcer: "Rick Lazio. He shares our values." Mr. Lazio: "My dad used to say, show me your friends and I'll tell you who you are. Well I've made a lot of friends in Long Island by getting the job done. Now I'd like to earn your friendship too, here in upstate, by getting the job done, for you."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Lazio has proposed a sweeping package of tax cuts, including an elimination of the estate tax and so-called marriage penalty, cuts in the capital gains tax on investments, and a plan to make Social Security tax payments deductible for couples who make less than $106,000 a year. The Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a conservative group, estimated that these cuts would be worth $4.2 billion to New Yorkers. But almost none of the tax cuts have anything to do, directly, with job creation. Like many Republicans, Mr. Lazio argues that putting money into the hands of consumers and investors will ultimately create jobs.

SCORECARD -- This ad is a clear effort to respond to the perception in upstate and Western New York -- fueled by Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign -- that Mr. Lazio does not understand the economic woes of communities north of Westchester County, and does not have a plan to help them. It also makes a subtle dig at Mrs. Clinton's "listening tour," conducted at the beginning of her campaign when she wanted to learn about voters' concerns. Mrs. Clinton has put forth many proposals, ranging from job tax credits to technology training programs to utility deregulation (sort of), which she says will help an area she describes as economically beleaguered. Some economists are dubious about the effectiveness of so-called targeted tax cuts, like Mrs. Clinton's. Whether New Yorkers are persuaded by Mr. Lazio's reassurances, and his promotion of public-private partnerships, may depend on whether they believe in the theory that has been called "trickle-down" economics by its opponents. LESLIE EATON
