LENGTH: 1709 words

HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT GREETED WITH A FANFARE BY NORTH KOREA

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PYONGYANG, North Korea, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright plunged into Communist North Korea today, meeting with the nation's mysterious leader, Kim Jong Il, and attending a gargantuan spectacle of about 100,000 performers that celebrated the cult of her host.
In a day of surprising high-stakes diplomacy, Mr. Kim and Dr. Albright, the first senior American official to meet a North Korean leader, spent more than six hours together, discussing strategic differences that divide the two countries but also impressing each other with warm gestures and words. 
 The North Korean leader went out of his way to play the gracious host, moving up by one day his negotiating session with her and then inviting her to the spectacle, where Dr. Albright, who ordinarily champions Western democracy, enthusiastically applauded the 90-minute authoritarian display of choreography and chorus.
The biggest surprise was the invitation to Dr. Albright to attend the spectacle at the sports stadium this evening, where she arrived with Mr. Kim, wearing his standard khaki jacket and pants. She sat next to him on a dais above the performance, and from time to time Mr. Kim would ask the interpreter to point out special features of the event.
As the two arrived, the huge crowd at the stadium rose in unison, and to thunderous music, people fervently stretched their arms toward Mr. Kim as if to a deity.
The dome then filled with fireworks, and an entire side of the arena in front of Mr. Kim and Dr. Albright blinked with changing images, mostly graphics of Communist symbols and triumphs, with tractors, great potato harvests and electrical transformers.
The images were created by about 30,000 people seated side by side holding color-coded cards in front of them and flicking them in highly synchronized movements to achieve the patterns, Korean officials said. The extravaganza was performed two weeks ago in a tribute to the Workers Party of Korea and repeated for the visiting American.
Dr. Albright responded to Mr. Kim's hospitality with a friendly toast tonight, saying as he sat next to her at a dinner table in a government guest house: "America's symbol is the eagle, a bird that soars, and Korea's pride is mountains that scrape the sky. There is no obstacle we cannot overcome if we make the strategic decision to do so together."
In three hours of talks, Dr. Albright got down to serious business with Mr. Kim, discussing "issues of concern to the United States." Her spokesman Richard A. Boucher said the talks had been "substantive and useful."
The length of the first face-to-face session and the fact that a second is scheduled for Tuesday appeared to indicate that both sides were trying to resolve questions about North Korea's missile and nuclear programs so that President Clinton could make a visit here before he leaves office.
The North Koreans agreed to a temporary moratorium on their missile-testing program last year and in return the Clinton administration lifted some economic sanctions. But the White House wants to see how much further the North Koreans will go in shutting down their missile research, development and exports before making a final decision on a presidential trip.
In 1998, the North Koreans test-fired a Taepodong missile, a move that hastened the Clinton administration's decision to move ahead with a national missile defense system and that unsettled Japan and South Korea. Since then, rapid efforts by South Korea to move toward reconciliation with North Korea have defused some of the tensions.
Mr. Boucher declined to be specific on the likelihood of a presidential visit but said that "being able to deal with these issues successfully is the key to a visit of the president." He said that Dr. Albright told him Mr. Kim was "fully engaged" during their discussions.
Dr. Albright gave Mr. Kim a letter from Mr. Clinton that outlined "the expectation of further developing relations" between Washington and North Korea, Mr. Boucher said.
In her toast at the dinner, where bottles of fine French wine were liberally set, Dr. Albright gave a sense of what might be in the presidential letter: "I believe that our meetings during these two days will help us to move further down the road of cooperation," she said.
"Mr. Chairman, the process in which we are now engaged is a process that your father, President Kim Il Sung, helped to begin. It can lead to reconciliation and reunification of the peninsula and to more normal and prosperous relations between your government and others in the region and the world."
Distance between the two countries was "no barrier to closer ties," she added.
Campaigning today in New York, Mr. Clinton said, "We have some hope of resolving our outstanding differences with North Korea and looking forward to the day when they will truly close the last chapter in the aftermath of the Korean War."
Many aspects of events in North Korea today, like the sudden planning of Dr. Albright's trip itself, were filled with unexpected twists and turns, apparently a technique that Mr. Kim likes to use with his guests.
The incongruity of Dr. Albright, who has made democracy a leitmotif, applauding a mass propaganda show dedicated to the 55th anniversary of the Korean Workers Party, was most likely lost on her hosts.
But there were several images in the show that must have unnerved Dr. Albright, including one depicting the launch of a long-range ballistic missile, superimposed on the wall of the stadium in front of her. The missile is the very weapon that Dr. Albright has come to persuade the North Koreans to abandon.
Most of the audience were men in dark suits with red lapel pins showing Mr. Kim and most were members of the Communist Party. Many in the audience looked with a combination of suspicion and awe as a group of Western reporters sat in comfortable green velour chairs in spots usually reserved for special guests.
The precision of dancing and gymnastics, and the din of brass and drum music, combined with choral works, made similar efforts at Socialist entertainment by the former Soviet Union and China pale by comparison. The effort took 10 months of rehearsing, said Foreign Ministry officials accompanying foreign reporters, and obviously involved many grueling hours of training for young children.
A closing scene titled "We will support our powerful nation with rifles" was staged by thousands of men in army uniform who marched in lock step and shouted, "We will safeguard our dear leader!" A less threatening dance called "The leader will always be with us" involved probably more than a thousand children dressed in white and performing gymnastics in exact formations. Pictures of Dr. Albright chatting amiably with Mr. Kim at the spectacle were used on government television news tonight, in a lead item that stressed the prestige of having such an honored guest attend the show.
The North Koreans set the tone of the visit soon after Dr. Albright's arrival by having her meet Marshal Jo Myong Rok, the military official who came to Washington earlier this month, at the mausoleum of Kim Il Sung, the father of the current leader. The secretary was escorted to the bier of Mr. Kim where she stopped briefly to pay her respects, Mr. Boucher said.
Dr. Albright then visited the Rangnang kindergarten, where American food delivered by the United Nations World Food Program provides three meals a day to the children, including cabbage soup and buns for lunch today. Even at the kindergarten, Dr. Albright was treated to a performance by 6-year-olds, who performed synchronized steps and sang to the glory of her host, Mr. Kim.
With the country suffering from famine, a survey by the United Nations two years ago indicated that two-thirds of the population suffered from chronic malnutrition and were stunted in their growth.
The children at the kindergarten appeared well fed, but this was because they were receiving almost their entire nourishment from the United Nations, said the program's director, Douglas Broderick. Further, as urban children, they were better off than those in the countryside, he said.
The children at the center came from the tall apartment blocks nearby where electricity functions about one or two hours a day. Most households have little to cook even when the electricity is on, and meat is a luxury distributed on holidays only, Mr. Broderick added.
Like this evening at the stadium, the main attraction at the kindergarten was the entertainment by rigorously trained children. "Pay attention to me," and "Head up," said a teacher as she rehearsed a group of girls, adorned with pale pink lipstick, ribbons in their hair and yellow-and-pink dresses.
Beyond the staged events for Dr. Albright, the city of Pyongyang went about its normal activities. Reporters were given a little more leeway than most foreigners to go outside the Koryo Hotel and walk a few blocks, apparently a gesture of openness. Interpreters and security officials from the Foreign Ministry tried to accompany reporters at all times, although a noodle bar down a side street near the hotel frequented by foreign aid workers and better-off Koreans seemed open to reporters.
A few buses were on the streets, but the main mode of transportation was walking. About 2,000 privately owned cars have shown up on the streets in the last year, officials said. Most of them are probably bought with remittances from relatives in Japan, they said.
On a street corner in the center of the city, two women -- apparently municipal workers -- were bent over a pile of sand and water mixing it for poor quality concrete to fix a manhole. A string of restaurants on a main street were closed, the windows dirty and only a few tables inside. A kiosk selling sweet potatoes, doing a fairly brisk business -- or at least creating a lot of interest -- was the only sign of retail life.
Usually, because of the dire energy shortage, the city is blanketed in darkness, foreigners who live here said. But streetlights were switched on tonight as were lights in the stairwells of the apartment blocks across the street from the Koryo Hotel, apparently in honor of the American delegation and in a signal that North Korea would survive no matter what.

HEADLINE: REGIONAL AIRPORTS IN GROWTH PHASE

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
At Stewart International Airport near Newburgh, N.Y., they are promoting a new corporate hangar, dreaming about helicopter shuttles to Manhattan and dubbing themselves the "Gateway to the Hudson." At MacArthur Airport in Islip, N.Y., they are hoping to add four gates to a refurbished terminal, buoyed by the recent arrival of Southwest Airlines. At Lehigh Valley International Airport near Allentown, Pa., 10 miles from the New Jersey state line, they are buying 1,500 acres of adjacent land and hoping to extend a runway to the lengths found at Kennedy or Newark International Airports.
At almost every regional airport within a 90-minute drive of New York City, operators are renovating, upgrading or expanding, in what urban planners and aviation groups consider the busiest -- and most contested -- flurry of activity ever at these medium-sized complexes. 
 For supporters, these projects are transforming sleepy outposts into vibrant, congestion-free alternatives to La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark Airports. But with that push has come more resistance, rippling farther and farther into the suburbs, from citizens' groups worried about noise, the environment and sprawling development.
Now, with La Guardia declaring limits on additional peak-hour flights, Westchester County Airport and Teterboro Airport mulling flight curfews and the appetite for air travel showing no signs of abating, the stakes have never been higher. How these battles play out will influence local economies, regional transportation and suburban landscapes for years to come.
"Economic development promoters are recognizing that their local airport has been a diamond in the rough, so this is definitely their moment of opportunity," said Janine Bauer, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a coalition of environmental and planning groups. "But it is also the next big battleground over sprawl, because the question is, is there a plan for growth, or is it just economic development and more sprawl?"
The same dynamic is playing out at small airports in metropolitan areas from Los Angeles and Chicago to Minneapolis. In all, more than 650 groups are trying to curb or shut down 3,300 airports. At the same time, aviation groups and some members of Congress want a national policy to aggressively build more airports, like the policy that fostered the interstate highway system, said James K. Coyne, a former Pennsylvania representative and president of the National Air Transportation Association, a trade group.
"It's a real yin and yang thing," he said, "where as a society we want the benefit of this transportation, but we don't understand that there's no free lunch."
In the last five years, federal money for all airports has almost doubled, enabling smaller airports to undertake more ambitious development and maintenance projects, said Bill DeGraaff, assistant manager of the airports division in the Federal Aviation Administration's eastern region office.
The number of corporate flights, particularly those originating at regional airports, has doubled over the last six years, Mr. Coyne said. One Chicago company, Indigo Business Air Service, started regular jet charter service between Midway Airport in Chicago and Teterboro Airport in February, plans to start a Westchester-Midway shuttle by November and is considering a link to MacArthur Airport next year.
And while the major New York area airports are also in the midst of construction projects, the congestion is getting much worse, due in part to a new federal law that, in the name of expanding service between New York and smaller cities, has crammed in more takeoff and landing slots.
In August, delays at La Guardia doubled from the same period last year, prompting the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to announce limits in September on additional peak-hour flights. And while the major airports, for the most part, are limited in how much they can expand, suburban airports with ample land and modest flight schedules can grow significantly. Aviation groups and officials say the airports are spread out enough to accommodate the extra air traffic.
Perhaps no airport has generated as much attention as Stewart, in New Windsor, N.Y., 55 miles north of New York City. Its longest runway, 11,818 feet, is second in the state only to Kennedy's longest, at 14,572 feet. But Stewart's potential has not been fulfilled because of aging buildings, high fares and poor connections.
In April, Stewart became the first airport in the country to be privatized under a new federal program, with management changing hands from New York State to National Express Group, a British company. Since then, the new operators have persuaded General Electric to build a new hangar, supported plans for a new highway interchange off Interstate 84, and worked hard to lure a low-cost jet carrier like Southwest.
Last month, one corporate tenant, Rifton Aviation Services, sponsored a lavish event to unveil a new 120,000-square-foot, 46-foot-high corporate hangar. Eventually, Rifton plans to arrange business charters to England and helicopter shuttles to Manhattan and the Woodbury Commons outlet mall in Central Valley, N.Y., said Christian P. Domer, Rifton's president and chief executive.
The expansion has also reinvigorated a longtime citizens' group, the Stewart Park and Recreation Coalition. Concerned that the expansion could adversely affect, or eat into, 7,000 adjacent acres of rugged open space, the group recently persuaded the Sierra Club to cite Stewart as New York State's worst example of sprawling development.
Some opponents fear that increased airport activity could lead to more pollution and traffic, too much commercial development, a loss of open space and an additional burden on water and sewer systems.
"You have a disaster in the making," said John Stouffer, legislative director of the Sierra Club's New York chapter. "They are rapidly turning what was probably 15 years ago a fairly rural community into a choked suburban or semi-urban community."
The Trenton-Mercer Airport is similar to Stewart in that local officials and businesses are banking on revitalization to spur economic growth. Earlier this year, for instance, a former Grumman factory site was converted into an 80,000-square-foot hangar. With corporate flights increasing by double-digit percentages annually, the airport also decided to accommodate general aviation flights 24 hours a day.
Now, the airport, which until a few years ago was called Mercer County Airport, is building a hangar for Merck, and is about to award a contract for one for Pfizer, said Justin P. Edwards, the airport manager. Both pharmaceutical giants have operations in New Jersey. Also, officials are assessing the environmental feasibility of a $18 million terminal that may include a movie theater, restaurants and stores.
But not if Heidi Kahme can help it. A board member of People Limiting Airport Noise and Expansion, or Plane, which formed about a year ago, Ms. Kahme has been working with a Bucks County, Pa., citizens' group to call for more thorough environmental assessments and a halt to any expansion plans in an area that has sprouted many new subdivisions.
"You're completely changing the character of the airport," she said.
Her adversary is Steven E. Some, a Trenton lobbyist who is the president of People Restoring Opportunity, a coalition of business and labor groups that formed in June. To him, the expansion is crucial to wooing Southwest, which has told him of an "intense desire" to land in Trenton -- if the airport is modernized.
He said a recent poll taken by his group found that 70 percent of local residents favored expansion. "If it's not in my backyard but they want the services, what do you do?" he said. 'Newark is impossible. La Guardia is too far. Kennedy is another country. Do we fold our arms and do nothing? The answer is no."
At MacArthur Airport, which is owned by the town of Islip, the issue is not the prospect of a rejuvenated airport, but the reality of one.
Since the arrival of Southwest Airlines last year, the number of passengers has doubled to two million a year, other airlines have beefed up service and ticket prices have dropped precipitously. The airport completed a $14 million face-lift earlier this year, and would like to add more terminal gates and flights.
But the progress, critics say, has come at a high price, epitomized by pollution and the sound of airplanes rattling chandeliers. So three years ago, some residents founded the Citizens for the Enforcement of MacArthur Airport Control; this year the group staged an anti-airport rally that drew 250 people.
It is basically the same story with the Lehigh Valley airport near Allentown -- roughly an 80-minute drive from Newark -- which wants to tap into the fast-growing, corporation-rich central New Jersey market.
The airport recently completed a land acquisition program for 1,500 acres, and hopes to extend its runway to 10,000 feet. Citizens for a Safe and Quiet Airport was founded in June. Last month, supervisors in one town passed regulations to limit noise and restrict the expansion.
Even smaller airports without commercial service, like Republic Airport in Farmingdale, N.Y., the Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport outside Bridgeport, Conn., Morristown Municipal Airport in Hanover, N.J., and Solberg Airport in Hunterdon County, N.J., find themselves at odds with some residents because of proposed expansions. To an extent, these airports, as well as some others, are now experiencing what some of the busy inner-ring airports, like Teterboro and Westchester County, have wrestled with for years.
At Teterboro, only seven miles from New York City in Bergen County, N.J., aircraft noise has been a big issue. In 1987, the airport established a noise-monitoring system, and promised to ban aircraft that exceeded 90 decibels. Since then, Teterboro has banned more than 60 planes, said Phil Engle, the airport manager.
But to residents, that is not enough. A few weeks ago, the Carlstadt Borough Council passed a resolution to initiate a class-action lawsuit to force the Port Authority and the federal government to reduce airplane noise.
Now, with corporate travel consisting of 90 percent of Teterboro's operations, compared with less than half 10 years ago, the airport is repaving a runway and planning for additional taxiway room to accommodate bigger but quieter jets like Falcons and Gulfstreams, which are quickly replacing noisy turbo-propeller planes throughout the industry. But to residents, such plans sound like a recipe for bigger ambitions.
Westchester County Airport, meanwhile, has long been in a delicate position because of its proximity to the Kensico Reservoir, a conduit for 90 percent of New York City's drinking water, and the clout of environmentalists and local officials.
The county executive, Andrew J. Spano, would prefer to keep the airport as a boutique operation, snuffing out plans to expand a business lounge and blocking the construction of a new hangar by General Electric (which went to Stewart).
Now there is a dispute with Atlantic Southeast Airlines, a Delta subsidiary, over the airline's new 5:59 a.m. flight from Westchester to Atlanta, which residents have complained is too early. Two weeks ago, a bipartisan group of congressmen introduced legislation that would impose a mandatory curfew. And because the airport is busy enough as it is, Mr. Spano said that he would not mind if some passengers or flights opted for Stewart or other satellite airports instead.
Arline L. Bronzaft, chairwoman of a new group concerned about airport noise, the Aircraft Noise Abatement Group of New York and New Jersey,said the competing pressures for adding air service and maintaining a suburban or semirural quality of life would be hard to reconcile.
"We have the need for people who want to get away as quickly as they can, and then we have the people on the ground saying, 'We're living here.' Something is going to have to be very Solomon-like in coming out."

HEADLINE: Technology-Rich Morris County Shrugging Off Mergers

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 23

 BODY:
In the last year or so, three companies based in Morris County have announced they were merging with bigger companies and closing at least part of their operations here. Now it is happening again.
The General Electric Company agreed Sunday to acquire Honeywell International, the diversified manufacturer that is based here. As part of the agreement, Honeywell will close its 550-employee headquarters here, although it will keep 1,750 workers in various businesses and laboratories here in place for now. 
 Honeywell joins Warner-Lambert, Schering-Plough and GPU Utility, all of which have announced mergers with other companies and expect to close their headquarters here. This is in addition to last November's merger of Mobil Oil with the Exxon Corporation, which had 1,000 employees in its engineering division in Florham Park in Morris County, most of whom were relocated to Fairfax, Va.
It is enough to make a region feel a bit rejected.
But not Morris County. Officials with the county and the area's economic development office do not want to play down the potential loss of 550 Honeywell jobs, but they say that the acquisition is part of a larger economic sorting out and that Morris County itself, with its large technology and manufacturing base, will not be hurt in the long run.
The companies are not closing down, they point out, but merely reorganizing, sometimes leaving hundreds of jobs with the new, bigger company.
The office space and manufacturing sites that some of the companies are leaving behind are quickly filled by other companies, they say, and employees of the merged companies have either relocated or found new jobs in the area.
It is not, they insist, a sign of a downturn in Morris County's healthy economy, where corporate campuses have replaced the farms that used to dot this hilly, lush area about an hour's drive west of New York City. The county's unemployment rate is less than 3 percent, lower than the state and national averages. It is home to 53 Fortune 500 companies, including Lucent Technologies and AT&T.
"I just think these corporations are trying to consolidate to better their positions in the market," said Douglas Cabana, the Morris County freeholder director. "A downturn would be companies losing profits and layoffs."
G.E., the network television and aircraft engine manufacturing giant based in Fairfield, Conn., expects to save money through the merger. But officials of G.E., which has 340,000 employees, said they did not yet know how many workers of its combined work force -- Honeywell has 120,000 employees -- might lose their jobs.
"If people are laid off, the company will help them in every way they can to find new employment," said Tom Crane, a spokesman for Honeywell.
"But clearly this is a good job market, particularly for highly skilled workers here."
Christopher Marra, executive director of the Morris Area Development Group, a private-public partnership for economic development, said the county had 230,000 private-sector jobs. The county has the second-highest inventory of office space and industrial space in New Jersey, with 23 million square feet, after Bergen County.
"There has been a lot of activity in the sense of mergers and acquisitions in the last year, more than at any time since I came here in 1993-94," Mr. Marra said. "But they're not fleeing the area."
Mr. Marra said there had been no increase in the unemployment rate in the county in the last year, in spite of the recent mergers, an indication that workers at the newly merged companies who lived in the county either relocated or found jobs at the area's other companies.
And space and land left behind by companies consolidating their operations are quickly gobbled up by others, he said.
For example, when Exxon and Mobil merged in November, the new company declared as surplus a 473-acre complex in Florham Park that used to house Exxon's engineering division.
This month, the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation of Manhattan agreed to buy the parcel, along Route 24 and Park Avenue, which it plans to develop into a $400 million office park with 2.2 million square feet of space.
Mr. Cabana said Morris County would survive.
"We all understand that corporate America is going through a restructuring," he said.
"Morris County has been fortunate for many years to be home to so many corporations because they understand the quality of life here is good and everybody seems to want to be here. That isn't going to change."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 25, 2000, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about companies that have moved corporate headquarters out of Morris County, N.J., misstated the reason Schering-Plough pharmaceuticals moved to Kenilworth, in Union County. The company, which still has an office in Morris County, moved to a new, larger building in Kenilworth to improve corporate communications, a spokeswoman said. Schering-Plough did not merge with another company.

SECTION: Section H; Page 35; Column 1; E-Commerce 

LENGTH: 1470 words

HEADLINE: ENTERTAINMENT;
A Fourth for Bridge or a Cozy Chat in an All-Night Bingo Hall

BYLINE: By HILARY APPELMAN; Hillary Appelman writes frequently about e-commerce and is an avid game player.

 BODY:
I HAVE some new friends. Well, not friends exactly. I wouldn't recognize them if we bumped into each other, and I don't even know their real names. But they are always there when I need them -- to play games.
There's Sooner, a student in Oklahoma who plays bingo when she should be writing papers, and Betsiew, a military wife in Germany whose daughter was hurt on the seesaw recently. There's Tdreed, who whipped me in Jeopardy, and Maacret and McWhite17, friendly and forgiving Spades opponents. 
 I used to dismiss computer games as shoot'em-up arcade fare or fantasy worlds populated by evil aliens and exploding spaceships. But it turns out there is a world of people online who are playing old-fashioned family games like checkers, bridge and backgammon. Whole communities have sprung up around these virtual card parlors and bingo halls, where you can find a game -- and a conversation -- 24 hours a day.
There are dozens of sites where game players can hook up with one another to play everything from chess to Jeopardy.
"Many people would tell you the reason they don't play as much in the real world is the pace of life," said Garth Choutreau, a spokesman for the Pogo.com game site. "It's just so hard to get four people around the kitchen table to play bridge, for example. At any given time on Pogo there are at least 1,000 people playing bridge."
More than 13 million people -- a whopping 25 percent of United States homes that are online -- play games on the Web at least once a month, said Jeremy Schwartz, a senior analyst at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. And unlike traditional computer games, which are played mostly by young men, leisure games draw women and men in about equal numbers across a broad range of age groups. The number of players is expected to swell as new technologies like broadband and cellular phones and other hand-held devices with Internet access allow people to get online more easily and stay on longer.
In terms of "stickiness," or how long people stay at a Web site, games are some of the most popular online destinations. The average visitor to Bingo.com spent eight and a half hours at the site during August, according to Nielsen/Net Ratings. The average visitor to eBay, by contrast, spent less than two hours.
In terms of numbers, the most popular game sites are lottery and sweepstakes sites, like Speedyclick.com and Freelotto .com, which give away cash or prizes. In its first operating year, the sweepstakes portal site iWon, where users earn sweepstakes entries by doing almost anything -- from clicking on an advertisement to checking the weather -- became one of the 10 most popular sites on the Web over all, with close to two million visitors a day.
Online game sites took in more than $100 million in advertising and subscription fees in 1999 and are expected to have revenue of more than $200 million this year, according to Jupiter Communications, the Internet research firm in New York. Jupiter projects that amount will grow to almost $770 million annually by 2003.
Advertising is still the top moneymaker in the games sector, but big off-line game makers are getting into the act with multilayered sites like Electronic Arts Inc.'s www.ea.com, which try to entice users to play pay-per-game or subscription-based games and buy console games, said Billy Pidgeon, an analyst at Jupiter. Internet portals are also acquiring game sites in an effort to attract and hold onto large audiences. Lycos bought Gamesville.com last fall and Excite@Home snapped up Pogo.com in August. The business model for a successful games site is still evolving, Mr. Pidgeon said, but he predicted it would grow harder for independent sites to survive unless they found a niche.
For my first venture into online game-playing, I headed for bingo. I had not played since grade school, but I had fond memories of those little boards and colored markers. Bingo was unthreatening; no one else had to know how well or badly I was playing. Bingo also lends itself to chat, because you don't have to think about your next move.
After signing in at Pogo.com's bingo site, I chose to play with other 30-somethings. (Pogo also has rooms with themes like movies, music and politics, as well as rooms for "uncensored chat.") Each player receives three boards at once; numbers appear at the top of the screen and are called out loud. Winners receive tickets for a $50 prize drawing.
A stream of chat runs down one side of the screen next to the game. Most of it is players greeting each other -- "Hi River," "Hi Lori," "Hi Room," and cheering one another on -- "Go Mindy," "Go Room."
At the start of each game, the chat box fills with choruses of "gle" (good luck everyone) and "gla" (good luck all). Later in the game, players post cryptic messages like "5tg" (five numbers to go) and "4tgX2" (four numbers on two boards). When someone wins, everyone cheers "wtg" (way to go).
Occasionally, a glimpse of someone's real life pokes through.
"Brb" (be right back), Spiritpa said during one game. "Have to take clothes out of dryer."
From the relatively staid Pogo site I headed to Bingo.com, where the graphics are purple and orange, and I was bombarded with pop-up ads and promotions for events like lunch-hour tournaments and tarot readings. Bingo .com goes out of its way to make new players feel welcome -- there is a guide to chat lingo and suggested chat topics for breaking the ice. (Reflecting the site's 67 to 33 female-to-male ratio, one recent topic was "Is your husband a football couch potato?") At Bingo.com's Cupid area, decorated with hot pink and purple hearts, someone asked, "Anyone from Indiana?" and suddenly everyone was talking -- "Maine," "Pa," "NJ," "Ky here," "Ill here." Dotty6 was from Georgia and, small world, Wilma 37 was going to Georgia on vacation.
Game chat tends to be superficial, to put it mildly. Sometimes an hour can pass with nothing more personal than a "wtg." And socializing online has its own peculiar hazards, including game sites' tendency to freeze at inopportune moments.
But then there was the game where worried players tried to figure out how to contact a regular who had not shown up in several days. And the time Betsiew's 4-year-old daughter was hurt on the seesaw and all of us at her bingo table spent the next hour debating whether she should go to the doctor. (She did, finally.) I do not know Betsiew's real name, but I have shared a little piece of her life, and we both play games. Friendships have been built on less.
Sara Schwab of West Coxsackie, N.Y., said she is at the same place every morning on Bingo.com, where her screen name is Sarasue351, and sees the same people logged on. "I say, 'gm friends,' and they say 'Good morning Sara,' 'Good morning Sara,' 'Good morning Sara,' " she said. A player in Canada e-mailed her a cake recipe, and Mrs. Schwab has corresponded with her ever since.
Not all game sites are as conducive to community-building, but they still can be a lot of fun. At Sony Online Entertainment's site, www.station.sony.com, I tried out the multiplayer test version of Jeopardy.
UNLIKE bingo, which had ads for decidedly adult-looking casino sites, Jeopardy featured ads for table saws from Sears, Lands' End and J. C. Penney. It took a few minutes for the game to load, and then I was joined by two other players, Tdreed and Dazed2000, and we were off.
Tdreed jumped out to a 2,000-point lead, cleaning up in the football category. When the category changed to literary quotes, I made my move, correctly identifying Anne Tyler as the author of "Breathing Lessons." (Online Jeopardy is multiple choice, which makes it much easier than the TV version.) In the second round I racked up 1,000 points by correctly stating the number of electrons in helium (two) and defining metal fatigue, then lost it all in Final Jeopardy by failing to name Radio City Music Hall as the theater where Martha Graham and the Flying Wallendas both played on opening night.
Jeopardy does not have a chat screen, but you can send short messages that show up over your icon's head. Given the pace of the game, there isn't really time for more.
Hasbro's Games.com is scheduled to go online in December with multiplayer versions of Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk, Boggle, Battleship and Clue. Laura Tomasetti, a spokeswoman, said the site would offer a 10-minute version of Monopoly.
My husband, son and I recently spent a week in the Adirondacks in a cabin with no telephone. We were there with my parents and my brother's family -- game aficionados all -- and a stack of board games from home. But the children stayed up late and the adults were tired; the week went by and the game boxes stayed unopened.
Vacation is over now; the phone is connected. It's time to play some games.

HEADLINE: A Glass of Wine Helps Show What Buyers Want

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
WHEN the Internet began evolving into a mass medium in 1995, it struck fear into the hearts of retailers, who worried that enabling consumers to quickly and easily compare prices would force ever thinner profit margins. Then their businesses, like the cursed fat lawyer in Stephen King's 1994 novel "Thinner," would be reduced to skin and bones.
Paying the lowest price possible might seem like a shopper's dream, but ultimately consumers would lose because there would be too little profit to sustain a vibrant market, resulting in a scarcity of goods. 
 But shoppers, it turned out, do not always pay the lowest price, and not because they are unaware of it, according to research by several professors who have studied Internet pricing. The research suggested that retailers could expand their businesses and keep healthy profit margins from Internet sales if they understand what consumers want.
"Price is not the only factor in making a purchase," said Erick Brynjolfsson, an associate professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management.
Many retailers discovered last holiday season that factors other than price could influence buying decisions, like convenience, quality and reliability. As the holiday neared and as carriers like the Postal Service and United Parcel Service became swamped with packages, many customers made buying decisions based solely on delivery needs.
But there is a difference between learning from a knock on the head and learning from studies that are more controlled and better designed. As a result, Professor Brynjolfsson's work is part of a growing field of Internet business research conducted by economists like himself, as well as consumer behavior specialists and psychologists. Research at M.I.T. has included what makes consumers trust, or distrust, commercial Web sites; how to design sites to make them easier to navigate; and how to convert more visitors into buyers by analyzing data on how people click through a site.
Other institutions and universities have been doing similar work. Research at the I.B.M. Institute for Advanced Commerce has included an examination of Web merchandising, an analysis of online advertising, a look at the effectiveness of online stores and a study of business negotiations on the Internet.
"We are now well past the point where you trust your gut on the Internet," Professor Brynjolfsson said. "Companies want solid research."
M.I.T.'s Center for eBusiness has 30 corporate sponsors, who are trying to understand how the Internet affects retailing and wholesaling. Many of the papers that M.I.T. researchers have written can be viewed at ebusiness.mit.edu.
In a paper that asked whether the Internet was to shopping what the Colt .45 revolver supposedly was to Dodge City, Kan. -- the great equalizer -- Professor Brynjolfsson and others found that when an identical product was offered, consumers would often shun the lowest price vendor, even when a list of vendors was ranked with the lowest prices on top.
RESEARCHERS studied book sales with the help of Deal time.com, a shopping site that scoured online booksellers to find every vendor and then rank them by price for a book from cheapest to most expensive.
"We gathered more than a million price observations," Professor Brynjolfsson said, "and we found that people often did not click on the lowest price, even when the lowest price was the first one listed."
Instead, consumers weighed brand recognition as well as concerns about whether an order would be filled promptly and accurately, and they showed a loyalty to vendors with whom they did business.
Analysis showed "that price was important, and having lowest price, all else being equal, increased odds that consumers would pick you," Professor Brynjolfsson said. "But we also found that advertising levels, which create awareness of the vendor, were a major factor. Amazon.com received 400 percent as many clicks as you would expect based solely on price."
The research found that quality issues, like whether orders would be filled quickly and accurately, weighed heavily on consumers. So did shopping habits. Consumers went with higher priced vendors if they had bought from them before or had an online account with them.
Prof. Dan Ariely, who studies consumer decision-making at M.I.T., said that "the Internet has this amazing power to convey information about quality and by giving good detailed information about what you are selling and how you are selling it." Merchants can not only charge higher prices, but they can also build customer loyalty.
Prof. John G. Lynch Jr. of the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University, and Professor Ariely, who was a graduate student there in 1998, sold wine during that time as an experiment to determine how consumers reacted to low prices, lots of information and other factors.
The professors said they decided to use wine in the test because most people lacked the knowledge to evaluate subtle differences in bouquet, flavor and body. They also did not know which wines go with which foods or in certain social settings. This lack of knowledge, Professor Ariely said, can make differences with satisfaction or regret over a purchase.
A wine expert filled the sites with quality information on wines, which were then offered for sale to graduate students and faculty at Fuqua.
Eight sites were created, some emphasizing price, others emphasizing information to help select a wine. There were different levels of ease in comparing sites, some wiping out tentative purchases when a customer switched between sites, while others retained the basket of prospective purchase until the customer returned to either buy the wines or cancel the order. The professors also held wine tastings to gather more information. (The professors did not actually sell the wine but acted as a marketing agent for a licensed seller to comply with alcohol control laws.)
"We found with wine that if you give good information, consumers become less price sensitive," Professor Ariely said. "They like the wine that they buy more, and they stay longer with the service that sold it to them."
Like Professor Brynjolfsson, the Fuqua researchers found that information is most important in swaying consumers who are buying subtle or exotic products. When people shop for a product they know is widely available -- Levi blue jeans, for example -- price trumps everything.
But that is not true of all products, even if carefully presented and accompanied by thorough information. "Before you buy a new chair for your office," said Professor Ariely, "you are still going to want to sit in it."
Professor Lynch said the wine project and other research showed that Internet merchants should in some cases adopt the same collaborative spirit with competitors as bricks and mortar businesses do. He cited the example of a hotel that has run out of rooms when someone drives up, or the hardware store that lacks equipment a customer wants.
Smart hoteliers and hardware store owners direct the customer to the competitor who has what the customer wants, expecting to build loyalty with the customer and make future sales.
In online retailing, Professor Lynch said, such collaboration works when sellers are offering products that consumers perceive are different, regardless of whether the differences are only illusory.
"Online shopping creates incentives for sellers to have more private labels," Professor Lynch said, "more exclusives and more branded variance, in which a manufacturer makes slightly different products with slightly different model numbers, but the differences are enough that consumers can't readily tell that they are essentially the same."

HEADLINE: A Health Revolution, in Baby Steps

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: WORCESTER, Mass.

 BODY:
IN many ways, Dr. Anne Seger could not be happier. From her home or office, she can key any of her patients into her computer and instantly spy almost every piece of information she needs -- results from a blood test and X-rays, the operating room's report from recent surgery and the patient's next appointment.
Nurses and doctors on the labor and delivery floor of her hospital, UMass Memorial, can monitor patients' labor from their computer screens. Doctors can plug drug orders into a computer program that will check the drug against a patient's other medications and immediately warn of possible dangers or unexpected interactions. And billing is electronic. 
 All this is light-years from where Dr. Seger and her hospital were just five years ago. But it is also far, far from where she and her colleagues in information technology at the hospital want to be. "We are not there yet," said Dr. Seger, an internist who is the medical director of system integration. Neither are most other hospitals.
There are perhaps few industries that have more to gain from the Internet revolution than medicine. Rapid advancements in biotechnology and medical research, increasingly curious patients who shop the Web for medical information and pressures from managed care companies to contain costs and speed treatments are just the central components driving, in the industry patois, "e-health."
What is more, medicine's most dirty open secret -- the glut of errors that occur in hospitals -- has become a high-profile and politicized issue, and many proponents of information-sharing technologies think that their products can help prevent tragic bedside errors.
"Hospitals are real laggards" when it comes to the Internet, said Dr. Russell Ricci, the general manager of global health care industry at I.B.M. "What e-health has to be used for is to transform the whole process of delivering care. But unfortunately, what most hospitals are doing is trying to go from bricks to clicks, but the system is still based on bricks, which is not going to get us there."
Computer types are even more dismayed when they look elsewhere in the notoriously inefficient health care system, particularly at the task of persuading the nation's harried, technology-averse doctors to wire their practices. Stocks of companies like WebMD and Medscape soared last winter, then dropped even faster when the gap between medical and Silicon Valley perspectives became apparent.
In the case of hospitals, the reasons for the delays are as complex as they are ubiquitous. The first, of course, is money. Hospitals, especially academic medical centers, which enjoyed years of unfettered spending until managed care reared its head a decade ago, are having a difficult time adjusting to the new lean years in medicine.
Cuts by the government in Medicare and Medicaid spending, combined with constantly declining reimbursements from managed care companies and skyrocketing drug costs, have made it difficult for medical centers to find the budget to expand their information systems as much as they would have liked. Mergers -- a staple activity for major medical centers over the last few years -- have further complicated matters. Hospitals love technology when it means complicated new machines to help diagnose and treat diseases, but they are not always attracted to software that calls for changes in age-old routines.
As a result, many centers entered the 21st century with the finest surgical talent and equipment in the world, but patients were still giving their social security number to seven different people, who were all scribbling it on paper.
And as hospitals attempt to evolve, they are also confronting new federal regulations on the privacy of medical information, which presents new problems in the electronic world: how can you be in the business of sharing information when, in some cases, that sharing might be illegal?
Keeping the finest technology minds on staff is also difficult when companies with far deeper pockets are within a few miles of every hospital's front door. UMass loses about four people a month to other companies.
In addition, those who make and sell e-health products often contribute to the problem, hospital technology executives argue. The dot-com world is unstable, with constant mergers threatening to render many costly systems obsolete. Systems quickly become outdated and are too costly to replace, and many of the most highly promoted items are not as practical as their companies proclaim. "It really is easy to be seduced by the dot-com of what is coming and what may be," Dr. Seger said.
UNTIL recently, dot-coms enamored of their own software were reluctant to tweak products in ways that doctors wanted. "It used to be that vendors had the attitude, 'If we don't make it, you don't need it,' " Dr. Seger said. "They have gotten a lot better about that, but it has taken time."
Some centers saw the revolution coming years ago and built their own systems, literally at home. The most highly recognized is Intermountain Health Care, which runs 22 hospitals in Idaho, Utah and Wyoming. Intermountain has been building its systems internally since the 1960's, long before it could buy the technology in the marketplace. Its highlights include computerized drug monitoring, electronic bedside charts and a robotic pharmacy delivery system, as well as a system in which doctors can enter orders for patient care into a hand-held computer. Right now, these features are available only at Intermountain's flagship LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City, but they are being peppered throughout the system. Rural hospitals already have the capacity to send high-quality images and information to specialists at LDS for consultations, something most big medical centers around the nation lack.
"We feel that real-time information on patients is absolutely critical," said Jess Gomez, a spokesman for LDS Hospital.
Fine hospitals in the Boston region are like fast-food stands at the mall -- abundant and fiercely competitive. In terms of technology, UMass Memorial -- the product of a 1998 merger between UMass and Memorial Health Care -- is considered one of the more advanced centers among those connected to a medical school. It serves a large and diverse population that includes a heavy dose of patients in Medicare or Medicaid.
The hospital does not have the fat budget of Massachusetts General in Boston, the envy of Dr. Seger and others in the area. But UMass has invested $40 million in infrastructure over the last five years and expanded its information technology staff to 140 from 20. Many of those people had worked delivering care, Dr. Seger said.
The center has particularly benefited from the new ability to integrate vast amounts of patient information into a single chart stored online. With X-rays and blood tests and other data centralized, decisions can be made more quickly and confidently.
Having an entire patient record also allows doctors to walk families through their loved one's entire medical history after a death, right there on one screen, to help them make sense of it all.
Drugs can now be ordered directly from the pharmacy without going through a clerk. Ditto for other supplies. All doctors have access to an online library, so research that once took librarians two days to collect can be downloaded much faster. Outside the two campuses, the hospital's 120 off-site doctors are also connected to the system, as is the center's new ambulatory surgical center.
When patients are admitted to the hospital, they are electronically checked for their insurance type, doctor and history with the center and assigned a bed in one fell swoop. Bills are submitted and paid electronically, and when they are not, insurance companies are nudged electronically, as well. The effect of such efficiencies cannot yet be quantified, but the center expects to save several million dollars a year, much of that coming from a more expedient and accurate payment process.
These transactions take place almost exclusively on an intranet, a private network that uses Internet technology but is not part of the Web. (The center does not have its own public Web site.) The center does not put any patient information online and will not until the privacy issues become clearer, said Richard F. Bretagne, a vice president and chief information officer at UMass.
"There are a lot more opportunities to share information going forward," he said, adding that the hospital does share information with the state's insurance companies and other health care providers. "The caveat is that we need the privacy and confidentiality regulations to become clearer and for the encryption details to become clearer," he said.
"That is happening pretty quickly," Mr. Bretagne said. The first thing that will be over the Internet will be billing information, he noted.
More important than any cool gadget or groovy program, Dr. Seger said, was simply preparing the hospital's technological guts for business in the new century. "Our infrastructure is better than most," she said. "Having guys with their behinds hanging out of the ceiling with a whole bunch of wires is not what people in this business want to talk about. It isn't sexy. But it is very important, and we think we are in good shape."
It has not been easy.
One of the biggest challenges by far, Dr. Seger and others at the center said, was not strictly technical. Hospital mergers tend to result in huge cultural and political conflicts -- which hospital's head of cardiology will get the job at the merged center? Who gets to sit on the new board? When UMass and Memorial joined, each center wanted to keep its own computer system and way of delivering care. In the end, the decision was made to meld the two into a new system, at a cost of $14 million, which left hard feelings on both sides.
"There were huge turf battles," Dr. Seger said. "Computer systems represent a culture." But now the two centers with two campuses could communicate. Technology purchasing became centralized, so departments could no longer buy renegade software that was incompatible with the network.
Then there were systems that needed tweaking before they were brought online. Why did a certain procedure, for instance, take 13 steps when to an outside observer it could be done in three? Often, the answer was "just because." "This was a way of pulling back the rug and looking at how you do business," Dr. Seger said. "We don't want to automate bad systems."
And at times doctors have resisted change. Some still refuse to put a patient's identification number into the digital dictation system that goes to patient records. They punch in a series of 9's instead, which requires it to be corrected on paper. And even though $60,000 a year has been saved by putting lab reports online, some doctors still protest. Most doctors love the system, Dr. Seger said. "But there is a bell-shaped curve. Some doctors still think that faxes are a Communist plot."
Instability among makers of all things technical has also presented problems. For instance, the center does lab work for the state's prisons and bought a system that connected the two. The company that provided that technology, however, recently went bankrupt -- a story line that has played out with other systems at the hospital. Vendors of e-gadgets often promise more than they can deliver and do not listen to feedback from doctors. "Frankly, many are more hype than reality," Mr. Bretagne said.
FROM one such vendor's point of view, doctors are not easy customers, although he can see their point. "For the most part, physicians are fairly risk-averse, and there has been a slow adoption time," said Dr. David Grayzel, the chief executive of Catalyst Medical Solutions, which makes a note-writing system for doctors that translates procedures into billing language and makes the notes ready for review in an academic setting. "Part of why I left academic medicine to go into this was because many products that are developed don't take into consideration physician work flow. You really have to understand how the doctors work on the front line."
On the front line at UMass, old tools are still in far too much use, administrators acknowledge.
A patient's electronic medical record is still not totally complete -- M.R.I.'s, for instance, do not yet mesh with the system, and the hospital is still trying to work with a vendor to make that happen. Bone density tests are not online, nor are electrocardiograms. And as useful as the fetal monitoring system is, the center is waiting for one that allows doctors to monitor a patient's progress from home or an office miles away. In the mundane department, there is no real way to rectify the problem of two patients with the same name. Just the other day, a CAT scan went into the wrong patient's electronic chart. The department that handles the formal, legal, full patient records still keeps them on paper, putting that department in another century.
Some hospitals are sending images like chest X-rays over the computer, but not UMass -- the hospital's network does not have enough capacity for high-speed transmission. A system that projects diagnostic-quality images has proved too expensive for any place but the emergency room and intensive care unit, even though it would hugely benefit doctors if it were hospitalwide.
And the center is a long way from a system in which a doctor puts in orders from a hand-held device like a Palm. Such systems are thought to be the most effective way to flag errors in drug dosage, which is a chief cause of medical mistakes. These systems, however, are used by centers with a lot of money.
"The Institute of Medicine study says that we kill 100,000 people a year with hospital errors," said Dr. Ricci of I.B.M. "Yet most of the hospitals still do not have an electronic point-of-care order-entry system. With it, that number of errors would never happen. But instead of investing in that, many hospitals are out building new buildings or buying new M.R.I.'s."
Executives at UMass say they are not spending unwisely. They simply have no more money, they argue. The hospital no longer receives state financing under the merger. "We lose money on every admission," said Dr. Seger, who figures the hospital will not be able to buy new products this year, upgrading what they have instead. It cannot afford Windows 2000.
On Mr. Bretagne's wish list is a system that would collect billing information into a marketing analysis and forecasting system; more online clinical information that can complete a true patient record; and a way to look at ultrasounds and other images from anywhere so that specialists can consult over the phone with community hospitals and one another. Oh, and products that live up to their sales pitches. The way some imaging systems are sold, he said, "People think they are on AOL at home and want to see a patient's radiology image, and they will click and there it will be. In reality, these are very dense, and we tell people if you want that image, click on it and go make a cup of coffee."
His all-time favorite technological product: e-mail.
Mr. Ricci of I.B.M. can barely hide his disgust with most of this -- it is as if he were living on the Starship Enterprise and he just landed on a strange little planet where the natives etch prescriptions on stones and use leeches to rid themselves of disease.
His vision of e-health goes far beyond the patchwork of in-house systems UMass is cobbling together. In fact, he wants e-health to take care almost completely out of the hospital.
Medical devices that use the Internet to connect home and doctor open vast new possibilities for improving care and lowering costs, he said. For instance, "A bathroom scale is a medical device," he said. "If someone has congestive heart failure and we give them a bathroom scale with a modem, it would decrease costs. They go to a party, gain two pounds because they're retaining fluid, and that scale calls to my case managers, locks the fridge, says order a diuretic. The bathroom scale is a pervasive computing device that decreases admissions, but if congestive heart failure is my biggest profit center, that could have a huge negative impact."
He added: "A hospital of the 21st century is an I.C.U. and an organization whose unit is knowledge and expertise, not necessarily health care delivery."
Dr. Seger said that her center did have a pilot program to use patient home devices that operate much like a bathroom scale. More such tests are "absolutely" coming, she said, even if she does not envision hospitals disappearing the way Dr. Ricci wants.
"Quality medicine is in prevention for sure," she added. "But saying that we don't want home devices is like saying we want more people to smoke so we can have more lung cancer patients. The issue is financial and human resources, and that is a never-ending struggle."

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
South African Firms Are Going High-Tech At Their Own Speed

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
WHEN Sasol Ltd., a world leader in energy resources and a powerhouse of South African industry, decided earlier this year to start buying its paper and pens online, it went to its longtime supplier and fellow Johannesburg company, Waltons Stationery, and outlined its plans.
If Waltons, the country's biggest office supplier, wanted to be part of Sasol's future, the 70-store Waltons chain had to change the way it did business. 
 Today, Waltons receives Sasol's orders, worth more than $2 million a year, over the Internet. For South Africa, a country where television first appeared little more than two decades ago, the arrangement would seem to have been a breakthrough.
Waltons's entry into e-commerce, however, is for the moment benefiting only Sasol and a few other big customers. It will be next year, the company said, before small businesses and individuals will be able to order a case of paper or a box of pens online from Waltons.
The reasons help illustrate the peculiar potential of e-commerce in South Africa, where first-world wealth and third-world desperation coexist in an uneasy amalgam of inequality.
Although South Africa's economy is only about the size of Belgium's, it dwarfs other African nations. Under President Thabo Mbeki, inflation has dropped and the country's credit rating has climbed.
But efforts to streamline its consumer economy are hampered by a huge gap between rich and poor, a legacy of the apartheid era, compounded by heavy nationalization. Adult illiteracy was estimated at 30 percent in 1995, and 4.2 million people out of an estimated total population of 45 million are currently thought to be infected with the virus that causes AIDS.
Waltons sells mostly to businesses, from small outfits to huge conglomerates. It began its business-to-business and business-to-consumer Internet effort about a year ago. But about six months ago, after the big companies came calling, it decided to make business-to-business its priority and postponed its consumer shopping site until next year. Its revised timetable suggests that Waltons is not fretting that it will lose many of its ordinary customers.
Not only do the big companies have the infrastructure to make business-to-business e-commerce and its enormous savings a reality, but they also have well-established relationships with their suppliers. These include systems for receiving regular orders, collecting payments and making deliveries. Often, the only step left is shifting much of that onto the Internet.
But South Africa has nothing like Sears, Roebuck & Company, Victoria's Secret or L. L. Bean and the mail-order culture that in the United States helped pave the way for Amazon.com and its imitators. Buying or selling -- whether it's a power drill or panties or a parka -- any place but a store is a new concept here and is only slowly taking hold.
"We are actually quite far behind," said Allison Mills-Daggatt, a former executive with the office-supply store Staples who is now the e-commerce director for Waltons. "There is so much potential in this whole business, but we're not even where Staples was four years ago. It's a bit frustrating how slow it is."
There are reasons for the reluctance to order online, or even over the phone.
Topping the list is a notoriously unreliable national mail service, which often forces the use of costly courier services. Then there is Telkom, the South African telecommunications monopoly, which is undergoing privatization. A 30 percent stake in Telkom has been sold and the company is set to face competition within several years.
That is way too long for a business revolution, so many people are looking beyond fixed-line phones and personal home computers.
Optimists are attaching their hopes to mobile phones, which have more than five million users, including a fair share in the impoverished townships.
Indeed, for every high-speed data line coursing through the corridors of the country's high-powered investment banks and industrial conglomerates, there are hundreds of homes that have never been connected to traditional telephone lines. And they are unlikely to be any time soon.
According to the 1996 census, only 11 percent of blacks, who make up just more than three-quarters of the population, had a telephone in their home or a cell phone. The figure for whites was 89 percent.
As a result, e-commerce has been an uneven exercise in South Africa. Big companies have plunged in at Pentium speed, while ordinary customers and the businesses that serve them have been far slower.
One argument says that too few people are shopping online to make noticeable discounts and speedy service economical; the counterargument says that more people would shop online if retailers offered more.
It is, however, possible to buy everything from cereal to books online in South Africa, and more sites are opening monthly. But it may be a less-than-satisfactory experience, leaving a shopper longing for a local shopping center.
Certainly the share of South Africa's 45 million people who have online access -- estimated at one million to two million -- is paltry. But it is hardly surprising, considering the apartheid regime's neglect of the black majority.
And for their part, many businesses in South Africa are still finding their way in a world in which they were isolated for so long. Big businesses with considerable international exposure, like Sasol, have been among the most aggressive, seizing on e-commerce.
With its office supplies now being ordered over the Internet, Sasol is poised to move on to more sophisticated and more expensive supplies like drill bits, grinders, electric motors and pipe fittings.
"It's early day for us, but at least we can say we're doing it," said Alex Zwiegelaar, the general manager of Sasol's information and logistics division.
And Waltons has benefited from its big customers' demands. "It made us make things happen," said Tina Piccione, the marketing director. "It was definitely a blessing in disguise."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
As Competition Heats Up, So Does the Threat of Collusion

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is a paradox of the new Internet economy. Thousands of companies have begun to participate in hundreds of new business-to-business exchanges, buying and selling supplies and products and achieving new economic efficiencies, creating a more transparent marketplace that holds great promise for better prices, lower costs, faster production and greater competition.
But experts have been warning that the same technological advances that make such exchanges more popular and efficient also could make it easier for there to be collusion among rivals, price fixing and other anti-competitive conduct that could lead to higher prices and less competition -- and would be harder to trace. 
 "To the extent there may be a serpent in the Garden of Eden, it is this," said Robert Pitofsky, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. "Whenever you put competitors together in a joint venture, you have to ask what information is being exchanged? Will it facilitate collusion?"
When the business-to-business markets are formed as joint ventures by traditional rivals, they cannot operate without government approval, and in recent weeks, officials in Washington and Europe have announced their views on the first of what promises to be a long line of proposals. American and European antitrust officials have moved cautiously, approving in principle the formation of the first joint ventures for the exchanges with caveats that they will be closely watched as they come online.
In approving the establishment of Covisint, an online venture that would allow five major automakers to buy supplies through a single Internet portal, the trade commission warned that it would continue to monitor the venture for possible anti-competitive issues after it opens . Automakers are expected to use the site to list parts they seek from suppliers, which would then offer bids to secure a contract in a procedure commonly referred to as a reverse auction. The participants include Ford, General Motors, DaimlerChrylser, Nissan Motor of Japan and Renault of France. They have said Covisint may wield enormous purchasing power, accounting for $240 billion each year.
A few weeks before that, the European Commission approved the formation of MYAircraft.com, a joint venture by United Technologies, Honeywell and the software company i2 Technologies that would allow aerospace companies to trade parts and services.
Antitrust experts say that they have three main concerns about the rise of such exchanges, which are appearing in industries ranging from steel, construction and chemicals to retailing and consumer goods. First, they may exclude some companies, limiting competition. Second, they may require that companies use one exchange exclusively and shun all others, creating one dominant exchange that would have too much power.
But the largest concern among consumer advocates and some experts is that buyers or sellers would collude on pricing and take steps to set prices in unison. The experts worry that because rival companies can see pricing information faster than in other markets, it is easier to coordinate prices without ever speaking to one another.
"The biggest fear is that there is a coordination of prices by companies and that, as a result of the new technology, the companies will leave no tracks," said Albert A. Foer, president of the American Antitrust Institute, a Washington research organization. "With these exchanges, we're seeing a Cambrian explosion of new animal forms, in all industries, and all at once. If we allow it to happen with businesses calling all the shots and no government intervention, it may be impossible to curtail problems later."
Lawyers working on these ventures for the companies say there is little to worry about as long as the exchanges are structured properly and adequate safeguards are put in place.
William Baer, a former antitrust official at the trade commission who has advised health care companies and retailers on business-to-business antitrust issues, said that the potential antitrust issues posed by exchanges were not novel to the Internet but had been seen in more traditional markets.
The biggest concern, he said, is if competitors are able to coordinate their pricing by learning in advance of the prices being offered by their rivals.
"As long as you aren't disclosing in advance your pricing information, then you should be able to deal with that antitrust risk," said Mr. Baer, a partner at the law firm of Arnold & Porter.
The issue is hardly novel. In 1994, six large airlines settled charges brought by the Justice Department that they had used a computerized reservation system to fix fares. The airlines agreed to end the practice of communicating proposed fare increases through the system maintained by the Airline Tariff Publishing Company.
To some extent, Mr. Baer and other experts said, the experience with the slightly older business-to-consumer exchanges is instructive of antitrust issues confronting the business-to-business marketplace.
In recent months, several companies with online operations have begun to face scrutiny by antitrust officials for possible anti-competitive conduct. The investigations often involve complaints filed by rivals and occasionally reflect tensions between Internet start-up companies and older, more established businesses.
Orbitz, an online travel agency being formed by five major airlines, has drawn scrutiny from the Justice Department and Capitol Hill after rivals like Travelocity and Expedia complained that the company would receive preferential treatment, and better fares, from its owners. The owners -- American Airlines, Continental Airlines, Delta Airlines, Northwest Airlines and United Airlines -- deny that they would steer more favorable fares to their online company, which they plan to introduce next summer.
And other business-to-consumer Web sites in the marine and real estate industries have denied accusations made by more traditional rivals of forming possible anti-competitive relationships.
Those experiences have not dampened the enthusiasm for business-to-business exchanges, although they have highlighted the need for taking great care in forming them. They have also led to a new and lucrative avenue of business for antitrust lawyers who are called at the formation of such exchanges to provide advice, set up safeguards and head off regulatory concerns.
Mr. Pitofsky of the trade commision said that when he spoke at a recent conference of general counsels of American companies, he asked how many were setting up business-to-business exchanges, and more than one-third of those in the audience raised their hands.
"Probably more than 900 companies are now making such plans," he estimated, a rise of more than 50 percent in the last few months alone. "It's amazing how trendy and fashionable these exchanges have suddenly become."
