SECTION: Section H; Page 24; Column 1; E-Commerce 

LENGTH: 1475 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
When Competitors Are Partners, How Bare Do They Dare?

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE 

 BODY:
CONVERSATIONS in the boardroom are using the language of the bedroom -- openness, commitment, vulnerability and trust -- as e-nabled companies give one another come-hither looks. It isn't mergers they want, but partners. With the Internet cutting the cost of information exchanges and transactions, e-commerce executives say networked partnering is the best way to create goods and services.
But declaring yourselves an item, even in business, always raises certain expectations of intimacy. In an Internet context, these expectations are higher. After all, the premise of the promised supply-chain revolution is that manufacturers and their suppliers can become vastly more efficient if the chain becomes see-through and everyone knows how things are going. 
 In this world, knowledge -- information, expertise and more -- is not just power. It is an asset to be appropriated, refined, enhanced and then sold. No wonder the demand is high among Internetworked partners to bare it all.
"Prepare to be naked," said Don Tapscott, the chairman of Digital 4Sight, a strategy consulting and research firm in Toronto, and a co-author of "Digital Capital," a guide to corporate survival in the new economy. "To succeed on the Internet, especially in these groups we call B-webs, companies must prepare to reveal information about themselves, their products and their business processes, even previously sacrosanct information, and even to sometime competitors, because it will be in their common interest."
It makes sense for businesses to want to give each other advice where and when it can do the most good. "You need your partners to be able to ask the right questions, to elicit the information they need to give you their best service or product," said Jakob Nielsen, a principal of the Nielsen Norman Group, a Silicon Valley company that specializes in making the Internet easier to use.
But many companies are, well, prudes. Justifiably so, say some business consultants, noting that no company wants to hand informational crown jewels to competitors. "Not everyone should whip off their clothes and hop into the hot tub," Mr. Tapscott said. "Companies need to think through what information do we need, and what do we have to provide? What are the safeguards? What deals do we make so that information is not used by our competitors? What is the level of trust here?"
Even in a trusting relationship, partners may want to keep some fig leaves strategically in place. "You may have supply-chain problems internally that you don't want to reveal," said Ken Ouchi, a corporate vice president at the Solectron Corporation, one of the nation's leading providers of electronic manufacturing services.
Or you may want to augment information with your knowledge. "That becomes your added value," Dr. Ouchi said. A customer orders 120 components, for example. You have 100 on hand and, in reality, you know only 90 will be needed. "Pure transparency, being stark-naked," Dr. Ouchi said, "would result in your telling your partner you don't have enough. But managing the relationship, and the information, means saying you can fill the order."
That information must be managed within a process, like invoicing or product servicing, that is also a relationship, consultants and e-business executives say. Witness the efforts of Fadi B. Chehade, the chairman and chief executive of Viacore Inc., which allows supply-chain trading partners to exchange and manage real-time business processes using the Internet. Mr. Chehade spearheaded RosettaNet, an industrywide consortium that built consensus among computer and electronic component supply chains to standardize information processes.
"Companies don't understand that information sharing is really business process /relationship-centric, not information/transaction-centric," he said. "From this ignorance, or maybe fear, they relegate information sharing to the technical side of the house, to people who can manage information but who cannot manage relationships, people who will take your knowledge currency and squander it."
An example: "Formulating RosettaNet, we gathered people from throughout the industry to discuss warranty management," Mr. Chehade said. "Some companies sent information technology people. What we needed were warranty experts who could determine what information is needed to guarantee warranties, what should the work flow be and its time constraints." Standardizing B-to-B dialogues in this way, he added, makes them replicable and gives participants a measure of control and security.
"It's all about the business process," said Eric S. Michlowitz, the director of supply- chain e-business solutions at the Dell Computer Company. "You have a set of objectives in mind. You need a process to achieve them. The process will involve Dell, a build-to-order computer company, and its suppliers, along with the information needed to support that process to meet the business objective."
By moving the process and the relationship to the Internet, Dell did more with the information it already shared, like quality deviation -- the number of components rejected on assembly lines. "Dell and its suppliers could see problems in real time at the same time, as they were forming," Mr. Michlowitz said, "so we could decide how to act."
But Dell went further, shedding some information inhibitions. "We gave suppliers access to the link between our planning side -- here's what we think we'll need in terms of components -- and our execution side -- here's what we're really consuming -- so that they can shift inventory to the factories in need," Mr. Michlowitz said. "Now, we can see the train wrecks coming and work to prevent demand outpacing supply."
And since Dell ships its own computers directly to customers, suppliers who introduce new products can immediately see how they are performing and where. "Internet technology allows our entire supply chain to capitalize on our information," Mr. Michlowitz said. "We think that makes us more attractive to suppliers."
Dell, however, does retain some modesty. "We won't show suppliers their share of our business -- what percentage of our hard drives any one company provides, for example," Mr. Michlowitz said. "We don't want them to be able to leverage that. We do give them score cards indicating how they are doing against the best in their class, without naming names." Nor will Dell share cost data. Of course, Dell would derive more than voyeuristic pleasure from learning what percentage of a supplier's business it constitutes. Not all suppliers are willing to show or tell, however.
As for security, Dell puts its trust in nondisclosure agreements and its own high standards. "We constantly remind people here that supplier information is sacrosanct," Mr. Michlowitz said. "Sharing it inappropriately is a firable offense."
AT I.B.M., the historically tight security is tighter still for its Dell service account, and includes a jointly held database external to both companies' computer systems. After all, in PC production, the two companies are competitors. It took "executive involvement on both sides" to open communications, said Tom E. Conway, director for global services at I.B.M., who negotiated the agreement for the company.
Nowadays, it seems that I.B.M. Global Services and Dell are playing "getting to know you," sharing information weekly, sometimes daily, regarding service calls; the warehousing of Dell replacement parts; which parts are needed for a repair, as against the ones Dell supplies; and how I.B.M. performs in the field. "Obviously, we see performance data about their products," Mr. Conway said, noting the "contractual fire wall" -- with stiff financial penalties -- requiring that that information stays within Global Services.
The safeguards don't end there. Not only are Global Services and the PC division housed in two different cities (Atlanta and Raleigh, N.C., respectively), but there is also the so-called DMZ database that holds all transactions and information moving between the two companies. "Only 57 people in all of I.B.M. worldwide have the ability to see those data," Mr. Conway said. And those 57 people, he added, are restricted from switching to I.B.M.'s PC company for at least three years after they finish with Dell.
It was yet another way, he said, to change I.B.M.'s culture regarding Internet-interfirm cooperation and to ensure that both sides were comfortable exposing themselves.
"We long ago learned that the most effective way to work with others in a firm is to let down your guard and share knowledge," Mr. Tapscott said. "Now, we're learning that the same is true for working with other firms. Before, we needed to break down the silos within the firm. Now, we need to break down the silos that are the firm."

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
How Do You Invest in Online Health? Very, Very Carefully

BYLINE: By JONATHAN BURTON 

 BODY:
THEIR euphoria has waned, but some venture capitalists remain hopeful about e-health companies, which use the Internet to disrupt antiquated ways of doing business in the specialized and fragmented health care industry.
"There's a deep-seated inefficiency and disorganization in health care, and a deep-seated resistance to change," said Barbara Santry, a partner at Capstone Ventures, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif. "If you could make a difference, the prize is probably the biggest, because health care is the largest single industry in the U.S. economy." 
 Yet e-health's promise has its perils. Memories are still fresh of the high-concept consumer health Web sites that went public at valuations that burned white-hot, then crashed. "The e-health stocks were a Wall Street event, as opposed to a health care event," Ms. Santry said. "People like myself have become much more interested in the path to profitability."
Accordingly, many of the e-health companies that receive venture financing sell proprietary technology aimed at streamlining the health care infrastructure. High on the list are services that eliminate tedious manual labor and paperwork, thus reducing costs and bureaucracy. These intermediaries tend to pocket a regular fee for their work, which provides them with a relatively predictable stream of earnings.
"We're trying to look for these broad waves of innovation," said Eugene Hill, a general partner at another venture capital firm, Schroder Ventures Life Sciences in Boston. "If it's really valuable, somebody's willing to pay for it."
Health care investors also have a high degree of patience for deals to play out, especially compared with venture capitalists who back the momentum-driven information technology start-ups that have made headlines and overnight fortunes. "We don't think in terms of a good deal having to return $1 billion," said Barbara N. Lubash, a partner at Versant Ventures, a health care venture firm in Newport Beach, Calif. "We're trying to return 10 times our money on a success. The information technology V.C. might be thinking in terms of 100 times."
Indeed, the phenomenal returns from venture investments in technology and telecommunications over the last couple of years have dimmed the health care sector's status as a durable long-term holding.
The latest results of the quarterly PricewaterhouseCoopers Money Tree Survey of venture capital show that health care-related investments in the second quarter of 2000 represented just 2.3 percent of the $19.5 billion of total venture financing, the smallest share recorded for the sector since the firm began collecting health care data in the first quarter of 1997.
"It's a more complex environment," Ms. Lubash said about health care. "Incumbent companies have a great advantage compared to newcomers."
One of Versant Venture's main bets is eHealthContracts, a Hayward, Calif., enterprise that helps doctors, hospitals and insurers negotiate and manage their fee-based service contracts. "Health care is such a tight-margin business," said Helen Wilmot, the chief executive of eHealthContracts.
"You live and die by your contracts," she said.
One of the company's underlying strengths is its neutrality in dealing with providers (doctors and hospitals) and payers (insurers and employers), Ms. Wilmot said.
Mr. Hill of Schroder Ventures described health care infrastructure companies similarly, as "selling picks and shovels to the miners," a reference to the purveyors who were big winners during another gold rush 150 years ago in California. "We like those kinds of businesses," he said.
For example, Schroder has invested in Phase Forward, which uses the Web to automate complex clinical trials of both existing and new drugs and medical devices. "All the pharmaceutical company has to do is get on with the business of running the actual trial, while we do all of the back-office work," said Shiv Tasker, the chief executive of Phase Forward in Waltham, Mass. He said that his company can shave at least $50 million and as much as two years off a clinical trial timetable, which can often last seven to nine years, he said.
Venture capitalists are methodical about how they spend money, but health care investors are especially deliberate because blockbuster successes are rare. Before Capstone Ventures commits to a new health care product or service, Ms. Santry said, she and her partners want to understand a few crucial points, including: can the product be quickly and widely adopted? Are top managers and engineers capable of delivering what they promise? How much money will the company realistically require to succeed?
"The need for knowledge is on the high end," said Ms. Santry, who was once a nurse in the Navy. "It takes longer to know health care well because it is a fairly complex industry with a lot of government regulation."
AND as the health care sector has become less popular, raising money for ventures has become more difficult. Companies that require less capital are more attractive to investors than those with higher demands.
"Many venture capitalists have eliminated health care or moved away from it," Ms. Santry said. Such lack of interest, she noted, suggested that health care could be one of the better investments around. "Straw hats in the winter," Ms. Santry observed.
Either an off-season bargain, or not much covering from the cold.

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Dr. Spock Lives On in Books; Coming Soon, the Web Site

BYLINE: By DAN BREKKE; Dan Brekke is a former deputy editor of Wired magazine.

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif.

 BODY:
DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK'S most widely quoted advice is contained in the very first words of "The Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care," the 1946 volume that redefined child-rearing in America. "Trust yourself," he told parents. "You know more than you think you do."
Spock's famously gentle directives made him a global publishing phenomenon. By the time he died in 1998 at age 94, "Baby and Child Care" had sold more than 50 million copies. Among baby boomers, he was equally renowned as a principled political activist for his leadership in the movement to end the Vietnam War. 
 Now, though, the doctor's name has been turned into a brand and a Web site, DrSpock.com. And his teachings have been taken into a realm -- the online content business -- that is devoid of the nurturing, patience and good sense he counseled. Investors who a year ago were soothed by the prevailing dot-com wisdom -- "Trust us! There will be profits!" -- have recoiled from content-driven ventures.
If anything, the retreat from content has been more punishing for health-information Web sites, like DrKoop.com, WebMD.com and PlanetRx.com, than it has been for the sector as a whole.
"This is not a good time to be entering the media-driven content market, and in the health space, specifically," said Elizabeth Boehm, an analyst with the health care group of Forrester Research, the consulting company in Cambridge, Mass. "This is in part because of the attention that the flailing e-health sites have attracted, and in part because the ad model doesn't work."
One of the flailingest of them all is DrKoop.com, where wild overoptimism combined with poor management to tarnish a "brand name" founder. The company that originated the site, named for Dr. C. Everett Koop, the outspoken former United States surgeon general, raised $88.5 million in an initial public offering in June 1999. The cash was gone in less than a year.
The company's management made deals to spend nearly $150 million over three years to be a health-information provider to the Disney Company's Go.com and to America Online. In September 1999, an article in The New York Times raised questions about a potential conflict of interest when it disclosed that unknown to the site's users, the doctor received commissions on product sales there. Dr. Koop's contract has been changed to eliminate such commissions, the company said in the same article. Development of online personal medical records, an important adjunct to the company's content business plan, hit a dead end.
DrKoop.com's shares fell below $1. The company is now in the hands of venture capitalists, who have vowed to wring profits from the site.
"The industry is certainly a challenging one to make a business-model rationale for," said Claudine Singer, a research director and senior analyst at Jupiter Research, an Internet consulting company based in New York. Most consumer-focused health-information sites have depended on advertising revenue for a big slice of their income; Jupiter projects that advertising spending in the sector will total $700 million by 2004. "That's just not enough to stay the red ink," Ms. Singer said.
With the market's lack of confidence in content investments and with the demonstrated hazards of trying to turn a mix of health information and e-commerce into profits, why would anyone start a venture built on the wisdom of a deceased pediatrician? Especially when other sites -- BabyCenter.com, Parent Soup.com and Parenting.com (a site featuring material from Time Inc.'s group of magazines on child-rearing), to name a few -- have well-established claims in the infant/parent/advice/commerce territory.
The answer, found in the cramped upper floor of a dingy two-story cinder-brick-and-aluminum bank building in downtown Menlo Park, Calif., has two distinct segments. DrSpock .com embodies a business rationale based half on enduring faith that a "killer brand" will overcome all obstacles and half on enduring commitment on the part of Dr. Spock's widow, Mary Morgan, to see his work brought to new generations.
Ms. Morgan, a board member and the company's vice president for publishing, brings a nearly religious zeal to the job of making sure DrSpock.com stays true to the spirit of her late husband's work.
"I look at Ben's face, his picture, every morning, and I say, 'It's with great love and great respect that I honor your work,' " Ms. Morgan said.
She has rented an apartment a few blocks from the start-up's office so that she can work there every day. Ms. Morgan said that some of the problems on Dr. Koop's site were caused by the fact that day-to-day operations were handled by executives in Austin, Tex., while Dr. Koop lived in New Hampshire. "I come to this place at 6 o'clock in the morning, I open it up, and the people here see me here every single day," she said. "The reason I'm so avid about that is that I want to make sure Ben's spirit will be in this company."
DrSpock.com -- its motto is "Trust yourself" -- was founded late last year and soon found itself caught in the market downturn. The company obtained $2 million in seed capital, then investor money dried up.
The founding chief executive, who had talked about a company that would go public with a valuation in the billions, left. The staff -- a mix of seasoned pediatricians and longtime journalists -- worked for stock while new cash was sought. The site, originally scheduled to open last spring, took its first halting steps the last day of September with no advertising and no signed partnerships in place. And the enterprise is already contemplating a name change -- to the Doctor Spock Company, perhaps -- to free itself from the stigma of a dot-com identity.
Douglas Lee, 35, a former health-industry venture capitalist and father of an 18-month-old daughter, became DrSpock's chief executive in May. When discussing the company's foundation and future, Mr. Lee repeatedly mentions its brand name.
Dr. Spock's cultural renown "is a penny from heaven," Mr. Lee said, adding, "To have a leading brand be available and put a brand-new business strategy behind it without conflict is a once-in-a-lifetime thing."
The business plan -- "We've put a formal business strategy around Ben for the first time in history," Mr. Lee said -- anticipates a media company that will work online, and off, to create an omnipresent "parenting channel."
"We're going across media whether it's the Web, magazines, publishing, TV, radio, wireless," Mr. Lee said. "You're going to see Ben everywhere."
He said negotiations were under way with several media companies to develop Spock-related projects. "You will see a flurry of major, major strategic deals that are going to show facets, though not necessarily the scale, of our media strategy," he said. He declined to give names.
For now, the Web site features searchable content that includes "Baby and Child Care," product-safety news and community discussions on topics like toilet training.
In the near future, the site plans to offer writings from other pediatricians, like Dr. Robert Needlman, a former colleague of Spock and the company's vice president for behavior and general pediatrics. In addition, he is an associate professor of pediatrics at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland.
DrSpock.com will also add a commerce element that Mr. Lee said will parallel CNet's handling of product reviews and purchases. The company will offer an overview of products -- baby monitors and strollers, for instance. It will be left to those who participate in the site's community areas to comment on or recommend products, he said. The site will also provide shopping links to retailers, so that they can buy the merchandise they have read about.
Mr. Lee acknowledged the competition but maintained that there were crucial differences. And that last word, he said, will be the defining feature of Dr. Spock, the enterprise. "Ben's brand is the brand of experts," he said, explaining that both vintage Spock material and new pieces written by doctors will speak with a voice that is accessible to consumers and authoritative among pediatricians.
ALOOK at the competitive landscape, however, shows sites, like BabyCenter and ParentSoup, that prominently feature advice from pediatricians on a wide range of topics, and ages. BabyCenter, through its new ParentCenter channel, addresses topics from prenatal to age 8, and ParentSoup tracks child-rearing through the teens. Parenting.com -- the newly revamped child-rearing portal site for Time Inc.'s Parenting, Baby Talk, Healthy Pregnancy and Family Life print magazines -- has adopted a cross-media strategy with book offerings and three weekly 90-second TV spots distributed through CNN.
On another point, Mr. Lee said that DrSpock.com's relatively late start matters little. "The brand gives us time, which will give us a way to catch up," he said. "And the brand will put us ahead."
Pat as that game plan may sound, the company has found investors. In addition to $2 million from Broadview Capital early this year, DrSpock.com has received $10 million from Zesiger Capital Group, an institutional investment firm in New York. The money is part of a planned $15 million round that values DrSpock.com at $35 million. Mr. Lee said the cash should last the company through the third quarter of 2001; it intends to expand to 45 employees next year, from the current 18.
Ms. Singer of Jupiter Research said that despite "a primary forecast of gloom and doom" for health-information concerns in general, one can detect glimmers of hope for the company in its brand and in the nature of parenthood itself.
"Parenting is a chronic condition -- you're a parent forever," she observed. "To the degree that a company can serve up relevant tools that are useful to you over time, there is an opportunity for a relationship, even the possibility that people will pay for what you're offering."

LENGTH: 956 words

HEADLINE: Job Seekers Are Looking Out for No. 2

BYLINE: By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU 

 BODY:
The transfer to London from Montreal was Sophie Bouchard's for the asking. And Ms. Bouchard, 31, the top sales representative in Canada for TMP Worldwide Inc., an executive recruiter based in New York, wanted it badly.
But what about her husband? Stephane Licari, 29, had a promising sales career of his own at an Internet company. Was he supposed to just quit his job and start over in a foreign country? 
 When Ms. Bouchard told her boss about their situation, she set up an interview for him with TMP's head of European sales that same day. A job offer soon followed.
"I never thought they'd think about my husband," marveled Ms. Bouchard, who moved to London with her husband and two sons, aged 7 and 8, this month.
Employers are thinking about every angle they can these days to keep employees happy, creating incentives from flexible working hours to signing bonuses and even discount shopping programs.
And now the latest perk: finding jobs for their employees' significant others.
"I wanted to make sure we retained Sophie," said Katherine Corrado, her boss, a senior vice president of global sales and marketing at TMP. "Her husband was perfect for the job."
The trend is most pronounced at the hiring stage, when counteroffers from rivals abound. A decade ago, most employers would have done little more than send out the help wanted section from the local newspaper to an applicant's spouse, recruiting specialists say. But with some key executive positions taking months to fill, companies are adding new inducements to their mix of pay and perks.
And the more desperate they are to fill a position, the bigger the boost they are willing to give to the spouses' careers, said Thomas Bloch, the owner of Southern Research Services, a recruiting firm in Tampa, Fla. Mr. Bloch cites the example of one of his clients, a South Carolina company, which was so eager to hire an executive in Michigan as its director of benefits and compensation that it offered to spend thousands of dollars to relocate her husband's car-renovation business.
The wife ended up turning down the six-figure job largely because of her husband's reluctance to start over. But nobody can fault the company for not trying. "Companies are to some extent going to extremes," Mr. Bloch said.
According to the most recent study by the Employee Relocation Council in Washington, about half of employers surveyed in 1998 provided some sort of spouse/partner employment assistance and of those, 34 percent had formal programs in place to address the issue, up from 22 percent in 1990. The average cost of the assistance was $1,545, the study found, though some employers spent up to $20,000 for expenses like hiring head hunters.
And those figures do not count the hours clocked by employees at companies that are trying to lure new talent. Kelsey Berg, a recruiting strategist at Microsoft in Redmond, Wash., recalled doing research to see if the local school system had any openings that would appeal to a job candidate's wife. "I even pulled a favor with my sixth-grade daughter's teacher so she could talk to someone who worked in the Seattle school district," Mrs. Berg said.
The growth of the two-career family, and the increasing self-confidence of skilled workers in the current hot economy, are driving the trend. "People don't operate today out of fear and trepidation," said Mordean Taylor-Archer, an associate provost at Kansas State University in Manhattan, Kan., who deals with career issues. "They are more willing and open to talk about their needs -- their spouse, their kids."
And their standard of living. The economy may be hot, but the dark side is a low savings rate and high levels of personal debt. Many families cannot afford even a temporary dip in their income. "People can't survive long these days without the second income," said Patrick Lennahan, director of the career center at Roger Williams University in Bristol, R.I.
Some companies are even plunging in with tips for spouses without being asked. Michael Honig, who moved to Seattle from Denver to start a job as a training specialist for Microsoft this month, said he thought the company was paying lip service to career of his wife, Emily, when it asked for her resume in his final job interviews.
But Mrs. Honig, who worked in human resources for a Denver company, is being considered for two jobs at Microsoft and for an opening at another Seattle company, thanks to Microsoft's help, he said.
While such employment assistance is becoming more prevalent, recruiting experts say, many companies are reluctant to talk about the practice, fearful of setting a precedent they will be unable to live up to for every new hire.
In September, the University of Alabama in Birmingham started the Spouse/Partner Relocation Network, a consortium of local employers that helps match job openings at member organizations with the spouses of new university hires.
"It's a lot better than just looking at the Monster.com listings," said Connie McLernon, an administrative assistant for a Montgomery design firm, who is getting career help from the university's network. Her husband, Dennis, accepted a job as an acting instructor at the University of Alabama in August but he has been commuting from Montgomery until the couple sells their home and she finds a job.
Whether a company has a formal policy or not, Damian Birkel, executive director and founder of the Professionals in Transition Support Group in Winston-Salem, N.C., suggested job seekers take the initiative and ask about partner help. But, he advised, wait until a potential employer is close to making a job offer.
In any case, he added, "You're not going to get it if you don't ask."

Chart: "Your Mate's Fate"
How to bring your spouse into the picture:
 
Wait until a job offer seems imminent to ask about career help for your spouse.
 
Get details about the company's formal policies. Does it hire spouses? Will it pay for a recruiting firm?
 
If no policies exist, request a job-search allowance for resume mailings and other expenses.
 
Get names of spouses who have benefitted from career assistance and ask about their experiences.
 
Get everything in writing.
 
(Source: Professionals in Transition Support Group)

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK;
The Furtive 3 P.M. Phone Ritual

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. E-mail: Belkin@nytimes.com

 BODY:
IT three o'clock this afternoon, give or take an hour, countless employees will pick up the telephone and make a most unbusinesslike call. If their employers were to listen in (which, as we all know, they can do, but that's a subject for another column) they would hear some variation of the following: "Did you do your homework?" "Are you sure you locked the door?" "Don't talk back to the baby sitter." "Don't let anyone in, and don't answer the phone."
With all the talk in the workplace lately about the needs of parents, it is striking how much of that talk is about the needs of new parents rather than those whose children are in school. Corporate America is justly proud of its maternity-leave policies and its child care centers. But, as my grandmother used to say "little kids, little problems; big kids, big problems," and less attention is being paid to those of us who are paying less attention once school lets out. 
 "Nearly all the progress has been around infancy and preschool, as if children have no problems once they start kindergarten," said Carol Maxym, a psychotherapist and author of "Teens in Turmoil" (Viking Penguin, 2000). The mother of one of her patients, she said, "won't make an appointment after 2 because she might not know where her daughter might be." Another told me she would sneak out of the office for an hour every afternoon to pick up her teenage son so she could be certain he would make it home from school.
The 3 o'clock phone call has its roots in the 19th century, back when most families lived on farms. There were crops to be tended during the summer, so schools necessarily closed for three months. There were chores to be done before dark, which is why schools let out in the middle of the afternoon.
"Our society is still living on a schedule that made sense then but makes no sense now," said Dr. Jody Heymann, director of policy for the Harvard University Center for Society. She is the author of "The Widening Gap: Why American Working Families Are in Jeopardy and What Can Be Done About It" (Basic Books, 2000).
"Our children, for the most part, don't live on farms anymore, and their parents aren't back on the farm waiting for them to come home," she said. "Still, we're stuck with a situation where school days are two-thirds shorter than workdays and the school year has 30 percent fewer days than the school year."
The result of this temporal gap are children like 9-year-old Josh Ray, who is profiled by Laura Sessions Stepp in "Our Last Best Shot" (Riverhead Books, 2000), her book about the rocky terrain of adolescence. Josh's mother, Gail, works in the loan department of a bank in Ulysses, Kan., and his father at a meat-packing plant. The local middle school doesn't offer any after-school activities, and because this family actually does live on a (nonworking) farm, there are few other children close enough to visit. After a bad experience with an inept baby sitter, Josh and his 8-year-old brother began to stay home alone in the afternoons, and their mother checked in by phone as often as she could.
"I spent a lot of time thinking about all the trouble they could get into when I wasn't there," Mrs. Ray told me. Those visions turned all too real one afternoon when the boys played with matches and accidentally set fire to a couch. After that, the calls came more often, and she found it even harder to concentrate on making bank loans.
As Dr. Heymann points out, as stressful and unsatisfying as the 3 o'clock call might be, workers like Mrs. Ray are lucky that they are able to call at all. "Sitting in your white-collar cubicle, listening to parents calling home, you forget that for many workers, that call is not an option," she said. "They have no access to a telephone, or they're not allowed to leave the factory floor."
The solution, she believes, lies not with the telephone, but with the clock and the calendar. "We need a longer school day and a longer school year," she said. "It's that simple."
Other countries, she points out, have done this "and their economies certainly haven't collapsed." American children go to school 180 days, while those in the Netherlands and Luxembourg have a 220-day school year, with Germany close behind at 213. If school textbooks and equipment were 100 years out of date, she said, parents would protest. So why do they accept a school schedule that is a century behind the times?

LENGTH: 831 words

HEADLINE: Ford Shows Off Devices for Improved Safety and Mileage

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 24

 BODY:
Seeking to restore its reputation for safety and respond to high gasoline prices, the Ford Motor Company announced today a half-dozen high-technology approaches to improving traffic safety and gas mileage.
Among the devices demonstrated at a news conference were tiny cameras that will send images from all around a vehicle to the dashboard as well as bumper-mounted air bags for the protection of pedestrians. Ford also showed off a six-speed automatic transmission and computer-controlled engine cylinders that are designed to help the company meet its pledge, made last July, to improve the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent by 2005. 
 Ford executives and engineers refused to say when the safety gear would go into mass production, a common tactic among automakers for competitive reasons, and acknowledged that some of the equipment could be 5 or 10 years away. All the engine and transmission changes are scheduled for introduction by 2005, however.
General Motors and other automakers are racing to develop similar safety and fuel-efficiency technologies, although Ford went further in disclosing the progress it had made. Priya Prasad, Ford's top safety engineer, said he began working on today's announcement half a year ago -- long before Firestone announced on Aug. 9 the recall of 6.5 million tires mounted mainly on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles and blamed for more than 100 deaths. The tire problems nonetheless came up repeatedly during the news conference, particularly because many of the technologies previewed today were aimed at addressing problems created by the growing number of sport utilities on the roads.
None of the technologies are designed to prevent tire failures or reduce the odds that a sport utility would roll over if the tires fail, the combination of events that has led to most of the deaths linked to Firestone tires. Ford said in August that it would begin offering optional, computer-controlled stability systems on all its sport utilities, and it said last January that it would start equipping sport utilities with ceiling-mounted air bags to reduce the odds that occupants would be thrown through side windows during rollovers.
Helen Petrauskas, the company's vice president for safety and environmental technologies, said today that Ford, like other automakers, was also working on technology to monitor tire pressure or temperature continuously. Firestone has said that its tires failed partly because of underinflation, which can cause tires to overheat and come apart.
Some of the safety technology may raise privacy issues. G.M. has been criticized for installing "black boxes" as standard equipment in some luxury cars for the last two years to record the details of crashes.
Ford demonstrated today a camera that takes a picture of the interior of a vehicle's passenger compartment every 15 seconds. When a crash occurs, the vehicle transmits to an emergency dispatch center the last photo taken before the crash plus a photo taken after the crash. Receiving both photos allows dispatchers to assess whether any occupants have been ejected from the vehicle and whether the occupants were wearing their seat belts before impact -- two considerations in deciding whether to send one or more ambulances to the site of the crash, said Srini Sundarajan, Ford's supervisor of safety research and development.
Ford also showed cameras the size of a pencil eraser that can be mounted around a vehicle so as to provide drivers with views in all directions, including forward-facing cameras on the side mirrors to help drivers see around trucks ahead. Engineers showed that the forward-facing cameras would even allow motorists in a Lincoln Navigator sport utility to look around a Ford Excursion, which is so big that if it was a fraction of an inch wider, it would have to carry special running lights on the sides like those of freight trucks.
Rear-facing cameras will include zoom lenses that will allow motorists to observe people and objects behind them in great detail.
Only police vehicles will be manufactured with the ability to record images from the any of the exterior-view cameras, but other customers may choose to buy off the shelf and install their own recording ability on their vehicles, said Gary Strumolo, a Ford engineer who helped develop the system.
Kary Moss, the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Michigan, said she was troubled by some of these features, particularly the zoom lenses. "It certainly has Big Brother overtones," she said.
Sara Tatchio, a Ford spokeswoman, said the system that takes pictures of a vehicle's interior, for transmission to rescue dispatchers, would be optional. As for the use of cameras on a vehicle's exterior, she said that was no different from mirrors, while adding that she was not aware of any discussion within the company on whether zoom lenses raised particular privacy concerns.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Fuzzier and Fuzzier

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Did you know that if Al Gore is elected president, and his economic plan is put into effect, 2.3 million Americans will die next year?
Supercilious Washington insiders may try to confuse you by pointing out that even if Mr. Gore isn't elected, 2.3 million Americans will die -- that next year's mortality rate has nothing to do with who wins the election. But you can deal with that by chanting "No fuzzy math!" until the election is over. 
 No, George W. Bush hasn't blamed Mr. Gore for American mortality. But he's done something comparable. Mr. Gore has been pointing out, correctly, that Mr. Bush has promised $1 trillion in Social Security taxes to two different groups of people -- telling young workers that he will allow them to invest the money in personal accounts, while assuring older workers that it will be available to pay for their retirement. So Mr. Bush has responded by charging that Mr. Gore's Social Security plan will add no less than $40 trillion to the national debt.
That seems like an awfully big number. It turns out to be an estimate of the total value of payments from the general government budget to Social Security, including interest, that will take place over the next 50 years. And I could bore you by explaining why that number is meaningless.
The really amazing thing, however, is that the number has nothing to do with Mr. Gore. It's true that Social Security will need transfers from general revenue if Mr. Gore's plan is put into effect. But it will need just as much money if Mr. Gore's plan isn't put into effect. The only way to reduce the required aid would be to reduce the benefits promised to retirees.
Meanwhile, Mr. Bush has said nothing about reducing benefits. So his plan for Social Security would cost just as much as his opponent's -- or rather considerably more, because to honor those contradictory promises he has to find another pot of money somewhere.
Maybe blaming Mr. Gore for future mortality wouldn't have worked; but Mr. Bush's advisers seem to think that blaming him for the entire future liabilities of the Social Security system will, or at least can serve temporarily to confuse voters who might otherwise have started to think too clearly about the subject. Only two weeks to go until the election, and we can clean up the mess later, right?
But what a mess it's going to be. Those Social Security payments aren't the only sums being promised to two different groups of people.
Mr. Bush's plans -- and, to a lesser extent, Mr. Gore's plans -- are based on projections that assume there will be no increase in federal discretionary spending over the next 10 years. But over the last few months, while you weren't looking, Congress went on a bipartisan spending spree -- with a cost estimated by both Democratic and Republican analysts at more than $800 billion over the next decade.
How will the next president deal with this bad news? Mr. Gore has a bit of slack in his budget, and has proclaimed that protecting the surplus is his highest priority; maybe he would decide to jettison his unloved and unlovely targeted tax cuts. But Mr. Bush's budget even now adds up thanks only to creative accounting, and he has made it clear that he cannot conceive of anything that would make him renege on his tax-cutting promises. (Did someone say "Read my lips"?)
The odds, then, are that soon -- perhaps as soon as next year -- those projections of future budget surpluses will have been revised dramatically downward, and longer-term projections will show deficits as far as the statistical eye can see. This will pose real economic risks; it will also be a severe blow to our self-confidence. We will shake our heads at our earlier optimism and wonder what we were thinking.
But the answer, of course, is that we weren't thinking, and in general disapproved of those who did. However the election turns out, the reaction to the debates made it clear that voters have a visceral dislike for candidates who seem intellectual, let alone try to make the electorate do arithmetic.
Indeed, the motto for this election year -- and the epitaph for the soon-to-be-departed budget surplus -- should be: Real men don't think. Unfortunately, what you refuse to think about can still hurt you.

HEADLINE: Con Ed's Plan To Buy Utility Looks Shakier

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Casting further doubt on its proposed $3.8 billion acquisition of Northeast Utilities, Consolidated Edison said today that it would ask Connecticut's utilities regulatory agency to reconsider its decision last week to impose dozens of conditions that company officials said could kill the deal.
Investors sent Northeast Utilities' stock price plunging $2.25 today to close at $19.13, 10.5 percent below Monday's closing price. 
 Earlier this month, Con Ed's chairman, Eugene R. McGrath, criticized the state's Department of Public Utility Control for issuing a draft approval document containing conditions that he said did not benefit company shareholders.
On Thursday, after the agency announced its final approval of the deal, Con Ed responded with less-than-enthusiastic silence. Finally, on Monday, the company issued a statement after the markets closed saying that the conditions were "substantially different from anything that we had any reason to expect."
"Unless the order is substantially modified," the statement said, "it so significantly changes the economic effects and risks of the merger that it calls into serious question whether the transaction will be completed."
Today, a Con Ed spokesman, Joseph P. Petta, said the company would not discuss specific conditions it objected to. But among the likely sticking points are those that would cost the merged company, to be called New Consolidated Edison, millions of dollars over several years.
To prevent the company from using labor cuts to recover a mandated cut in residential gas and electricity rates, the state agency demanded that the company impose a two-year freeze on layoffs. The agency would also prevent the company from recovering a $1.5 billion "acquisition premium" from consumers by forcing two Northeast Utilities subsidiaries to split any profits above 11 percent with consumers.
It would also force Con Ed to accept a $60 million loss in costs created by the deregulation process.
Con Ed has 11 days to send the agency a formal request to reconsider its conditions, an agency spokeswoman said. The agency would then have 25 days to respond.
The proposed merger would place 6.5 million gas and electricity customers in eight states under the aegis of what would be the largest utility company in the Northeast.
Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's attorney general, has urged the state to reject Con Ed, saying the deal would hurt the state's consumers, environment and economy.

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Leader Admits the Serbs' Role in Fomenting War

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Yugoslavia's new president publicly acknowledged today for the first time that Yugoslav forces committed widespread killings in Kosovo last year. Although falling short of an apology, the statements by the president, Vojislav Kostunica, marked the first time any Yugoslav leader had expressed regret for the conflicts in the Balkans.
In an interview to be broadcast by CBS News tonight on "60 Minutes II," Mr. Kostunica spoke about Belgrade's role in starting -- and losing -- four Balkan wars in the past decade. 
 So far he has refused to extradite anyone, including the man he replaced as president, Slobodan Milosevic, for trial on war crimes charges before a United Nations tribunal in The Hague. But he raised the possibility of trying suspects in Yugoslavia.
"I am ready to accept the guilt for all those people who have been killed," he said. "For what Milosevic had done, and as a Serb, I will take responsibility for many of these, these crimes."
Yugoslav state television broadcast the interview today with a voice-over in Serbian.
President Kostunica also strengthened his grip on power today by winning important concessions from the Serbian parliament, which approved a transition government to administer the republic until new elections on Dec. 23. Serbia is the dominant of the two republics remaining in the Yugoslav federation; the other is Montenegro.
Mr. Milosevic's party agreed to share power with reformist forces in the transition government -- a major concession because the current administration could have served until regular elections in the fall of 2001. Mr. Kostunica's supporters held only three seats in the 250-member legislature.
Establishment of new administrations at both the federal and republic levels are preconditions for receiving millions of dollars in emergency aid from the West to rebuild Yugoslavia's shattered economy.
Mr. Milosevic's Socialists, who hold 110 of the 250 seats in the republic's parliament, agreed to the transition government plan on Oct. 16 but parliamentary approval was delayed because of differences with Mr. Kostunica's Democratic Opposition of Serbia on individual appointments.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Official to Meet Kostunica
 (By The New York Times), PRISTINA, Kosovo, Oct. 24 -- Richard C. Holbrooke, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said today that he would meet President Kostunica on Wednesday in Macedonia.
Mr. Holbrooke arrived in Kosovo today to show his support for Kosovo's first post-war elections, scheduled for Saturday, and to allay ethnic Albanians' concerns over the political changes in Serbia, of which it is technically still a province.
At a news conference here, he said Mr. Kostunica had suggested that they meet during a gathering of regional leaders in Skopje, Macedonia's capital.
"I want to hear what he will say," Mr. Holbrooke said. "He is the first democratically elected leader of Yugoslavia ever."
The meeting will be a continuation of talks held in Belgrade by James O'Brien, special adviser to President Clinton on the Balkans, and will range over all the issues that loom over peace in the Balkans, including implementation of the 1995 Dayton peace accords in Bosnia, the prosecution of war crimes and Yugoslavia's re-entry into the United Nations, Mr. Holbrooke said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Redeveloping Space to Keep Manufacturing Jobs

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
When the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center opened in 1994, supporters of manufacturing in New York City cheered: what had once been a decrepit rope factory on the Brooklyn waterfront had been turned into a low-cost home for light manufacturing companies and artisans.
When the center opened, the nonprofit development organization behind the project, the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center Development Corporation, said it was looking at other old industrial sites to renovate in an effort to stem the migration of manufacturing jobs from the city. Now the organization, which typically redevelops properties that private developers might find unprofitable, is starting to translate those intentions into reality. Last month, it opened a second manufacturing center in Brooklyn and announced plans to develop seven more projects in the next three years. 
 According to J. David Sweeny, the corporation's chief executive, the new centers will give the city up to 1.5 million square feet of new manufacturing space, enough to help create 2,500 to 3,500 manufacturing jobs.
The group's newest manufacturing center is in an 80,000-square-foot building at 810 Humboldt Street in Greenpoint. The two-story building, which was built in 1961, had been used as a warehouse and bowling alley but was largely unused for the last three years.
Last May, Mr. Sweeny's group bought the building for $4.3 million from the Commodore Manufacturing Corporation, a Brooklyn-based distributor of Christmas ornaments. Then his group began a $2 million renovation to prepare it for tenants by mid-August.
The building had a lot going for it, said Curtis Cravens, the director of development and government relations at the Mr. Sweeny's organization. It was in sound structural shape, and it is close to a number of important transportation points, like the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, as well as to two subway stations, Nassau Avenue and Greenpoint Avenue, both seven blocks away.
The inside of the building, however, was another story. According to Mr. Sweeny, it was essentially open space that needed to be subdivided into 12 smaller spaces. But the interior also needed new electrical wiring, heating, ventilation and windows, as well as new interior doors and walls.
All 12 of the building's spaces, ranging from 4,000 to 20,000 square feet, have been leased, to 10 woodworking concerns and one garment company that makes quilts and curtains. There will also be space, Mr. Cravens said, for a services shop where tenants will be able to use equipment like spray painting booths.
One of the tenants on Humboldt Street is a woodworking business owned by Weber Roberts and Brooks Crane, a husband-and-wife team that makes custom cabinetry and furniture. Mr. Roberts said they are paying an annual rent of $9 a square foot for 4,350 square feet.
Mr. Roberts and Ms. Crane used to lease space for their business at 60 Broadway Street in Williamsburg. But they lost their space on Sept. 4. Their former landlord, Mr. Roberts said, "was trying to get high-tech companies into the building at $30 a square foot; we were paying $6 a square foot."
Mr. Sweeny said his organization decided to gear the Humboldt street building to woodworkers after receiving numerous phone calls from local artisans -- mostly in Manhattan and Brooklyn -- who were either losing their work spaces or who could not find new space.
"The screams came the loudest and with the most frequency from the woodworkers, so we decided to solve their problems first," he said. He added that rents at the property were in the $6-to-$9 range, which is 30 percent to 50 percent less than similar space in Manhattan and 10 percent less than the market rate in Brooklyn.
Woodworking concerns and artisans also account for the tenants at the first manufacturing center that Mr. Sweeny's organization opened in Brooklyn, in 1994. That building, at 1155 Manhattan Avenue, is being converted into a co-op for its 72 tenants, who together employ 500 people.
Eventually, Mr. Sweeny's organization hopes to help other types of manufacturers at the centers that it is still developing.
The group is in negotiations on two of the properties. One of them is a four-story, 115,000-square-foot building at 37-24 24th Street in Long Island City. According to Mr. Sweeny, it would provide ideal space for garment manufacturers. The second property is a 65,000-square-foot building at 191 Harrison Avenue in Williamsburg that the organization hopes to renovate for Arlington Press, a local company that makes pharmaceutical insert labels.
The Greenpoint nonprofit group has acquired, or is in contract on, five other properties, Mr. Sweeny said.
While he could not disclose details on one of them, because of a confidentiality agreement, he said that the four other properties were a vacant 65,000-square-foot former candy factory at 132 Harrison Place in East Williamsburg, scheduled to be ready for occupancy by small food manufacturers by the end of the year; an 80,000-square-foot, mill-style building at 37 Greenpoint Avenue whose tenant base has not yet been determined; a 24,000-square-foot vacant loft building at 7 St. Nicholas Avenue in East Williamsburg that will probably be used for industrial tenants; and a 70,000-square-foot industrial building at 130 North Fourth Street in the Williamsburg area that will be marketed to upscale food producers and distributors who are looking for adjacent retail space.
Kathryn Wylde, the president of the New York City Investment Fund, founded by Henry R. Kravis, the financier, to invest in projects to promote the city's economy, said that last month her fund gave Mr. Sweeny's group a $1 million loan.
"We're generally not a real estate investor, but we see our investment in them as having a real multiplier effect," she said. "They are going to create the infrastructure that is going create hundreds of businesses, which, in turn, are going to employ thousands of people."

HEADLINE: In the Land of Kim Jong Il

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to North Korea this week illustrated the opportunities and risks of defrosting relations with the world's last Stalinist state. Dr. Albright was given a gracious reception and spent six hours in constructive talks with Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader. But she and the reporters accompanying her saw a highly regimented society organized around a slavish personality cult even as it struggles with severe shortages of food, electricity and most of the basic conveniences of modern life.
Coaxing North Korea out of its long international isolation and limiting its development of advanced weapons are important American goals. The Clinton administration has handled North Korea well, but diplomacy has now reached a critical stage as President Clinton weighs whether to visit Pyongyang in the waning days of his presidency. 
 Dr. Albright reports "important progress" toward agreement on restraining the North's development, testing and export of longer-range missiles. Firm agreements on these and other subjects, like a North Korean commitment to distance itself from international terrorism and return abducted Japanese nationals, could justify a Clinton trip. But Mr. Clinton should go only if concrete results are assured in advance.
North Korea has good reasons for cultivating improved relations with Washington. If Pyongyang wins removal from America's list of countries supporting terrorism, it will become eligible for badly needed loans from the World Bank and other international institutions. North Korea also wants the prestige of establishing formal diplomatic ties with the United States.
For the past six years North Korea has frozen its nuclear weapons development program in exchange for American and international help in constructing two civilian power reactors. For more than a year the North has abided by an agreement to suspend long-range missile testing. More recently it offered to abandon its missile development effort in exchange for foreign help in launching space satellites. Specialists from both countries will soon meet to discuss specific steps North Korea can take to limit its missile program.
The North also enhanced its credibility when Kim Jong Il met with South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, in June, although it has lagged in following up with further gestures of reconciliation. Dealing with North Korea remains full of uncertainties, as Dr. Albright discovered when Kim Jong Il brought her to an elaborate tribute to the achievements and military strength of North Korean Communism. That is not the kind of spectacle Mr. Clinton should attend if he travels to Pyongyang.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE BATTLEGROUNDS;
Florida Interstate's Heavy Campaign Traffic

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 24

 BODY:
The parties and the presidential candidates are concentrating their campaigns in Florida in these last, tense days before the election on the cities and towns along Interstate 4.
The nearly three million voters who live more or less along the maddeningly overcrowded, 100-mile-long highway that bisects the state from Daytona Beach on the Atlantic Coast to the Tampa Bay on the Gulf of Mexico are the swing voters in this, the largest of the swing states. 
 They may be getting more attention these days than any other voters in the country as the candidates compete for Florida's 25 electoral votes. Hardly a day goes by when one of the presidential or vice-presidential candidates, or a family member, or a prominent supporter from outside the state is not campaigning somewhere along this narrow corridor.
"This state is the key to this election," Vice President Al Gore declared at a rally in Orlando earlier this month, "and Central Florida is the key to this state."
On Wednesday morning, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, and Senator John McCain of Arizona are to attend a rally in Daytona Beach, then board a bus to campaign the length of the I-4 corridor, stopping at midday near Orlando to appear on television there, and finishing up with an evening appearance at the state fairgrounds outside Tampa.
"This is the critical area for Republicans in any statewide election," said Representative Charles T. Canady, a Republican from Lakeland, a town along the Interstate about halfway between Orlando and Tampa.
Much of Florida is already locked up by one party or the other. The Gold Coast, from Miami to Palm Beach, is solidly Democratic. The dominant voters moved down from the Northeast, especially from New York and New Jersey. Many are Jewish, and the politics are decidedly liberal.
The Cuban vote in South Florida, which is overwhelmingly Republican, and the black vote, largely Democratic, tend to offset each other.
North Florida, from Jacksonville across the Panhandle to Pensacola, is almost indistinguishable in its politics from Alabama and South Georgia. A recent Democratic poll showed Mr. Bush winning the region by better than 2 to 1, according to Buddy Dyer, Democratic leader of the Florida Senate.
Southwest Florida, with a large number of affluent retirees from the Middle West, is also strongly Republican.
In fact, Susan MacManus, a political scientist at the University of South Florida in Tampa, has calculated that in all but 8 of the 67 counties in Florida, one party or the other has an advantage in voter registration of more than 3 percentage points. Of those eight most closely divided counties, she found, five are in the I-4 corridor.
In 1992, Ross Perot won more than 25 percent of the vote for president in some counties in the area. No one has tabulated who won along the corridor in the last two presidential elections, because there is no consensus on exactly which communities to count and which to exclude. But the best guess, the authorities say, is that President George Bush probably won a narrow plurality in 1992 and that Bill Clinton may have won a majority in 1996.
Few other places in the country have changed more than this area. A generation ago, the Tampa area was beginning to grow. Daytona Beach was already famous for spring-break frolicking and stock-car races. Slightly south of Daytona, the economic boom and population growth stimulated by the space program at Cape Canaveral had begun.
But between the coasts, I-4 was a sparsely traveled highway through mile after mile of orange groves, small lakes, pine woods and prairie.
Then, on Oct. 1, 1971, Disney World opened, and Central Florida was changed forever. The groves became theme parks and hotels. The pine trees with their gray Spanish moss were thinned to accommodate golf courses. The flat prairie land was turned into one subdivision after another.
And in the last decade, high-technology businesses have sprouted throughout the region, bringing high-paying jobs and conspicuous affluence. The unemployment rate along the corridor is almost nil.
For the politics of the state, this has meant a great deal of uncertainty. The people who have moved to Central Florida are not primarily retirees, like those in, say, St. Petersburg or Naples, but young families with children. And they mainly brought with them the suburban values of northern sprawl, not the values of the big cities in the East or the small towns of the Middle West.
The prevailing view among politicians is that these voters, much more than others in Florida, cast votes based on their pocketbooks, not their ideology, and are more concerned about education than Medicare.
So politicians cannot rely on one-note speeches and advertisements the way they can take stands on Social Security in retirement communities or against gun laws in the Panhandle. They have to articulate their entire range of positions if they expect to appeal to a substantial number of voters along the I-4 corridor.
"They don't adhere to party labels," Bob Poe, the state Democratic chairman, said of residents along the corridor. "Their vote is completely up for grabs."
Al Cardenas, the state Republican Party chairman, agreed with that assessment and said that was the reason the Bush campaign was placing so much emphasis here.
"In any election in Florida," he said, "if you know who wins the I-4 corridor, you can pretty much predict what the outcome of the election will be."

HEADLINE: Bush's Better Inclination

BYLINE: By Richard Lowry and Ramesh Ponnuru; Richard Lowry is editor and Ramesh Ponnuru is a senior editor of National Review.

 BODY:
For George W. Bush, compassionate conservatism has been a fair-weather campaign theme. When he was dominating the Republican field in 1999, or maintaining a sizable lead over Al Gore most of this summer, Mr. Bush could afford to spend all his time talking about his innovative programs for the poor and what they said about his heart.
But Mr. Bush has twice jettisoned compassionate conservatism when sharply challenged. After John McCain defeated him in New Hampshire, he came back as an unmodified conservative, suspicious of federal campaign-finance regulations, disdainful of Washington and eager to cut taxes. He has fought Mr. Gore similarly, running as a reformist outsider against a big-government Democrat. 
 There's a reason that when the going gets tough, compassion goes. It has proved to be a limp and expendable campaign theme, especially for a conservative Republican.
The danger of a candidate's describing himself as compassionate is that it enables his opponents to portray him as self-involved, morally vain and softheaded. Senator McCain attracted many voters because he appeared to be a tough, plainspoken leader. And Mr. Bush, as long as he was promising to be a uniter, not a divider, and to touch every willing heart, didn't have that appearance. Nor could he refute Mr. Gore's contention that he was running on a warm and fuzzy personality rather than on ideas that would benefit the public.
Of course Mr. Bush all along presented his political philosophy, and not just himself, as compassionate. But that didn't work, either. Conservatism practically begins with the fear that the attempt to express compassion through the state is likely to backfire. It insists instead on the importance of judgment in moral matters and self-reliance in economic ones. Both virtues are in tension with compassion, and even more with the sentimentality that often mistakes itself for compassion. People sense all this instinctively, and recent surveys show that the public considers Mr. Bush no more compassionate than any other Republican and thinks he "cares" less about people than Mr. Gore does.
Compassionate conservatism fails, finally, as a political strategy. It might have worked if the public were so eager to leave the Clinton years behind that it would vote for any reasonably competent Republican who showed that he didn't have fangs. There was no shortage of would-be strategists who believed that the weariness with President Clinton did go that far. But especially after Mr. Gore established himself as his own man at the Democratic Convention, it became necessary for Mr. Bush to advance a more compelling argument.
Since Labor Day, he has been doing that. He has not stopped claiming that as president he would govern with the interests of all Americans, including minorities and the poor, in mind; nor should he. But he has also made the argument, much more clearly than in the past, that he would serve the values and interests of the middle class better than Mr. Gore would. And those values and interests point toward a smaller federal government.
So do those of the successful Americans Mr. Gore denigrates as the wealthy. In the national elections in 1998, Republicans lost crucial ground among people in households making more than $75,000 a year -- a quarter of the electorate that year. Now, according to at least one poll, Mr. Bush is winning their votes by 23 points.
If Mr. Bush is elected, it will not be primarily because of his personality, compassionate or otherwise. It will be because America remains, in crucial respects, a conservative country that wants energetic conservative leaders. Mr. Bush would be wise to remember that, should he move to the White House. After a tumultuous year, he surely appreciates a bedrock truth of conservatism: It's not always fair weather.

HEADLINE: Europe's Aid Plan for Colombia Falls Short of Drug War's Goals

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Signaling reservations about Colombia's deep reliance on American military support, the European Union announced a package of nonmilitary aid today that fell short of expectations. The decision could undercut Colombia's $7.5 billion program to curtail coca production and curb the influence of leftist guerrillas.
As envisioned by President Andres Pastrana, the program -- known as Plan Colombia -- would require $3.5 billion in international aid to go along with the $4 billion that Colombia had vowed to contribute. 
 But European diplomats, meeting with officials here at the Foreign Ministry, said the European Community's contribution would now total about $321 million in nonmilitary aid. That appears to leave Colombia short of the total. The United States has earmarked $1.1 billion in mostly military aid. International lending institutions and Japan are providing $1.3 billion in loans, but the Colombians had hoped for much more in donations.
"We don't know if they are disappointed," a European diplomat said of Colombian leaders. "But we can't be dreamers."
Colombia tried to put a positive spin on the European commitment, with Colombian officials saying that, with the loans and donations, about $3 billion of the $3.5 billion expected from the international community would now be available.
"This is a demonstration of the solidarity for Colombia," said Colombia's Foreign Minister Guillermo Fernandez de Soto. "We feel very positive that this plan has support."
But in Washington, a senior congressional staff member said that more international money for social programs and development was needed to balance out what the United States was spending.
"Everyone was looking for the rest of the world, particularly the Europeans, to do the soft side," said the official, referring to nonmilitary aid. "We have done the military side. You can't do one without the other."
A high-ranking Colombian official, citing American reports that Europe is consuming 30 percent of the coca that Colombia produces, said Europe should do more. "If they don't do it, we'll never resolve this problem," the official said.
Some people doubt that the Pastrana government can allocate as much as it has said it would contribute. Colombia, for decades a bastion of economic stability, is now in the midst of a debilitating recession.

HEADLINE: Anti-U.S. Fury in Jordan's Streets Overshadows a Trade Pact

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 24

 BODY:
On the day that Bill Clinton held a White House ceremony with Jordan's king to sign a trade pact, Muhammad Nubeni and his friends paraded through the streets here today denouncing the American president.
Tens of thousands of Jordanians -- most of Palestinian origin, like Mr. Nubeni -- marched toward the border with Israel, demanding an end to Jordan's diplomatic and economic relations with Israel and condemning American support for Israel. 
 "To hell with Clinton! To hell with Barak!" they chanted as they filed out of town, furious at the televised scenes they had watched Monday night of Israeli tanks in Jerusalem shelling nearby Palestinian villages.
The marchers converged with protesters from other Jordanian cities at a point a few miles from the West Bank, and then skirmishes with the Jordanian police quickly became open battles and enveloped the crowd in billows of tear gas. Police helicopters hovered overhead and youths pelted riot squads with stones, in scenes that marchers and other witnesses said mirrored the daily clashes on the western side of the Jordan River.
Scores were injured, though few seriously, said march organizers, who criticized "the exaggerated response of the security forces."
Such a display of turmoil and anger would have been unusual in Jordan before the past month's battles between Israelis and Palestinians set off raucous demonstrations here. And by the end of the day, the protests had completely overshadowed the trade pact.
The government had hoped the deal would present Jordan and its economy in an attractive light abroad, while convincing critics at home that the country was getting tangible rewards for its support of American mediation in the region.
"The timing is a bit awkward," said Rami Khoury, a Jordanian political commentator, "because the U.S. is now seen here to be the bad guy." What's at issue, he said, is the "overpowering importance of the Palestinian issue here."
The events in Washington and on the streets of Jordan underscored the competing pressures on the Amman government as it tries to maintain ties with Israel and the West while paying allegiance to Arab nationalism and the Palestinian cause.
The government recently challenged the United Nations sanctions against Iraq and played host to the Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi. Both steps scored points with critics of Jordan's ties to Israel. Still, outrage at the deaths of more than a hundred Palestinians in the recent conflict in Israel and the Palestinian lands intensified public sentiment against Israel and the United States.
Business leaders and diplomats praise the trade accord as a personal triumph for King Abdullah, who has ruled now for 20 months, capping an ambitious economic liberalization program that he hopes will attract investors and jobs to his country, which has few natural resources.
Jordan is just the fourth country to sign a free-trade agreement with the United States, and the first Arab nation to get barrier-free access to the American market.
The agreement, which is subject to Congressional approval, would put Jordan on an equal footing with Israel and with the Palestinian Authority, which enjoys duty-free access to the American market under the umbrella of the Israeli agreement.
Though trade between Jordan and the United States barely exceeds $300 million a year, the potential of such a big market has great appeal to investors. Such investors are the key to providing good jobs to the young, underemployed and largely Palestinian work force.
But the market potential does not overcome fears of upheaval.
"Everything falls down like a house of cards when there is political instability," said Omar Salah. Three months ago, based largely on the pending trade accord, Mr. Salah's company was asked to start a $100 million venture with Vishay Intertechnology, an electronics manufacturer based in Pennsylvania.
Last week, after watching televised scenes of demonstrations here and hearing warnings from the State Department about travel to Jordan, Vishay executives told Mr. Salah they were pulling out.
"With everything that is going on, we decided to put it on hold," Felix Zandman, Vishay's chief executive, said in a telephone interview. "Most of Jordan's population is Palestinian, and we weren't sure that our people would be safe there."
For the thousands of Jordanians who marched towards Israel's border today, a trade pact is at best a distant abstraction, and at worst an unwelcome symbol of Jordanian dependence on the United States.
Today's march was organized by professional groups -- including the lawyers' and doctors' associations -- that have campaigned against the peace treaty with Israel that Jordan signed six years ago. They have also fiercely opposed any normalization of economic and cultural relations with a country they see as an enemy.
Opponents of normalization have been gaining momentum for several years, propelled by widespread disappointment that the peace treaty failed to deliver much in economic benefits. But the government was able to portray the opposition as a movement on the wrong side of history. Not only Jordan and Egypt, but Morocco and Tunisia and Qatar and Oman were also quietly establishing trade links with Israel. So was Indonesia, the largest Muslim nation.
But with the violence of the past month and the Arab League's call over the weekend for a freeze in relations with Israel, all Islamic countries except Egypt and Jordan, the two with peace agreements, have severed their tentative ties.
"The most disturbing thing that has happened is that any regional cooperation or integration has practically ended," said Taher Masri, a former prime minister of Jordan. "The Arab League summit effectively ended any hope of integration. And now Barak, for his own political reasons, is also shutting the door."
Jordan is also pulling back, refusing to dispatch its newly appointed ambassador to Israel and asking state employees to donate a day's salary to support the Palestinians.
