HEADLINE: Lazio Criticizes President on Cancer Bill

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 24

 BODY:
President Clinton is missing an opportunity to promote breast and cervical cancer awareness, Representative Rick A. Lazio said today, by deciding to privately sign a bill that Mr. Lazio had backed.
Speaking to reporters here before touring a breast cancer screening center at a hospital, Mr. Lazio said he believed politics might have influenced the White House's decision not to hold a public bill-signing ceremony. 
 "I think it's a missed opportunity for the president," Mr. Lazio said, standing before a poster promoting breast cancer awareness month. "I don't have to be there at the bill signing if he feels it's not a politically wise thing for him to do. But it is an opportunity for us to promote breast cancer awareness and cervical cancer awareness."
Mr. Lazio, however, said he believed the priority should be for the president to sign the bill, the Breast and Cervical Cancer Treatment Act, into law. The president did sign the bill sometime today, doing so without ceremony or even a simple announcement by the White House.
The congressman was a leading advocate for the bill as chief sponsor of the original legislation and manager of the debate in the House that led to its approval in May, although Democrats complained that he had lost interest until he surfaced as a Senate candidate that month. Mrs. Clinton, the president said, was also a major advocate for the bill, which authorizes states to provide Medicaid coverage to low-income women whose breast and cervical cancer is diagnosed in free screenings set up under a 1990 law.
Mrs. Clinton, after speaking on the upstate economy in Syracuse, said today that she was not aware of a decision by the White House to forgo a public ceremony.
"I didn't know about the decision until I read about it," Mrs. Clinton told reporters. "The president signs hundreds of bills and they make those decisions. I was also actively involved on behalf of that legislation."
Mr. Lazio has championed his role in the legislation as he seeks to court women.
Mr. Lazio started the day with a "Women for Lazio" event at a convention hall in Syracuse that drew 1,300 women, who paid $20 each to dine on quiche and listen to Mr. Lazio deliver his stump speech for about 45 minutes. In the works for about three weeks, the event produced one of the largest turnouts at any of his campaign events, and Mr. Lazio and his advisers said the size of the audience was a sign of momentum.
"For me, this is a great kickoff for the last two weeks of the campaign," Mr. Lazio told the audience members, who among the usual bumper stickers and fliers also received nail files with Mr. Lazio's campaign logo on them. "To all the people who talk about a gender gap," he added to laughs and applause, "I wish you would please tell your male friends to make sure they're supporting me, would you?"
Mr. Lazio then flew to Buffalo for a campaign stop similar to one Monday in which he deplored Mrs. Clinton's 1993-94 attempt to remake the health care system.
Mr. Lazio does not have a health care plan of his own but favors passing legislation that would provide tax credits to help people pay for their own insurance. Mrs. Clinton released new radio ads in upstate markets to counter ads Mr. Lazio is running there criticizing her health care proposal.
After his event here, he met his obligations as a Mets fan and attended the third game of the World Series at Shea Stadium. Even this was a campaign event; he rode the No. 7 subway to the game with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki -- in the front car with the Mets logo painted on the front. At the game, his campaign aides handed out masks made from a blown-up picture of Mrs. Clinton wearing a Yankee cap as a way to mock her claim to be a Yankee fan.
Traveling in Syracuse and Rochester today, Mrs. Clinton kept a focus on the upstate economy, criticizing Mr. Lazio for what she has said has been his insensitivity to economic troubles upstate. She said her plan for the region would provide lower utility costs, tax incentives and business partnerships with the state and federal government to create jobs.
Mrs. Clinton, speaking to about 75 people at a community college in Syracuse about an hour after Mr. Lazio left, stood before a large poster that highlighted population losses upstate.
"We've lost all this population in the last 10 years," Mrs. Clinton said. "We've kind of gotten ourselves into a bind because, among the people who have left, are young people who are seeking their fortunes elsewhere. We don't have the work force with the skills we need to attract, in a critical mass, some of the new economy, information technology jobs that I think upstate is natural for."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
A New Lure for Loyal Shoppers: Buy a Little, Save a Little

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
FELICIA GRIFFIN intends to hoard a little holiday cheer for herself this year when she buys gifts. Her strategy is to shop with a select group of online merchants -- those who share a percentage of the purchase price in a rebate that will be invested in a choice of mutual funds.
"This way I can be a consumer and reward myself," said Ms. Griffin, a 34-year-old business-conference planner from Dallas. Since last spring, she has been accumulating shares in a growth mutual fund offered through SaveDaily.com of Irvine, Calif. 
 SaveDaily is among a handful of start-up financial-service companies that are using the Internet to convert shopping loyalty programs into something more substantial than frequent-flier credits. They may also be a tool to draw lower-income households online and into the financial mainstream.
"Isn't it about time, if we're the locomotive of the global economy, that we get something back?" asked Eric A. Solis, the chairman and chief executive of SaveDaily. "If we can get back just 4 percent on our planned consumption, we can double the savings rate."
The notion of using everyday shopping for online microinvesting, of pennies or dollars, is surfacing at a time when politicians and public-policy experts are pushing to provide lower-income and low-saving customers access to financial tools.
"One of the things that stops banks from developing products for this market is because the costs are too high relative to the balances," said Michael A. Stegman, the author of "Saving for the Poor: Hidden Benefits of Electronic Banking."
Whether the account is for check writing, stock trading or mutual funds, the rule of thumb in the financial services industry is that it costs as much to service a $100,000 account as a $1 million account. A result is financial products geared mainly for higher-income people.
"Our competitive advantage is being built from Day 1 to be a very low-cost provider" to small savers, said Mr. Solis, a former financial adviser in Indian Wells, Calif., who grew frustrated at having to turn away advice-seeking friends because they lacked what are considered adequate resources.
By comparison, little is required of SaveDaily's microinvestors, other than a checking account and a credit card.
SaveDaily's site offers its 6,000 clients two ways to invest with its mutual fund partners. Clients can make direct deposits of any amount from their checking accounts by electronic transfer. Or clients can earn retail credits of 1 percent to 10 percent at SaveDaily's 80 retail partners, like J. C. Penney, Barnes & Noble and the Sharper Image. In the last year, SaveDaily clients cumulatively invested about $2 million in funds managed by the Pacific Investment Management Company, or Pimco; Berger Funds; and ING Group. Investors never see a paper statement or a transaction charge, though they are charged an annual fee of 1 percent of assets, comparable to the fees banks charge their best customers.
"It's virtually no cost to us," said Greg A. Bishop, a vice president for Pimco in Newport Beach, Calif., explaining that SaveDaily customers are pooled into a single account. "It's another distribution opportunity," he said. Pimco funds are generally marketed through financial planners and broker-dealers, who charge a fee or a commission, unlike SaveDaily. "If we do our job and deliver good financial results, potentially there's an opportunity for brand building" with SaveDaily customers, he said.
For people who realize they are under-saving, these loyalty rebate programs appear to be a way to start a nest egg without changing one's buying habits. A Citicorp survey showed that 80 percent of the population is interested in saving for either college or for retirement.
Mary L. Bennett, a self-employed recruiter in Redondo Beach, Calif., has retirement accounts elsewhere, but uses SaveDaily as a place to save for quarterly estimated tax payments and a house-buying kitty. "Since it's so easy to put it in and out, that's how I feel it's best utilized," she said.
Yet, with such tiny investments, "a lot of people are going to get discouraged because they won't see very much growth," said Shaw Lively, a financial services analyst for International Data Corporation in Boston. But with a long investment horizon, even a 3 percent rebate off a $100 weekly shopping tab compounded at 8 percent over 15 years amounts to about $8,000. "Providers must put as much or more effort into nurturing a customer as they put into acquiring one," he said.
The challenge, Mr. Lively said, will be to keep customers investing, to have a stable of national merchants in which people will shop and not suffer a nose dive in the stock market. "I think they're well aware a downturn is a risk to their business model," Mr. Lively said, although none of the companies he has looked at have yet to focus on a plan for investor hand-holding and education.
Another risk would come from a competitor who already has high name recognition in either Internet commerce or finance, which could quickly dominate the nascent industry. "If AOL or Fidelity decides to do it, they're dead," Mr. Lively said, referring to SaveDaily. (Fidelity says it wouldn't consider such a rebate plan, but it is making one of its funds available to clients of UPromise.com, a competitor of SaveDaily based in Boston.)
UPromise has a slightly different microinvesting strategy: to help families save for college by accumulating retail rebates online and off-line in a tax-deferred fund. The brainchild of a marketing entrepreneur, Michael Bronner, the site is to be activated in November and expects to be available nationally in the first quarter of 2001. It will adapt the idea of pooling frequent-flier spending credits offered by participating merchants.
Once enrolled, UPromise users can direct their purchase credits from a wide variety of merchants, even grocers and gas stations, into mutual funds managed by Fidelity; Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney; TIAA-Cref, a teachers' pension fund; and Merrill Lynch. Among merchants UPromise has signed up are a computermaker, telephone company and major credit card merchant. Besides getting a rebate from UPromise retailers, customers using the credit card, whose identity UPromise has not disclosed, will get a second rebate from the card company. Customers will also be able to invest cash directly in mutual funds offered through UPromise.
ALTHOUGH college-savings plans, also known as 529 plans, came into law in 1996, they are still little known because of inadequate marketing by the 41 states that offer them, said Liz Carpenter, a UPromise spokeswoman. Yet in a May survey underwritten by UPromise, only 29 percent of parents said they felt prepared to cover the cost of sending their children to college. On average, to send two children to college costs $87,000 for a public college and $189,000 to a private campus, according to the College Board.
"It seems like a good marketing device for their partners, and a nice benefit for consumers who get the rebate tacked onto their college savings account," said Joseph Hurley, a Pittsford, N.Y., accountant who established a Web site, savingforcollege .com, which focuses on 529 plans.
Another wrinkle comes from Customerowner.com and Stockback.com, both sites still under development, which plan to offer e-commerce patrons rebates that are actual shares of a merchant or in a mutual fund.
State Street Global Advisors will manage the proposed fund for patrons of Customerowner.com, which is currently in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to a report by Mr. Lively, the analyst. About 35 retailers, including CVS Pharmacy, Lands' End, Office Max and Sony are offering rebates to Customerowner.com's customers.
Stockback and Customerowner will be attractive to customers with strong retail loyalties, but a drawback is that customers end up with little diversification in their portfolios.
"It's innovative, but is it sustainable?" asked Matt Carrick, a financial services analyst for Gomez Advisors, an Internet research company in Lincoln, Mass. "I'm not sure it can take off without a lot of marketing money," he said.

HEADLINE: MARKETING;
Austin's 'Dellionaires' Aren't Ready for the Ranch Just Yet

BYLINE: By COURTNEY BARRY; Courtney Barry writes about technology and business in Austin, Tex.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
EVERY wheel has a hub. In Seattle, Microsoft laid the groundwork for the broader software scene that has grown up there, luring talented young people to the Northwest, then turning them into millionaires able to comfortably jump ship and start their own companies.
Silicon Valley's more varied endeavors reflected the influence of alumni of Hewlett-Packard, Fairchild Semiconductor, the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center and Stanford University. 
 Then there are the former employees of Dell Computer, the leading direct seller of personal computers, who became millionaires through stock ownership or options and are driving the growing and increasingly varied e-commerce boom here. By some counts, there are thousands of these former Dell employees.
Just what do these rich young retirees from a hardware company bring to a scene that is increasingly dominated by software and commerce?
Cash, for one thing.
"There are a lot of Dellionaires that have to place their money somewhere," said Andrew Harris, a former president of Dell International, who runs a start-up company, HandTech.com, which sells computer products and offers personalized technical support.
For another, they have too much energy to relax and enjoy "life on the ranch," as Mr. Harris described his time between Dell and HandTech.
Bruce A. Ezell, another Dellionaire, said, "There was a saying that working at Dell was like jumping out of an airplane with your hair on fire -- there was an extreme sense of urgency to the corporate culture."
Mr. Ezell, who helped coordinate Dell's move into software and peripherals, is trying to match money from former Dell workers with start-up companies, as the head of a venture capital firm, Techxas Ventures.
Finally, there was the perception at Dell that a hardware business was more than just a hardware business.
Mr. Ezell and Mr. Harris both said that Dell had more influence as a fast marketer of good computers than as a technology laboratory. The company is known for "its ability to package technology into a solution," Mr. Ezell said.
This emphasis trained Dell employees and managers to look beyond the manufacturing of computers and see how technology fit into the new economy. When workers left, they took that knowledge with them and spun permutations that have made Austin a center of e-commerce.
But it is not just Dell. Austin has companies like the Trilogy Development Group, which provides software to automate sales and other business operations, and Tivoli Systems Inc., which develops software to manage computer systems. Both companies have spawned technology start-ups. Tivoli is now a division of I.B.M.
Dell's influence, however, may have the greatest reach.
At HandTech.com, which Mr. Harris founded with Martin Slagter, the former president of Dell Europe, the focus is on the "need-help majority," providing Web systems for computer resellers. That contrasts with the "don't-need-help minority" that Mr. Harris said Dell was concentrating on; that is, "the tech heads, which developed into the business model for the Fortune 500 companies."
At Techxas Ventures, Mr. Ezell compared his strategy for capitalizing on technology growth with the early days of the gold rush.
"Before the railroads were built, you could get gold out of the mine, but you couldn't easily get it to market," he said. "Railroads ultimately led to faster transportation, which led to technology improvement in ways to mine and bring more gold out.
"The same holds true with the Internet," he said. "We're not investing in the information companies" or gold miners. "We're investing in the infrastructure, the guys that sell the pickaxes and lifting equipment."
FOR Mr. Ezell, who left Dell in 1998, the company also underscored the importance of corporate frugality, emphasized by its founder and chairman, Michael Dell.
"We sat in a management meeting at Dell," Mr. Ezell said. "There were probably about 100 managers, so we all fit into one room. Michael was talking about how we have to continue to lower our costs. And he said: 'Just this morning I was sitting in my office and there was a credenza there, and I said: 'Why do I need this credenza? It's full of all this stuff I don't need. Why are we spending money on credenzas?'
"There was a pause," Mr. Ezell continued, "and then Joel Kocher, the president of Dell USA at the time, stood up, and said, 'Michael, you can have my credenza today.'
"The rest of us -- sitting in the audience as managers -- are saying, 'Well, what are we supposed to do?' So all of a sudden another hand went up, and someone said, 'You can have mine,' and then another hand went up, and before Michael knew it we sent around a pad of paper and everybody who had a credenza signed the list and said, 'Come take my credenza.'
"And for a three-month time period," Mr. Ezell said, "the Dell factory outlet in Austin was the only place in the country where you could get a smoking-hot deal on a wooden Kimball credenza bundled with a used laser printer for $300."
Mr. Ezell said the emphasis on keeping costs low has led to a strategy in which an e-business does not build a warehouse to hold inventory, but sends the order to a wholesale distributor. He estimated that more than 50 percent of dot-coms use the method pioneered partly by Dell.
It is a method that Mr. Harris has taken to HandTech.
"At Dell, you learned that 'inventory is anathema,' " Mr. Harris said in his office, where he oversees 110 employees on Austin's Loop 360, which, like Sand Hill Road in Silicon Valley, is becoming a corridor for technology developers and venture capitalists.
Steering clear of inventory is important in the technology reseller industry for the company that is trying to develop a viable business, Mr. Harris added.
"In the 1980's this was an eye-opening concept" he said. "And at Dell there was an emphasis on 'thinking outside the box.' The company wouldn't be hampered by what the history tells you is right or wrong."
Mr. Ezell, Mr. Harris and others say that Austin's new economy continues to be shaped by Dell's influence. Mr. Ezell says that Austin is now seen as a technology mecca for venture capitalists. There are a lot of future Dellionaires waiting in the wings, he said. "We say they're 'vesting in peace,' " he added, laughing.
Hans Severiens, an investment banker turned venture capitalist who manages Band of Angels Fund, a group of 150 high-technology investors in Silicon Valley, said: "People always ask me about other parts of the country, and I say, 'Well, you've got to have a certain infrastructure to make these things work; you've got to have money, an intellectual center, like a good university, a decent climate and the stimulation of other companies.' And I generally come up with two or three places. Austin is one of them."
But money, courtesy of Dell, may still be the biggest factor in Austin.
"It's just easier for young businesses to get cash in Austin, and that's definitely had an impact," Mr. Harris said. "An idea is not much good without money."

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- MINI-MALLS;
Replacing Shoppers With Students

BYLINE: By Frances Anderton 

 BODY:

Mini-malls are in vast supply in Los Angeles, and there is a shortage of schools. Philip Lance, an Episcopal priest and director of Pueblo Nuevo Development, a community redevelopment organization, had a creative solution: turning a mall into a school. He enlisted a nonprofit school developer, EXED, as well as Paul Cummins, an expert in founding new schools, and hired the architects Daly Genik to create the newly opened Camino Nuevo Charter Academy, above. The architects transformed an 11,000-square-foot mini-mall, which had never opened, into a vibrant school building in the Rampart district with classrooms for 250 children, from kindergarten to fifth grade. They added new windows and doors and gave the building a bright splash of paint. An existing external balcony and stairs were transformed into a striking structure made of steel and a beige synthetic "lumber" made of recycled plastic and paper pulp. An entrance to underground parking was relocated, making way for more classrooms and a play area, and giving teachers their own parking area under the school, an important security issue in this low-income area. 
 The $1.1 million Camino Nuevo represents a bright light for the community. "There's always a chance to rethink the city fabric, and having an opportunity to turn it into a school was a special one," said Kevin Daly, whose firm is better known for spare, modern residences. Camino Nuevo Academy is at 697 South Burlington, at Seventh Street.

HEADLINE: Born in Iran, Trained in France, Sought in America

BYLINE: By MALLERY LANE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WHAT magic ingredients turn a designer like India Mahdavi into a success in three years' time? The answer is talent, certainly, but also luck and an eclectic background that marks her work as exotic, global and sophisticated.
Her influences range from classical to cutting-edge: from the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris, where she received an architecture degree, to Cooper Union in New York, with its reliance on the craft of building and exploration of materials. 
 Note that she is also in a field where successful men strikingly outnumber successful women. Since taking on her first client in 1997, India Mahdavi, 37, has opened a Paris design studio, IMH Interiors; succeeded Philippe Starck in designing the next hotel for Ian Schrager, the Empire, opposite Lincoln Center; fashioned a breezy hotel in Miami and a private nightclub in New York; and come up with a new concept for Givenchy stores worldwide -- the first will open in Paris next spring.
So what is her style? "You can't pin it down to a specific influence or reference," said Yann Le Coadic, a freelance interior designer in Paris, who says the French call the look faux coordonne -- meaning something appears to have been conceived of as a single thing but "on close inspection is composed of elements coming from different sources." He added, "Every detail of a space India designs is thought out to the millimeter, and yet the overall impression is very uncontrived. India focuses on how a space will be lived and not what visual impression it will make."
Ms. Mahdavi began working for Christian Liaigre in 1990, when he had just redesigned the interiors of the Montalembert Hotel in Paris, the project that put him on the map. Mr. Liaigre's studio had a staff of only four, and "I was able to do a little of everything," Ms. Mahdavi said. The studio later tripled in size, and she become the art director.
In 1994, Ms. Mahdavi met Derek Hudson, a photojournalist, when he walked into Mr. Liaigre's shop. Two years later, she gave birth to their son, Miles.
"Having a baby changes your perspective," she said. And after working with Mr. Liaigre on the tailored Mercer Hotel in New York, she began a solo career working from home. "I didn't have a clue how things were going to work out," she said.
Only a few weeks later, she got her first big commission: two shops, a line of furniture and the office headquarters for the fashion retailer Joseph in London. Joseph Ettedgui, who runs Joseph, hired her on instinct, convinced she could be a lead designer.
Why? "Her attitude," he said. "It was a pleasure working with her, which is not always the case with gifted people."
Ms. Mahdavi designed eight pieces of furniture for his men's store on Sloane Avenue. They included typical bachelor items: a daybed, mirror and free-standing suit racks with masculine, graphic lines in sycamore and wenge wood. She used clothing fabric like navy pinstripe for upholstery. British critics gave rave reviews.
A few private residences in London followed, and then America came calling. Jonathan Morr, a New York restaurateur who owns Bond Street and Republic, asked her to create an "undesigned" hotel in Miami, called Townhouse. Because there was no way to build a swimming pool, she created a roof terrace. Guests can sunbathe on queen-size water beds or wade in a fountain that she put inside an old water tower, adding tiled walls and benches. Throughout, Ms. Mahdavi used colors inspired by sand and sky and created multifunctional furniture suitable for gathering, dozing or having a room service meal. Benches offer a selection of daily newspapers, and there's an exercise bike at the end of each corridor facing a window.
"Miami is basically a beach place," Ms. Mahdavi said. "Why try to do some chic European thing when all you really want in Miami is to get a little suntan, sit on a terrace with a drink, go out at night, feel at home?"
Mr. Morr encountered the same practical attitude when he asked her to design an invitation-only New York hangout, tentatively called the Apartment. (He will give its location only as 13th Street, in the meatpacking district.) "When I asked India if she'd design a nightclub for me, she said she never goes out to bars and clubs so she wouldn't know what to do," he said. "Then she suggested the idea of entertaining in an apartment, because that is what she does when she sees friends."
Ms. Mahdavi said the space, which occupies 2,500 square feet on two floors of a seven-story building, has the scale of a real apartment. "You even have to ring the bell," she said. "There is an open kitchen, dining table, sofa area, even a bed. It's meant to feel like an open house with friends coming and going." Invited friends, that is.
Mr. Schrager saw her work on the Miami hotel and heard about her from Mr. Ettedgui. "India is a great stylist in the genre of Andree Putman," he said, referring to the Parisian interior designer who was his collaborator (along with Steve Rubell) at Morgans hotel in the 80's. "She has a tremendous amount of strength and she's inventive and original. That's a potent combination." The Empire hotel, which he sees as "the next generation of Morgans" -- with vibrant colors instead of black, white and grays -- is expected to open in 2001.
Ms. Mahdavi was born in Tehran of an Iranian father and a half-Egyptian, half-Scottish mother. The family moved to Cambridge, Mass., when Ms. Mahdavi was an infant and her father, an economist, entered the M.B.A. program at Harvard University. The family then moved to Germany and ultimately to the south of France. Ms. Mahdavi was raised with four siblings in a home where French and English were spoken.
At age 7, she began attending the progressive Ecole Freinet, near Nice, where students defined their own studies and activities and pottery was seen as equal to math.
"It was up to each student to take initiative to choose what they wanted to do, carry it out and present it," Ms. Mahdavi said. "The Ecole Freinet had a big impact on me. It is where I learned to have confidence in my choices."
Though she wanted to study filmmaking, "there were no accessible film schools in Paris at that time," she said, "so I thought I'd do like Fritz Lang and study architecture first." She completed the seven-year program at the Ecole des Beaux Arts, but her first job persuaded her to try another profession. "I never liked the ambience of architects' offices," she said. "They give me the blues."
Finding interior design more lively, she headed to New York City, where she spent a year studying graphics at Parsons, furniture at Cooper Union and industrial design at the School of Visual Arts.
Her style is rooted in a modern elegance that marries the contemporary with the tried and true. One of her best-selling designs, a floor tray nearly six feet long called Celibataire, is meant to sit under stacks of books and magazines or under pictures leaning against a wall.
"I like the idea of an accessory that becomes a piece of furniture," she said. (The tray can be ordered from IMH Interiors at 3, rue Las Cases, 75007 Paris, 011-331-45.51.63.89, for about $400, plus shipping.)
Her home, in the Left Bank neighborhood of St.-Germain-des-Pres, is a reflection of her ever-evolving ideas. An L-shaped, high-backed corner bench that Ms. Mahdavi designed sits in the dining area next to a table she inherited from her grandmother and a 1950's swivel chair she bought in Miami. In the living area an orange velvet love seat and matching screen, which she also designed, mix with pieces that influence and inspire her: a three-legged Adnet metal stool upholstered in leather, a 40's plexiglass chair coupled with a Pierre Paulin desk from the 60's, a Royere side table, a bronze cylindrical stool by the contemporary French designer Eric Schmidtt.
"I like mixing things," she said. "My apartment doesn't have to be all about me and what I do."
It seems her only fear is becoming successful too quickly. "One should always be able to make mistakes, because that is how you learn," she said. "But it is hard when everyone is looking at you. It's not that I don't trust my talent, but I am so much at the beginning of what I could do."

HEADLINE: Bottoms Up, the Murphy's Back

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY STEVENS 

 BODY:
IVY FAHRER recently built a seven-bedroom Gothic-style home with her husband in Harrison, N.Y. A wing of their house includes a large suite for her sister, who visits occasionally from Texas. What's unusual about the suite is where sister will slumber: A Murphy bed, king-size and custom-designed, complete with a pillow-top mattress. "Only the best for the princess and the pea," Ms. Fahrer, the president of Cebon Cosmetics, said, laughing. "My sister is very particular about where she sleeps."
The brushed-aluminum concoction, which incorporates shelves, closets and a nifty retractable desk, cost $15,000 -- the price of several conventional beds. But they wouldn't have folded up out of sight. "The novelty is wonderful," Ms. Fahrer said, "and when she's not around, my husband and I have an artists' retreat where we can paint and sculpt." 
 The century-old Murphy bed is experiencing a renaissance, and not just among the space-starved. No longer the wacky clunker that tormented Abbott and Costello, the Murphy bed (now a generic term for the presto-chango bed patented by William L. Murphy in 1908) has gone millennial, springing from brushed-steel cabinetry, cherrywood armoires, maple bookcases. It's upwardly mobile, as well, with a clientele that ranges from Ashton Hawkins, the executive vice president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to Jimmy Smits, the former "NYPD Blue" heartthrob, to Ralph Acampora, the Wall Street forecaster.
A remote-control Murphy was a big draw in a 525-square-foot beach home on the market for $3.95 million in Del Mar, Calif. "The Murphy bed has become cool again," said Tom Pearson, the property's broker. "All these young Internet moguls, with their surfboards in one hand and their computers in the other, get a real kick out of the bed." That's if they even know it is a bed.
With his Murphy bed's cherrywood and steel cabinetry, "friends think it's a really mod entertainment center," said Joe Hill, 35, a hair stylist, who recently moved into a converted 18th-century schoolhouse in Tarrytown, N.Y., with his partner. When the bed's not in use, the two use the room to work out, do business or entertain.
Gene Kolakowski, the vice president of the Murphy Bed Company International in Farmingdale, N.Y., whose doors opened at the turn of the century, contends it is a trend that simply follows a lifestyle. "Multifunction is the key," he said. "People are savvy about the use of space these days. They want a room where they can sleep, work, play and entertain. And they don't care how much it costs."
Jessica Goldbogen, the managing editor of InFurniture magazine, which covers trends in the industry, says designers are testing the perimeters of a bed and its function. "It's a hot concept," she said by phone from High Point, N.C., where designers and manufacturers have been experimenting with Murphy bed design. Some beds turned into tables; other beds tried a different turnaround: they opened from both sides.
Born to be comic props, the original beds of cast iron were bolted into the floor, with coiled box springs that leapt from the wall -- bonking Charlie Chaplin in the head, trapping the Muppets and offering Vinnie Barbarino (John Travolta) a bachelor lair.
In 1989, after a challenge to its patent, the founding family lost its exclusive right to use the name Murphy bed, and ever since, competing manufacturers have vied for consumer attention. Most of the systems have been simplified and streamlined; with the help of air pistons, beds now glide from cabinetry instead of whomping down with a comic twang.
Perhaps that is why Mr. Kolakowski's sales have doubled over a decade. Robert Meyers, the owner of the Murphy Bed Center, with two showrooms in Manhattan and another soon to open in Staten Island, says his sales are up 40 percent in just the last year.
"People are finally really taking the bed seriously," he said excitedly as he paced around his West 23rd Street showroom last week. The company installs from two to five beds a day.
The sales boom goes against the trend in the Murphy bed business. "Murphy beds have always done well when the economy is flat," Mr. Kolakowski said. "And this is the first time that it has done well in a strong economy. I think a lot of empty nesters are purchasing the beds so they can make their kids' rooms into offices, dens, sewing rooms -- you name it."
The bed's image still needs some improvement, though. Recently, the definition of a Murphy bed stumped a contestant on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire."
Henry Smith Miller, an architect, considers himself a pioneer of sorts in the comeback of the Murphy bed. In 1989, he designed a model apartment in the Police Building, at 100 Centre Street, furnished entirely with mobile furniture, including a Murphy bed.
"We call it cross-programming," he said. "We realized people want to be given the ultimate choice in shaping their environment, and the Murphy bed fits perfectly into this concept." Mr. Miller used Murphy beds last year, when he designed a loft space for Arnold Lehman, the director of the Brooklyn Museum.
"For some reason, the Murphy bed always gets lumped together with a pull-out sofa bed," said Marjorie Noto, the president of American Linguists, Interpreters and Translators Inc. and proud owner of four Murphy beds. "It's a travesty. My husband, Stan, and I wouldn't lie down on a sleep sofa if you paid us."
They have two Murphy beds in their Manhattan apartment and two in a condominium they recently purchased at Brown's Hotel in the Catskills. During the condo renovation, Ms. Noto had two Murphy beds with old mechanisms ripped out and replaced with up-to-date versions. "The beds went, bolts, springs and all, as well as a dancing platform and a disco ball," she said gleefully.
Accurately speaking, the Murphy bed has not so much returned as evolved. What was once considered an economical sleeping solution has in many cases become a luxurious and pricey alternative. The Murphy bed mechanism alone costs around $500, and custom cabinetry, mirrors and special mattresses make the price soar.
Recently, Mr. Meyers of the Murphy Bed Center built a $30,000 traditional white lacquer unit complete with molding in a three bedroom Fifth Avenue apartment for a young couple who needed extra space for visiting in-laws. "Clearly, for this couple money was no object," he said. "They just wanted to make better use of the space."
But potential renters weighing the difference between a one-bedroom for $1,800 a month and a two-bedroom for $2,400 -- $600 a month -- might find that it doesn't take that long to amortize a Murphy bed, even one that costs $6,000. For Lisa Valentino, 30, a lawyer who lives in a 600-square-foot apartment in Battery Park City, the bed has made it possible to have a life.
"I always had visions of getting stuck in the bed," she said. "But I got over it. It's really cool, and I'm actually adding shelves to the basic unit I got. It has given me the space to really live."

HEADLINE: Not Just a Roof, but Roots for a Season

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

DATELINE: ORRTANNA, Pa.

 BODY:
DOMINGO RODRIGUEZ, in after-shower boxers and a T-shirt, appeared fresh even after nine hours of apple picking. While a stereo played Spanish music, the lacy window curtains fluttered and the bistec sizzled under the broiler, Mr. Rodriguez, a migrant worker, gave a tour of the modest 810-square-foot house he shares with Alain Leon Burgos. He reveled in its comforts as if it were a fine hotel. Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Burgos are part of a six-man crew that came up from Puerto Rico in June to help harvest 400 acres of apples and 200 acres of peaches at Bream Orchards, in the fruit-picking heartland of Pennsylvania near Gettysburg.
The house is a prefabricated metal shed with aspirations: a pitched roof, a columned porch and an overstuffed Victorian armchair angled to catch the last warm rays of October sunlight. It is the work of Bryan Bell, the founder of Design Corps, a nonprofit operation dedicated to bringing design intelligence to bear on the enduring problem of substandard housing for migrant workers, "among the poorest and worst-housed groups in the United States," according to a report released last week by the Housing Assistance Council, an advocacy group in Washington. 
 The house where Mr. Rodriguez, 54, lives for five months each year is one of four identical buildings in a neighborly row in an apple orchard. Vincent Scully, the architectural historian, has called them "small temples for migrant workers." Mr. Rodriguez, pausing to show off a washing machine tucked neatly in a closet off a sunny hallway that leads to two bedrooms, called it a "dream house," one step toward the suburban ranch pinups he had torn from magazines to decorate the walls. It was a world away from the chicken coop crudely adapted to human use that Mr. Rodriguez used to occupy. And it is nothing like the dilapidated mobile homes, concrete-slab dormitories with outhouses or decades-old one-room bullpens, where male workers sleep on cots crammed side by side. Such substandard housing is still visible along the county roads of rural America. Every picking season, local newspapers chronicle even worse conditions throughout the country: migrants sleeping in tents, caves, cars or under bridges.
Moises Loza, the executive director of the Housing Assistance Council, which issued the report "Abundant Fields, Meager Shelter," called migrant housing "an undeclared disaster of the highest urgency."
There are more than 1.3 million migrant workers in the United States, who come mostly from Mexico but also from Puerto Rico, Haiti, Jamaica, Florida and Texas and travel state to state in search of work. Many don't speak English. According to the Labor Department's National Agricultural Workers Survey, released in March, 52 percent of the hired farmworkers are illegal immigrants. They are also largely invisible: ladders poking up along horizons of fruit trees, or the weekly rush of Spanish-speaking customers at a local grocery store, offer the only evidence that they are here -- until they make the news. Last month in Farmingville, N.Y., two Mexican men looking for work were beaten and knifed by two men posing as contractors promising jobs -- a brutal testament to the sometimes uneasy relationship between laborers and the communities where they work.
Migrant workers usually stick to themselves. Their median income is $850 a month, earned over a five-month picking season, and their yearly income is well below the poverty level. When the growers who hire migrant workers do not provide them with a place to live, their housing options are dismal: they cannot take on rental leases for their short stay, and motels are prohibitively expensive.
"What's tragic is that what migrant workers do is critical to everyone, to all of us who eat, and yet they don't have any influence to get things done," Mr. Loza said, lamenting the lack of a comprehensive federal policy easily applicable to migrant housing. "In any other situation, war would be declared and the problem would be addressed, but still nobody is doing anything about it." Migrant workers are even losing ground, according to the Workers Survey report, which found that their earnings, adjusted for inflation, are 11 percent lower than they were 10 years ago, having stagnated at a national adjusted average of $7,500 a year.
In an old sewing machine factory overlooking the battlefields of Gettysburg, Mr. Bell, 40, has pledged himself to the fight. A bashful man (he could be a von Trapp sibling in "The Sound of Music") in a flannel shirt and tan work boots, Mr. Bell has himself come a long way from the kind of work he did as a graduate with architecture degrees from Princeton and Yale.
Ten years ago, Mr. Bell was doing what was expected of him, working his way up in a prestigious New York firm, Steven Holl Architects, designing doorknobs and details for a multimillion-dollar house. "I realized that that wasn't what I wanted to be doing with the talents I had, with the education I had," Mr. Bell said, over tacos and papaya juice at a roadhouse near the fields, where workers come for lunch on their 30-minute breaks. "I was determined to do something different, something that I valued."
At the time, Mr. Bell's sister, then a legal aide, began sending him photographs showing the degraded conditions of migrant housing in Pennsylvania. She was inspecting camps to see that they met federal and state housing codes. She described motel-style buildings with communal toilets and dank barrack-type dwellings, images of "overcrowding, overflowing toilets, raw sewage."
"My sister also told me about the fear and paranoia," he said. "People were so afraid to talk about the problems, they'd pass notes instead."
Mr. Bell quit his job and moved down to a fishing shack on a stream with no electricity in Gettysburg, a part of one of the largest fruit-processing regions on the East Coast, where outhouses, though uncommon, are still in use. "I wanted to try and see if I could get to know a very small community very well, and do appropriate architecture for them," he said. "I was challenging my value as an architect. I saw a problem and thought here was someplace I could come in and help. To me it was a design problem."
In many states, there are small pockets of activism -- church groups and nonprofit organizations working with communities to build a handful of better houses. Mr. Bell himself has spent considerable time learning from Samuel Mockbee at Rural Studio in Greensboro, Ala., where each semester students make buildings for the impoverished residents of Hale County, Ala.
But Mr. Bell's goal is more ambitious: develop a national housing program tailored to the financial realities of farmers and the daily needs of workers, and installed at very low cost. "I'm against the generic," said Mr. Bell, who envisions as many building types as there are migrant communities. "Every tiny cultural group should somehow have the opportunity to shape their environment."
Mr. Bell started out by interviewing dozens of migrant workers and growers on the East Coast. He recruited volunteers to work with him, sending them to local migrant health centers, where workers were more likely to speak freely. "Nobody ever really talked to migrant workers about what was best, what was good and what was bad, or what was the housing like where they came from," Mr. Bell said. "The workers themselves didn't want to complain, because they think of themselves as guests in this country."
For five years he worked with Rural Opportunities, a program financed by the Agriculture and Labor Departments, learning how to apply for grants and how to tap into the byzantine world of federal aid.
And he talked to growers, traveling to their association meetings to lecture. "I always spoke after the guy who was talking about dagger nematodes, a parasite that kills apple trees," he recalled. "I knew that lecture by heart." Mr. Bell slept in his car, short of hotel money, but stored up a wealth of raw experience. He learned that farmers were resentful but resigned to remaining the main providers of worker housing. "They had gotten into it out of necessity, because no one else could afford the operating costs," Mr. Bell explained.
In 1991, he opened Design Corps and began designing in earnest. Mark Bream, a third-generation farmer, was one of the first fruit growers to sign on. "I wish I could just put my ad in the paper, get workers and get the job done," he said in an interview. "But that's just not the way it works. It doesn't make you any money. But at least I have workers when I need them."
Mr. Bell has built 10 houses for 50 migrant workers in Pennsylvania, including the one occupied by Mr. Rodriguez. Mr. Bream paid $75,000 for his four units, with matching funds Mr. Bell helped him get from the state. Mr. Bream provides the land and pays for utilities and maintenance. "If you don't have the housing, it's really hard to get the workers," said Mr. Bream, who charges each laborer $9 a week for housing.
Mr. Bell alters prefabricated units to need, using design to meet and often exceed federal and state code requirements. For example, a house is required to provide 100 square feet per person. Mr. Bell's five-man dwelling at Bream Orchards is 810 square feet, with no extra cost to the farmer.
When asked to describe his designs, Mr. Bell refrains from professional jargon, describing instead how design can make a typical picker's job a little less spirit- and backbreaking. "Not all design issues are about money," he said. "Having the sun come in your window in the morning doesn't cost anything. They come back from work with some equipment. So I made a screened porch where they can drop off their tools, and I have a big sink there so they can wash up some from the pesticides. Generally, a couple of them will start cooking, while some are showering, taking turns." He made sure to build in a long kitchen counter that could double as a dining bar for ad hoc meals.
Exhausted pickers' most popular activity was watching television lying down. "Originally, I had the TV in one bedroom, but they were all piling on one guy's bed to watch it," Mr. Bell explained. So in one model he has arranged a four-bed space with a television in the middle so that everyone can watch while reclining. He aligned windows on each side of the living room "to make sure there's plenty of cross ventilation, because there are rarely any air-conditioners." he said, adding: "And I always try to include porches. They just seem to remind people universally of home."
Early next year, four new units will be constructed near Gettysburg. Farmers often ask for housing that can accommodate as many as 30 men, but Mr. Bell prefers a more intimate scale. "They come up from the South by car, four or five men," he explained. By the time workers reach Pennsylvania, "the core group of friends has already formed," he added. The housing unit itself is shaped aerodynamically, with a rounded roof and a porch with a flaring roofline. "I wanted it to suggest modes of transportation: a Conestoga wagon, or an Airstream trailer," Mr. Bell said.
Mr. Mockbee, his mentor, said: "Seeing Bryan's work, you say, 'Ah! There's intelligence at work here,' but it doesn't scream at you. His work is much closer to the client's aspirations than what most architects would ever consider catering to."
This winter, Mr. Bell is taking his campaign on the road to South Carolina, where living conditions are more squalid and farmers are slower to upgrade. This time, his model house has four bedrooms for eight people, two airy porches and a communal living room with 10-foot ceilings, two stoves and two refrigerators for families who told him they preferred to live in pairs, as long as each family could have its own kitchen space. Mr. Bell's conviction that design can improve lives is unshaken. "It started out as a search," he said. "Now I know it's the truth: designers are needed to address social issues."
In Pennsylvania in early October, Mr. Rodriguez was expecting only one more week of work, as the harvest was ending. His earnings this year will be about $4,000, a disappointment after last year's bumper crop, when he brought home $6,000. He offered three visitors plastic cups full of crunchy, savory green bananas, which he had sauteed with onions to accompany his bistec.
Mr. Bell noticed that Mr. Rodriguez had moved the refrigerator to hide the trash can from view. The architect made a mental note. Next time, he'd make sure to design a cabinet to do that job.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Corporate Taxes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is disheartening that corporate America, the real hero in the current expansion, is being bashed by a study that ignores the tax burden on American corporations and mischaracterizes legitimate tax provisions as tax avoidance schemes (Business Day, Oct. 20). 
 Internal Revenue Service data show that on average, corporations pay almost 30 percent of their profits in federal income taxes, a figure that signals a high rate of compliance, not widespread tax evasion. A deeper concern is the attack on the pro-growth tax policy that has contributed to our strong economy.
Corporations provide well-paying jobs, investment opportunities and services for all Americans. Instead of legitimizing the class warfare rhetoric of the current campaign by bashing corporations for alleged tax avoidance, let's focus our efforts on reducing taxes for both corporations and their employees.
 
MICHAEL E. BAROODY
Senior Vice President
Natl. Assn. of Manufacturers
Washington, Oct. 24, 2000 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Home Resales Dropped 2.7% In September

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes fell last month to a pace that still shows the economy has not lost much of its vigor, industry figures showed today.
Home resales fell 2.7 percent in September, to an annual rate of 5.14 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. The decline came after a 9.5 percent rise in August resales that was the biggest monthly increase since June 1999. 
 Resales will probably total about 5 million this year, second only to last year's record 5.2 million, according to the trade group's projections.
"Everything that comes on the market seems to be sold and seems to be sold fairly quickly, which is consistent with a strong economy," said Mark Vitner, senior economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. At September's sales rate, there was a four-month supply of houses on the market, association figures showed. While that is up from the 3.8-month supply a month earlier, it is below the 5-month average for the more than nine years of economic expansion.
Sales of previously owned homes, which account for 85 percent of all houses on the market, are considered an important gauge of consumer demand. Home sales can stimulate spending on goods like furniture and appliances. Shipments of major home appliances rose 3.7 percent in September and are up six of the last nine months, according to the latest figures from the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers.
By region, sales fell 8.8 percent in the Northeast; 3.5 percent in the Midwest; 3.5 percent in the South; and rose 2.1 percent in the West.
Meanwhile, the median price of a home fell 1 percent, to $141,800 in September, from $143,200 in August.
The average rate on the 30-year mortgage has held below 8 percent since mid-August, according to the mortgage provider Freddie Mac. Rates have fallen since reaching a five-year high of 8.64 percent in mid-May.

HEADLINE: DuPont Earnings Fall 14%; Pessimism This Quarter, Too

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 25

 BODY:
The DuPont Company said today that its third-quarter profit fell 14 percent and that profit in the fourth quarter would be hurt by a slowing economy and lower sales in its drug business.
Profit from operations fell to $537 million, or 51 cents a share, compared with $625 million, or 59 cents a share, in the third quarter a year earlier. Sales were little changed at $6.45 billion. 
 The results matched forecasts of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Analysts had lowered their estimates in September after the company first said it would not meet profit targets for the year.
In the recent quarter, DuPont had special charges of $72 million, or 8 cents a share, related to last year's acquisition of Pioneer Hi-Bred International and to a plant closing, and one-time gains of $97 million, or 10 cents a share, from sales of stakes in two businesses. These resulted in net income of $562 million, or 53 cents a share. In the quarter a year earlier, after charges of $444 million, or 42 cents a share, for reorganization in the company's agricultural and nylon businesses, net income was $181 million, or 17 cents a share.
The DuPont Company, which last month forecast profit as high as $2.95 a share for the year, now says $2.85 is the best it can "reasonably expect to achieve." That is 3 cents below Wall Street estimates and the second time in two months the company has lowered its forecast.
In trading today, DuPont shares fell 50 cents, to $42.38.
The company's third-quarter profit was hurt by a 45 percent rise in oil prices and a 75 percent increase in natural gas prices, key ingredients in chemical products. The results were also hurt by a 7 percent decline in the euro, which makes European sales worth less in dollars. The currency fluctuations and rising energy prices cost the company $250 million in the quarter.
DuPont expects "significantly lower fourth-quarter results" from the its pharmaceutical business, Charles Holliday, the chief executive, said in a statement.
Drug sales, which were $389 million in the third quarter, will be reduced by $100 million in each of the next three quarters, said Gary Pfeiffer, the chief financial officer. The company said it was phasing out promotional programs for some of its drugs, including the Parkinson's disease treatment Sinemet, which is losing sales to generic competitors.
The company did not discuss the outlook for 2001 earnings.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Bush Returns to Education

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

 BODY:
The Bush-Cheney campaign has begun showing more television commercials about education. Mindy Tucker, a campaign spokeswoman, said the advertisements were being shown in "battleground" states, which she would not identify. One is titled "Expect More."
 
PRODUCER -- Cold Harbor Films
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial opens with a boy tossing a baseball and catching it. Then a girl is shown watching through a screened backstop. The boy reaches for the ball on the ground. Gov. George W. Bush is then shown in shirt sleeves, then with a little girl in a schoolroom, in what appears to be a campaign photo opportunity. Then children wave flags as the words "leave no child behind" appear on the screen. Mr. Bush then appears again, speaking, in shirt sleeves. Then a little boy in a classroom appears, followed by Mr. Bush in a suit with some adults in a classroom. Then Boy Scouts raise a flag. Finally, Mr. Bush appears again in shirt sleeves, as he finishes his comments and the words "accountability," "discipline" and "end social promotion" appear on the screen. Children in half-tones wave as the commercial ends. 

THE SCRIPT -- Governor Bush: "How come the hard things don't get done? Because they're hard. If we really want to make sure no child gets left behind in America, we need the courage to do some tough things. We need to raise standards in our schools. We need more accountability and more discipline. And we need to stop promoting failing kids to the next grade because we've given up on them. It's easy just to spend more. Let's start by expecting more."
 
ACCURACY -- Complete. None of his simple prescriptions are remotely controversial.
 
SCORECARD -- This advertisement was prepared and started showing before a recent study by the RAND Corporation, a California research organization, challenging the claims Mr. Bush has made about progress in education in Texas. Its pace is not as frantic as some earlier commercials. It deals with the issue that voters, regardless of whether they support Mr. Bush or Vice President Al Gore, cite more often than any other as the most important issue facing the next president and Congress. The return to this theme emphasizes the central issue that Mr. Bush has used to portray himself to voters as a different kind of Republican. ADAM CLYMER

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
An all-out effort is under way to market an artificial sweetener.

BYLINE: By Constance L. Hays 

 BODY:
WORLD of home-baked coconut pie, made without sugar? That is among the promises that the marketers of Splenda, an artificial sweetener generically known as sucralose, are making through a large-scale campaign that began last month and will peak in January with a series of television commercials intended to create consumer interest in the product.
Splenda is made by McNeil Specialty Products, a division of Johnson & Johnson. While McNeil executives would not disclose spending for the campaign, one industry expert put the figure at about $40 million, citing publications that the company distributed at trade shows this summer to describe how it planned to support the product. 
 While the market is crowded with artificial sweeteners -- Equal and Sweet 'n' Low, to name just two -- advertising has trailed off in recent years.
"It's a category that from a marketing standpoint spends a third of what it spent 15 years ago," said Kieran Walsh, executive vice president and managing director at Lowe Lintas & Partners in New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group, which produced the Splenda television ads. "And that's without accounting for inflation."
Executives in charge of Nutrasweet, generically known as aspartame and sold to consumers as Equal, confirmed that ad spending is down. Part of the reason is that in 1992, the patent held by Monsanto expired, which opened the field to competing manufacturers, said Nick Rosa, the president and chief executive of Nutrasweet's sweetener ingredient division, which was sold earlier this year by Monsanto to J. W. Childs Equity Partners.
No new advertising is planned in response to Splenda, he added, noting the lessons of the past. "When we launched Equal's tabletop sweetener, instead of cannibalizing Sweet 'n' Low, both businesses grew," he said.
Still, executives at Merisant, which owns the Equal consumer business, indicated they planned a campaign of their own. "We have plans to address the opportunity that there will be increased consumer interest in the category with another competitor," said Dan Beck, general manager for North America. "And we are confident they will choose Equal."
McNeil is betting that Splenda's distinguishing characteristics -- it is derived from sugar and can be used in cooking -- will turn out to be strong selling points. In sucralose, three of the hydrogen-oxygen groups in each sugar molecule are replaced with chlorine atoms. The effect is that the sweetener is not absorbed into the body, meaning there are no calories to burn off later.
The process was discovered by researchers in Britain in 1976 and was approved for consumer use by the Food and Drug Administration two years ago. Since then, it has become an ingredient in an array of foods and beverages, including Diet Rite cola, Swiss Miss sugar-free cocoa mix and Diet V8 Splash. It can withstand heat, making it unusual among artificial sweeteners. Now its promoters want to build up its image with consumers and persuade them to buy it in stores. The target audience is mostly women 35 and older, with busy lives involving lots of demands on their time and yet an inclination to bake. Diabetics are also being singled out through the company's Web site and other efforts with doctors.
"What we have found is, the proposition that resonates with consumers is the fact that Splenda is made from sugar and tastes like sugar," said Debra A. Sandler, McNeil's vice president for worldwide marketing. "The ads will focus on the origins of the products as well as the versatility of the product."
That versatility, particularly the idea of using Splenda in baking, will be a chief selling point. The product can be poured and measured in the same proportions as white sugar, Ms. Sandler said, although it weighs far less and looks more like powdered sugar than the granulated kind. Other artificial sweeteners have focused squarely and almost exclusively on the table top and the coffee wagon. Ms. Sandler sees the cooking realm as a big part of potential sales.
"Upwards of 75 percent of the low-calorie sweetener category is the packet," she said. "We feel there is an opportunity to grow the whole category, particularly the granular."
To do that, the company is distributing recipes, both on laminated cards and on its Web site at www.splenda.com. Predictably, many of the recipes are for pies and cakes, but others are for dishes like "Sweet and Spicy Shrimp." Samples of Splenda are being handed out in stores and other public places.
At the same time, McNeil also wants to be sure Splenda is a contender for use in coffee and tea. A partnership with 7-Eleven will feature Splenda in radio ads and put packets of it next to Equal and Sweet 'n' Low in the chain's 5,200 stores, beginning this month.
"We saw it as a win-win-win proposition," said Alan Beach, 7-Eleven's category manager for hot beverages. "We worked out a very extensive agreement that included a lot of different pieces."
While similar partnerships have been formed in the past, "every product doesn't have the opportunities this one does," he added. "It's new, it's unique and it has a lot of benefits."
McNeil is also distributing coupons for Splenda in newspapers. The sweetener is expensive compared with regular sugar but comparable to other artificial sweeteners. A 55-gram box of Splenda costs $2.50, a company spokeswoman said, and is the equivalent for cooking purposes of a pound of sugar.
The company also signed Mia Hamm, the soccer player, to help promote the brand at an event earlier this month in New York. Ms. Hamm cited a story, commissioned by McNeil, that ranked United States cities by sugar consumption.
Leading the pack was New Orleans, which could not have been a surprise, considering a propensity for pralines and an annual event called the Sugar Bowl. Ms. Hamm urged her audience to cut back on their calories by using Splenda and received a check from McNeil for her foundation, which promotes women's sports and finances research on bone-marrow disease.
The television ads, scheduled to be broadcast in January, have been years in the conceptualizing, Mr. Walsh said. "It's important for us to put a contemporary twist on this," he said, while declining to give any details, except that there will be no dancing molecules.
"We have done a significant amount of research on this, and consumers are very excited about this," Mr. Walsh said. "The demand for that silver bullet, food products that taste good and are also good for you, is eternal."

HEADLINE: Brown Brothers Makes Offer on Site in Battery Park City

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Brown Brothers Harriman & Company and a developer have made an offer to buy control of a site in Battery Park City where the bank plans to build a new waterfront headquarters.
But the bank first has to negotiate a complicated series of special zoning changes and tax breaks with both state and city officials and come to terms with the Battery Park City Authority on a price for the land. 
 Brown Brothers, the oldest private commercial bank in the nation, has searched fitfully for a new home over the last four years. It had looked at the vacant waterfront parcel earlier this year before it found space at the top of a tower at the nearby World Financial Center. But when the bank failed to move quickly and lost the space, real estate executives said, it turned its attention back to the land on the Hudson River waterfront.
Brown Brothers and the developer, Brookfield Financial Properties, have proposed building a 23-story glass tower just north of the New York Mercantile Exchange in Battery Park City. The bank, whose headquarters has been on Wall Street for 157 years, would own and occupy about half the 800,000-square-foot building, while Brookfield would control the rest, Battery Park City officials said.
The authority, the state agency that controls the site, had planned on selling the development rights for the parcel to the highest bidder, for an apartment house. But city officials asked the state authority to accommodate the bank and to amend the master plan for Battery Park City so that a commercial tower could be built there.
Fearful that Brown Brothers would make good on a threat to move to New Jersey, the city's Economic Development Corporation has gone to great lengths to help the bank find a new home. But real estate executives scoffed at the idea that Brown Brothers, the epitome of an old money, white-shoe bank, would move its headquarters out of Manhattan, although it does have an office and 550 employees at the Newport Office Tower in Jersey City.
In any event, last week Brookfield made an undisclosed offer for the site that fell short of what the authority wanted. Timothy S. Carey, president of the authority, said he was putting together a counteroffer and expected negotiations to accelerate. He said he wanted to get the full value of the property, a rare downtown development site.
"We're looking for a return on our investment," Mr. Carey said. "The tax breaks are a negotiation between the developer and the city."
Michael Carey, president of the Economic Development Corporation, did not return calls requesting comment.
Radford W. Klotz, a partner at Brown Brothers, and Richard Clark, president of Brookfield, said that the two companies were working together on a proposed project at Battery Park City. But they declined to discuss details of the negotiations.
While it is no longer a powerhouse, Brown Brothers still has a list of wealthy clients and about 850 employees at its historic home at 63 Wall Street. It moved an operations center to Jersey City in 1994.
For the last four years, as it searched for a new home, the bank has considered a number of sites, including 350 Madison Avenue and 875 Third Avenue in Midtown, and 100 Broadway and 125 Broad Street downtown.
But an agreement was never reached, and, as the search dragged on, rents skyrocketed and the prospect of a deal became more and more expensive.
Even after the bank began talks with city officials about Battery Park City earlier this year, Brown Brothers focused on space available at the top of 1 World Financial Center.
But Lehman Brothers moved more quickly, according to real estate executives, and has struck a tentative deal for the space. So Brown Brothers went back to the waterfront site three weeks ago and selected Brookfield to be the developer.
The Brown Brothers search was complicated by the lack of vacant space downtown and in Midtown. To try to stem the resulting rent increases and the flow of companies to New Jersey, the Battery Park City Authority is about to put a large separate parcel up for sale that could accommodate a 1.8-million-square-foot tower.
The city is selling another vacant site, at Murray and Greenwich Streets. The Brown Brothers tower would also help, since it would include 400,000 square feet of space for other tenants.
But, even if the deal for the waterfront property does not work out, few brokers believe that Brown Brothers, which closed its brokerage business in May and laid off 78 investment analysts and traders, is going anywhere outside of Manhattan. "They're not leaving the city," said one prominent broker who has talked with Brown Brothers. "It's not a critical mass of jobs anyway."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: FOCUS ON THE ISSUES;
Comparing Social Security Proposals

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
With the population about to get decidedly older and the nation enjoying a moment of prosperity, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush agree that now is the time to put Social Security on sound footing for generations to come.
But their deep differences about how to do so have made the future of the retirement system one of the most supercharged issues of the presidential campaign, and the first test of whether Social Security's status as politically untouchable has been altered by the fact that more than half of all households now own stocks. 
 The debate has turned vigorous and occasionally nasty in the campaign's final weeks, with each campaign throwing around big numbers to suggest that the other side's approach is irresponsible.
Mr. Gore, playing to older voters who turn out reliably at the polls, has been asserting that Mr. Bush's plan would drain from the system $1 trillion needed to pay benefits to current retirees. Casting themselves as the true reformers, Mr. Bush, of Texas, and his advisers said Mr. Gore's plan would saddle today's young people with $40 trillion in debt.
Each side has a point, though each is arguably exaggerating to make it. In any case, neither candidate's plan by itself would assure Social Security's solvency for the next 75 years, the benchmark the system uses to assess its financial stability. And both candidates have avoided acknowledging that fully restoring Social Security's health would almost inevitably require choosing from among a menu of politically painful options including benefit reductions and tax increases.
"When you look at the big picture, neither of them has solved the whole problem or addressed the details and the pain issue," said Ron Gebhardtsbauer, senior pension fellow at the American Academy of Actuaries, a nonpartisan research organization.
Driven by projections that the retirement system will run short of the money it needs to pay all benefits within a few decades, both candidates are proposing what would be the most sweeping changes to Social Security since its inception in 1935.
Mr. Bush wants to harness the power of the financial markets by allowing individuals to invest a portion of their Social Security payroll taxes in stocks and bonds.
Mr. Gore wants to leave the system unchanged and maintain the current level of guaranteed benefits even as the number of retirees grows substantially. To do so he would supplement payroll tax revenues with general income tax receipts. Separately, he has proposed tax incentives to help low and middle income people save for retirement outside of Social Security.
While Mr. Bush's proposal would bring more far-reaching changes to the system, each approach is revolutionary in its own way.
Mr. Bush's plan would move the system away from its identity as a collective pact under which each generation of workers helps support the retirement of its predecessors. The Bush plan would nudge the system in the direction of having each worker save for his or her own retirement, shifting both opportunities and risks to individuals.
Mr. Gore's plan would end the tradition of Social Security being wholly self-financed through the payroll tax, and in the long run would require higher taxes, reduced spending or additional government borrowing. Critics say the change would undermine support for Social Security by making it more like welfare than a pension, a pawn in the unceasing battle over taxes and spending.
Social Security's difficulties are rooted in demographic trends. As the population ages, the proportion of working people to retirees is declining. In 1960, there were more than 5 workers for every Social Security beneficiary; today there are 3.3, and by 2030 the figure will be 2.
Those proportions are important because of the way Social Security raises money to pay benefits. Workers and their employers split a 12.4 percent payroll tax. But the levy is not set aside to pay benefits for the workers who pay it; rather, it goes to pay benefits to current retirees.
Right now the system is generating more than enough money to pay all benefits. Payroll tax receipts will exceed benefit payments by more than $900 billion over the next decade, allowing the system to invest that surplus in government bonds. If interest payments from the bonds are included, the surplus over the next 10 years will be more than $2 trillion.
But that favorable situation will deteriorate rapidly as the 76 million baby boomers begin retiring. By 2015, payroll tax revenue will no longer cover benefit payments.
At that point, Social Security will need to start drawing on the interest income from its bond holdings -- the Social Security Trust Fund. That means the government will have to start appropriating money out of general tax revenues each year to begin supporting Social Security.
By 2025, even the combination of payroll tax revenue and interest payments on the bonds will no longer cover benefits, forcing the system to redeem the bonds it holds.
If nothing is done, Social Security will have exhausted its store of bonds in 2037, leaving it totally reliant on payroll tax revenue to pay benefits. Payroll taxes at that point would cover just over 70 percent of promised benefits.
Mr. Bush's plan would allow workers to place into their own investment accounts each year a little more than one-sixth of what they and their employers currently contribute directly to Social Security -- that is, 2 percentage points of the 12.4 percent payroll tax.
The idea is that workers would benefit from the higher rates of return available over the long run in the financial markets. Increasing the rate of return would narrow the gap between what Social Security can afford to pay in benefits and what it has promised.
Mr. Bush's plan would be voluntary. People who are retired or near retirement would not see any changes in benefits.
For those who do participate, Mr. Bush has said, there would be a menu of relatively safe and conservative investment options available.
But his approach creates problems that Mr. Bush avoids discussing. The most immediate is that allowing workers to place a portion of their payroll taxes in a private accounts reduces the amount of money available to pay benefits.
Prodded by Mr. Gore in their final debate last week, Mr. Bush acknowledged that he would need to use $1 trillion out of the surplus over the next decade to cover the shortfall created by the establishment of personal accounts.
Because Social Security is projected to run a surplus of more than $2 trillion during that period, using $1 trillion for private accounts would not immediately imperil the system's ability to pay full benefits to current retirees, as Mr. Gore has implied it would.
But it would substantially move up the date at which Social Security would run through its store of bonds and become completely reliant on payroll tax revenue.
According to the Gore camp, diverting two percentage points of the payroll tax into personal investment accounts would exhaust the trust fund in 2023, 14 years earlier than under the current system. In 2024, assuming no other changes are made, the system would be short of the money needed to pay benefits by hundreds of billions of dollars.
One partial solution would be to reduce the guaranteed Social Security benefit for those people participating in the private accounts plan. The idea would be that the investment returns from the private account, plus the reduced guaranteed benefit, would still leave retirees, at least those young enough to have participated in the plan, just as well off.
But Mr. Bush and his advisers have declined to say if they would reduce the guaranteed benefit, a step that would clearly open a new line of attack for Mr. Gore.
Indeed, Mr. Bush has not been willing to provide any details of how their plan would work, saying the specifics would have to be hashed out in a bipartisan way between Congress and a Bush administration.
A guide to what a complete Bush plan might look like comes from similar plans introduced in Congress in recent years. All of them would cut guaranteed benefits, pump substantial amounts of general revenues into the system or require individuals to return to the system a portion of their investment gains from the personal accounts.
The possible benefit cuts include such politically unpopular steps as raising the retirement age and reducing annual cost of living adjustments. And Mr. Bush has not given any indication of whether or how workers would be insulated from the risk of a stock market downturn around the time they retire.
Mr. Gore's approach would dedicate nearly all of the Social Security surplus to paying off the $3.4 trillion national debt within a dozen years.
Starting in 2011, Mr. Gore would then allocate to Social Security, out of general tax revenues, an amount equal to the interest saved from debt reduction -- $250 billion a year by 2016. The additional money, and the interest paid on it, would extend the system's solvency to 2054 from 2037.
On Monday, Mr. Bush said the revenue transferred to Social Security by Mr. Gore's plan, plus interest, would total nearly $40 trillion over four decades ending in 2050. That huge sum, Mr. Bush said, would weigh down the economy and future generations of taxpayers.
Aides to Mr. Gore said the $40 trillion number had to be considered in the context of the size of the problem. Using the same type of calculation, they said, Mr. Bush's plan would require $57 trillion between 2023 and 2054 to keep the system solvent, unless Mr. Bush was willing to reduce guaranteed benefit payments or increase the payroll tax.
Still, Mr. Gore's reliance on general revenues means much of the bill would be borne by people decades down the road in the form of higher taxes, reduced spending or increased borrowing.
