GRAPHIC: Photos
 
Chart: "Saving Social Security"
Both candidates are proposing substantial but very different changes to keep the retirement system solvent.
 
BASIC APPROACH
 
GEORGE W. BUSH
 
Would create personal investment accounts within the retirement system, seeking to use the higher returns historically available on Wall Street to help fill the financial hole facing Social Security. Would allow workers to invest in stocks and bonds 2 percentage points of the 12.4 percent payroll tax withheld from their checks.
 
ADVANTAGES
 
Would allow all workers a chance to build wealth on Wall Street. Would be a start on shifting Social Security from a "pay as you go" system under which current workers pay for benefits to current retirees -- an approach that becomes increasingly difficult to sustain as the population ages -- to a "pre-funded" system under which each worker saves for his or her own retirement.
 
DRAWBACKS
 
Subjects workers to the risk inherent in volatile financial markets. By diverting money into personal accounts, moves up the date at which Social Security can no longer pay full benefits using payroll taxes. Would not by itself keep Social Security solvent over the long run, and the additional steps needed to do so, including cuts in the guaranteed benefit, are politically unattractive.
 
AL GORE
 
BASIC APPROACH
 
Has proposed using nearly all of the Social Security surplus to pay off the $3.4 trillion national debt over the next dozen years, and then channel the interest savings back into the retirement system. Would result in annual payments to the system that would rise to $250 billion a year in 2016 and would continue through 2050.
 
ADVANTAGES
 
Maintains Social Security as an intergenerational compact that guarantees all workers a retirement benefit based on their lifetime earnings. Has ruled out any increase in the retirement age. Also contains an increase in benefits for elderly women, a group that frequently has high poverty rates.
 
DRAWBACKS
 
Would push most of the bill for keeping the system solvent onto future generations. Would require money each year from general revenues, forcing Social Security to compete with other priorities for money. Would extend solvency to 2054 from 2037, but does not address the painful choices that would be necessary to keep the system afloat for 75 years, the accepted benchmark for financial health.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Bond Market Signals Worry Over Economy

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The bond markets appear to be signaling that America should be more worried about an economic slowdown than about the prospects of higher inflation. Are bond investors -- who have been pretty good at spying clouds on the horizon well before the rest of the world -- right this time?
On Monday, investors retreating to the safe haven of United States Treasury securities pushed yields to their lows for the year. Government bonds have weakened a bit since then, but the yield on the five-year Treasury note, at 5.72 percent, is down from 5.9 percent in early October. The security maturing in two years is yielding 5.89 percent. 
 At the same time, high-yield bonds issued by corporations have plunged in price and rocketed in yield. The Merrill Lynch high-yield corporate bond index carried a yield of 13.24 percent yesterday; in September 1998, when economies around the world seemed at the precipice, the yield was just 10.28 percent.
You would expect a flight to Treasuries as investors react to the unrest in the Middle East, the ravaging of technology stocks and recent problems at old-line companies like Eastman Kodak and Xerox. The surprise is that the Treasury market's meteoric rise -- and the corresponding fall in yields -- comes at a time when inflation is rising.
Today's announcement of the employment cost index, a closely watched inflation measure, will give the market more information about where costs are headed. But from other data it is already clear that inflation is higher than it has been in a decade.
Yet real returns on government bonds -- that is, returns adjusted for inflation -- are at extremely low rates of around 2.5 percent, down from around 4 percent earlier this year. Numbers like those are hardly what you would expect from a market worried about rising prices.
Why parse the numbers so closely? For investors interested in divining where the economy is headed, the bond market's gyrations have been worth following in recent years. For example, in December 1994, when the economy was growing at 3.5 percent, yields on the 10-year Treasury bond peaked around 7.81 percent and began to slip, reaching about 6.2 percent six months later. What bond investors had spied was a decline in economic growth in the United States. By the end of 1995, growth had fallen to 2 percent.
Bond investors have also signaled significant risks in the financial system in recent years. In 1998, for example, the bond market bottomed in May and by July had moved up almost a half percentage point, driving yields lower. A month later, news that Russia had defaulted on its debt rocked the markets -- tremors that worsened with the bailout in September of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund. In retrospect, it is clear the bond market had sensed the speculative excesses in both the United States and overseas.
Some observers dismiss the rising price of bonds as solely the result of the government's repurchases of Treasury debt. With investors chasing fewer bonds, they argue, bond prices are sure to rise. But others say this cannot be the whole story, if only because investors have been aware of the government buybacks for months.
Unlike in 1998, the bond market is not foretelling systemic risk, says Stan Jonas, managing director at Fimat U.S.A., a brokerage firm in New York. Rather, he contends, it is reacting to more specific risks associated with individual companies, like Xerox, that are experiencing problems with earnings or with their overall businesses.
"It's a very different horror show than before," Mr. Jonas said. "It's about creative destruction. People are very frightened about individual credit risk; they don't know which one of these companies will survive."
Still, falling Treasury bond yields have often presaged a recession or an economic slowdown. Some economists have begun to fear that the Federal Reserve will not be able to manage the wished-for economic soft landing -- and to warn that investors should get ready for a bumpy ride.
Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, worries that events in the Middle East could transform an orderly increase in energy prices into a classic oil shock. "That's the stuff of recession," he said, "a shock that hits the economy when it is already on a slippery down-slope." Mr. Roach said he thinks a hard landing by the middle of next year is highly probable.
If Mr. Roach is right, the Fed could cut interest rates, fueling a further rally in Treasury securities. That could explain why yields in the government market are as low as they are today.
But if bond investors are focusing on that scenario, they are ignoring an important piece of the inflation puzzle, according to Alan W. Kral, vice president for portfolio management at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen in New York. Mr. Kral pointed out that in the past three months, the broadest measure of money supply has been growing at an annualized rate of 11 percent.
"What we've got is a volatile economy caused by things like oil and capital spending potentially declining that is offset by the Fed providing tons of liquidity," Mr. Kral said. So while the Fed talks tough on inflation, its actions send a different message. "We see this great bulge in money supply as potentially resulting in inflation," he said.
Regardless, some observers think that the bond market's current behavior is a reflection of investors' staunch belief in Alan Greenspan's ability to save the day no matter what. In the event of a slowdown, "people are making a strong bet that the Fed will ease immediately," Mr. Jonas said.
Even more so, Mr. Kral says, today's Treasury bond yields reflect the fact that the investors known as the bond vigilantes are no longer around.
In the early to mid-1990's, these powerful investors -- people like Stanley F. Druckenmiller of Soros Fund Management and Louis Moore Bacon of Moore Capital Management -- made huge bets on government bonds. They had the upper hand in monetary policy, driving interest rates up when they thought they saw signs of inflation and pushing rates down when the price data looked benign. It was these vigilantes to whom the early Clinton administration economic policy makers were in thrall; the bond market's anxiety about inflation played a big part in the tax and spending policies that contributed to today's big budget surpluses.
"The bond vigilantes are gone, and the reason they are gone is that Greenspan has been elevated to a status that is enormous," Mr. Kral said. "The bond market may be saying, 'Alan's going to bail us out.' We bailed out Russia, we bailed out Long-Term Capital Management. Maybe some people are beginning to feel that Nasdaq is too big to fail."

Bond Prices Pull Back
 By Reuters
 Treasury bond prices sank yesterday despite weakness in technology shares as investors moved to take profits in government bonds ahead of key labor market and growth data later this week.
The decline in Treasury prices was cushioned somewhat by a dramatic dive of almost 6 percent in the technology-heavy Nasdaq stock index, which drove some investors to seek the safe haven of government issues.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 12/32, to a price of 100 18/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.67 percent from 5.62 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32, to 107 5/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.74 percent from 5.71 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Poverty, Paradox and a 'Dear Leader'

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PYONGYANG, North Korea, Oct. 25

 BODY:
When Kim Il Sung, the father of the current leader of North Korea, founded the Communist Party here in the 1940's, educated North Koreans say that he had an uncommon piece of wisdom. Unlike the Russians and the Chinese, they say, Mr. Kim respected intellectuals and embraced them as true members of the North Korean party.
Thus, the symbol of the party here is not just a hammer and a sickle, but also a paintbrush that appears on posters and badges between the two worker's tools. 
 Several young men who proudly described this to Western reporters called themselves "intellectuals," meaning they had gone to a university. They were assigned to baby-sit the Americans so that they would not stray beyond the official program of this week's visit by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. Their common attribute, aside from fealty to the "Dear Leader," Kim Jong Il, was their ability to speak English.
One of the men, a Mr. Li, 29, was single and lived at home with his parents. "Miss Right has not come along," he explained, using his very colloquial and fluent English.
A university English teacher, Mr. Li, who has never set foot outside North Korea, said he used American movies and books to encourage his students to learn English as it is spoken. He knew the story lines of Dustin Hoffman's movies by heart: "Hero," "Kramer vs. Kramer," "Rain Man" were among his favorites. John Grisham and Sidney Sheldon novels were among his basic texts. Combined with this seeming flair for American culture and an ability to crack jokes at his own expense, Mr. Li became almost childlike when it came to describing the Dear Leader. Recently, he said, he had proudly joined tens of thousands of others waving a pink pompom during a mass demonstration in honor of the leader.
 
Ghost Town of 2 Million
Where are all the people? Pyongyang, the showcase of the country, is supposed to have a population of two million. But with cars the preserve of a few privileged government officers, and bicycles not common either, the streets are usually empty, giving an eerie impression of an overbuilt ghost town. The most common form of transportation is by foot and it is not unusual for workers, clad in sneakers and ankle socks, to walk several miles to their jobs. Even so, around 9 a.m. when offices open, the sidewalks are not exactly packed with people.
There are some theories for the scarcity of humans. The first is that the economy is at such a low point -- the energy shortage has left factories idle -- that people stay home. Many have virtually no money and even if they did, there is nothing to spend it on. And that people have such meager diets that they are lethargic.
The second theory is that the city can sustain only about 1.5 million people but as hard times have swept the countryside, many more have sought comfort here. In response, the authorities have organized campaigns to sweep nonresidents back out of the capital, to join work gangs or help with the harvest.
 
Flown-In Feast
The Albright visit was packed with luncheons and dinners. Aside from the six hours of negotiations, the Americans and North Koreans spent another six hours socializing with each other. To thank her hosts, Dr. Albright threw a dinner on the last night of her visit in honor of Mr. Kim, his close aides and officials from the Foreign Ministry.
How does the State Department arrange a diplomatic dinner in North Korea, where there is little meat, few vegetables and shortages of almost everything else? And how does Dr. Albright live up to the standard she set when she invited the North Korean vice marshal, Jo Myong Rok, to a sparkling dinner at the State Department earlier this month with 150 top-drawer guests, including the French and British ambassadors?
The Americans asked the North Koreans for the use of a suitable locale and were given Magnolia Hall, a grand octagonal banquet room used for state occasions and replete with a large kitchen. North Korean cooks suggested dishes, which were approved by Dr. Albright's deputy chief of staff, Suzanne A. George. Some American touches were added: broiled steak and roast turkey, which the local Korean kitchen staff cooked along with the rest of the menu.
The ingredients for the dishes were the responsibility of the North Koreans (the meat was flown in from Beijing) and California wine was flown in on Dr. Albright's plane. The high point came when Dear Leader, Mr. Kim, ordered one of his most senior military officers to pour the wine for every guest at the head table. The officer did so with aplomb and drama, stopping after the pouring of each glass to make sure the recipient sampled the wine and exclaimed approval.
Afterward, the Americans said the evening was most memorable for the sight of a senior North Korean man offering wine to guests who, despite the aura of good feelings this week, formally remain the enemy.

AT&T Outlines Its Plan To Split Into Four Parts
AT&T pulled back from an expensive three-year effort to become the first one-stop shop selling long-distance, wireless, cable television and Internet services as a single package with a single bill. Instead, the company announced, it will break itself into four parts.
The nation's eighth-largest company, which only two decades ago dominated the telephone business and ranked with General Motors and Mobil among the nation's very largest companies, will soon be four much smaller businesses competing against many formidable, and sometimes larger, rivals. Page A1. 

Northwest Airlines Trial Delayed
A federal judge agreed to postpone a court battle in which the Justice Department is trying to force Northwest Airlines to sell its controlling stake in Continental Airlines. The closely watched trial was set to begin in Detroit today. But the judge pushed back the start to Nov. 1 at the request of Northwest, which asked for time to try to settle the case. C5.
 
Judge Puts Limits on Tax Company
Renaissance/The Tax People, which has been marketing a system to reduce income taxes that the authorities say is really a pyramid scheme, was ordered by a Kansas judge to stop soliciting new clients. Carla J. Stovall, the attorney general of Kansas, filed a civil lawsuit on Friday seeking to shut down the company, which is owned by Michael C. Cooper. But her office agreed in negotiations with lawyers for the company to allow the business to operate in limited fashion. C6.
 
Bond Trader Files More Complaints
A bond trader at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter who has accused the firm of sexual discrimination filed additional complaints with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, accusing Morgan Stanley of firing her on Tuesday in retaliation for her complaints. A spokesman for the firm confirmed that the trader, Allison K. Schieffelin, had been dismissed. C6.
 
CBS has agreed to pay $8 million to about 200 female technicians who said in a class-action lawsuit that they had been sexually harassed and discriminated against. C14.
 
AOL Asks to File Microsoft Brief
America Online asked a federal appeals court for permission to file a supporting brief in the appeal of the Microsoft antitrust case, noting that the plaintiffs in the case -- the federal government and 19 states -- support the idea while Microsoft opposes it. The company did not say what its brief might discuss, though it is clear that the brief will support the government's argument and a federal judge's rulings against Microsoft. C4.
 
For Team Owner, a Business Slump
For John W. Henry, who owns the Florida Marlins and has a minority stake in the New York Yankees, the World Series can help take his mind off his other business, an investment company. The Financial and Metals Portfolio, one of his largest and most aggressive funds, fell 18.7 percent last year and is down 17.4 percent this year. The assets of his investment group have been sliced to about $1 billion from $2.4 billion a year ago. C9.
 
Viacom Profit Beats Expectations
Viacom reported higher revenue and cash flow for its third quarter, but net income fell sharply on higher taxes and costs associated with its acquisition of CBS. The company earned $33.4 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with $96.7 million, or 14 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had been expecting a loss of 2 cents a share. Shares of Viacom fell $2.44, to $53.94. C10.
 
September Home Resales Fell 2.7%
Sales of previously owned homes fell 2.7 percent in September to a pace that still shows a vigorous economy, a report showed. C5.

Since the political conventions, Vice President Al Gore has emphasized the fiscal discipline of his agenda and referred less to programs for working families, confusing his message in the process. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: A Team in the Series and a Business in the Doldrums

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
If you squinted over Paul O'Neill's shoulder, past Todd Pratt and around the home plate umpire, you might have seen John W. Henry Saturday night in Yankee Stadium. Mr. Henry, a genial and soft-spoken man of 51, is a farmer's son living in a field of dreams.
First, the good dreams. Mr. Henry owns one major league team, the Florida Marlins, and has a minority stake in the New York Yankees. His four seats in Yankee Stadium are next to the opposing dugout, close enough to get him a piece of the bat that shall go down in infamy, at least for Mets fans. (For the record, a bat boy actually gave a piece of the bat to a Merrill Lynch executive who was a guest of Mr. Henry. It was the middle of the bat Mike Piazza shattered in Game Two, not the top shard that Roger Clemens tossed Piazza's way.) 
 Then there are the bad dreams -- the market. Since the middle of last year, it has been a nightmare for Mr. Henry, the manager of his own investment company, John W. Henry & Company, based in Boca Raton, Fla. The Financial and Metals Portfolio, one of his largest and most aggressive funds, fell 18.7 percent last year and is down 17.4 percent this year. And thanks to that performance and investors' withdrawal of funds, the assets of his investment group have been sliced from $2.4 billion a year ago to about $1 billion today.
Recently, Mr. Henry significantly reduced the fees he charges and announced a plan to consolidate his operations by shutting his firm's second office, in Westport, Conn.
Mr. Henry and professional investors like him use complex systems and formulas to trade futures contracts, which promise the delivery of an asset like a commodity or a stock index on a future date at a set price. Futures contracts become more or less valuable when the value of the underlying asset -- for example, the stock index or the commodity -- changes.
Managed futures money managers like Mr. Henry follow trends in the global market, looking for price discrepancies that they can take advantage of -- fluctuations in the euro, in the price of oil or in interest rates. But until the Middle East crisis and the spike in oil prices, there were few global upsets like the Asian crisis of 1998 for these money managers the last few years.
Shifting global economic conditions and bad bets on such trends have burned many prominent money managers recently. The roster of pain includes two of the world's most prominent hedge fund managers: this year, Julian H. Robertson Jr. shuttered his Tiger Investment empire and George Soros sharply scaled back his operations.
But while Mr. Soros and Mr. Robertson manage hedge funds, investment funds that cater to the wealthy, managed futures funds such as Mr. Henry's have investment minimums that can be as low as mutual funds'. One of Mr. Henry's funds has been available through Merrill Lynch, so some average investors are experiencing his troubles up close.
Though Mr. Henry and other managed futures managers use a different approach from Mr. Soros and Mr. Robertson, some of the same trends have hurt them all.
The managed futures industry has been "battered almost beyond recognition in the past couple years," said Barry Colvin, chief operating officer of Tremont Advisers, a hedge fund consulting firm.
"These kinds of fund managers need turmoil. They need global macroeconomic volatility," he said.
Managed futures is a particularly volatile area of fund management. But in a field where money managers frequently go under, Mr. Henry is known as a survivor. Despite his firm's record this year, his Financial and Metals fund has returned 28 percent, on average, every year since its inception in October 1982, well ahead of the 17.7 percent annual gain of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over the same period.
Still, while technology investors enjoyed unmatched gains last year, Mr. Henry and others in the managed futures industry suffered.
"Over the last three years, you could argue that this industry has no place in anyone's portfolio," Mr. Henry said. But that proves nothing about the future, he argued. "Things are dynamic," Mr. Henry said. "What did work for the last couple years is not necessarily where you want to be the next three years."
October has been a relatively encouraging month for his funds' performance. Surging oil prices, tensions in the Middle East and the continuing slide of technology stocks have all contributed to a rebound for Mr. Henry's funds. His Financial and Metals fund was up 11.6 percent for October, as of Tuesday.
Mr. Henry's introduction to futures was something of a crash course. When he was 25, his father died, and he took over his family's 2,000-acre farm, which was mostly in Arkansas, and taught himself hedging techniques. As he learned how to market his crops and protect against weather and price fluctuations, he had a few lucky early trades and decided to make futures his business instead of farming.
His love of baseball goes back further.
"I grew up listening to Harry Caray," the legendary announcer, he said.
"My father had a brain tumor when I was 8 years old and he was taken to the hospital in St. Louis," he added. "The St. Louis coach was staying at the same hotel where we were staying and heard the story and heard I was just a complete fan, knew all the statistics, so he offered me his seats."
"I sat through a doubleheader one day that week and ended up in the same hospital as my father," he remembered. "I had heat stroke -- St. Louis in the summer," he said.
"It was just magical," he added. "I'd been listening on the radio but I'd never seen a game. So my ambition in life became to move to St. Louis someday and get a job that would enable me to afford season tickets so I could go to 80 games a year."
He got his season tickets -- albeit to the Yankees -- when he bought 1 percent of the team in 1991. But his ultimate dream -- to own a team -- came true when he bought the Marlins in January 1999 for $150 million.
Major League Baseball rules stipulate that one cannot own one team and have a stake in another. Since he bought the Marlins, Mr. Henry has promised to sell his Yankees stake a few times, but he has yet to part with it. Is there a deadline for divesting himself of the Bronx bombers and the ringside seats?
"I think I've passed that," he admits. "Something will probably get done in 2001."
One thing is certain. As performance goes, the Yankees sure beat the futures market.
"As long as they send me a ring every year," said Mr. Henry, "I can't complain."

HEADLINE: Lautenberg to Raise Funds as Term's End Nears

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, N.J. Oct. 25

 BODY:
Frank R. Lautenberg is not leaving quietly or easily.
"It feels lousy," said Mr. Lautenberg, who tells anyone who asks that, in hindsight, he regrets his decision to retire from the Senate after 18 years in office. "I'm going to miss this place." 
 Still, Mr. Lautenberg's final days in office have been a whirlwind of last-minute lawmaking, campaigning for Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic nominee to succeed him, and figuring out what to do with the rest of his life. As if that were not enough, he is still hoping to raise nearly $400,000 to pay off some old campaign debts.
The senator's third term does not expire until Dec. 31, but his careerwill effectively end as soon as Congress adjourns, probably within the next few days.
Mr. Lautenberg, 76, is leaving at the height of his influence.
On Monday, President Clinton signed a bill Mr. Lautenberg had pushed for since 1997 into a law that lowers the legal threshold for drunken driving to a blood alcohol level of 0.08 percent.
It was a fitting bookend to the senator's 1984 law that raised the drinking age nationally to 21; both bills made federal highway financing contingent on states changing their laws. "He is leaving a true legacy as a champion for the children, the families and the economy of this nation," the president said at a Rose Garden bill-signing ceremony.
And on Tuesday, after Mr. Lautenberg called his home state "retarded" on the issue of drunken driving in a news conference in Trenton, New Jersey officials quickly indicated they would be likely to comply with the lower blood-alcohol limit.
Two weeks ago, the Senate passed Mr. Lautenberg's measure to allow victims of terrorism to collect court-awarded damages from countries that sponsor terrorist activity.
He also won $500 million for construction of the New Jersey Transit's Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Line. And still awaiting approval is one bill providing $10 billion in bonds to develop high-speed passenger rail service and another promoting the cleanup and redevelopment of polluted industrial properties.
Mr. Lautenberg has also played an important role in Mr. Corzine's campaign to succeed him. For instance, after the first New Jersey Senate debate, which Mr. Lautenberg attended, the senator defended Mr. Corzine, who angered some Jewish voters by saying that he supported the Clinton administration's abstention from a United Nations vote condemning Israel over its recent confrontations with Palestinians.
Meanwhile Mr. Lautenberg is doing what retiring senators do. He is soaking up accolades, such as the naming of the old federal courthouse and post-office building in Newark in his honor; arranging for the transfer of his papers to a new archive at Rutgers University; and musing over what possible role he might play in a Gore administration. (Democratic headhunters, be advised: he is not interested in an ambassadorship because it would require him to spend too much time away from his eight grandchildren.)
But Mr. Lautenberg's most difficult and awkward remaining chore, he said, is to hold one last campaign fund-raiser. "I'd like to do it as soon as we can," he said.
At a time when Mr. Corzine is under enormous criticism for spending more than $50 million of his own fortune for his Senate campaign, it seems almost quaint to recall that Mr. Lautenberg -- one of the wealthiest members of the Senate, whose own assets are worth between $11 million and $56 million, according to his Senate financial disclosures -- was criticized for trying to buy his own initial election in 1982 for $5.5 million. Mr. Lautenberg, who had made his fortune as a founder of Automatic Data Processing, contributed most of that from his own pocket. Like many wealthy candidates, he lent the money to his campaign; about $3.2 million in those loans remain on his campaign's books. But Mr. Lautenberg said that he had written off the 1982 debt in his mind.
He said he still hoped to recover what he borrowed in 1994, however. That year, facing a challenge from Chuck Haytaian, then the Republican Assembly speaker, Mr. Lautenberg raised $5.5 million. But he still needed a $900,000 infusion just three weeks before the election. His campaign borrowed the money from Valley National Bank in Wayne, N.J., and has since paid off all but $390,000, records from the Federal Election Commission show.
"I contributed to my race in 1982," he said. "I didn't like it, and I didn't want to do it again. But I did it a lot more modestly in '94. But that's still out there, and I'd like to get it paid off."
The 1994 loans are guaranteed personally by Mr. Lautenberg -- meaning that if he is unable to raise the entire $390,000 from others, he will have to pay off the rest himself. "If I fall short, I fall short," the senator said. "I still owe it to the bank, so I've got to pay."
But he bristled at the prospect of having to do so. "I may be fairly well off, but $400,000 is a lot of money," he said. "And there's a principle involved with me. Why should I have to pay to represent people when people think I did a good job?"
Mr. Lautenberg's associates say he was always a reluctant fund-raiser, and often deferred his own campaign financing efforts to other Democrats with more pressing financial needs. After his 1994 re-election, he waited three years to hold a major fund-raising event, a December 1997 gala at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. He mainly used the proceeds to retire earlier debts.
After he announced in February 1999 that he would not seek re-election, Mr. Lautenberg said, he was too busy to raise money, and decided to wait until after Nov. 7 so as not to compete for contributions with Mr. Corzine and Democratic congressional candidates.
Still, he said, he was confident it was not too late to put together a tribute to himself -- especially because he is counting on the help of such formidable fund-raisers as Mr. Corzine himself.
Mr. Lautenberg said he had asked Mr. Corzine for help raising money to pay off his debts when the two were getting to know each other, some time before he endorsed the candidate in February. Mr. Corzine agreed to help raise money, he said. Some campaign finance experts questioned the timing of Mr. Lautenberg's request for such help, especially given that the senator's outstanding campaign debts are essentially to himself.
But Mr. Lautenberg stressed that his understanding with Mr. Corzine -- which has not yet come to fruition -- had nothing to do with his endorsement. "It was never a deal," he said. "It was never a handshake. It was never, 'O.K., Frank, you do this for me, I'll do that for you.' "
The senator said he had far more important reasons for backing Mr. Corzine -- like his longstanding differences with former Gov. Jim Florio, the other Democrat running in the primary, and his belief that Mr. Corzine could be a force in the Senate on issues like fiscal policy, the environment and transportation.
He added: "Jon Corzine couldn't have bought my endorsement a hell of a lot more than $400,000."

SECTION: Section A; Page 35; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: In America;
At Last, the Issues

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Lesson number one: Be careful what you wish for.
Not too long ago Al Gore was howling that he would debate George W. Bush anytime, anywhere. The debates were supposed to nail down the election for Mr. Gore. They nearly buried him. 
 But now that the debates are over the polls are showing some movement back toward the vice president, which should tell you something. The less he's seen, the better he does.
Mr. Bush has a similar problem. He's fine as long as he's shaking hands and smiling and hugging little children. He's got personality. But something weird happens when he puts aside his programmed responses and starts speaking extemporaneously.
So there he was in LaCrosse, Wis., last week, proclaiming, "Families is where our nation finds hope, where wings take dream."
His handlers hate when that happens.
Mr. Gore's personality problems and voter concern over Mr. Bush's readiness to assume the presidency have muted enthusiasm for both men and drawn attention away from issues that might otherwise have been decisive.
A Page 1 article in Monday's Times said: "Even after absorbing three debates and months of campaigning, American voters are thoroughly ambivalent about their choices for president, still vexed by doubts about Vice President Al Gore's sincerity and Gov. George W. Bush's preparedness for the White House, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows."
The doubts will likely remain. But with less than two weeks to go until Election Day, and with the debates over, the media can be expected to focus less on personality and more on what should be the real issues of this campaign.
That sigh of relief you just heard is coming from the Gore people. The vice president's personality has gotten in the way of his message throughout the campaign. Even at the Democratic convention, where it was generally agreed that Mr. Gore delivered a credible acceptance speech, the strongest case for continuing the policies of the Clinton administration was made by the president.
Referring to his budget proposal in the first year of his first administration, Bill Clinton told the convention's roaring delegates: "It passed by a single vote in both houses. In a deadlocked Senate, Al Gore cast the tie-breaking vote. Now, not a single Republican supported it. . . . Their leaders said our plan would increase the deficit, kill jobs, and give us a one-way ticket to a recession. Time has not been kind to their predictions."
Moments later, he added, "You know, Harry Truman's old saying has never been more true: If you want to live like a Republican, you better vote for the Democrats."
Mr. Clinton is itching to take that message to the American people one more time. But polls have tended to show that Bill Clinton campaigning full-blast for Al Gore would turn off substantially more voters than he would turn on. So the big dog remains leashed.
If, finally, the spotlight is turned away from Al Gore's personality, the last days of this campaign are likely to focus on the differences between the two candidates on the following: the fate of Social Security and the budget surplus, tax cuts, appointments to the Supreme Court, abortion, federal aid to public education, the environment and a variety of health care issues, including the future of Medicare, proposed prescription drug benefits and the establishment of a so-called patients' bill of rights.
At first it was thought these issues would get a thorough airing in the debates. But the debates became dreary popularity contests refereed by pundits obsessed with declaring an instant winner and loser. If we've learned anything from this campaign it's that the debate formats should be changed (and additional questioners added) in an effort to make them more informative for the voters.
The trends to watch over the next several days are whether Al Gore can keep the personality questions behind him and get a bounce from hammering home the differences between him and Mr. Bush on specific issues, and whether Mr. Bush, in the pressurized finale of a presidential campaign, can avoid being undermined by voter unease over whether he is ready for the White House.

HEADLINE: Talks Advance on Bill With Tax Relief and Increase in Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton and Congressional Republicans narrowed their differences today over a tax-cut package that includes relief for small businesses and an increase in the federal minimum wage, but significant hurdles still blocked final agreement.
The tax bill, which would cost roughly $245 billion over 10 years, is also intended to help people pay for retirement and for long-term health care, to offer incentives to revitalize poor urban and rural areas and to impose new tax rules for American exporters to avert a trade war with the European Union. 
 After months of partisan bickering, Mr. Clinton and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert exchanged amiable letters today, promising cooperation in hammering out a year-end tax relief package.
But House and Senate Democrats, as well as the White House, said they had not seen final details of the Republican plan, and after looking at Republican summaries distributed today, they raised objections about provisions that they said would draw a presidential veto.
Nonetheless, Republican leaders said they would try to schedule votes in the House and Senate on Thursday for the bill, and they all but dared Mr. Clinton to veto legislation that contains provisions he wants, like the antipoverty program and higher minimum wage.
"We've gone as far as we can go, and we've made a lot of adjustment, taken consideration of the things that they had concerns about or wanted," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader.
"But at some point," Mr. Lott continued, "we have to get the votes in the House and in the Senate, and the president has to do what he feels like he has to do."
Mr. Lott said it would be "unfathomable" for Mr. Clinton to veto the tax package.
But Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, and Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's economic policy director, said the president would do just that unless Republicans agreed to several changes, including more money for school construction and less money back to Medicare for health maintenance organizations.
"We're still too far apart for the president to sign this bill," Mr. Sperling said, "but we're hopeful that negotiations lead to a bill that's mutually agreeable."
The dueling tax proposals came as Congress approved a 24-hour extension of spending at current levels to keep the government running through Thursday. It is the only type of extension that Mr. Clinton says he will now approve -- 25 days into the new fiscal year -- in an effort to force lawmakers to wrap up the budget process.
The House approved a bill today to finance primarily the nation's foreign aid programs, legislation that also contained authority to raise the budget ceilings for discretionary spending to $637 billion from $600 billion for the current fiscal year.
Aside from the tax bill, lawmakers and administration officials said major differences over education and immigration policies still stalled final action on two major spending measures. Republican negotiators met tonight to decide whether to push their immigration plans over the White House's objections.
"We're stopped," Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said. "We're dead in the water. Nothing's happened in two days."
Frustration was evident on the Senate floor.
"It's time we realized that at the end of this week we will be one week away from the election," said Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee. "I do not believe Congress should be in session one week before the election."
The tax bill contains several popular provisions.
Workers would be able to set aside $5,000 in individual retirement accounts, up from $2,000 now. In 401(k) plans, which permit workers to set aside savings from their pay and allow employers to take tax deductions for adding to those amounts, the annual limit on tax-deferred employee contributions would rise to $15,000 from $10,500. An exception would be made for those people over 50, who would be allowed to save an extra $5,000 a year.
The minimum wage would increase by $1, to $6.15 an hour, over two years. In exchange, Mr. Clinton agreed to $30 billion in tax breaks for small businesses, to offset the increased wages. But at Mr. Clinton's insistence, Republican leaders dropped several proposals, including one to freeze the wages of waiters and waitresses who earn tips, at $2.13 an hour.
Republican leaders want the bill to include a full deduction for people who pay 50 percent or more of their own health insurance premiums and a $10,000 deduction for the costs of adopting a child.
Democrats argue that this approach will not do enough to help uninsured Americans. In his letter to Mr. Hastert, the president said such deductions were "inefficient" and proposed making them tax credits instead.
Critics of the Republican plan complained that while pension limits were increased for people with higher incomes, two other Democratic measures, one intended to encourage savings for middle-income workers and another to provide tax incentives for small businesses to provide pensions for their employees, were dropped.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Tumble On Sales News From Nortel

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Technology stocks plunged yesterday, pulling the broader stock market with them. The Nasdaq composite index fell 5.6 percent, its biggest daily decline since May, while the Dow Jones industrial average ended down just 0.6 percent.
The selloff was spurred by the announcement on Tuesday by Nortel Networks, the Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, that its the third-quarter sales, although very strong, rose less than analysts had expected. 
 The fact that such a sales shortfall with otherwise strong growth sent investors scrambling to sell stocks is a sign of how uncertain many investors feel about the outlook for the economy. High oil prices, the continued weakness in the euro -- which is undermining the earnings of American multinationals -- and the turmoil in the Middle East are all keeping investors unnerved and with their fingers on the sell button.
Nortel dropped 29 percent, to $45, on the New York Stock Exchange and led the Toronto Stock Exchange, where it is also traded, sharply lower. The flood of sell orders forced a halt in the trading of Nortel because the Toronto computers could not handle them. The Toronto Stock Exchange index of 300 stocks dropped 840.26 points, or 8.1 percent, to 9,511.84.
Other fiber optic stocks also plunged. JDS Uniphase, which is scheduled to announce its quarterly earnings today and is a supplier to Nortel, fell 25.3 percent, to $71. SDL, which JDS Uniphase is acquiring, dropped 25.9 percent, to $234.19. Ciena, which makes optical networking equipment, fell 19.9 percent, to $108.38. These stocks had been holding up rather well, until now, compared with other technology stocks, which have helped push the Nasdaq index down 20.6 percent for the year.
Lucent, which is Nortel's competitor, fell 6.1 percent, to $20.25. But Lucent stock had already dropped nearly 70 percent this year as its earnings eroded. The Lucent board fired Richard A. McGinn, its chief executive, on Monday. Some analysts had pointed to Nortel as an example of how Lucent should have been run.
The fiber optic sell-off spread quickly throughout the technology sector, where many companies have cautioned about the near-term outlook for sales and earnings. Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M. helped lead the Dow lower, while Cisco, Sun Microsystems and Applied Micro Circuits joined JDS Uniphase in pulling the Nasdaq lower. These stocks and Corning, the fiber optic cable maker, worked with Nortel to bring the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down 2.4 percent.
At the end of the day, the Nasdaq was down 190.22 points, to 3,229.57, while the S.& P. 500 fell 33.23 points, to 1,364.90. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.59 points, to 10,326.48. The Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500 are still above the 2000 lows they fell to two weeks ago, and the Dow is still above 10,000, below which it broke last week.
Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, said that it was clear that there was still a big gulf between the earnings expectations in the market and the actual numbers that companies are reporting. "We've got a 1,300 target for the S.& P. 500 for the year- end, and it is my sense that the Nasdaq could find a bottom in the 2,500 to 2,700 range," he said. "But I have no idea if we are going to get there in the next few weeks or the next few months."
While Nortel sales jumped 42 percent, to $7.31 billion, they were about $300 million below expectations. That shortfall, said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation, is fueling investor worries that the United States and world economies are slowing more than expected. And if that is the case, future earnings and sales growth for fiber optic and other technology companies will be less than expected, making their stocks overpriced.
He said that many investors were concerned that the American economy may have a hard landing, instead of the soft landing they have hoped for. "The fear is that the Federal Reserve will be seduced into to keeping interest rates too high too long," he said, because of concerns about inflationary pressures, in part because of the sharp rise in oil prices.
"The stock market is telling us that there should be a soft-landing but don't count on it," he said.
But he said that investors are also struggling with another disappointment. That is that many of the favored technology companies, like Nortel, are proving unable to produce a steady stream of quarterly increases in the growth rates of both earnings and revenues. The high prices that many of these stocks had reached were a bet, he said, that this fantastic growth would continue.
"Now, we don't believe that any more," he said.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia, Turning a Page, Is Expected to Rejoin United Nations

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Yugoslavia will soon apply to join the United Nations, indicating a clear change in policy under its new president, Vojislav Kostunica, the American ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Holbrooke, said today after meeting with Balkan leaders.
"It is clear that Yugoslavia will join the United Nations in a very short time," Mr. Holbrooke said. "We are very pleased to hear that." 
 Mr. Holbrooke, who was the first prominent member of the Clinton cabinet to meet with Mr. Kostunica, said he had long argued over the issue of Yugoslavia's membership in the United Nations with the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, who insisted that his country was the sole successor to the old Yugoslavia, even after four of its republics obtained independence, and he refused to apply to join the United Nations.
Because of that, the old Communist flag of Tito's Yugoslavia still flies outside the headquarters of the United Nations, which has left issues of the property and liabilities of the former Yugoslavian republics frozen.
Those countries also urged Mr. Kostunica in a joint communique today to respect the equality of the states that emerged from the nation's breakup.
The issue was just one of many that Mr. Kostunica grappled with today, just weeks into his new job as president, and still without a federal government or even a foreign minister.
After his meeting with Mr. Holbrooke he also said that he would cooperate with the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, but that it was not high on his agenda. "There is an interest for truth of events, but it is not a priority," he said.
Mr. Kostunica also said he was working on releasing some 800 Kosovo Albanians being held in Serb prisons, and suggested that a law granting them amnesty was a possibility.
Mr. Kostunica's discussions with Mr. Holbrooke, a longtime negotiator in the Balkans, centered on the Dayton accords that ended the war in Bosnia, as well as on Kosovo and the United Nations resolution under which that province is now governed. The issues of Albanian prisoners in Serbia and the missing Serbs and Albanians were also discussed.
Mr. Holbrooke played down any differences, saying that the changes in the way Yugoslavia is run following the departure of Mr. Milosevic would be enormous. In particular, he said, there would be an end to the subversion by Milosevic allies and Interior Ministry police.
Working with Mr. Kostunica on Bosnia would be easier, one senior American official predicted, but serious differences on Kosovo remained.
"He is a nationalist and he is proud to be one," the official said of Mr. Kostunica. "To a Serb nationalist, Kosovo is part of the Serbian state. But he repeatedly said he was a pragmatist, that Dayton was a part of international law, and that he recognizes that the economic future for Yugoslavia lies in these things. It is encouraging."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE GREEN PARTY;
Under Fire From Democrats, Nader Assails Gore's Record

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
In the face of growing efforts by the Democratic Party and its allies to deflate his support, Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate for president, criticized Vice President Al Gore today more sharply than ever before, accusing him of repeatedly breaking promises to clean up the environment, help the poor and reform the federal government.
"Al Gore is suffering from election-year delusion if he thinks his record on the environment is anything to be proud of," Mr. Nader said at a packed news conference at the National Press Club. "He should be held accountable by voters for eight years of principles betrayed and promises broken." 
 Mr. Nader's remarks came as Mr. Gore's supporters in the liberal wing of the Democratic Party have mounted an aggressive campaign using rallies, television commercials and phone banks to dissuade people in several closely contested states from voting for Mr. Nader.
Today, for example, officials with the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League said the group would begin running television commercials in Portland, Ore., Minneapolis and Madison, Wis., late this week urging people who support abortion rights not to vote for Mr. Nader, on the premise that the election of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas would lead to a Supreme Court that would overturn those rights.
Mr. Nader said today that prominent Democrats and labor leaders, including Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, have urged him to quit the race. But he scoffed at the effort, saying it was merely helping him communicate his anti-corporate, pro-third-party message to disenchanted, disengaged voters.
"It's actually giving us greater publicity," he said. "Let these Democrats be more vociferous."
In his wry way, Mr. Nader seemed almost gleeful about the sudden burst of media attention his campaign had received. As he entered the news conference today, he glanced at the forest of microphones clipped to his lectern and joked, "There used to be a podium here." (There were more than 30 reporters and a dozen camera crews at the event, far more than usual for him.)
Mr. Nader also batted aside suggestions from some Democrats that he confine his campaigning to states where the race was not close, so he would not hurt Mr. Gore. Rather, he said, he planned to stump through several swing states over the next two weeks and hold major rallies in two of them: Wisconsin and Iowa.
Democratic Party officials and their allies in the labor, women's and environmental movements are concerned that Mr. Nader is drawing away just enough liberal voters in several states, including Minnesota, Oregon, Washington and Wisconsin, to threaten Mr. Gore's chances of winning the election.
For that reason, a number of prominent labor unions and interest groups, including Naral, the League of Conservation Voters, the Sierra Club and the Human Rights Campaign, the nation's largest gay and lesbian organization, have recently begun major campaigns to convince liberal voters that a vote for Mr. Nader is effectively a vote for Mr. Bush.
Naral's new commercial, for instance, warns that Mr. Bush's goal is "ending legal abortion" and concludes, "Before voting Nader, consider the risk."
Kate Michelman, Naral's president, said the group is considering running the spot in Maine, Michigan and Washington as well. And she said the organization had begun calling voters in swing states who support abortion rights to urge them to vote Democratic, not Green.
Most of those organizations have said liberals should vote for Mr. Gore because Bush appointments to the Supreme Court could pose a threat to causes like abortion rights. But today, Mr. Nader shrugged off that argument, asserting that some Democratic nominees to the court have compiled conservative voting records.
"I don't give the Democrats much credibility here," he said. He added that several respected justices, including Earl Warren, Harry A. Blackmun and David H. Souter, were nominated by Republican presidents.
Mr. Nader opened his news conference by attacking the Clinton administration as having failed to improve the condition of the poor. He argued that most low-income workers make less today in inflation-adjusted dollars than they did in the 1970's. And he called for raising the federal minimum wage to $8.50 an hour, from $5.15, repealing laws that restrict labor organizing and devoting much of the federal surplus to a "Marshall Plan" to rebuild cities.
"The cruel truth is that few of the benefits of a booming stock market and good economic times at the top have trickled down to millions of American families," he said.
But Mr. Nader quickly moved to a wide-ranging attack on Mr. Gore's environmental record, accusing the vice president of reneging on a host of pledges over the past eight years. Among them: failing to close a hazardous waste incinerator in Ohio, not pushing for higher fuel-efficiency standards in automobiles and allowing federal prosecution of environmental crimes to decline.
Kym Spell, a spokeswoman for the Gore campaign, said: "Voters who are informed about the issues know that big things are at stake in this election, like a woman's right to choose. The voters who care about these issues know that the differences between Al Gore and George Bush are like night and day."
During an extensive question-and-answer period, Mr. Nader said his campaign would actually help liberals fight for their causes by forcing the party's dominant centrist wing to pay more attention to them.
"Already the progressive wing of the Democratic Party suddenly is getting its calls returned by the right-wing Democratic Party operatives who are running that party into the ground as they morph it into a Republican Party impostor," he said.
He dismissed assertions that he might derail Mr. Gore's candidacy, paraphrasing David Letterman.
"Only Al Gore can beat Al Gore," Mr. Nader said. "And he's been doing a pretty good job of that. Up against one of the most bumbling, corporate-indentured, horrible- record Republican candidates, George W. Bush, and he's still in a neck-and-neck race."
 
In His Own Words
RALPH NADER
 
Remarks yesterday at the National Press Club, Washington:
 
"In the addresses and debates by George W. Bush and Al Gore, there are lots of references to the middle class -- the shrinking middle class, but they don't mention that it's shrinking. There is very little reference to the working poor in this country. Forty-seven million full-time American workers in this country are making less than $10 an hour, many of them at the federal minimum wage of $5.15 an hour, and the rest not much more.
The lack of affordable housing, the number of children who go to bed hungry every night and the more than 32 million Americans who live in poverty put the lie to the Gore-Lieberman claim of broad-based prosperity under the current administration's regime. Much like their Republican counterparts, Gore and Lieberman have great faith in the discredited concept of trickle-down economics.
But the cruel truth is that few of the benefits of a booming stock market and good economic times at the top have trickled down to millions of American families. Despite a decade of economic growth, the majority of the workers are making less today in inflation-adjusted dollars and working longer -- about 163 hours longer on the average -- than they did in the 1970's. Working longer, making less. "

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Battling for Tennessee, Gore Attacks Bush on Education

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Forced to campaign in his home state today, Vice President Al Gore framed his differences with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on education by emphasizing his commitment to the public schools while criticizing Mr. Bush's proposals as "half-measures" and his Texas record as "hollow."
After rallying their headquarters staff and attending a series of fund-raisers that brought in $4.3 million in Nashville on Tuesday night, Mr. Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, campaigned in two distinct media markets in central and western Tennessee today before the vice president flew to Kansas City for an evening rally. 
 It is disconcerting for the Gore campaign that the vice president cannot take Tennessee and its 11 electoral votes for granted at this point, and that the Democratic National Committee has had to invest money in advertising there. But Mr. Gore and his aides have argued that the vice president's roots in Carthage, Tenn., and his 24-year political career in the state cannot be expected to overcome its recent political domination by Republicans.
With Mr. Gore as his running mate, President Clinton won the state by only two percentage points in 1996 and by five percentage points in 1992. Its governor, both of its United States senators, and five of its nine members of Congress are Republicans.
"I think Tennessee always is a competitive state in national races," Mr. Gore said today in an interview with WTVF in Nashville. "This is a classic border swing state."
At a rally in Jackson, his grandmother's West Tennessee hometown, Mr. Gore asked how many relatives he had in the crowd and beamed when dozens of hands were raised.
"You know from your own experience that I want to fight for you," he said. "I have kept the faith with Tennessee. Now, here is what I'm asking from you. I am asking you to get out there in these next 13 days."
After summarizing his philosophy about the role of government on Tuesday, Mr. Gore turned his attention today to education in his address to students at Tennessee State University, a historically black college.
Mr. Gore outlined his proposals for using federal money to hire 100,000 new teachers, to reduce class sizes, to provide universal preschool to 4-year-olds, to provide families with tax deductions of up to $10,000 a year for college tuition, to force states and local school boards to change the administration of persistently failing schools and to increase testing of students and teachers.
But Mr. Gore devoted most of his remarks to arguing that Mr. Bush's support for private school vouchers would undermine public education, that his "budget-busting tax cuts for the wealthiest" demonstrate misplaced priorities and that the integrity of student testing in Texas was questionable.
Mr. Bush, he said, "would give more in tax cuts to the wealthiest 90,000 multimillionaires than he would give in the form of all the new investments he has proposed to make in all 90,000 public schools combined."
As he has throughout the campaign, Mr. Gore rejected the concept of vouchers, which would provide some parents of children in poor-performing schools with grants to send their children to private schools.
"Turning around failing schools isn't easy," he said. "Our public schools aren't perfect and can't always turn on a dime. But we all have a moral obligation as Americans to help them and improve them and defend them, not just walk away from them."
Dan Bartlett, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, said Mr. Gore's comments defined him as "the chief defender of the status quo in the public schools."
Mr. Gore laced his attack with provocative new metaphors. Mr. Bush's voucher plan, he said, would make Washington "a national private school headmaster." Because not all students would receive help from vouchers, the plan amounts to "education roulette," he said. Mr. Bush's opposition to spending federal money to hire thousands of new teachers, Mr. Gore added, "is like trying to write on a blackboard without any chalk."
Mr. Gore also used the speech to make his first remarks about a study released this week by the RAND Corporation, a research organization in Santa Monica, Calif., that raised questions about the effectiveness of student testing in Texas.
The study found that Texas students had demonstrated greater improvement in recent years on the state's Texas Assessment of Academic Skills exam than on the leading national assessment test. The report said these "stark differences" in performance raised "serious questions" about the credibility of the state test as a meaningful gauge of academic progress.
The report speculated that the state test scores might have been artificially inflated by, among other things, a practice known in educational circles as teaching to the test, or drilling that helps students prepare for specific types of questions but does not result in real learning.
Because Mr. Bush has made his educational record in Texas a hallmark of his campaign, the Gore forces have treated the RAND study as an October gift. Mr. Lieberman used it to attack Mr. Bush on Tuesday, and Mr. Gore took his turn today.
"This is the bottom line," Mr. Gore said. "We cannot afford to teach kids how to take a state test while leaving them with serious learning deficits. We cannot afford that kind of short-sighted shortcut in education policy any more than we can afford it in economic policy where we cannot afford to cook the books and bust our budget, leaving America with endless financial deficits."
Mr. Gore said practices like teaching to the test "might elevate the reputations of school administrators and politicians but actually do nothing to really raise standards."
 
In His Own Words
AL GORE
 
Remarks yesterday at Tennessee State University in Nashville:
"To me, education is all about raising standards and expanding choices. Raising standards to help our children learn more and ultimately earn more in this new economy. Providing choices so that parents can help their children do better and go further with their own hard work and initiative.
 We should let all of our families have the choice of high-quality preschool for their kids, by making preschool available and by making child care more accessible and refocusing it on learning and by making high-quality preschool available on a voluntary basis to every 4-year-old in America.
We should let all families have the choice of an excellent public school for their children with more public charter schools run by teachers and parents, free to adopt a cutting-edge curriculum and approach. And we should let every family have the chance and the choice of sending a son or daughter to college by making up to $10,000 a year of college tuition tax deductible.
Now, my opponent, Governor Bush, has a different approach because he has different priorities. He would give more in tax cuts to the wealthiest 90,000 multimillionaires than he would give in the form of all the new investments he has proposed to make in all 90,000 public schools combined. . . .
"There are only two real proposals of any substance in his entire education plan: private school vouchers and what he calls accountability. His vouchers, I believe, would actually harm education. And his claims to accountability rest on half-measures and a hollow record. In fact, the governor's private school vouchers would give no choice and no chance to the millions of children he would leave behind in failing schools.
I believe we have to change and improve our public schools, not walk away from them. I believe that it is wrong to drain away public money from public schools that educate 90 percent of American children.
Under the Bush plan, states would be forced to offer vouchers and finance them out of their budgets -- a brand new federal mandate -- whether states and local school districts like vouchers or not. . . . Governor Bush says he doesn't want a national superintendent of schools, but his mandatory voucher plan would make Washington, D.C., a national private school headmaster."

HEADLINE: In Last Days, Lazio Forced To Focus On Upstate

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25

 BODY:
When Rick A. Lazio arrived here for a Monroe County Republican reception this evening, he could be forgiven for feeling that he had been in these parts before. He had. Many times.
In fact, tonight's was the 22nd campaign appearance Mr. Lazio had made in upstate New York over six straight days: from Amherst to Syracuse, from Catskill to West Ghent (it's in Columbia County), and from Utica to Hornell. And he will be back next week. 
 With two weeks to go until Election Day, Mr. Lazio is devoting a great deal of attention to a part of New York that should be easy country for a Republican. And that is stirring concern among some of his supporters as the geographic forces that have traditionally shaped New York elections appear to be shifting this year -- and not necessarily to Mr. Lazio's advantage.
That this is happening is a result of Hillary Rodham Clinton's unusually aggressive effort over the last 15 months in a part of New York that Democrats have tended to neglect. It also reflects what Mr. Lazio's aides say were some miscalculations in his initial approach to upstate, in particular the assumption that Mrs. Clinton would not be received well north of Westchester County.
As a result, while Mr. Lazio is being pressed to spend the final days of this campaign in a region that should be solidly in his corner, Mrs. Clinton is comfortable enough about her Democratic support to spend relatively more time in competitive regions of the state, starting with the New York City suburbs. She is even finding time to venture onto what has been the Republican base: he was in Syracuse on Tuesday and so was Mrs. Clinton, delivering a speech on the economy. It was her third trip upstate in a week; she is planning a three-day upstate bus trip starting Saturday.
Mr. Lazio's advisers said the decision to devote so much time upstate was a sign of strength, not weakness, and reflected their confidence of his support in the suburbs. Mr. Lazio's senior campaign consultant, Mike Murphy, argued that the race would be decided largely upstate, and that the region is not as Republican as it once was.
"The upstate hasn't been Republican base country in 15 years," said Mr. Murphy. "It's swing country -- and it's swinging our way, and we're winning."
"Upstate is coming back strong," Mr. Murphy said. "We've got to watch it, but upstate is coming back."
But some senior New York Republicans sympathetic to Mr. Lazio's campaign, as well as some independent political analysts, said that Mr. Lazio should have nailed down upstate by now. They said that the need to tend to his base had emerged as a campaign-ending distraction that was pulling Mr. Lazio away from places where he might more profitably search for support.
"He's constantly in upstate New York -- constantly -- and that's really killing him," said one Republican strategist, who insisted on anonymity. "He's spending an inordinate time for this late in upstate New York, which prevents him from appealing to suburban voters."
Maurice Carroll, the director of the Quinnipiac University Poll, said Mr. Lazio was forced to head upstate now because he didn't do it earlier. "He has to do it," Mr. Carroll said. "She has worked her tail off upstate, and she has cut into the traditional overwhelming Republican preponderance up there."
Further, while Mr. Lazio's aides argued the candidate was keeping a presence in the suburbs through television advertisements, his relative physical absence from the metropolitan area has meant he is not getting the "free media" that comes with television news coverage. Most suburban voters get their news from the New York City television stations, which means that they have not been seeing much of Mr. Lazio.
At the same time, Mrs. Clinton has been a more regular presence on the news, because of her time spent in the metropolitan area and, not incidentally, the frequent visits by President Clinton, including a fund-raiser in Manhattan tonight.
Political analysts expect that in this election, about 45 percent of the vote will come from upstate New York, 31 percent will come from the suburban counties and 24 percent from New York City. Based on those figures, Mr. Lazio's aides said that in order to counteract the advantage Mrs. Clinton would gain in New York City, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, he needed to draw at least 55 percent of the upstate vote.
But pollsters who have been following the race say that Mr. Lazio has yet to assure himself of that margin. Thus, it was no surprise that Mr. Lazio, after flying back to New York to attend the third game of the World Series on Tuesday, hopped back on his campaign jet for the Monroe County G.O.P. Annual Pre-Victory Grazing tonight. An aide said that he would spend "the vast bulk" of his time between now and Election Day in upstate New York.
Part of what is going on reflects the change in electoral politics in New York. As Mr. Murphy noted, upstate is not as reliably Republican as it once was; Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, won 45 percent of the vote upstate, when he defeated Alfonse M. D'Amato for a fourth term in 1998, by 8 percentage points statewide. (Mr. Schumer won 74 percent of the vote in the city, which is higher than anyone expects Mrs. Clinton to do, and 48 percent of the suburban vote.)
Mr. Schumer, in an interview, argued that upstate voters no longer automatically view Democrats as loyal advocates for New York City, and thus foes of upstate, as they once did. And while Mrs. Clinton is not from New York State, as Mr. Lazio has noted with some regularity, she is not from New York City either.
By contrast, Mr. Lazio assumed -- incorrectly, Mr. Schumer argued -- that a Long Island native would not be viewed as another downstate candidate, and thus would be quickly embraced in a way that Rudolph W. Giuliani was not, when he was the Republican candidate for Senate. For a long time, Mr. Lazio's television advertisements included a shot of him walking on a Long Island beach with his family. He dropped the scene at the urging of some Republicans who said that it was hurting him among upstate voters.
Mr. Lazio also let the summer pass without nailing down his position upstate, notwithstanding advice from some New York Republicans that he should, in the words of one, have "camped out" upstate in August. "Upstate has been the battleground all along: Lazio just came to the war late," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie.
At the same time, while Mrs. Clinton was talking about the upstate economy at every opportunity -- she even gave a speech to business leaders in Manhattan asserting that it was in their interest to invest upstate -- Mr. Lazio declared at a debate that the upstate economy had "turned the corner," an assertion that was questioned by some Republicans and newspaper editorial writers.
For their part, Mr. Lazio's advisers argued that Mrs. Clinton would end up doing relatively poorly in New York City, because of what they asserted was a lack of enthusiasm about her among many Democrats. In particular, they are hoping that reservations about her among Jewish voters there will lead many Democrats to either skip the Senate race or vote for Mr. Lazio when they come to vote for president. And Mrs. Clinton's aides are concerned that the absence of Mr. Giuliani on the ballot will result in a lower turnout among black voters, who, they said, would have turned out in greater numbers against the mayor.
"Her numbers are not quite as good as they appear on the surface," said Bill Dal Col, Mr. Lazio's campaign manager. Still, Mr. Lazio's aides acknowledge that the place to watch is upstate. And there, pollsters and political analysts say, voters are very familiar with Mrs. Clinton, while uncertain about Mr. Lazio, who remains something of an unknown quanity -- even to those who, by now, should be pledging their allegiance to him.
"She has really worked hard to convince people that they can trust her," said Donna Colangelo, a 38-year-old cashier at a convenience store near Utica, who described herself as a lifelong Republican, a note of admiration in her voice. "I don't think he's been as aggressive as she is. But he still has time."
