HEADLINE: Sensor Fish Brave the Bumps to Tame Dams for Young Salmon

BYLINE: By HENRY FOUNTAIN 

 BODY:
FOR a young salmon, spawned on the upper reaches of the Columbia or Snake Rivers in the Pacific Northwest and determined to make it to the Pacific Ocean, a trip through one of the rivers many hydroelectric dams is like a ride on a bad roller coaster with a giant blender thrown in for good measure. Severe pressure changes as the fish travels through the dam can leave it stunned and disoriented, easy prey for other fish and birds once it gets through. And the spinning turbine blades that power the electric generators can kill the fish.
Over the years, the Army Corps of Engineers and state and federal wildlife agencies have tried to help juvenile fish avoid this wild ride altogether. Screens have been built near turbine intakes to divert fish into bypass channels. Barges and tanker trucks have been used to give young salmon a lift past the dams. 
 Despite these efforts, millions of unlucky fish inevitably end up going through the turbines. So some scientists have focused their attention on making the ride a less lethal one. And theyve developed a unique tool -- what might be called bionic salmon.
These fake fish, developed by the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, which is managed by the Department of Energy, contain tiny sensors and other electronics to measure stress and strain as they flow through the dam (they don't swim). The goal, said Dr. Thomas J. Carlson, who manages the project for the laboratory, is to understand the conditions the fish encounter. "If you know those, you can go back and design turbines for safer fish passage," he said.
The idea of creating the fish came up about a decade ago, Dr. Carlson said, "but it's only in the last three or five years that the technology has been available to build something like this."
The fish, which are about six inches long and, in the earliest versions, coated in rubber, include accelerometers that can measure the effect of the turbulence, the pressure changes and the shearing forces that occur as the fish are bounced and buffeted through the turbine and through an outflow tunnel, called a draft tube.
The sensor data are stored in memory chips and downloaded later when the fish are recovered. To aid retrieval, the fish have tiny air bags, which inflate to carry them to the surface, and tiny transmitters that help researchers find them.
So far the sensor fish have been used at Bonneville Dam, the last one that fish encounter on their way to the sea, to test whether a new turbine design there is effective in protecting fish. Since many fish that are injured in turbines are caught in the gaps between the blades and the turbine walls, the new design has narrower gaps to make it safer for the fish.
The number of fish killed or injured by the blades of any of the turbines along the river is actually quite small, Dr. Carlson said, between 2 percent and 4 percent. Of greater concern is what happens in the turbulent water of the draft tube. Using the sensor fish, the researchers have found that where a fish ends up in the tube is often determined by where it enters the turbine, and that a fish is better off in some parts of the tube than in others. "Were just starting now to look at a redesign of the draft tube," Dr. Carlson said.
The sensor fish are also being used to measure the turbulence in the bypass channels that are intended to keep the fish out of the turbines. These channels, called high-volume outfalls, are essentially small rivers, Dr. Carlson said, and are often designed so the water cascades violently back into the river. The battering and froth that produces can hurt the fish.
Outfall designs will have to change to protect more fish, Dr. Carlson said. "Were looking at outfalls that will allow water to come out and skim along the surface and not plunge deep."
The sensor fish studies are just a small part of what has been a long and expensive effort to protect salmon and steelhead on the Columbia and Snake, both the juveniles moving downstream to the sea and adults traveling upstream to spawn. For all the billions of dollars spent, the effort has not been particularly successful: some species on the rivers are extinct, and others are endangered.
For some environmentalists and others, the only solution is to demolish four of the Snake River dams. The Clinton administration has considered this proposal, but recently postponed any decision for at least five years. Critics of that plan say that tearing down the dams will not save the fish and will harm the region's economy.
It's not clear to Dr. Carlson that the dams are responsible for most of the problem. "It could be the way that the bypass systems are being operated," he said. Transporting young fish to the ocean on barges, for example, may get them to the ocean too soon and interfere with their development.
What is clear to Dr. Carlson is the need to continue research with tools like the sensor fish so the system can be improved. "The focus is increasingly on finetuning elements of this fish-management capability," he said.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Drawings (Frank OConnell/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Fishing for Data in Turbulent Waters
Researchers and engineers at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory have developed sensor fish to help them measure the forces that young salmon encounter when they travel through hydroelectric dams on the Columbia and Snake Rivers.
 
A trip through the turbines
Fish usually travel through an inlet pipe down through the spinning hydroelectric turbine, then into the draft tube and eventually back into the river. The sensor fish are inserted through a tube directly into the turbine area.
 
CIRCUIT BOARDS
The fish contain microprocessors and circuitry on their circuit boards to convert the analog signals from their sensors into digital data. They also have memory chips for data storage, output cables for downloading data to a computer and tiny transmitters, which help researchers find the fish more easily
once they are through the dam.
 
AIR BAGS
A gas-creating mixture of chemicals slowly inflates the bags as each fish travels through the dam so that when it reaches the downstream side of the dam, it bobs to the surface for retrieval. A few fish were lost after the bags were torn off so metal rings are now used to attach them.
 
ACCELEROMETERS
Three accelerometers, each oriented along a different axis, measure the forces acting on each fish as it moves through the water to help determine how it is buffeted by turbulence.
 
STRAIN GAUGE
A gauge is used to measure how much the fish bends in the middle, between the circuit boards.
 
BATTERY PACK
The fish's electronics run on standard AAA batteries.
 
EXTERIOR
Early versions of the fish had a rubber coating, but later models have a harder shell made of polycarbonate. Some fish have been painted orange to make them easier to spot.
 
Chart also shows the TURBINE, DRAFT TUBE, WATER INLET PIPE, GENERATOR, POWER INDICATOR, PROCESSOR, MEMORY MODULE, OUTPUT CABLES, and the INLET PIPE FOR PRESSURE GAUGE.
 
(Source: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Are Bush and Gore flip-flopping over how to manage the economy?

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a new collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." Mr. Madrick, Virginia Postrel, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
JUST after the political conventions this summer, it looked as if America had a clear-cut choice about how the economy should be managed. About $2.7 trillion of the projected $4.6 trillion in surpluses over the next 10 years are estimated to be generated by Social Security and Medicare. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas favored giving most of the rest -- some $1.3 trillion -- back to Americans in the form of a tax cut.
Vice President Al Gore wanted to spend roughly $350 billion of it on a Medicare-based prescription drug plan for the elderly, but much of the rest, he said, should be devoted to a litany of programs for America's "working families." Mr. Gore bolted out of the Democratic convention with a ratings lead. 
 Since then, however, the vice president has made a rhetorical course correction. He started emphasizing the fiscal discipline of his agenda and referred less to what he would do for working families. Today, it would be hard to find a man or woman on the street aware of Mr. Gore's most interesting social proposals, including his provocative program to provide up to $200 billion in a program to help middle-income people accumulate long-term savings.
"He backed away from a full-throated emphasis on working families," says Ruy Texeira, co-author with Joel Rogers of "America's Forgotten Majority" (Basic Books, 2000). "And in the process, he muddied his vision of how to make the new economy work for these families."
Now, of course, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore are about dead even in many polls.
In truth, once we had a closer look at Mr. Gore's budget proposal, it was clear that he had locked himself into a stingier program than his convention rhetoric suggested. He earmarked the Social Security and Medicare surpluses -- $2.7 trillion -- to pay down most of America's federal debt. He set aside another $300 billion as a cushion because the surpluses were no sure thing. Chalk up about $3 trillion, therefore, or 65 percent of the projected surplus, to demonstrate fiscal probity.
Working with a smaller pie, Mr. Gore also gave precedence to the elderly over working families. The Social Security and Medicare surpluses would be placed in a "lock box" so they could not be spent. The prescription drug proposal was his largest social program by far, and some complained that even it was too restrictive. That left $1 trillion or so for other social programs, or $100 billion a year, including his own tax cut. He only proposed another $115 billion for education over 10 years, for example.
Despite that, Mr. Gore came up with several enticing ideas. He proposed to spend $200 billion to match the savings of middle- and lower-income Americans, which he called Retirement Savings Plus. A couple earning $25,000 a year, for example, could put away $500 and receive another $1,500 from the government. The federal match would decline as incomes rose.
Mr. Gore proposed universal schooling for preschoolers and tuition tax credits -- solid new economy ideas. He wanted a higher minimum wage and a more generous earned-income tax credit. His tax cuts in general were aimed more at middle- and lower-income workers than Mr. Bush's.
But once Mr. Bush started accusing Mr. Gore of being a big spender and stressing a few social programs of his own, the tone of the campaign changed. One of the first hints was that the Gore campaign started using the term "middle-class families" instead of "working families."
In the 1980's and early 1990's, politicians made hay over the middle-class fear that social programs, especially for the poor, were eating into their standard of living. Apparently, Mr. Gore did not want to rekindle those fears, even though most American families, not just the poor, were still strained by stagnating incomes and more hours of work.
As part of the new plan, he also spent a lot of time criticizing Mr. Bush's budget plans. And Mr. Bush certainly appeared vulnerable. His stimulative tax cuts were proposed at the height of the business cycle, when they might have been most inflationary. The governor also refused to be specific about how he would pay for his Social Security privatization plan -- estimated to cost $1 trillion. Mr. Gore must have thought that he would strike gold, but so far it is lead.
How good are Mr. Gore's own fiscally conservative economics? A strong case can be made that paying down some of America's debt -- that is to say, not spending all of the projected surplus -- makes economic sense. It may raise scarce savings when the nation is overly dependent on borrowing from overseas to meet its capital needs.
But the tax increases under former President George Bush and President Clinton, along with federal spending cuts of the early 1990's, were also intended to raise national savings. What happened instead was that, while the government reduced its deficit, individual Americans saved less and borrowed more. Over all, national saving has not risen appreciably to this day.
The true benefit of the tax increases and spending cuts, it turned out, was that they calmed investors, who bought bonds and sent interest rates lower. Today, the nation simply does not have to pay off the entire national debt, as Mr. Gore wants to do, to retain investors' confidence.
Do working families really want help from government? Daniel Cohen has little doubt. As executive director of New York's small Working Families Party, Mr. Cohen brings blue-collar white workers together with inner-city black and Hispanic workers to find common economic ground.
Mr. Cohen says that issues like capital punishment and police brutality often divide his members, but on issues like investment in education, healthcare and a living wage, they rally together. The two-year-old party's organizational strength has been influential in local elections across the state.
The new economy has new needs, including better education, more accessible child care, flexible work hours and higher wages for lower-income workers. If Mr. Gore loses the election, it will be wrong to say he overemphasized social spending. To the contrary, he doggedly tried to prove he was a fiscal conservative -- and confused his message in the process.

HEADLINE: Visit Revises Image of North Korean

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PYONGYANG, North Korea, Oct. 25

 BODY:
When Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright landed here this week, the Clinton administration had closely watched what it viewed as the erratic and threatening behavior of the leader, Kim Jong Il, for more than six years.
A series of crises that concerned the North Korean nuclear program and its ability to build and launch long-range missiles had driven Washington to believe that the reclusive Mr. Kim was determined to destabilize the North Asian region and, possibly, attack the United States. 
 After negotiating with Mr. Kim over two days, Dr. Albright and her team of North Korea specialists who left the country this morning said they had come away with a different impression. They found, they said, a leader who could be reasoned with and keeps up on events through the Internet and CNN and who has traveled to China, India and Russia.
The assessment of Mr. Kim toward the end of this visit is vastly more positive than it was several months ago, when there was considerable disbelief in Washington, and even some quiet scoffing, at similar descriptions given by President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea after his visit to North Korea in June.
In one of the many conversations with the secretary that ranged over subjects like his annual viewing of the Oscars -- presumably by videotape -- Mr. Kim said he was examining alternatives to his Communist economy. Specifically, he said he liked the Swedish model.
As the Americans try to fathom what has prompted what is apparently Mr. Kim's new readiness to abandon his missile program on conditions that would be acceptable to the United States, the central theme of the talks here, they have come up with two basic reasons: the economic survival of a country that is teetering on the brink of collapse and the survival of his own dictatorship.
"I think he's beginning to think about how to sustain his economy over time," a senior administration official said. "He has some understanding that missile exports, although they obviously bring in hard currency, also produce problems for him."
Most significantly, the official added, Mr. Kim apparently understood that maintaining a hard-line posture on his missile program and exports prevented any possibility of a relationship with the United States.
The Americans said they believed that Mr. Kim, who inherited the leadership from his father, Kim Il Sung, who died six years ago, needs to shore up his vulnerabilities. He runs a country where the 1.1 million-member military wields a disproportionate degree of authority. But as the indulged child of a powerful man, he never worked his way up through the ranks.
Whether Mr. Kim, whom officials said they found smart but far from being a creative thinker, will actually put into effect any economic changes remains a question. Improving the economy would mean opening the country to foreign investors, much as China has done. But that is a move that could produce profound shocks in one of the most isolated countries in the world.
Asked whether Mr. Kim understood the implications of opening his society to the Internet and a global economy, the administration official replied, "I think that is, in part, why this will be a slow process."
In preparing for Dr. Albright's visit here, possibly the prelude to a trip by President Clinton before he leaves office, Washington has had to build on the little that it knows about Mr. Kim. At home, his life story is murky and subject to wild rumors.
Despite hagiography that insists that he was born in a log cabin on a legendary mountaintop, American officials said they believed that Mr. Kim was born in a military camp in the Far East of the Soviet Union in 1942, when his father was fighting Japanese troops. Mr. Kim's father moved back to Korea at the end of World War II, heading the Korean Communist Party in the Soviet-occupied North and becoming its leader after 1948, when a Communist-led republic was proclaimed, until his death in 1994.
The younger Mr. Kim was educated in Pyongyang, the capital, and graduated from university in political economy, essentially a degree in Marxism-Leninism.
Kim Jong Il then began to rise through the ranks of the Communist Party and was put in charge of agitprop and then the all-important personnel department. In 1980, he was proclaimed the successor to his father, and granted the title of Dear Leader, close but not quite the same as the title of Great Leader that belongs to the senior Mr. Kim.
In his rise to power, rumors abounded about his love affairs. North Korea experts said they believed that he has an official wife, Ko Yong Hui, and that he has had other wives and children with them. There was no sign of a wife at the social occasions with Dr. Albright. But he has told visitors that he has children in their 20's.
Many of the anecdotes about Mr. Kim's personal life came from a South Korean actress and her former husband who were kidnapped in Hong Kong and taken to North Korea on Mr. Kim's orders. After their escape from the North, that couple publicized accounts about Mr. Kim's extravagant spending on movie productions and on his love for luxury, including Mercedes-Benzes.
Those accounts, combined with intelligence reports that implicated Mr. Kim in the bombing of a South Korean airliner and other terrorist acts, encouraged the impression that Mr. Kim was somehow dissolute and, perhaps, a little unstable.
The Americans were apparently relieved to find now that this was not the case. Anyway, they argue, as a senior administration official said today, that the issues of North Korea's building missiles and encouraging nuclear proliferation were too "important to say glibly: 'This guy is kooky. He's out of this world. Who could possibly deal with him?' "
After 12 hours of dealing with him, undoubtedly on his best behavior, the Americans found that there was nothing obviously odd about him. But they also recognized that the enormous cult of personality that surrounds Mr. Kim means that he is treated as an infallible leader, who by definition finds it difficult to make change quickly.
At the core of a change in North Korea's strategic posture is the start of reconciliation with South Korea, a process that began with the visit of President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea to Pyongyang in the summer.
How much investment North Korea welcomes from the South will be one measure of Mr. Kim's intentions. Perhaps more important will be the movement that the two sides make in having their militaries reduce tensions between them.
The Americans said they tried to explain to Mr. Kim some basics about the American political system so that he would understand that the White House, as it considers proposals about how to finalize North Korea's missile contraction, did not act in a vacuum. He was told by Dr. Albright that the administration would consult Congress and its allies and try to build support as it considered any quid pro quo for North Korea to abandon its missiles.
Mr. Kim, who does not speak English nor appear to understand it, asked Dr. Albright few political, cultural or social questions about the United States. But toward the end of their first meeting, he did ask Dr. Albright whether she had just seen coverage of their meetings on CNN. She had not. But he had, presumably with the help of an interpreter.

HEADLINE: Once a Monopoly and Still a Threat

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
The telecommunications dispute between the United States and Mexico that has simmered for most of this year involves pennies. But since those pennies add up to hundreds of millions of dollars a year in interconnection fees, this has become one of the thorniest trade squabbles to test relations between the two nations.
American trade officials have gone so far as to threaten to drag Mexico before the World Trade Organization to force Mexican regulators to level the playing field for competitors, including some with American partners, that are seeking part of the country's $12 billion telecommunications market. 
 There has been a bit of detente recently. Mexican officials agreed early this month to lower interconnection rates, fees charged to long-distance companies by local carriers, to 1.25 cents a minute from 3.36 cents. And last month they put new rules into effect that could force Telefonos de Mexico, the former national phone monopoly widely known as Telmex, to more strongly embrace open competition.
So United States officials have decided to hold off action. A 60-day waiting period for proceeding with the W.T.O. complaint ended on Oct. 17 and the trade officials decided not to go ahead with the complaint -- at least not now.
But tensions remain. "If we don't feel that our concerns are being adequately addressed," said Brendan Daly, a spokesman for the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, "we have the right to bring a case before the W.T.O. and we will not hesitate to do so."
Telmex has agreed to honor the new rates, but the company has challenged them in the Mexican courts. The rules enable regulators to treat dominant companies like Telmex differently from smaller companies to foster competition.
Carrying out the new regulations "would result in higher prices for consumers while depriving them of the benefits of Telmex's increased productivity," the company said in a statement. "The only beneficiaries will be the competing companies, which will be able to increase profits because of undeserved advantages that actually harm the national interests."
United States officials think that Telmex still looks and acts too much like a monopoly. They say that in the years that the Mexican long-distance phone market has been open to competition, Telmex first lost, then began regaining market share. It now controls 81 percent of long-distance customers, up from a low around 70 percent. It also, they say, has more than 95 percent of the market for local phone service, which was opened to competition last year.
As the cross-border dispute continues, one of the handful of competing local phone service start-up companies in Mexico, Axtel, has added a twist -- accusing the rival companies with United States partners of doing their best to stifle competition by using some of the tactics for which they are criticizing Telmex.
"We've been caught in the middle of a battle," said Carlos Escalante, director of regulatory affairs for Axtel, which provides local phone service in Monterrey and Mexico City. Axtel phones are wireless and quickly installed because they are not connected to the existing copper-line grid.
The two American-related long-distance companies are Alestra, in which AT&T holds a 49 percent ownership stake, and Avantel which has WorldCom as a 45 percent partner. They entered the Mexican market in 1997, seven years after Telmex was first sold to private owners, and have invested heavily to build networks all over the country.
They say they are struggling to become profitable in part because Telmex has used its position as the dominant local and long-distance carrier in Mexico to hinder competition and persuade government regulators to act in its favor. Specifically, they say that Telmex has occasionally refused to provide access to its network or sometimes provided lines of inferior quality. And until recently, they complained that Telmex charged excessive interconnection fees.
All long-distance companies pay local carriers for the originating and terminating parts of calls they handle. Thus, under the old rates, Telmex could receive 3.36 cents a minute for a long-distance call made on its lines, and 3.36 cents a minute more if the call ended in one of its local-service areas.
Alestra and Avantel had accused Telmex of ignoring international conventions, signed by Mexican officials, that are intended to keep such rates as low as possible to encourage competition. Further, they say Mexican regulators have in large part ignored the issue.
Regulators in the United States and Mexico both say this is a public policy question, not just a matter of corporate interests. Despite the privatization of Telmex, the arrival of competing companies and a sharp increase in Internet use, Mexico remains one of the world's least wired nations, with about 10 lines for each 100 people, compared with 60 per 100 in the United States.
AT&T and WorldCom have aggressively made their cases known to Mexican and American officials, and have dogged the office of the United States trade representative.
The complaint from Axtel against Alestra and Avantel has received less attention.
Axtel, which competes with Telmex on the local level, contends that Alestra and Avantel are not taking into account the impact that lower interconnection fees can have on Telmex's local-service competitors. Axtel officials say they based their business plans on fees as high as 5 cents a minute -- a level needed, they say, to generate enough resources to help them grow and significantly increase the number of phone lines. They also say Alestra and Avantel have so far refused to sign interconnection contracts with their company.
In a statement in March, Axtel officials accused Alestra and Avantel of trying to restrain the opening of Mexico's telecommunications market. "Instead of encouragement, Axtel and other independent telcos now face interconnection obstacles that have been thrown up by the very carriers that have unfurled the banner of competition in Mexico," the statement said.
Jim Talbot, a lawyer at AT&T, Alestra's partner, said he found it hard to understand Axtel's argument. "Mexico made commitments two years ago to open its market and it simply has not done so," he said. Mr. Talbot added that Alestra had agreed to route the calls from Axtel customers through its long-distance network even without a formal contract so service would not be disrupted.
The American companies point out that Axtel has its own foreign partner, Bell Canada International, which also recently entered into a Latin American joint venture with Telmex. (The regional Bell giant SBC Communications owns 8.5 percent of Telmex.)
"We don't have to speculate a lot, then, to see that there is a connection in their relationship," Raul Ortega, an Alestra spokesman, said of Axtel, Bell Canada and Telmex.
But Mr. Escalante of Axtel said it was absurd to think that his company was shilling for Telmex. "In this time of alliances, mergers and acquisitions, everybody has a relationship with everybody else," he said. "But Telmex has no common ground with us."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 40; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"GIORGIO ARMANI," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 17). The Guggenheim has served up another plateau of urban history: a retrospective of the Milanese fashion designer Giorgio Armani. What it lacks in depth it makes up for with sparkle, and Robert Wilson's architectural transformation of the museum's rotunda may be the best yet. In an inverted version of a life class, instead of the undraped body, the show offers just the drapes. The mannequins have been pared down to the edges of the costumes, and they cluster in groups in the building's structural bays, spatial modules with the proportions of shop windows. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 students and the elderly (Herbert Muschamp). 

 "A BRUSH WITH NATURE: THE GERE COLLECTION OF LANDSCAPE OIL SKETCHES," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Nov. 12). Most of the artists in this show -- English, French, Italian, German, Belgian and Scandinavian, from the 17th to the 19th centuries -- are barely known today. In their own age they did something quite offbeat: they left studios to paint outdoors, registering transient moments of light and atmosphere by sketching quickly in oil from nature. Until recently it was assumed that this plein-air approach, used to train hand and eye for more ambitious compositions, began with the Impressionists. Mostly painted in Rome and the surrounding countryside, the works capture such painterly events as the seamed face of a rock, the rush of water through a valley, the play of sunlight on a ruin, the quirky architecture of a building or a wall. Tune your eye to small when you look at this show, and you'll find it a treasure. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students (over 10) and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 * "THE CHINESE PAINTER AS POET," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through Dec. 10.) In China, painting, poetry and calligraphy were the dream team of art: the "three perfections," they were called. Any truly evolved person was adept at each, and discussion of any of them was framed in the same terms: rhythm, touch, tone, spiritual energy. This eloquent exhibition examines the three-way partnership through some four dozen paintings, several of them of the first rank, ranging in date from the Song dynasty (960-1279) through the 20th century. In many cases the artist has inscribed his own poem on the surface of his painting in what amounts to a virtuoso multimedia solo performance. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays and Thursdays, until 8 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with hand-written words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that to non-Chinese speakers can all too easily seem unapproachable. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students 12 and older and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 "AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART," 2 Lincoln Square, at West 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Jan. 7). This show celebrates the largess of Mr. Nelson, a book editor and folk art collector, who has given 113 objects to the museum with the promise of more. The works, from the late-18th to the mid-20th centuries, cover the traditional areas of folk art -- portraits, landscapes, sculptures, painted and decorated furniture -- but the focus is on American needlework: quilts, coverlets, blankets and the like. Among the quilt spectaculars is the "Samuel Steinberger Log Cabin Quilt, Courthouse Steps Variation," by a 19th-century immigrant. Painted furniture, too, shines in this show. The painting and sculpture pieces make a more modest impression, but over all, what's on view represents a refined, solid ensemble that is very visitable. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Glueck).
 
 "HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Dec. 31). The complex cultural amalgam of music, poetry, break-dancing, art and fashion that is hip-hop poses a serious challenge to any art museum, but with the proper resources and curatorial expertise, it could have been done. Instead this show offers a partial outline of hip-hop history, conveyed by photographs, posters, magazine and album covers, memorabilia and monotonous expanses of clothes that make the show nearly indistinguishable from the gift shop. Garnished with graffiti art, it bypasses many other equally interesting connections to contemporary art. Because the show omits music videos, it manages to be virtually devoid of the sounds, words and moving bodies that are the essence of hip-hop. The results are a cross between a mall and a mausoleum. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 "IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS: AFRICAN ART FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ETHNOLOGY IN LISBON," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Dec. 31). The more than 140 objects on view relate to the secular and the supernatural in African culture: masks, power figures, dolls, decorated stools and chairs, pipes, posts and other artifacts. Outstanding is a group of initiation masks made from wood and more fragile materials like feathers, fabrics and barkcloth fibers. Ranging from fierce to benign in expression, they are giddily imaginative. Impressive, too, is a selection of dolls, important in the socialization of girls, from the Ambo people of southwestern Angola. The objects in the show were chosen for their high aesthetic value, and it doesn't disappoint. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly; free on Sundays (Glueck).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).
 
 "MOROCCO: JEWS AND ART IN A MUSLIM LAND," Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Feb. 11). When Arab Muslims arrived in Morocco, Jews had already been living there for centuries, and the two cultures formed a cooperative and uneasy bond. Their relationship is explored in this exhibition, which offers a little bit of many things, mostly dating from the 19th and 20th centuries. In elaborate jewelry, shimmery textiles, liturgical objects and folk amulets, Jewish and Islamic ingredients often form a distinctive hybrid blend. A selection of European Orientalist paintings, by Delacroix among others, provide a firsthand outsider view of a once-vibrant interaction. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students over 11 and the elderly (Cotter)
 
 "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000," the year-and-a-half-long millennium-marking rethinking of the Modern's permanent collection, is off and running, with the first of three staggered floor-through sections in place. The dates covered are 1960 to the present, so there's some sense of how a bastion of modernism is dealing with a postmodern world. Pretty well, judging from recent acquisitions of work by Pipilotti Rist, Matthew Barney and Cai Guo-Qiang. The real interest is in smart theme shows that play with such contemporary fixations as childhood innocence and adult experience, and the blend of art, abjection and design. (The third-floor galleries open on Nov. 5.) Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 "PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 7). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but this beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4.). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21.). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above ( Cotter).
 
 * EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 4). A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organized aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
DAN FLAVIN, Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Nov. 4). Flavin's simple fluorescent-light works from the 60's illuminate this posh new gallery to simultaneously matter-of-fact and mystically radiant effect. The white ones have classic Minimalist rigor; examples consisting of just two or three colors are almost hedonistically sumptuous (Johnson).
 
 "REMBRANDT AND THE VENETIAN INFLUENCE," Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through Nov. 18). The Venetian influence in Rembrandt's later paintings has long been noted; this show is an attempt to demonstrate by specific examples. But the topic is more suited to a museum presentation; this one mounts only a dozen paintings, three by Rembrandt and one labeled "Studio of Rembrandt," along with oils by Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese. It is too small and catch-as-catch can to make the case. The most salient example here of Venice in Rembrandt is his great painting "Flora" (circa 1654). Next to it, the other works in this show pale (Glueck).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
* JACQUES HENRI LARTIGUE, Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through Nov. 4). This magical exhibition of more than 60 vintage prints was drawn from the private collection of the French photographer's widow, who died last May. Concentrating mostly on small, wonderfully lively pictures made when he was a teenager, it vividly conveys his boyish enthusiasm for childhood games and horseplay, his fascination with flying, racing cars and fashionable women, and his excitement about the miracle of photography itself (Johnson).
 
 TABITHA VEVERS, "Flying Dreams," Kraushaar, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 307-5730 (through Nov. 11). Updating medieval manuscript illumination, Ms. Vevers combines handwritten texts and deftly painted narrative imagery to document dreams of flight, her own and those of friends. One of these small, mysterious works illustrates the artist's dream of running a seaside flying school for babies, who are equipped with little golden parachutes (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
DAVID RABINOWITCH, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Nov. 18). Restricting his vocabulary to circles, ovals and straight lines, and his means to pencil, ink or colored pencil, this Constructivist-Minimalist sculptor produced this series of extremely spare drawings during the early 1970's. Called "Construction of Vision," they are resolutely abstract and quasi-scientific. But the ellipses and angled lines, cleanly drawn with mechanical drafting tools, have a subtly playful animation (Johnson).
 
 CHRIS VERENE, American Fine Arts, 22 Wooster Street, (212) 941-0401 (through Nov. 11) and Paul Morris, 465 West 23rd Street, (212) 727-2752 (through tomorrow) With often piercing intimacy, this 31-year-old photographer chronicles the lives of friends and relatives in his hometown of Galesburg, Ill. Each of 60 richly colored, squarish images in this two-gallery show has a brief handwritten text added by the artist. Under the picture of a cousin, Steve, and his young daughter at a McDonald's, the text says, "His wife had just left them to go to a battered woman's shelter." A dozen prints, at Paul Morris, tenderly document the daily existence of Mr. Verene's grandfather (Johnson).
 
 CINDY WORKMAN, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through Nov. 4). Laminated to the reverse side of Plexiglas panels that are attached to the wall by heavy bolts, Ms. Workman's layered, digitalized montages of found imagery -- little girls, scientific or technical diagrams, girly cartoons and old smut photographs -- meditate on innocence, experience, consumerism and modernity (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
ROE ETHRIDGE, Andrew Kreps, 516-A West 20th Street, (212) 741-8849 (through Nov. 4). Mr. Ethridge's clever orchestration of his own almost hallucinogenically clear photographs includes portraits of UPS delivery men in their trucks, head shots of two pretty young female models, close-up studies of young pine trees and a big picture of an ambulance that had just crashed. Believe it or not, these disparate images are persuasively connected by the theme of perfection and its tragic impossibility (Johnson).
 
 DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111 (through Dec. 16). Welcome to the Damien Hirst Universe. It's a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 SHARON LOCKHART, Barbara Gladstone, 515 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9300 (through Nov. 4). This cerebral photographer accompanied two anthropologists to former rubber-producing regions in Brazil where she photographed the humble dwellings of villagers and rephotographed their family snapshots. Both are presented in groups in the gallery. Another series of large color prints show a worker repairing the glossy stone floor of an archaeological museum in Mexico. It is all about "the ethnographic gaze" and it makes one feel perplexed and defensive (Johnson).
 
 SCOTT RICHTER AND BILL SMART, Elizabeth Harris, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 463-9666 (through Nov. 11). In opposite but equally engaging ways these two artists address basic elements of painting. Mr. Richter piles up paint into great heaping stacks of viscous color, exaggerating its sumptuous materiality to the point of absurdity. Mr. Smart reduces paint to almost pure primary colors in a series of square monochromes that have rounded corners and white circles like punch holes, giving Minimalism a subtle Pop spin (Johnson).
 
 ALEXIS ROCKMAN, Gorney Bravin + Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through Nov. 11). Inspired by a trip into South American jungles, Mr. Rockman's Pop-realist paintings depict a Northerner's lurid fantasies of tropical adventure and danger. One shows the artist himself gripped in the tentacles of a man-eating plant; another portrays him surrounded by parasites and dangerous fish. Something political about tourism is implied, but the satire is less biting than it should be, and the painting looks like overblown magazine illustration (Johnson).
 
 JANE AND LOUISE WILSON, 303 Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-1121 (through Nov. 4). The British twin-sister video makers here direct their haunting ultraformalist vision to sites of post-cold-war resonance: two centers of research, training and development for the Russian space program. Focusing mostly on architecture and high-tech equipment, their four projections take you on a mesmerizing Cubistic journey through places that seem at once futuristic and dilapidated, a mix of "2001: A Space Odyssey" and "Blade Runner" (Johnson).
 
 RANDY WRAY, Derek Eller, 526-30 West 25th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through Nov. 11). To make his oddly confounding paintings, Mr. Wray first creates a funky, coffee table-scale abstract sculpture that he then photographs; the photograph is in turn digitally transformed into a kind of paint-by-numbers diagram that the artist copies in paint using brushes and various sorts of extruders, adding three-dimensional canvas elements as well. The final products are ambiguously suggestive and slightly creepy, hovering between pixilated abstraction and surrealism (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"REDRAWING THE LINE," Art in General, 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-0473 (through Oct. 28). This unfocused show of works in which line figures, literally or conceptually, includes an invigorating giant doodle by Diana Cooper; whited-out ledger pages by Peter Wegner; the image of a scribble cut from brown felt by Arturo Herrera; a dripped line from a performance by Francis Alys; a string sculpture by Pae White; and tangled plastic zip ties by Mungo Thomson. The importance of line in obliquely conceptual works by Alessandro Balteo and Sophie Tottie is harder to see (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
MAGDALENA ABAKANOWICZ, Marlborough, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through tomorrow). This pre-eminent Polish sculptor's regiment of 95 life-size headless shells of human figures in rough bronze confronts the visitor here, creating a theater of tragic existentialism. On the terrace, giant, simplified dinosaur heads suggest a deep background of primordial terror (Johnson).
 
 "AGAINST NATURE," Sperone Westwater, 142 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 431-3685 (through tomorrow). This elegant exhibition presents three famous Italian avant-gardists who, during the 1950's, sought a raw and biting materialism. Alberto Burri created Cubist compositions from coarse, stitched-together burlap; Lucio Fontana punctured his canvases or cut into them with graceful knife slashes; Piero Manzoni, later famous for more provocative conceptual works, is here represented by all-white, small but aggressively physical pictures, like one made entirely of little Styrofoam balls (Johnson).
 
 "AMERICAN MODERN, 1925-1940: DESIGN FOR A NEW AGE" (through Jan. 7) and "A CENTURY OF DESIGN, PART 2: 1925-1950" (through Sunday), Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710. "American Modern," the larger and more interesting of these shows, deals with the period between two design extravaganzas, the Exposition des Arts Decoratifs et Industriels Modernes in Paris in 1925 and the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. Drawn from the Met's own collection and that of a patron, John C. Waddell, the show presents furniture, appliances, clocks, radios, cameras, textiles, tableware, posters and parts of a snappy blue-and-chrome dining room, along with other work by Bel Geddes, Deskey, Dreyfuss, Frankl, Loewy, Noguchi, Teague and Wright. "A Century of Design," Part 2 of a four-part survey focusing on European 20th-century styles, also draws from the Met's collection. Although studded with star names like Aalto, Breuer, Eames, Ruhlmann and Mies, the show is lackluster by contrast. There is no scarcity of famous chairs; other good things include a wonderful scale drawing for the Daimler-Benz sport convertible No. 3384 (circa 1933). Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).
 
 JOHN CONSTABLE, Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, at 11th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 929-5800 (through Thursday). This exhibition of more than 60 small studies by the famous English landscape painter is not uniformly great, but it has enough gems to urge a visit. A lovely study of a dark gray wind-whipped cloud under white-streaked blue sky is a fine piece of meteorological observation and, in its painterly vivaciousness, looks forward to Abstract Expressionism. Best of all is Constable's small but spectacularly rich and luminous watercolor copy of "The Mill" by Rembrandt (Johnson).
 
 * RINEKE DIJKSTRA, Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160 (through tomorrow). This Dutch artist's solo debut in the United States includes a video (much seen elsewhere) of dancing teenagers in European clubs and a series of photographs she has been taking since 1997 of children in parks. In the video the youngsters preen touchingly. The photographs, color pictures along the lines of Thomas Struth's but more casual and less chilly, are heroic portraits, acutely sympathetic (Kimmelman).
 
 * PETER HUJAR, "Photographs, 1980 to 1987," Matthew Marks Gallery, 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-0200 (through tomorrow). A show of 98 photographs from Hujar's estate, some never shown before. The prints, on a particularly warm paper that is no longer made, are quite beautiful. One would not use that adjective for the images, which are powerful and quietly, deeply disturbing, full of pain but resolutely refusing to dramatize it, now and again touching, now and again amusing in an elegiac sort of way. They are portraits of friends, some nude, some in costume, some engaged in odd enterprises like biting into a strawberry. They are portraits -- they cannot be called anything else -- of animals. They are images of destruction: collapsed houses, the flayed carcasses of slain cows, a dead dog on a heap of trash. They are intense and reticent at the same time. They are memorable (Vicki Goldberg).
 
 "PARADISE NOW: PICTURING THE GENETIC REVOLUTION," Exit Art, 548 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-7745 (through tomorrow). "We are at a threshold," declares the text panel at the start of this show. And we are, you know. Never mind that most of the art isn't great, because with more and more artists tapping into science, something big is bound to happen soon. Think of this as a preliminary report. The works span a decade and run the gamut from paintings and sculptures to the collecting of sperm and the breeding of very tiny exotic frogs. The artists fret predictably about tampering with Mother Nature and stress identity politics, also predictably, but the spirit of the show, an intangible, tips the scales in a positive direction (Kimmelman).
 
 * NEIL WINOKUR, Janet Borden, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 431-0166 (through tomorrow). For this delightful portrait of his hometown, Mr. Winokur has produced a series of 32 still-life photographs, each a crystal-clear deadpan picture of an ordinary but richly iconic object against a bright colored backdrop. A Greek-style paper coffee cup, a Chinese food container, a Giants pennant, an old Broadway playbill, a Con Edison orange cone, a hot dog, a rat, a toy-size Empire State Building: these images produce a resonantly evocative cross section of New York experience (Johnson).

PUB-DATE: October 27, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 3; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1649 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Guy Thing: Strutting Past Trouble

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
SO what do you want to know first? Do they really take off all their clothes? Yes. Can you see, you know, everything? No, at least not from where I was sitting. And -- oops, almost forgot -- is it any good? Well, put it this way: the Eugene O'Neill Theater won't have to look for a new tenant for a long, long time.
"The Full Monty," the hearty singing adaptation of the popular English film about a motley male troupe of amateur strippers, opened last night in a blaze of pure mass appeal. The show calculatedly pushes as many buttons as an elevator operator, but it mercifully doesn't hammer at them. With a winning, ear-catching pop score by David Yazbek and a lively gallery of performers who seem truly in love with the people they're playing, "The Full Monty" is that rare aggressive crowd pleaser that you don't have to apologize for liking. 
 Well, for the most part, anyway. "The Full Monty," which began life at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, is leagues away from the classic New York musical, the sort of urbane, witty fare created by Rodgers and Hart, on the one hand, and Stephen Sondheim, on the other, and currently represented among nonrevivals only by "Contact" at Lincoln Center. The book, by the multiple Tony Award winner Terrence McNally, is sometimes as lame and pandering as a midseason replacement sitcom, especially in the first act.
Fortunately "The Full Monty" has more to do than just talk. And as long as it lets its ideally cast ensemble translate blue-collar blues into vigorous song, it's hard not to sigh in appreciation and relief.
Hokey, formulaic, vulgar, preachy: "The Full Monty" is all that, but it redeemingly tempers these traits with an honest affection. The warmth the evening gives off has less to do with the titillation of its central premise than with its enormous good will. And it makes other Broadway adaptations of hit movies -- "Saturday Night Fever" and the late, unlamented "Footloose" -- seem as blank and sterile as an unilluminated computer screen.
There are so many ways the production could have gone wrong, too. The original British film of the same title, which was directed by Peter Cattaneo and became the Cinderella sleeper of 1997, was a shrewd variation on the classic mainstream rooting movie ("Breaking Away," "Rocky," "Chariots of Fire") in which underdogs triumph in a mist of sweat and tears. (It was made under the aegis of Fox Searchlight Pictures, which is a producer here, along with its former president, Lindsay Law.)
The revitalizing gimmick was undeniably catchy: having a group of unemployed steelworkers in the North of England come together to raise money by taking off their clothes in a one-night performance, emulating the touring Chippendales-style companies that have bewitched the town's working women. The story was simple, predictable and brazenly sentimental, kept this side of both bathos and slapstick by low-key, idiosyncratic performances.
There was something nervous-making in the idea of transplanting the plot to Buffalo for an all-American musical, a form that demands that everything be big. Scaling up the film's tear-jerking and ribald qualities and substituting the rah-rah antics of Buffalo Bills fans for scrappy soccer enthusiasts seemed to be a sure recipe for shattering charm.
The transformation is not without casualties. The characters in the musical are drawn more in crayon than in charcoal: they are baldly exaggerated types, defined by two or three large personality traits and no discernible interior life. And the pleas for tolerance -- for the identity crises of men out of work, for less-than-perfect bodies, for homosexuality (part of a late plot twist) -- that the movie kept sotto voce have been rendered by Mr. McNally with the equivalent of a rebel yell.
Yet while "The Full Monty" may not be subtle, it isn't shameless. Jack O'Brien's direction is disarmingly relaxed. And if Mr. McNally's book occasionally condescends to its characters, the performers themselves (led by Patrick Wilson as the earnest organizer of the strippers) never do. The broad mugging and rim-shot delivery that would seem to be unavoidable are consistently avoided.
The show is stocked with figures you would expect to be caricatures, from the prim executive and his shopaholic wife to the salty old retired club pianist who accompanies the men in their routine. Yet as embodied by Marcus Neville, Emily Skinner and Kathleen Freeman, respectively, these characters acquire a touching reality through judicious restraint. No one is pushing too hard.
There is also, conspicuously, Andre De Shields who, for the duration of his one big solo, seems to own the whole island of Manhattan. But more on that later.
The cast is immeasurably aided by Mr. Yazbek's score and lyrics, the success of which is the production's most refreshing surprise. Mr. Yazbek is a novice to the world of musicals, having worked mostly as a television script writer and a pop composer and performer. But he makes a much smoother transition to Broadway than more celebrated artists from the realm of pop, like Paul Simon ("The Capeman") and Elton John ("Aida").
Mr. Yazbek's ambitions are not lofty. He isn't trying to reinvent the organic musical or to out-Sondheim Sondheim. His formula is to infuse variations on top-40 styles, from the 1950's to the present, with Broadway brassiness. This gives his songs an air of immediate accessibility, even recognizablity. But they aren't the blatant pastiches that the numbers in, say, "Grease!" are.
Mr. Yazbek devilishly sends up the feel-good "You've Got a Friend"-style anthem with a terrific number in which three men consider how they might assist one another in committing suicide. A homage to lost masculinity slyly incorporates the cowboy theme from those old Marlboro cigarette ads.
There's a propulsive, percussive rock drive in the opening numbers that set up the opposing camps of the hapless men and the women who, for once in their lives, are in economic control. The lyrics traffic in outlandish rhymes with open, silly self-delight, using brand names, celebrity names and a steady flow of obscenities.
The show is weakest on ballads, which tend to flow in a treacly stream that brings to mind B-sides of discs played on easy-listening stations. But Mr. Yazbek knows how to bring down a curtain with memory-grabbing melodies, nicely complemented by Jerry Mitchell's choreography, which cleverly addresses the problem of creating dances for men who aren't supposed to be able to dance. And there is a flexible variety in the assorted character-defining solos, like the ones performed with bright panache by Ms. Skinner and with deadpan panache by Ms. Freeman.
John Arnone's neon-toned sets, suggesting a coloring-book version of the industrial cityscape from the movie "Flashdance," provide a fittingly bright frame for the performers, who are, after all, the main attraction. In the central role of Jerry, the young father struggling to scrape together money for child support, Mr. Wilson gracefully plays straight man to the eccentricities of the others, and he sings with shimmering sincerity. (His voice seems to emanate from his gleaming white teeth.)
Jason Danieley and Romain Fruge are delightful as the loopiest of the strippers, who discover a common affinity for "The Sound of Music." John Ellison Conlee is understated and touching as the group's token fat man, and Annie Golden matches him as his patient wife. The protean Ms. Skinner, seen to very different effect in "Sideshow" and "James Joyce's 'The Dead,' " here suggests a delicious hybrid of Nanette Fabray and Vivian Vance. But none of the performers strike false notes, even when the script does.
There is also the formidable Mr. De Shields, who achieved fame on Broadway as a member of the top-drawer ensemble in the Fats Waller revue "Ain't Misbehavin'." His character, nicknamed Horse, first shows up for an audition for the strip act. Arthritically gnarled, with the beaten, resigned expression of a man who expects nothing to go his way, Horse is not on the surface promising showbiz material.
But by degrees the old fellow unbends, thawing into pantherine agility with a resonant voice that growls, twangs and purrs. His number, called "Big Black Man," is a spirited sendup of and salute to James Brown. Watching Mr. De Shields perform it brings to mind those providential thrills occasionally afforded by karaoke bars, when some lumpy sad sack takes the mike and lets loose with the sound of a Sinatra or a Streisand.
A loser becomes, for just a few minutes, a winner. That's the transformation that "The Full Monty" trades on, frankly and unpretentiously. Even those who go expecting to sneer are likely to be surprised by the smiles that keep sneaking onto their faces.

HEADLINE: Labor Expenses for Businesses Climbed Slightly in September

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Labor expenses for businesses showed the smallest gain in a year in the third quarter, government figures showed today, suggesting that the 30-year low unemployment rate was not stoking inflation.
The 0.9 percent increase in the employment cost index in the three months ended Sept. 30 came after a 1 percent gain in the second quarter, the Labor Department said. The third-quarter increase was the smallest since a 0.8 percent rise in the third quarter of 1999. 
 While companies still paid 4.3 percent more than they did a year ago for workers' wages and benefits, the report suggests companies are under diminishing pressure to raise consumer prices. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and other central bankers have cited as one benefit of the record nine-year expansion the ability of companies to produce more with less labor thanks to technological gains.
"With labor cost rises tame and productivity growth ample, profit margins seem less threatened from this source than from nonlabor costs" like energy, said Peter E. Kretzmer, senior economist at Banc of America Securities in New York.
Low unemployment also helped push up homeownership. A record 67.7 percent of households owned their houses in the third quarter, compared with 67.2 percent in the second, a report from the Commerce Department showed. A rise in ownership among Hispanic families to 46.7 percent from 45.4 percent led the increase.
The jobless rate -- declining the last five years -- fell to 3.9 percent in September, matching a three-decade low first reached in April. Unemployment is likely to stay in the 4 percent range, analysts said, after the Labor Department reported today that initial claims for state jobless benefits fell by 5,000 last week, to 305,000 -- about the level claims have averaged the last six months.
Wages and salaries, which make up about three-quarters of the employment cost index, rose 0.8 percent in the third quarter after rising 1 percent in the second. The third-quarter rise was the smallest since wages and salaries rose 0.5 percent in the first quarter of 1999.
"If workers continue to expect modest inflation, then they don't have an incentive to push very hard for higher wages," said Suzanne Rizzo, an economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc. in New York.
The overall cost of benefits, like referral bonuses, health insurance, vacations and the employer-paid portion of Social Security taxes, rose 1 percent, the smallest gain in a year. Benefits increased 1.1 percent in the second three months of this year.
By contrast, the overall index rose 1.4 percent in the first quarter of this year, the largest gain in a decade, largely reflecting the rising cost of health care.
Increases in worker productivity so far have outstripped wage and benefit growth in recent months. Productivity was 5.2 percent higher in the second quarter compared with a year earlier, the largest increase in 17 years.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors' Late-Day Spree Gives Nasdaq a Brief Boost

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The growing belief that technology stocks are reaching a bottom turned the battered Nasdaq composite index around in a late-afternoon rally yesterday, but the overall market ended a volatile session mixed.
The technology-focused Nasdaq, down more than 140 points in early afternoon, closed 42.61 points, or 1.32 percent, higher at 3,272.18 after losing 190 points on Wednesday. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 53.64 points, or 0.52 percent, at 10,380.12, but retreated from larger gains earlier in the day. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.46 point, to 1,364.44.
Investors seemed to be searching for a trend after Wednesday's session, when a disappointing revenue report from the telecommunications equipment maker Nortel Networks touched off a decline in the fiber optics and telecommunications sectors and brought the overall market lower. Yesterday's turnaround appeared to be linked to Nortel and other technology stocks.
Nortel traded erratically yesterday after a 29 percent plunge in the previous session. But it closed up 50 cents, at $45.50.
"The market is so quick these days to try to anticipate trend changes," said Chris Dickerson, an analyst with Global Market Strategists in Gainesville, Ga.
In the last hour of trading, investors began feeling better about technology, Mr. Dickerson said. So, they pulled money from the Dow to buy depressed technology shares, including JDS Uniphase, which reported better-than-expected earnings after the markets had closed.
"I think there is a memory that last week's rally was spurred by surprising earnings by Microsoft. And I think there was a feeling that JDS Uniphase would surprise," Mr. Dickerson said.
JDS Uniphase rose $3.44, to $74.44, in regular trading, recovering from earlier losses. The company released its first-quarter earnings after the close, and beat analyst expectations by 2 cents a share. Its shares slipped to $70.56 in after-hours trading after rising as high as $77.63.
Analysts said investors should expect prices to fluctuate given the current market environment, where any signs of bad earnings news send stocks tumbling. A permanent market recovery or even a consistent rally will take a while.
"The market is feeling for a bottom," said Eugene Mintz, financial markets analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "We thought it had bottomed a few weeks ago."
Some computer chip makers also recovered from Wednesday's decline. Intel rose $3.38, to $44.69, and PMC-Sierra jumped $10.56, to $171.69.
But yesterday was not better for AT&T. The telecommunications company fell again, a day after it announced a major restructuring that would break the company into four separate units and dismantle plans to be an all-in-one communications service provider. AT&T also announced on Wednesday that it was cutting its dividend and warned that fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations. AT&T fell $1.38, to $22.
No single stock or sector appeared to drive the Dow. I.B.M. was among the biggest gainers, up $5.69, at $92.69. Decliners included American Express, which lost $2.94, to $54.44.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Are Mixed
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices were mixed as a rebound in stocks cut demand for the relative safety of government securities.
Treasuries rose earlier as the Nasdaq composite index fell more than 4 percent, after a 5.6 percent drop on Wednesday on concern that corporate earnings growth would slow. The Nasdaq pared losses to gain 0.3 percent in late trading.
Investors "rescued the stock market and upset the bond rally," said Michael Cheah, who bought 30-year bonds yesterday for the $1.5 billion he manages at SunAmerica Asset Management. Still he's comfortable with his bets because a cooling economy justifies lower yields, while volatility in stocks, the Middle East and the euro may yet renew demand for bonds, he said,
The 10-year Treasury note fell 2/32, to a price of 100 16/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.68 percent from 5.67 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 7/32, to 107 12/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.73 percent from 5.74 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: European Report Says Hong Kong Tycoon Is Too Influential

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 26

 BODY:
This is a city ruled by business, so it is little surprise that a businessman, Li Ka-shing, is widely thought to be Hong Kong's most powerful person. The question is whether Mr. Li has become too powerful even for a city that celebrates his kind of empire-building.
In a report adopted today by the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, Hong Kong came under fire for allowing Mr. Li, 72, and his family to amass undue influence over the city's commercial life and its stock market. Saying the Li family's companies accounted for up to a third of Hong Kong's total market value, the report expressed concern that competition in the city was no longer fair. 
 In particular, the Europeans noted that Mr. Li had been granted a passel of exemptions by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange for the listing of his Internet company Tom.com and that his son Richard, 32, had been awarded a lucrative contract to build a science park without open bidding.
"If there is any substance to these allegations," the report concluded, "they have significant implications for E.U. businesses who either trade with or locate their Asian headquarters in Hong Kong."
Though the European Parliament's judgments carry limited force, they nevertheless struck a nerve here. Hong Kong has built an economy far out of proportion to its size or population, based on a reputation for honest courts and untrammeled commerce.
The government rejected the accusations, saying that "all businesses, irrespective of their origins, are competing on a level playing field." It said the younger Mr. Li won the contract to build the park, called Cyberport, because he promised to build it quickly and to bear the risk.
The Beijing-appointed chief executive of Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa, said: "Hong Kong's economic freedom is one of the best in the world. It's the same or better than any of the advanced countries."
Unlike Europe or the United States, Hong Kong does not have antitrust laws. It relies on government agencies to monitor some industries, like telecommunications. And it takes a rigorously hands-off attitude toward business -- accepting as a fact of life that monopolies take root in small economies.
Mr. Li, who came here in the 1940's as a refugee from Guangdong province, just north on the mainland, is a testament to that laissez-faire philosophy. Starting as a maker of plastic flowers, he cobbled together an empire that ranges from telecommunications and ports to supermarkets.
His son Richard followed him into business, starting an Internet venture in 1999. Barely a year later, he began a $38 billion takeover of Hong Kong's dominant telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT.
Richard Li's company, Pacific Century CyberWorks, has been humbled by an 80 percent decline in its share price since February. Still, with the exception of his father, he remains the most prominent businessman in Hong Kong.
And the Li family's influence does not end here. The Far Eastern Economic Review reported this week that the Chinese government had ordered the local authorities to limit the influence of Li Ka-shing's most prominent company, Hutchison Whampoa, in future port projects on the mainland. Hutchison, which already dominates Hong Kong's port, owns large stakes in the ports of Shanghai, Shenzhen and Xiamen.
A spokeswoman for Hutchison, Laura Cheung, said today that Beijing officials had not told the company they wanted to curb its role. She also said the European Parliament's report was inaccurate, adding that Mr. Li's companies accounted for only 15 percent of the Hong Kong market's value. Even adding Pacific Century CyberWorks, the figure was less than 18 percent.
John Cushnahan, the European Parliament member who wrote the report, said in an interview: "Even if it's only 15 percent, it's a substantial holding. More to the point, look at the way Tom.com was taken public."
Mr. Cushnahan said the government should secure passage of antitrust laws to reassure its trading partners that they would receive fair treatment. "When Hong Kong companies trade with us," he said, "they do so in an environment where monopolies are not allowed. It's only fair that they do the same for us."
Even business people who have tangled with Mr. Li question whether an antitrust law is the best way to curb his power. Jimmy Lai, a newspaper publisher who challenged Mr. Li's supermarket chain with a home-delivery service, cautioned that new laws would allow the government to pick winners and losers.
Mr. Lai said the bigger concern ought to be the relationship between the government and the Li family.
"It is true that some tycoons have monopolies," Mr. Lai said. "That's natural in a small market. But cronyism is something the whole world should focus on. We should base our judgments on his ability to push the government."
