HEADLINE: White House Reassures Steel Makers Over Imports

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Reacting quickly to pre-election pressure brought by steel companies, unions and 235 members of Congress, the Clinton administration has promised to take the first steps toward new limits on steel imports.
The industry and unions maintain that they are facing a historic crisis, and they blame foreign steel producers, which, they say, receive direct or indirect subsidies from their governments. They say the situation has resulted in six recent steel company failures, thousands of layoffs and historically low stock prices. 
 West Virginia and Pennsylvania, two of the largest steel-producing states, are seen as competitive in the presidential election. Vice President Al Gore needs union workers to turn out in large numbers in those states to beat Gov. George W. Bush.
John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, told corporate and union leaders in a letter this week that the administration would send emissaries to four nations -- China, India, Taiwan and Ukraine -- to warn them that the "dramatic recent increase" in their steel exports could soon be subject to higher duties or other restrictions. Mr. Podesta also promised that the government would take "all reasonable steps" to guard against import surges like those that damaged American manufacturers in the late 1990's.
The measures promised by the White House will not necessarily lead to new duties on foreign steel. But that the administration acted so quickly -- little more than a week after the industry appealed for help -- and without waiting for the industry to file formal charges through the International Trade Commission, an independent federal agency, indicates how politically sensitive the perceptions of a steel crisis have become.
"This is an unprecedented response; they jumped right into this," George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said of administration officials. "They recognize that there is a crisis in the steel industry, and intend to do something about it."
Administration officials acknowledge that they acted with unusual speed but deny that they did so for political reasons. They say they have learned to move quickly when confronted with the possibility of a steel crisis because earlier episodes made clear that the industry could not withstand prolonged import surges without vast job losses.
"This is not because of politics, but because there is real hardship and bankruptcies in the industry," said Gene Sperling, White House economic adviser. He said the actions were interim steps that could be taken while the administration researched whether broader legal action was needed.
The White House has so far resisted invoking a provision that would allow the president to impose blanket import restrictions temporarily if the International Trade Commission determines that imports have contributed heavily to the woes of domestic producers.

HEADLINE: New Lawyers At a Big Firm Get Bonuses Of $35,000

BYLINE: By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
A leading Wall Street firm, Sullivan & Cromwell, opened the season of annual bonuses this week, announcing on Wednesday that its first-year lawyers, most of whom began practicing law last fall at an annual salary of $125,000, would receive a year-end bonus of $35,000 this year. That is more than double the $15,000 that first-year associates received last year.
The size of the bonus demonstrates that the market for corporate lawyers is still extremely hot, and that keeping them remains a concern despite a round of salary increases of as much as 25 percent early this year. It also raises the bar for other top-tier law firms, which will have to decide whether to match Sullivan & Cromwell's bonus. 
 The timing of the announcement is sure to affect the firm's recruiting efforts both by attracting top law students who are deciding which firm to intern with next summer, and by impressing those law students who were interns last summer and were offered permanent jobs after they graduate but who may be thinking about going to other firms.
Some of those prospective employees asked questions about how much they could expect to be paid, prompting Wednesday's announcement, said Benjamin F. Stapleton, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell. "People wanted to know and we told them," he said.
The bonus brings the total compensation for first-year lawyers at Sullivan & Cromwell to $160,000. Second-year lawyers, whose base salary is $135,000, stand to earn even more when their bonuses are announced. Sullivan & Cromwell announced bonuses only for first-year lawyers.
The bonus "creates a buzz," said Stephen Gillers, a New York University Law School professor who studies the legal industry, and that buzz is critical to recruiting because Sullivan & Cromwell is competing with other firms for the same narrow slice of the top of the class at leading law schools.
Raising compensation to such levels may create risks for some law firms if the economy slows down. Although firms are not obligated to pay a specific bonus, once given, it may be difficult to reduce in future years.
Less profitable firms may be reluctant to match the $35,000 bonus, which may be to Sullivan & Cromwell's advantage, Professor Gillers said.
"If 5 or 6 firms do it, and another 10 or 15 are behind, then you are creating an exclusive tier, and Sullivan & Cromwell will be the leader," he said. "You're first or you're an also-ran."
News of the bonus at Sullivan & Cromwell spread at the speed of the Internet among lawyers at top-tier firms in New York, filling them with anticipation of sizable bonuses of their own.
"Everyone here is incredibly enthusiastic" about the Sullivan & Cromwell bonus, said one junior lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, another large corporate firm.
"Everyone is thinking 'that's just the bar now,' " and other firms will have to meet or beat it, he said.
Partners at other firms were less enthusiastic about paying large bonuses, but sounded resigned to increases. "We haven't made a decision about the year-end bonus yet," said Rhett Brandon, a partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, which usually announces bonuses in January. "It is our full intention to remain competitive in the marketplace."

HEADLINE: New Optimism Brings Money For Franks

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Newly optimistic because of polls suggesting that Representative Bob Franks has drawn within striking distance of Jon S. Corzine in the New Jersey race for the Senate, Republican officials in Washington released $600,000 today to help Mr. Franks pay for campaign commercials, meaning the long-lopsided Senate race could appear an even match on television in its final 12 days.
The 11th-hour help, the maximum allowed by law, could be as important symbolically as it is practically. It will allow Mr. Franks to increase his television presence by about half. But it is also meant to broadcast the party's sudden shift in outlook about Mr. Franks's chances of victory. 
 "It's moved from a race that we had crossed our fingers and wished for, to a race that's eminently winnable," said Stuart Roy, a spokesman for Senator Mitch McConnell, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
Mr. Franks was ebullient on the campaign trail today, describing the race in David-and-Goliath terms. "I'm a real happy man," he all but shouted into his cell phone to an Atlantic City radio talk-show host while warming up in his van between bursts of hand-shaking at a Morristown train station this morning. "A clear perception is developing that momentum is wearing a Bob Franks jersey."
Still, even if Mr. Corzine's lead, according to one Quinnipiac University poll, has shrunk to five percentage points, that is a wide margin by the standards of recent statewide elections in New Jersey.
And Mr. Corzine, the Democratic candidate, received his own boost today: After several newspaper opinion pages backed Mr. Franks earlier in the week, it was Mr. Corzine who received two glowing endorsements, one from The Times of Trenton and the other from The Daily News.
"So much for the big momentum that we heard about yesterday," said Tom Shea, Mr. Corzine's spokesman.
Moreover, though the new money from the Republican National Committee will help Mr. Franks to pull even on television, television is not everything, as was illustrated today when the candidates released their latest campaign-finance reports.
As of Oct. 18, with three weeks to go in the campaign, Mr. Corzine had spent $52.8 million on his Senate bid, and was on track to spend at least $62 million by Election Day. By contrast, Mr. Franks's total campaign expenditures fell just short of $3.8 million.
Mr. Corzine's campaign spent nearly $500,000 a day in the first 18 days of October, his report showed. Mr. Franks spent about $70,000 a day.
While Mr. Corzine has now spent more than $11 million on television in the general election campaign, and is expected to purchase another $4 million or more in commercials before Nov. 7, his financial advantage may have a more pronounced effect in getting out the vote.
Much of Mr. Corzine's expenses, indeed, included polling, printing and postage for direct mail advertisements, telephone calls to voters, and fees and expenses for consultants and labor organizers who will be crucial to what is expected to be a $3 million, statewide canvassing operation on Election Day.
It remains possible, albeit unlikely, that Mr. Corzine, who so far has poured $52.7 million of his own money into his campaign, could match the $65.6 million that Ross Perot spent running for president in 1992.
Both candidates spent today gearing up in one way or another for what is likely to be an arduous campaign homestretch. Mr. Franks is set to begin a 12-day bus tour on Friday. Mr. Corzine, meanwhile, spent the early evening rallying Democratic troops in South Jersey at the party's Camden County headquarters and at an event in Voorhees.
Mr. Franks began his day in Morristown at 6:30 a.m. "Something's going on," he said, in between shaking hands with New Jersey Transit riders. "Wherever we've gone -- street fair, firehouse, what have you -- people are responding more than they did. They're saying, 'Stay in there,' and 'Run! Run!' There's a David and Goliath outlook."
Of course, Mr. Franks could not have picked a better place to start his day on a cheerful note. Morris County is a Republican stronghold, and the commuters he met seemed to have Mr. Franks's message down cold.
"I made my mind up about two weeks ago: I'm going to vote for Bob Franks," said Valerie Haus, an editor and writer for a financial house in New York. "Listening to Corzine talk and all the money he's spending just annoys me. The idea of buying a Senate seat is intolerable."
But not everyone was convinced. Hamilton McLean, an Internet consultant also headed for Manhattan, said: "I've only followed it as far as all the money Corzine has spent on his campaign, but I don't think it changes anything. At least I know more about where Corzine stands."
Mr. Corzine, meanwhile, spent the early part of his day along the Jersey Shore, beginning just before 7 a.m. at a foggy New Jersey Transit station in Middletown, the largest community in Monmouth County -- an electoral battleground that heavily favors Republicans but which Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, nearly carried in 1996.
After a relaxed breakfast with local Democratic officials at a small diner in Middletown, he visited a retirement community in Lakewood in Ocean County. It was his third campaign stop among the elderly this week.
Mr. Corzine bristled a bit during brief remarks before about 15 people in a small theater in the community. One man asked Mr. Corzine if the millions he has spent on television ads was an attempt to control voters.
Mr. Corzine responded that he was not about to follow people into the voting booths. "I don't think I control people when they go behind the curtain," he said.
Then, as he has said several times in recent campaign stops, Mr. Corzine said he was beholden to no special interest groups. "I am going to owe nothing to anybody but you," he told the small crowd. "I have not sold my soul to any pharmaceutical companies."
On the endorsement front, Mr. Corzine, who was scored in several newspaper editorials this week for his campaign spending, was given a welcome lift today when the opinion pages of The Daily News and The Times of Trenton both endorsed him. "Corzine's economic savvy, social conscience and personal integrity will bring to the Senate qualities it sorely needs," The Daily News said, calling him "truly a man of and for the 21st century."

HEADLINE: Dot-Com Fever Followed by Bout Of Dot-Com Chill;
Tech Stocks Down, But No Threat Is Seen To City's Economy

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON and JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
A year ago, BigStar Entertainment looked as if it was living up to its name.
The New York City dot-com had just raised more than $20 million from investors excited by its plan to sell movies over the Internet. Some of its executives were paper millionaires. And with its offbeat advertising generating that all-important buzz, BigStar seemed well on its way to becoming a leading light in the city's Silicon Alley. 
 Today, BigStar is in big trouble. It has burned through much of the money it raised, dismissed about 70 of its 110 employees, and may soon be kicked off Nasdaq because its stock is now trading for pennies. David Friedensohn, 39, the company's chief executive, says he thinks BigStar still has enough money to hang in there. But, he said, "I can't make any promises."
BigStar has plenty of company. In the last few months, Silicon Alley's dot-coms have laid off about 3,000 people. They have given up acres of office space. A couple have gone bankrupt, and more seem headed that way. Even the big fish in the pond, DoubleClick, has announced that its revenues are likely to fall as Internet advertising drops (its stock, of course, has plunged).
All this is quite a comedown for an industry that held itself up as the hottest -- and coolest -- business sector in New York City. Just a few months ago, a report commissioned by the New York New Media Association, a trade association, said that interactive cyberbusinesses employed more than 100,000 people in the city and were "rapidly challenging many other traditional New York industry sectors as an essential cornerstone of the growth of the regional economy."
Or maybe not. The good news, perhaps, is that Silicon Alley is still not big enough to have much effect on the city's overall economic health.
"As a share of income and employment, it's 2 or 3 percent," said Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "That's not bad, but Wall Street accounts for 20 percent of income in the city," not including all the lawyers and accountants and temps and black-car drivers and bartenders who, one way or another, work for Wall Street.
Even economists who think Silicon Alley is important to the city's economy say the dot-com meltdown has had little measurable effect on overall jobs or unemployment data, at least so far. "We actually don't have too much weakness yet," said John Tepper Marlin, chief economist for Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.
And for people looking for commercial real estate, the dot-com decline is actually a good thing. "So far, it has not had any negative effect, but a positive effect," said L. Craig Lemle, corporate managing director at Julien J. Studley, a commercial real estate broker. "The market is so tight many people cannot find places, and this is returning much needed space."
However you define Silicon Alley -- and some people define it so broadly as to include practically everyone in the city who uses a computer at work -- the industry was embraced by government officials. The Giuliani administration set up several programs to help foster dot-coms. Digital NYC strives to bring cyberbusinesses to Harlem and the boroughs outside Manhattan, while another program sponsors specially wired buildings in lower Manhattan.
Now, those same government officials are less likely to talk about the economic benefits of Silicon Alley; in fact, they play down its importance.
It "is a facet of the city's economy, it is not the singular driving force," said Robert M. Harding, the deputy mayor for economic development and finance. "You monitor it and encourage it, and encourage people to come and stay like other industries, but it is only part of the overall economic development policy of the city."
Part of the appeal of Silicon Alley to the public sector was that encouraging the technology industry would diversify an economy that was heavily dependent on Wall Street. But as it turned out, the most troubled denizens of Silicon Alley had less to do with technology than with raising and spending other people's money -- which is to say, with Wall Street.
Enthusiasm among investors (and therefore investment bankers) for anything related to the Internet -- no matter how goofy -- helped create many of Manhattan's dot-com companies.
Last year alone, venture capitalists -- the investors who finance fledgling companies -- poured $1.5 billion into New York City companies, according to the VentureOne Corporation, a research company in San Francisco. That's only 10 percent of the amount of money that surged into Silicon Valley, but it was more than triple the amount that New York companies got in 1998.
One reason these financiers were willing to spend so much was their confidence that they could quickly recoup their investments -- and then some. That was because stock market investors were willing to pay huge amounts for stock that venture capitalists got on the cheap. In fact, investors seemed happy to fling money at companies that they could not understand ("We supply resource-rich sync solutions in the optical space"), that had never earned a penny, and that did not plan to make money for years. Last year, New York Internet companies raised almost $3.8 billion in initial public offerings, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data.
The stock market party came to an abrupt end last spring, as investors suddenly slapped themselves on their collective forehead and said, "What were we thinking?" The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavy on tech stocks, has plunged 38 percent since its high last March. Silicon Alley stocks have been hit even harder, dropping 53 percent from their spring peak.
Now, it seems that no one on Wall Street will touch Internet stocks with a barge pole. New York City companies have raised a mere $150 million in the stock market since April. More than a dozen companies here, including The New York Times Company, have postponed or withdrawn Internet-related stock offerings.
This cycle is typical of Wall Street, and has been for decades, said Charles R. Geisst, a finance professor at Manhattan College and the author of "Wall Street: A History" (Oxford University Press, 1997). "They did it with rocket fuel companies after Sputnik went up," he said. "Everything that looked like it had any potential got financed; 80 percent of it falls by the wayside."
As a result of the drought on Wall Street, venture capital has become scarce, at least compared with earlier this year. "New York is being hit worst," said Bill Tucker, president of the Elevator Club, a networking group. "The people who are being hurt the most are the ones who are overexposed. I am just telling people to lay low and weather the storm."
Even within the high-tech business, some people say that the problems in Silicon Alley were neither unexpected nor undeserved. Last year was a bubble, "like the front end of the Dutch tulip problem," said Bruce E. Bernstein, president of the New York Software Industry Association. "The technology sector is not going to go away, instead it will shake out some of the most extravagant pure Internet plays."
New technology companies are still springing up all over New York City -- but most of them are focused on things like computer animation, optical switching and gene sequencing, said Ken Perlin, director of the Center for Advanced Technology at New York University.
"There isn't this whole idea that we'll hire a bunch of young kids and throw money at them and write a business plan later," he said. While he still sees companies that are more interested in throwing parties than in turning profits, he added: "I worry about them. That's not a revenue model, that's a buzz model."
And the Internet is not going away -- it's going mainstream, like the telephone. There will still be Internet jobs, but they are likely to be at stodgy, old-fashioned companies that don't offer stock options (or in-house ping-pong tables). One joke going around is that the shorthand phrase B-to-B no longer refers to "business-to-business"; it now means "back to banking."
"A lot of folks who will actually make money on this are household names," said David S. Berry, research director of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a Wall Street firm that specializes in banks and other financial institutions. "The technology is real, and it is having a real impact -- but whether it will be wielded by start
ups with funny names is another question."
And the Silicon Alley stalwarts that survive are trying their best to cope. BigStar, for example, has cut costs so that its film Web site is breaking even, Mr. Friedensohn said, and is focusing on turning its e-mail marketing abilities into a new line of business. And like a lot of other Silicon Alley executives, he said, he is open to merging his company with another.
As for no longer being a paper millionaire, Mr. Friedensohn said it did not bother him. In New York, he said, "There's always somebody making a lot more money than you. New York keeps you humble."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1270 words

HEADLINE: Dot-Com Fever Followed by Bout Of Dot-Com Chill;
What a Long, Strange Trip: Pseudo.Com to Dot.Nowhere

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
He still wears the uniform: leather boots, leather jacket and a dark T-shirt. He is twitchy, he grooms his sideburns and he smokes a lot.
Steve Fine is a dot-com guy without a dot-com and he'll accept a free drink. He is sitting in a bar on the Lower East Side in the middle of the afternoon pulling stolen software from his bag. 
 "This is it," he says to the bartender. "This is my severance package."
"How's your job hunt going, Steve?" she asks. She serves a lot of out-of-work new economy types these days.
"Not as good as I thought," he says. "But I've got my unemployment check, $308 a week, and I've got five and a half months left to find one."
He drains his free beer and orders another.
Steve Fine is a 30-year-old who has become a has-been before he ever became anything, on the unemployment line with 290,000 stock options worth nothing.
He was the art director for pseudo.com, one of the most flamboyant addresses on the World Wide Web. The company closed operations in mid-September after spending millions of dollars without earning a nickel.
Pink slips are blowing through Silicon Alley these days. According to industry trade sites, there have been about 3,000 reported layoffs at Manhattan technology companies since the beginning of September. Pseudo Programs, with 175 layoffs, is by no means the largest of these companies to go under, but its crash has gotten a good amount of press coverage, since its acolytes had crowed so loudly and flown so high.
Building a sort of online television network of video channels, its employees used to boast that they would destroy television as we knew it. Six years later, the networks are still here and Pseudo is nothing more than a memory of a brash company gone bad.
It is 5 o'clock in the afternoon and the bar is filled with unemployed techies who listen as Mr. Fine retraces his rise and fall, from working stiff to master of the new technocratic universe -- and back.
He grew up in Scotch Plains, N.J., a middle-class community where, he said, Italians lived on one side of the tracks and blacks on the other. Steve Fine called himself Steve D'Fino to anyone who did not know him, because being a Jew meant getting your head kicked in, he said.
His father, an industrial roofer and asbestos remover, went by D'Fino too. "There was more work that way," Mr. Fine said. It was a solid, middle-of-the-road childhood. There was a Cadillac in the driveway, but it was always aging and Steve Fine wanted out.
"I always thought there had to be more to life than an old car and physical labor," he says.
There was. It wasn't wealth, exactly; Mr. Fine never earned more than $70,000 a year at Pseudo. But in the new economy, a lot of money wasn't an essential for feeling rich. There were the trappings. In 1995, he began working in a hip 10,000-square-foot loft at Broadway and Houston Street, and spent time watching the European women walk by. Those women once would have laughed at him. Now they wanted to party.
Wealth was a state of mind, Mr. Fine said. The dot-com sons and daughters of middle managers -- once dropouts and misfits and nerds -- were suddenly at the epicenter of a limitless technology. It was a job in which you didn't really have to work. You surfed the Net. In the office, there was the electronic water pipe that five people could smoke at once. The scent was of marijuana, not the must of yellowing books. It was the way out of their fathers' 9-to-5 work world. Then there were those options that would be worth millions when some witless investor took the bait.
"We really thought we were going to make it," says David Mulkey, an ex-lighting specialist who earned $40,000 at Pseudo and who now plays music in the subways. "We were making art, we thought. And we were escaping the middle class."
"It was an amazing time," Mr. Fine remembers. "Geeks got girls and people thought we were a club."
For the first few years, Mr. Fine did work hard, more than 80 hours a week, he says. He had, after all, been raised with his father's work ethic. And he believed the work he was doing was important. His job was to design the Web pages for the different channels, design the promotional materials and logos and eventually to manage the mess that went with an out-of-control staff.
Employees smoked marijuana for lunch and snorted cocaine for supper. They slept under their desks. "It was wild and the Wall Street suits would come to the parties and get high and write us a check in the morning," Mr. Fine says between beers, a hint of pride still lingering in his voice. "We ate from the trough of the venture capitalist pigs."
Pseudo had started as an online radio station in 1994 before expanding to video, featuring boutique channels of hip-hop, punk rock and counterculture programming. It was one of the first Silicon Alley darlings and perhaps better known in the early days for its Warholesque parties, which were often held in the loft of Pseudo's founder, Joshua Harris.
"CBS is our competition," Mr. Harris once boasted on television.
Now, in the bar, the chalkboard reads: "Quit your dot.com!"
"No reason to quit," Mr. Fine says. "Nobody has a job."
Back in his school days, Mr. Fine was a misanthrope who wore a green Mohawk and drank 151-proof rum at the local amusement park. Italian or not, he still got beaten up and the girls made fun of him. He dropped out his junior year but earned his equivalency diploma. He went on to art school and came out thinking he was going to be a famous painter.
But no one was hiring famous painters at the time and he settled for working in a bookstore and then as a receptionist at an audiovisual company. He taught himself computer graphics there and went on to design T-shirts.
"Then in '94 I met a guy at a party," he says. "He told me about this joint called Pseudo."
With 300 employees, many of whom sat around doing little more than downloading pornography, the company ran through $18 million in 1999; it received $14 million more in May. Investors wanted to see some action. David Bohrman, the former head of CNNfn, a financial news network, was hired to run Pseudo. The suits arrived and things changed.
"It wasn't a freak scene anymore," Mr. Fine said. "The parties faded away and the regular work world took over. In a way it's a relief that I don't work there anymore."
The use of drugs in the office was banned. The content was paired down into a one-channel, talk-show format. Pseudo spent a lot of money covering the political conventions in a grandstanding ploy to find new investors. Few tuned in.
"Why would they?" Mr. Fine asked. "Cable does it better."
By the end, Mr. Fine was doing a whole lot of nothing. He was smart enough, however, to put a few thousand dollars in the bank. His savings plus his unemployment checks allow him to make rent, drink in the afternoons and wander the streets of Manhattan with his hands in his pockets mulling over his prospects.
"It's over," he says. "Now I'm crawling back to the corporate dog bowl."
A woman with two-tone hair walks into the bar. She, too, is an old Pseudo hand. She is an Internet consultant now. She "puts people together." Steve Fine hands her his resume.
He tells her he wants to start his own design firm. Then he regresses into talk about the Web and video-streaming technology. In the next breath he says he is a failure. And then it is dreams about a dog farm in Iceland. Then a farm upstate. He's shellshocked.
"I'm just down on myself and the whole thing," he tells the woman through cigarette smoke. "I would have been an architect if I was smart."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Kellogg Plans to Acquire Keebler for $3.86 Billion
Kellogg, the maker of Eggo waffles and Rice Krispies, agreed to acquire Keebler Foods for $3.86 billion.
The deal would combine the world's leading breakfast cereal company with the second-largest cookie and cracker maker in the United States, and bring together several widely recognized marketing icons, including Tony the Tiger, Snap, Crackle and Pop and the Keebler Elves. Shares of Kellogg rose $1.56, to $24.31, while Keebler rose $1.06, to $40.44. Page C2. 

Early Claims on Budget Surplus
Congress and the Clinton administration are still wrangling over the final pieces of this year's federal budget, but by the time they are finished they could spend more than 40 percent of the surplus that the two presidential candidates are counting on to pay for their own proposals, analysts from both parties said. A1.
 
Limits Promised on Steel Imports
The Clinton administration has promised to take the first steps toward imposing new limits on steel imports. A20.
 
Vinik to Close $4.2 Billion Fund
Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of one of the nation's largest hedge funds, said that he would shut down his $4.2 billion fund and return his investors' money by the end of the year to spend more time with his family. C4.
 
Nasdaq Closes Up After Early Dive
Stocks ended mixed after a volatile session in which the Nasdaq composite index fell more than 140 points before rebounding in the afternoon to close 42.61 points, or 1.32 percent, higher at 3,272.18. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 53.64 points, or 0.52 percent, to 10,380.12, but the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.46 point, to 1,364.44. C10.
 
Europeans Criticize Hong Kong
In a report adopted by the European Parliament, Hong Kong came under fire for allowing Li Ka-shing, 72, and his family to amass undue influence over the city's commercial life and its stock market. Saying the Li family's companies accounted for up to a third of Hong Kong's total market value, the report expressed concern that the city was no longer a level playing field. C4.
 
DaimlerChrysler Profit Falls 78%
DaimlerChrysler said that its third-quarter profit fell by 78 percent because of a loss of $512 million at the Chrysler Group in the United States, and executives said that the bad times might continue well into next year. C4.
 
Law Firm Awards $35,000 Bonuses
A leading Wall Street law firm, Sullivan & Cromwell, announced that its first-year lawyers, most of whom began practicing law last fall at an annual salary of $125,000, will receive a bonus of $35,000 this year. That is more than double the $15,000 that first-year associates received last year. B3.
 
Measure to Halt Phone Deal Dropped
Deutsche Telekom won a battle in its effort to enter the United States when Congress abandoned legislation that would have blocked its proposed deal for VoiceStream Wireless. C8.
 
A Gerbil-Free Campaign for Go.com
Cliff Freeman & Partners, the agency responsible for the gerbil-launching ads for Outpost.com, is taking a more direct approach for promoting the revamping of the Go.com Web site. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.

HEADLINE: BUDGET THREATENS CANDIDATES' PLANS TO SPEND SURPLUS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Congress and the Clinton administration are still wrangling over the final pieces of this year's federal budget, but by the time they are finished they could spend more than 40 percent of the surplus that the two presidential candidates are counting on to pay for their own proposals, analysts from both parties said today.
Without even taking up most of the big-ticket promises made by Vice President Al Gore or Gov. George W. Bush in their race for the White House, the Republican-controlled Congress and President Clinton are negotiating over tax cuts and spending increases that could use up $900 billion or more of the projected non-Social Security surplus of $2.17 trillion over the next decade, the analysts said. 
 Should the two sides reach agreement on the main provisions, they would effectively reduce the surplus to $1.27 trillion or less.
Mr. Bush has proposed tax and spending programs totaling at least $1.9 trillion over 10 years. Mr. Gore's budget proposal totals at least $1.5 trillion.
Because the economy has remained relatively strong, the surplus projection is likely to be increased again when it is updated early next year, helping the new president as he submits his first budget to Congress. Early estimates circulating on Capitol Hill are that the surplus projection could be revised upward by anywhere from a few hundred billion dollars to $1 trillion.
The effects of this year's budget on the surplus could be higher or substantially lower than $900 billion depending on how a number of disputes are resolved in coming days.
For example, Mr. Clinton threatened today to veto a $240 billion tax cut bill, although he backs or has accepted many of its main provisions, including increases in contribution limits for individual retirement accounts and 401(k) retirement savings plans and tax breaks for economic development in poor neighborhoods.
Whatever the final figure, the allocation of such a big chunk of the surplus even before voters go to the polls suggests how quickly unimaginably large sums of money can come and go in Washington. And it is an indication that the agendas set out by Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush could prove overly ambitious even in this age of fiscal plenty.
"There's a disconnect between what's going on on the campaign trail and what's going on in Washington," said Robert Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan fiscal watchdog group . "The surplus number the candidates are using is unrealistic."
The Bush campaign said it was confident that money would be available for its $1.3 trillion tax cut and other initiatives and that if elected Mr. Bush would end the profligacy of both parties in Congress.
"Each of the past three years, despite Congress and the president agreeing to spend more money, the surplus surged as a result of stronger than anticipated economic growth," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Mr. Bush. "The best way to stop politicians from spending more money is to put George W. Bush in the White House."
Doug Hattaway, a spokesman for Mr. Gore, said he did not want to comment on a situation that was still hypothetical.
On the campaign trail, the candidates continued to attack each other today over their budget proposals. Much of the back and forth was about a report by the American Academy of Actuaries concluding that Mr. Bush's budget and Social Security plans would leave the nation unable to pay off the $3.4 trillion national debt.
Aides to Mr. Bush said the report's assumptions were flawed and stood by their estimate that their proposal would pay off the debt by 2016. Mr. Gore, who says his plan would pay off the debt in 2012, said the report was evidence that Mr. Bush's agenda was fiscally irresponsible.
It is unclear how the budget showdown between Mr. Clinton and the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill will play out. Some members of both parties say they expect deadlock on some of the biggest pieces of outstanding business, including the $240 billion tax cut package and a proposed increase in the minimum wage. Other Democrats and Republicans say there is still room for a deal in which both parties get most of what they want before Election Day.
Either way, it is clear that Congress and the administration are unfazed by the prospect of allocating a substantial portion of the surplus in a flurry of last-minute horse trading.
Asked for his assessment of the new budget, G. William Hoagland, the Republican staff director of the Senate Budget Committee, said the tax and spending legislation as it stood would reduce the surplus by $910 billion over 10 years.
Asked separately for his assessment, Thomas S. Kahn, the staff director for Democrats on the House Budget Committee, came up with a slightly higher estimate. Mr. Bixby of the Concord Coalition put the figure at $700 billion to $800 billion.
Mr. Hoagland said the increase in discretionary spending for this year to around $647 billion -- about $20 billion more than the Congressional Budget Office assumed in calculating its latest surplus projection -- would reduce the surplus by $310 billion over 10 years.
That figure assumes that spending in future years will rise at no more than the rate of inflation, even though spending in recent years has risen at a rate far higher than inflation. Discretionary spending encompasses everything from fighter planes to Head Start. This year the two parties have agreed to big increases for popular programs like medical research at the National Institutes of Health as well as for myriad election-year "pork" projects in districts all over the country.
An additional $295 billion of the surplus would go to two tax cuts: the $240 billion package that Republicans and Mr. Clinton were battling over today, and a separate $55 billion reduction in taxes on long distance telephone calls.
Increased payments to Medicare would use up $74 billion of the surplus, Mr. Hoagland said, with another $44 billion going to increases in pension benefits to military retirees.
The tax cuts and spending increases would come to $723 billion over 10 years, Mr. Hoagland said. But the surplus would actually be reduced by an additional $187 billion in interest costs, he said, bringing the total to $910 billion.
That is because the surplus projections assume that all of the surplus will go to reducing the national debt; to the degree that the surplus goes to other purposes, the debt, and the interest on it, remain higher than assumed in the projections.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Five Myths

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: NANJING, China

 BODY:
The U.S. ambassador to China, Joseph Prueher, was answering questions the other day after a lecture at Nanjing University, when an American student rose and asked him something like this: Why is it that whenever I'm back home Americans ask me what it's like to live in a Communist dictatorship that abuses its people, but when I'm here in China I feel that I'm living in a society that's becoming more open?
The young man's question reflected an important truth. While views of China in America -- and particularly in Congress -- still remain frozen in many cases on the Tiananmen Square massacre, the reality here is now a much more complex combination of iron fists and Web servers, personal freedoms and political handcuffs. Here are the five biggest myths about today's China that the next U.S. president should know: 
 Myth #1: The main threat to the Chinese regime is a resurgence of the coalition of pro-democracy students and intellectuals who led the Tiananmen movement. Wrong. The fact is, the students have been among the biggest beneficiaries of the stability and foreign investment in China in the past decade, and they are unlikely to rock the boat. The big challenge to the regime is the workers and farmers who will be laid off as a result of China's pending entry into the World Trade Organization. Many uncompetitive factories will be shut down and 10 million farmers alone could lose their jobs as superior U.S. sugar and wheat start flooding China. Unrest among this group is the biggest threat to the regime.
Myth #2: The Internet will promote democracy in China. Wrong. Talk to Chinese dissident groups and they will tell you they can now send one million e-mails of uncensored information into China every day. That's true. But what can the recipients do with those e-mails? "If you just have information, but can't use it for organization or action to promote change, its political impact will be limited, and for now the Chinese government is still very good at preventing people from turning information into political action," said Michael Chase, who with his colleague James Mulvenon has been researching the Internet in China for the RAND Corporation.
Myth #3: The Internet will not promote democracy in China. Also wrong. Yes, it's true that the Chinese government has tried to block access, but it's not working. Come with me here in Nanjing and I will show you how to view online Tibet.com -- the official Web site of the Tibetan government in exile -- or NYTimes.com. No problem. Deep down, the leadership here knows that you can't have the knowledge that China needs from the Internet without letting all sorts of other information into the country, and without empowering more and more Chinese to communicate horizontally and create political communities. In the long run this will only give more tools to the forces here pushing for political pluralism.
Myth #4: Every Chinese youth is building a replica of the Statue of Liberty in his basement. If only that were true. The most popular political attitude among students in China is nationalism, with an underlying sense that America is trying to keep China down. As one Nanjing professor said to me, "I had a student tell me the other day that in 1989 he was in Tiananmen Square as a young boy and in 1999 he was outside the U.S. Embassy throwing stones after the Americans bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade." A lot of people assume the next generation of Chinese will be more liberal and pro-American. In fact, a more democratic China that truly reflects public opinion will be a more nationalistic China.
Myth #5: The natural successor to China's Communist system is Jeffersonian democracy. I wish. The most likely thing to come after the Communist Party is a mess -- unless the Communists can slowly introduce the rule of law and necessary governing institutions for a more open society. We may think the problem in China today is too much control, but in most cases it's too little control. Half the time the central government either has no idea what's going on in a province or is unable to get provincial leaders to apply laws. (Get ready for the fracas that is going to break out between the U.S. and China when every Chinese province tries to interpret W.T.O. rules on its own.) In the cold war it was China's strength that threatened us; tomorrow it will be China's weakness.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE GREEN PARTY;
Nader's Damage to Gore Most Evident in Oregon

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 25

 BODY:
In the downtown streets of the biggest city in Oregon, it is remarkably easy to find people who say they are truly struggling with how to cast their vote this year. But it is remarkably difficult to find people in that group who see the decision as a choice between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush.
Instead, the choice they find so agonizing is between Mr. Gore and Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate. 
 Democratic leaders here and around the country have mounted a ferocious appeal to convince such people that a vote for Mr. Nader is tantamount to a vote for Mr. Bush. But while this argument weighs heavily on many minds here, there are also many voters who will have none of it. Oregon is the closest thing to Nader country, after all, where polls suggest his support is higher than in any other state.
"I'd like to vote for Nader, I really would," explained Kevin McGrorty, 31, the proprietor of Bad Kitty Koffee, a sidewalk stand. "I like what he stands for. I like the questions he's raising. But I've got to vote for Gore. I'd feel horribly guilty if I woke up the day after the election and Bush won, and if I felt that my particular vote had in any way could have swayed things toward him."
But no such conflict troubled one of Mr. McGrorty's customers, Danielle DeDee, a sales clerk at a local gallery and a fiercely pro-Nader voter. She knows her candidate is an extreme long shot on Nov. 7, though she said that was no reason to withhold a vote for him. And though she firmly believes that Governor Bush, of Texas, is "dangerous," especially on environmental issues, that does not mean that she would rather see Mr. Gore become president.
"If Bush gets in, I feel that it might bring things to a head much more quickly," Ms. DeDee said. "Pollution's going to increase in the short term, but I think that will bring a lot more people into the environmental movement a lot more quickly. Sometimes you've got to hit bottom before you come back up."
Oregon has voted for the Democratic presidential nominee in the last three elections.
But with plenty of support in the suburbs and rural regions of the state, Mr. Bush stands a very good chance of winning this state and its seven electoral votes if Mr. Nader drains away critical votes from Mr. Gore in cities like Portland and the college town, Eugene.
The same dynamic is at work in neighboring Washington State, and in some Midwestern states like Minnesota and Wisconsin, and perhaps even in California, the biggest electoral prize of all. But in no other state but Oregon does there seem to be more of a risk for Mr. Gore. That goes a long way toward explaining why the vice president showed up here at a rally on Sunday night, pledging to "fight to protect the environment with all my heart and soul."
Polls this year in Oregon have shown Mr. Nader with support ranging from 5 percent all the way into double digits. An American Research Group poll of 600 likely Oregon voters, taken Oct. 20-24 and released today, showed Mr. Bush with 45 percent, Mr. Gore with 41 percent, and Mr. Nader with 10 percent. (Of self-identified Republicans, just 1 percent said they were for Mr. Nader; among Democrats, the figure was 12 percent.) The margin of sampling error for the entire group surveyed is plus or minus four percentage points.
But whether those who now say they prefer Mr. Nader will actually mark their ballots for him is a different question. Democrats here are banking on the notion that a blitz of rallies, speakers and radio and television advertisements will persuade many of these people to support the vice president in the end.
The advertisements are aimed at voters in states with significant percentages of people who have indicated they support Mr. Nader. They focus on issues such as the environment or the prospects that Supreme Court nominees under a Bush presidency would be far more hostile to abortion rights than those who would be selected if Mr. Gore wins.
The argument that a vote for Mr. Nader could help put Mr. Bush in the White House seems to be backfiring."It's manipulative," said Joe Reinhorn, a shipping clerk for a computer parts company. "Some of my friends are arguing, 'Well, Bush is really bad, and Gore is somewhat bad, so it's important to vote for Gore.' Whatever happened to voting your conscience?"
Mr. Reinhorn and others also said that the main point in supporting Mr. Nader was not so much to elect him president, but to get him 5 percent of the total vote, which would award the Green Party federal campaign funds for the 2004 presidential election.
In some cases, the choice has split households. Susan Harlan, an associate professor of art at Portland State University, said she is veering toward Mr. Nader while her husband backs Mr. Gore.
"I just feel, in the long run, I'm being more honest by voting for Nader," Ms. Harlan said. It also bothers me that we haven't really been allowed to hear more from Nader, that he wasn't in the debates."
She said her husband, a systems analyst, was frustrated with her decision.
"He loves Nader, but he does not want to see George W. Bush in the White House," she explained.
"I appreciate Nader's left-leaningness," said Steve Fosler, who owns an architectural firm. "But a vote for Nader takes a vote away from Gore. It's as simple as that.
Tim Hibbitts, an independent pollster in Portland, has calculated that among those who indicate a preference for Mr. Nader in the polls, about half are unlikely to change their minds, in part because they view both major parties as "two peas in a very corrupt pod." The other half, he said, are more up in the air, and may well decided to weigh in on the Bush-Gore match-up if the race looks to be very close in their state, which it certainly does now.
One such a voter is Sean McCuen, 30, a mover and carpet layer who described himself as "temporarily unemployed."
"If it wasn't so close, I'd go for Nader for sure, just to show my support for what he's talking about," he said. "But if it's close, I want to be realistic. If there's really a chance of Bush getting elected, I guess I'd like to have a say about that. I don't want that to happen."

HEADLINE: Undecided Voters Remain Skeptical On Soft Money Pact in Senate Race

SERIES: Undecided: The Soft Money Issue

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
The soft-money deal between the candidates for the United States Senate in New York has backfired, some undecided voters say, drawing more attention to the fund-raising activities of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio than if they had quietly raised and spent millions and not made an issue of it.
"They're both saying, 'I have more integrity; I want to stop this,' " said Bob Harrison, a high school social studies teacher in Amsterdam, N.Y. "But neither of them are following through." 
 Tom Smith, who works at a Wal-Mart near Saugerties, pointed to the same disconnect. "Publicly, they say soft money is no good," Mr. Smith fumed. "But privately they say, 'Give me all you've got.' "
Doug Taggart, vice president of a Wall Street financial services concern, said he was offended enough to consider not voting. The soft-money pledge was political theater, Mr. Taggart said, pointing to subsequent disclosures: Mrs. Clinton's use of a White House invitation list for campaign solicitations; Mr. Lazio's spending of money from the Republican National Committee for television commercials; and both candidates' attendance at fund-raisers to harvest soft money for their allies.
The latest fuss, concerning $50,000 from a Muslim group that Mrs. Clinton says she will return, might have passed without remark but for the context. "On the surface, it's not that big a deal," Mr. Taggart said. "But my question is, if it wasn't publicized, would she have given the money back? One gets cynical when there's such a long track record of egregious behavior."
These three undecided voters, part of a panel whose members have been sharing their thoughts on the Senate race with The New York Times for 10 months, have more in common than their perception that both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Lazio have behaved hypocritically.
All of them understand, in broad strokes, that soft money is less regulated and more easily abused than other contributions, even if they are shaky on the technicalities of the candidates' pledge. All know that money can decide an election, leaving officeholders beholden to big donors.
"Would there be AK-47's out in the streets if the National Rifle Association wasn't cozy with Congress?" Mr. Taggart asked. "Would health care plans, good or bad, have passed if it weren't for the insurance lobby and the H.M.O.'s? You can go down the list. This is common-sense stuff."
All see the pledge proposed by Mr. Lazio -- to ban use of soft money, largely unregulated donations, for radio and television ads -- as a way of putting Mrs. Clinton at a financial disadvantage while staking out the moral high ground. "It was just a way to limit her war chest," Mr. Harrison said. "She has more to lose, so he's not the wholesome boy he wants us to think he is."
All say that the candidates struck such a narrow bargain that they left room for misconduct. They cite Mrs. Clinton's use of a White House invitation list, which she said was an honest mix-up. "Should we call it a brain cramp?" Mr. Smith asked. "A senior moment? It wasn't a legitimate oops, that's for sure. She was seeing what she could get away with."
And all think the candidates have been silent on the subject of campaign-finance overhaul legislation, a noteworthy misperception among otherwise well-informed voters. Mr. Lazio has voted twice for such a bill in Congress, and Mrs. Clinton has endorsed it.
"I haven't heard them say anything about it," said Mr. Taggart, the most diligent newspaper reader in the group.
Mr. Harrison, a registered Republican; Mr. Smith, a registered Democrat; and Mr. Taggart, an independent, are among a group of undecided voters culled from early New York Times/CBS News polls. The original panel of 11 has been winnowed to these 3, who say their minds are still not made up with Election Day near.
Two of the voters dropped out in May, unhappy with how the newspaper portrayed them. Tom Beck, a Long Island guidance counselor, cast his lot with Mr. Lazio, a familiar congressman from a neighboring district, as soon as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani withdrew as the Republican candidate. Two lifelong Democrats, Charlene Clinton, a mother from Buffalo on public assistance, and Dave Temkin, a telecommunications expert from Queens, settled on Mrs. Clinton in mid-September.
The latest to make up their minds, barring dramatic new circumstances, are Cathy Harrison, a nurse; Karl Schwartz, a computer consultant from Staten Island; and Barbara Smith, who inserts circulars in a weekly newspaper and also works in a day care center.
Mrs. Harrison, a lifelong Republican and the wife of Bob Harrison, has swung back and forth, leaning toward Mrs. Clinton after the candidates' first debate because of her assured presentation on upstate economic issues. But she has now landed in more familiar partisan terrain, choosing Mr. Lazio because of the first lady's "background, the corruption and everything with her husband." In a nutshell, Mrs. Harrison said, "I'd rather know I voted for a good person."
Mr. Schwartz, too, has chosen Mr. Lazio because he sees this as a one-issue campaign. Mr. Schwartz's wife, Joanne, has non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and he has been preoccupied with cancer. Mr. Lazio has been a sponsor of legislation to help poor women with breast and cervical cancer and, even more important to Mr. Schwartz, the congressman won an award from the Lymphoma Research Foundation of America.
Despite her customary loyalty to the Republican Party, Mrs. Smith, the wife of Tom Smith, has been inching toward Mrs. Clinton since the beginning of the campaign. The first lady's compassion for the less fortunate impresses her, Mrs. Smith said. She said she also admired Mrs. Clinton's demeanor during her very public marital difficulties, and how she handled the subject when it was raised in debates.
Neither Mrs. Harrison nor Mrs. Smith knows or cares much about campaign finance. But the rest of the panel defies the conventional wisdom that voters are not interested, capable of understanding or swayed by how candidates raise and spend money.
Mr. Schwartz said that "campaign finance reform is the most important mechanistic change we can make to rescue the political future of America." And Mr. Taggart said that nothing is more important than campaign finance reform when electing someone to the Senate, which he calls "the special-interest, favor-cutting branch of government."
There is a risk for candidates when voters know a lot, but not everything, about campaign finance activity. Sometimes, accustomed to misconduct, they will mistakenly assume a partisan fund-raising group is affiliated with the candidate who shares its views.
This is the case with Mr. Harrison, who has received strident fund-raising literature from the Emergency Committee to Stop Hillary Rodham Clinton, also known as the Conservative Leadership Political Action Committee. "Wherever Hillary goes, corruption, crime and cover-up follow," the mailing said, while seeking a contribution.
Mr. Harrison was unaware that the Lazio campaign had disavowed the committee. So the letter, copies of which were sent both to him and his wife, made him angry. He noted the return address. "Just a post office box," he said. "Who are these guys? They're sure taking away from the image of Lazio as an honest candidate."

HEADLINE: Ex-Fashion Model Vanishes And Police Open Investigation

BYLINE: By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

 BODY:
The police are investigating the mysterious disappearance of a former fashion model from the Upper East Side who they say has been missing for two weeks.
The woman, Lourdes Gruart, 46, has not reported to her job at a Manhattan executive-recruiting firm since Oct. 13, the police said. On Monday, a co-worker reported her missing to officers at the 19th Precinct station house, they said. 
 The police added that they did not know if foul play was involved.
"At this point we don't have a crime, so there is no suspect," said Deputy Inspector John W. Cutter of the Manhattan North Detective Squad.
Inspector Cutter raised an inconsistency between information that the police had collected so far and statements made by Ms. Gruart's brother, Mario, 31. Mr. Gruart told the police that he last saw his sister on Oct. 14, and that she told him she was leaving for a trip to Europe. But Ms. Gruart's passport has expired, the inspector said, adding, "At this point we do not believe she has gone to Europe."
In an interview with The Daily News, Mr. Gruart denied any involvement in the disappearance of his sister. There was no answer last night at Ms. Gruart's East 83rd Street apartment.
Mr. Gruart, who the police said is unemployed, has been staying at his sister's apartment for about a month and a half, said their mother, who is also named Lourdes Gruart and who lives in Plantation, Fla.
During her modeling career, Ms. Gruart lived in France, Italy and Japan and was a runway model for such fashion houses as Missoni and Armani, her mother said in a telephone interview.
The elder Ms. Gruart said she had been in close touch with her daughter and had planned to visit her for Thanksgiving. She also said that she had spoken with Mario Gruart recently. "He called here to know how I was doing," she said. "He said Lourdes told him that she was going to Europe for a couple of weeks and that's it. He said she was going to an interview for a good job."
 But Ms. Gruart added that "Lourdes would never go to Europe or any place without telling me."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES;
Holy Cow! Profits Are Outta Here!

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
With its concrete floor and exposed sheetrock, the small store near Grand Central Terminal looks like a bar with an under-construction motif or a place with no interest in a long-term lease.
And in fact, it won't be around long. This store trades in baseball ephemera, and will be gone before that Subway Series sweatshirt goes through its first rinse cycle. 
 There, and in temporary outlets throughout the metropolitan area, a Kansas company called Sportswon is peddling the gimmicks of the moment. There are Subway Series shot glasses, Subway Series pennants, Subway Series pins, Subway Series T-shirts seared with images of Derek Jeter's piercing eyes and Mike Piazza's Fu Manchu. For those with a spiritual bent, there are Yankee Christmas ornaments. For those with a romantic streak, Met earrings.
"Business is fantastic," said Tom Horne, the store's harried manager, whose forehead glistened like that of a base runner who had just gone from first to third. He was surrounded by items that were priced to make noses bleed. Most of his merchandise, as well as the Subway Series items being sold at stores everywhere, was feverishly slapped together in factories around the country so that people who live in the faraway city of New York could adorn their walls, their shelves and themselves with gaudy reminders and remnants of a certain baseball series.
In Seattle, Indianapolis and a Minnesota town called Winona, printing presses hissed to the glory of the Mets and Yankees. In Buffalo, machines hummed to embroider subway designs onto novelty caps. In San Diego, 20 people recently worked 15 hours straight to glue tiny metallic Mets and Yankees hats to World Series souvenir pins that had been produced weeks earlier in China.
Such nationwide dedication has allowed local businesses like the Grand Slam store in Times Square to push aside those Statue of Liberty cigarette lighters and make room for any inanimate object large enough to bear two phrases: "World Series 2000" and "Subway Series."
Those are the money phrases. And they have combined to create a red-hot moment for the $525-million-a-year sports-merchandising business. A trade newsletter, Sporting Goods Intelligence, recently chose a vivid image to reflect the industry's excitement: "New York Subway Series Has Retailers Salivating."
And even though the 4-2 triumph by the Yankees ended the formal playing of games in the series, the opportunity for making money will endure. It is an optimism undaunted by the claims of economists questioning the true impact of the series on the local economy. If need be, they said, they can show you the money.
The Yankee triumph, in fact, was hardly a headache, for the Yankees generate more sports-apparel sales than any franchise in sports.
All along, though, manufacturers worked overtime to meet the demand and to coin a catchphrase for the victorious team. The Mets victory on Tuesday thwarted the Yankees from winning four consecutive games for a third consecutive championship; that meant that Logo Athletic Inc. in Indianapolis had to reject tentative plans for T-shirts reading: "Sweepeat!"
Last month, the industry that brings material manifestation to hero worship and hometown pride began preparing for a harmonic convergence in baseball: a Yankees-Mets World Series. Beyond the shipping-cost savings from having two teams from the same sports-frenzied city, the matchup provided subtexts of nostalgia and rareness to exploit.
"This Subway Series has that added marketing play that they couldn't do if it was St. Louis and the Yankees," Bob McGee, the editor of Sporting Goods Intelligence, said. "They can convince consumers around the country that -- even if you hate the Yankees -- it's a once-in-the-lifetime thing."
Many major sports-merchandising businesses have New York consultants to advise graphic artists on which phrases and faces resonate with fans. This year, artists learned that Mr. Jeter of the Yankees and Mr. Piazza of the Mets had come to personify their respective teams; that the No. 4 subway line goes to the Bronx, while the No. 7 goes to Flushing; that Mets fans now claim ownership to the Baha Men song, "Who Let the Dogs Out?"
"We're looking into that," acknowledged Eddie White, a vice president for Logo Athletic.
Two guiding principles of the trade are to secure the necessary approval of Major League Baseball for every design, and to get the merchandise to retailers within hours of a deciding game. "You move in when the stuff is hot," Mr. McGee said. "And then get out of there before the stuff gathers dust on the shelves."
For example, shortly after the Yankees ensured a subway World Series by winning the American League pennant last week, workers at the Peter-David factory in San Diego dived into piles of pins. "We had all the Mets caps put on the day before," recalled Jerry Mischler, the company's general manager. "Then, about two in the morning, after the Yankees won, we put those caps on."
Peter Lindenbaum, an executive for the Modell's sporting-goods conglomerate -- with 57 outlets in the metropolitan area -- said his company had "if when" orders placed with factories around the country.
"The moment that the game was clinched, they started printing and producing the merchandise," he said. "We had trucks and vans that already had their routes planned out to get the merchandise delivered to our stores so that by the time we opened the next morning, at 7 A.M., we had the merchandise on the racks waiting for sales."
A brief foray into Subway Series semiotics suggests that the Yankees name or logo almost invariably appears above those of the Mets. "It is subtle," said Bill Whitlock, a Sportswon vice president. "But obviously, the Yankees have won so many for so many years now, and are favored for this one."
Then there is the near-deification of Mr. Jeter and Mr. Piazza. At the Sportswon outlet near Grand Central Station, a baseball bat bearing the likeness of Mr. Piazza was available for $129.87. That was cheaper than the $179.87 being sought for a framed, one-square-inch piece of pinstripe fabric that accompanied a photograph of Mr. Jeter.
Mr. Horne said the Sportswon outlets opened around the city a week ago, and will continue selling baseball ephemera for several days. And then, like the moments they try to exploit, they will vanish.
