HEADLINE: HIDDEN CHARGES: A special report.;
Extra Costs on Car Loans Draw Lawsuits

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES; This article was prepared under a joint reporting agreement between The New York Times and ABC News. A report on car dealers' lending practices will be televised tonight on the ABC program "20/20."

 BODY:
Shawn Core and Retina Massey-Core, newlyweds from Athens, Tex., were shopping for their first car -- a Valentine's Day gift for each other -- when they found a used Lincoln Town Car at a local Ford Lincoln Mercury dealer in 1995. With no established credit history, they were grateful when the dealer declared that they had been approved for a car loan by the Ford Motor Credit Company.
Ford agreed to finance the Cores' car at 14 percent. But that is not the rate they were told they got. Without their knowledge, Ford permitted the local dealer to add on two and a half percentage points. This increased the Cores' total finance charges by $466, which Ford immediately paid to the dealer. 
 This industrywide but obscure practice is called the dealer markup. In today's increasingly transparent world of consumer credit, it is an anomaly, almost a throwback to an earlier era.
Over several decades, laws and federal actions have pried open the credit process. Under fair housing laws, for example, all points and commissions must be specifically disclosed. More recently, banks and other major lenders have spend millions of dollars on credit systems that screen out subjective bias.
But there is no legal requirement that car dealers or lenders must tell consumers about the role dealers play in setting the interest rate on dealer-arranged car loans. At the dealership, the ultimate decision about a loan's cost is left to the discretion of an employee who profits immediately by charging the highest possible rate, even though the dealer has no money at risk.
Now this markup practice is coming under legal attack in at least five states, a joint investigation by The New York Times and ABC News "20/20" has found.
The Cores are plaintiffs in one of two class-action lawsuits in Texas state court seeking to have the markup declared a fraudulent and deceptive business practice. "If they're going to make money off the loan, then they need to tell people," said Mrs. Core in a recent interview.
A similar class-action case has been filed in California, said Jack E. McGehee of Houston, one of the lawyers working on the cases. In New Jersey, lawyers are seeking permission to expand an earlier individual case against Chase Manhattan into a class action. Litigation is also being prepared in Pennsylvania, he said.
"We're saying that this is a huge lie," Mr. McGehee said.
The dealers and lenders named as defendants in those cases, which include the Bank of America and the Ford Motor Credit Company, described dealer markup as a legitimate business practice that in no way misleads or defrauds consumers. Texas courts have affirmed this position in the past, they noted.
Dealer markups are also under attack in class-action cases pending in Nashville against the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation, two of the nation's most prominent auto finance companies.
Those lawsuits, filed under seal two years ago and recently made public, accuse the lenders of participating in arrangements that have resulted in black car buyers being charged higher dealer markups than whites, on average, regardless of creditworthiness.
"There's two problems from a consumer perspective with dealer markup," said Gary Klein, a lawyer with the National Consumer Law Center in Boston, which is helping plaintiffs in the Nashville cases. "The first is that it's secret. The second is that there's discrimination: blacks are typically charged more than whites in markup."
General Motors Acceptance, Nissan Motor Acceptance and the local auto dealers involved in the cases deny any discriminatory practices and say the plaintiffs' claims rest on flawed statistical analysis.
Car financing is an enormous business. In 1998, the most recent year for which the Federal Reserve has figures, there were more than $450 billion in car loans outstanding in America. This year, according to industry surveys, about half of the 17.7 million new vehicles expected to be sold will be financed. More than 75 percent of those loans will be arranged through car dealerships.
Industry experts say that the money dealers make on markups -- part of what dealers call "finance and insurance" income -- can make the difference between profit and loss for many dealerships.
The National Automobile Dealers Association and the American Financial Services Association, which represents lenders, say that markups compensate dealers for the expense involved in offering consumers the convenience of dealer-arranged financing.
Besides providing one-stop shopping for credit, dealer-arranged loans also give consumers access to more sources of credit than they would have on their own, especially if they have a poor credit history, these industry groups say. And they assert that the competition among lenders for each dealer's loan business keeps rates low even after dealers have added their "retail markup."
Lenders and dealers say that consumers who know their creditworthiness and the rates available from other sources can negotiate an excellent dealer-arranged car loan.
But consumer advocates dispute that, noting it is almost impossible, short of litigation, for consumers to find out the rates at which lenders approved them for dealer-arranged credit.
"If the dealers honestly think that this is a service that customers are willing to pay for, then let them tell the customers what they're charging for it," suggested Kathleen Keest, Iowa's assistant attorney general for consumer protection and the former chairwoman of the National Association of Consumer Advocates.
"I would very much doubt many people will think that it was a service worth three percentage points, or five, or even more," she said.
 
The Mechanics of the Buy Rate
With his strawberry-blond hair and blue eyes, Scott Zajaczkowski looks like a well-scrubbed choirboy. His earnest demeanor and college polish helped him succeed as a car salesman in the suburbs of Cleveland. "People trusted me. I'm an honest person, and I like to help people," said Mr. Zajaczkowski (pronounced Zage-ah-COW-ski).
But in the months after he was promoted to finance and insurance manager at his dealership, he became uncomfortable with his new role.
He said he was trained to persuade customers to pay the highest interest rates possible on dealer-arranged loans and to discourage them from paying cash or financing their car elsewhere. He was also expected to push other high-priced financial products, like extended service warranties and credit insurance policies that would pay off consumers' car loans if they died, he recalled.
After about 18 months, Mr. Zajaczkowski resigned. "I felt I was scamming people," he said. "I was so depressed."
His former dealership is now under new management, and executives there declined to comment on his remarks.
Mr. Zajaczkowski's reaction to his work is hardly typical, though. The finance and insurance manager -- or F & I manager, in dealer parlance -- is usually one of a car dealership's highest-paid employees, earning commission-based incomes of $100,000 or more a year, Mr. Zajaczkowski said.
Those paychecks reflect how important these "back end" products -- warranties, insurance and the loan markups -- are to dealer profits.
"We were expected to average $400 to $500 on all transactions, which includes leases and deals that you can't mark up because of special promotions," Mr. Zajaczkowski said. "So many are much, much more."
In his experience, he said, a customer's credit rating was entirely irrelevant to the size of the interest rate markup.
Dealers arrange car loans by collecting credit information from the customer and submitting it, by fax or e-mail, to one or more lenders -- major banks, the finance arms of major automakers, even local credit unions. The lenders analyze the customer's credit history and arrive at a minimum interest rate, called the buy rate, at which they would be willing to finance the purchase.
If the dealer quotes that minimum rate to the customer, and the customer accepts it, the dealer immediately sells or "assigns" that loan to the lender, which will typically pay him a small flat fee, between $50 and $150, for arranging the paperwork.
If possible, however, the dealer will quote a higher interest rate to the customer. If the customer accepts it, the dealer sells the loan to the lender and collects, from the lender, all or most of the cash value of the difference between the buy rate and the higher rate set by the dealer.
Some lenders, including Nissan, limit the number of percentage points a dealer can add to the loans they finance; other lenders, including G.M.A.C., will buy loans even if the dealer markup exceeds the fixed limit -- but will keep a share of the higher markup themselves.
Some lenders, bidding aggressively for a dealer's business, may impose no limit on markups at all. In those cases, finance managers "can charge whatever rate they want," Mr. Zajaczkowski said. "There's no rhyme or reason."
David Robertson is the founder and executive director of the Association of Finance and Insurance Professionals, a trade association for finance managers. He sees their role very differently.
In his view, endorsed by the trade associations for the dealers and lenders, finance managers are selling a service: the arrangement of credit.
"A retail merchant buys products at wholesale, sells them at retail and hopes he has the products his customers need -- and one of those products happens to be money," said Mr. Robertson.
Finance managers may work hard to find lenders willing to extend credit, especially to more marginal customers, he said. And finance managers have access to many more sources of credit than a typical consumer has, he added.
No informed consumer, Mr. Robertson said, should expect the dealer to arrange vehicle financing free.
Lawyers for the lenders and dealers point out that several earlier lawsuits challenging dealer markups have been largely unsuccessful.
The exceptions have been a few cases where the consumers could argue -- as Mr. McGehee's clients do -- that the dealers promised to seek "the best rate" on their behalf. Dealers who make such promises may unwittingly assume a fiduciary duty to look out for the consumer's best interests, lawyers say.
The Federal Reserve and Congress have declined to require dealers or lenders to disclose loan markups. The Truth in Lending Act requires only that consumers be informed about the actual interest rate and total finance charges they are paying. The loan documents that dealers use do that, although the dealers' own share is not disclosed.
To Mr. Robertson, it is just as legitimate to mark up the price of the car loan as it is to mark up the price of the floor mats the dealer sells. Must a grocer tell shoppers how much he marked up the lettuce?
No, consumer advocates answer, but the grocer bought the lettuce and is at risk if it goes bad before it is sold. Dealers have no money at risk in the car loans they arrange, they said, and are almost always free to cancel a customer's purchase if they cannot sell the loan immediately.
Moreover, they argue, the grocer does not pretend that the farmer actually set the price of his lettuce, nor does the grocer arbitrarily mark up the lettuce by 50 cents a pound for one customer and by $1 a pound for the next.
 
A Question of Discrimination
But what if this hypothetical grocer were found to be charging a 50-cent markup to his white customers and a $1 markup to his black ones?
That, in essence, is the allegation at the heart of the two class-action cases now pending against Nissan Motor Acceptance and General Motors Acceptance in Nashville.
The case against Nissan's financing unit began in late August 1995 when Betty Cason, who is disabled, went to a Nissan dealer in Nashville to shop for a four-door vehicle to accommodate the five foster children she is raising with her husband, Robert.
She selected a Pathfinder, trading in a two-door Chevrolet Blazer as her down payment and agreeing to finance the rest of the $24,292 purchase price through the dealer. She filled out an N.M.A.C. credit application.
The Casons' credit history is pockmarked with problems. But the Nissan credit unit would finance the Pathfinder purchase for 16.49 percent. The finance manager at the Nashville dealership marked the Casons' loan rate up to 19.49 percent, adding $3,520 to the price they would pay over the loan's six-year term.
Addie Coleman, a fragile-looking woman with two children, also went shopping for a new car in 1995, visiting a local Pontiac dealer. She, too, had a poor credit history and had been denied financing by several other lenders. The dealer arranged her loan with G.M.A.C., which agreed to finance the car purchase at 18.25 percent. The dealer presented her with a four-year contract showing an interest rate of 20.75 percent, which added $809 to her financing costs, and Mrs. Coleman signed it.
Both women later consulted Nashville Legal Services about other complaints they had against the local dealers and were referred to Clinton W. Watkins, a local lawyer. Initially, the lawsuits he filed on their behalf simply challenged the legitimacy of the loan markup.
But while litigating those cases, he and his co-counsel, Michael E. Terry and Wyman Gilmore Jr., obtained data on thousands of G.M.A.C. and N.M.A.C. loans in Tennessee. Using state motor vehicle records, they racially coded as many of the loan applications as they could.
They then asked Dr. Debby A. Lindsey, a business professor at Howard University, to analyze the loans -- roughly 9,600 from N.M.A.C. and slightly fewer than 5,000 from G.M.A.C.
Their theory was that the buy rate fairly captured all credit variables unique to individual consumers without respect to race.
In the plaintiffs' view, the dealers had no money at risk and should have been indifferent to any variations in consumer creditworthiness. So how did they decide how much to add to the buy rate on each loan?
What Dr. Lindsey found, in both cases, was that the amounts dealers added to the buy rates of black consumers were, on average, several hundred dollars higher than the amounts added to white consumers' rates.
Nissan ordered its own studies of the loan data, conducted by Dr. Janet Thornton, an economist with a private research firm in Florida. Dr. Thornton disputed whether differences in creditworthiness were fully captured in the lender's buy rate. Indeed, she argued, it was exactly those credit differences -- not race -- that explained the markup disparities.
Mark A. Cohen, a business professor at Vanderbilt University who confirmed Dr. Lindsey's findings, said that such differences were indeed examined, but they did not adequately explain the pattern.
The plaintiffs' lawyers said the dealers have testified that they do not consider credit factors when they set markups. The discriminatory pattern is "as bad, or worse" among consumers within the best credit tiers, said Mr. Klein, one of the plaintiffs' lawyers.
At a hearing in August, Anne Fortney, a former Federal Trade Commission member who is representing Nissan, dismissed the studies as unreliable.
"If I thought there was a problem here such as the plaintiffs described, I would not be defending this action," she said.
 
Defining the Dealer's Role
 In fact, the Nashville reports are only the latest in a decade-long series of studies that suggest there is pervasive discrimination against black car buyers, said Ian Ayres, a law professor at Yale University.
Professor Ayres, who also has a doctorate in economics, has conducted two audits of car dealers' behavior toward white and black customers, one in 1991, another in 1995. In each experiment, matched pairs of shoppers, identical except for their race, used the same script to negotiate for cars at dealerships in the Chicago area. And in each experiment, black shoppers got poorer deals, he said.
More recently, Professor Ayres analyzed five years of customer sales records from a Mazda dealership in suburban Atlanta. That data, too, showed that black customers paid higher car prices and larger finance charges than whites.
Professor Ayres said he cannot say for sure what causes these patterns: "There are lots of possibilities but none of them is inconsistent with old-fashioned racial discrimination by dealers."
The legal issues being tested in these cases are just as contentious as the statistical arguments.
The key question is whether the dealers are acting as the lenders' agents when they arrange car loans, as the plaintiffs contend, or whether the dealers are actually negotiating the loans and then selling them after the fact, as the lenders insist. The lenders' view has prevailed in many court tests and has been endorsed by staff interpretations from the Federal Reserve.
But the Justice Department, which recently has intervened in the Nissan case in Nashville, is arguing that the lenders actually exercise enormous control over the dealers as part of the loan process and should be held accountable for the outcome.
At a court hearing in August, Carolyn A. Evans, a Justice Department lawyer, noted that lenders design the application forms and limit how many points dealers can add to loans. They forbid markups on certain promotional loan programs. They determine how much of the markup the dealer can collect up front and how much must be shared with the lenders.
The Nissan finance unit makes dealers use its own forms to insure their loans comply with truth-in-lending laws, she added. "Why can't N.M.A.C. take steps to insure that the loans it approves and funds comply with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act?"
 
Getting, and Using, Information
These knotty questions are anything but academic for consumers making what may be, after their homes, the largest purchase they will ever make -- as Natolie Davis, a working mother who lives with her husband and three children in Bedford Heights, Ohio, can attest.
According to a lawsuit she has filed in Cleveland, Mrs. Davis had been assured by her local bank that she could get a 9.5 percent loan to finance her purchase of a new Ford Taurus she found at a Dodge dealership in November 1996.
Her dealer still arranged financing for her -- without her knowledge or approval, she contends in her lawsuit -- and found a lender willing to finance her purchase at almost the same rate her bank had quoted. Then, she contends, he marked up that loan rate, charging her 12.5 percent and receiving $963 in markup from the lender.
The dealer's lawyer contends that Mrs. Davis, who had taken possession of the car, did not provide proof of bank financing within the set time limit, and that the dealer had no choice but to seek financing for her.
The dispute captures the debate about markups: The dealer did, indeed, get a competitive loan rate for Mrs. Davis.
But that did not save her any money, since the loan's rate was raised. Over the term of the loan, the dealer's rate would cost $3,000 more than the bank rate, according to her complaint.
At least Mrs. Davis knew what rate she could command in the marketplace before she shopped for her car -- knowledge any consumer with access to a computer and the Internet can obtain. Consumers with excellent credit can now even arrange their loans online, through Internet lending services.
In the future, according to industry consultants, these developments could affect dealer-arranged car lending more than the litigation now making its way through the courts.
"The Internet has made consumers more aware of what constitutes a fair discount from the dealer's price on the car," said Chris Denove, a partner with J. D. Power & Associates, the customer-service consultants. "It has the potential to have an even more powerful impact for consumers who are attempting to finance their vehicles."
 
Preparing to Make a Deal
Consumer advocates offer these tips for car-loan shoppers:
*Before shopping, check with a bank, a credit union or an Internet site to learn what rates they offer.
*Ask credit agencies for a complete consumer credit history.
*Take note of the annual percentage rate the dealer offers, not just the monthly payments.
*Bargain for a lower rate; the dealer sets it and can change it.
*Never sign blank loan documents, even if that delays driving the new car home.

BUY RATE
The interest rate that lenders forward to dealers after reviewing a consumer's credit rating.
 
DEALER MARKUP
Percentage points that dealers add to the buy rate to produce the final rate that the consumer pays.
 
A.P.R.
Annual percentage rate; the sum of the buy rate and the dealer markup.The only rate that consumers learn.

County Executive Robert J. Gaffney of Suffolk County yesterday signed what is believed to be the nation's first countywide ban on driving with a hand-held cellular phone. HEADLINE: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES;
Unexpectedly, Series Brought Fans Together

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Strange that something so extraordinary and enchanted had such a familiar ending. For Yankee fans, that accustomed rush of self-satisfaction in their hearts; for Mets followers, that old sunken feeling in the pit of the stomach.
But as the Yankees finished off the Mets last night at Shea Stadium, shards of something special were still clinging to the Subway Series. New Yorkers had somehow managed to become friends with one another. 
 At Shea, the vendors stopped selling beer sometime around midgame as a hedge against disorder. This made the night an especially long one for Eddie Sanchez, who went from concession stand to concession stand in the sixth inning in search of liquid anesthetic.
"Not even for the No. 1 Mets fan?" he asked a stadium worker, pulling out of the pocket of his Mets jacket a New York Post article describing his devotion. The stadium worker shook his head.
But fears of rowdiness proved unfounded, as they had throughout a Series in which the only relevant violence took place on the field, and even that was potential rather than actual -- a piece of wood hurled by Roger Clemens that missed Mike Piazza, who may or may not have been his intended target.
By the end last night, there seemed to be more screaming Yankee fans than silenced Met fans at Shea, but there was peace.
"There are this many Yankees and Mets fans and there are no problems," said Steve Santanastasio, 32, of Jamaica Hills, Queens. "That's the one encouraging thing about this."
Daniel Rush, 20, of the Bronx, a Yankee fan, pronounced it simply "the most incredible game I've ever seen in my life."
At a pizzeria on East 83rd Street, not far from the apartment of Mets pitcher Al Leiter, three Yankee fans and a Mets fan took turns buying each other rounds of drinks all night.
After the Yankees scored two runs in the top of the ninth inning, the Mets fan, Angelo Monterroso, said, "Hey, we still got last licks."
His friend Louis Atanacao, 35, said, "Yeah, you're right, you're right." There was a long pause. "Next year."
Both of them started to laugh.
As Bernie Williams pulled down Piazza's long fly ball to end the game, Atanacao and his two buddies jumped up and down and embraced.
For one long week, there was a spell over New York City. The weather was perfect -- clean and crisp, never too cold to play, never too hot to feel un-Octoberish. It was a weeklong holiday of the sort usually found in places where go-go-go is not the overriding rule.
If New York was not the center of the universe during that time -- according to the A. C. Nielsen ratings, most Americans watching television were not too interested in seeing the teams from the nation's most annoying city battle it out -- New Yorkers did not care. For one week, the games knocked the homestretch of a tight presidential contest and a crisis in the Middle East off the top of the news.
While the Series may not have proved the economic boon that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promised -- after all, there was no out-of-town team to pull thousands of followers into the city -- it was a bonanza for the seeming thousands involved in the merchandising of baseball paraphernalia.
Now it is all over, except for the parade on Monday. Now New Yorkers can go back to ignoring each other, back to real life.
For Kevin Duffy, 25, a Mets fan who was slinking back home to the Bronx from Shea, this meant: "I go watch the Giants. You know, football. You've got to move on."
Tomorrow it is supposed to rain.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Prices Cool a Little for Apartments in Manhattan

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Market surveys by two major brokerage companies indicate that average sales prices for Manhattan apartments moderated a bit in this year's third quarter, with one report showing a 5 percent increase and the other -- coming off a record average price of almost $855,000 during the previous quarter -- indicating a 7.7 percent decline.
Price increases at the luxury end remained strong, however. 
 "My sense is that people have done a reality check and are more deliberate in their purchase decisions," said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, an appraisal company that prepares one of the Manhattan reports, for the Douglas Elliman brokerage company.
Even with its high-altitude price tags, the Manhattan market in the third quarter was a barometer of the wider economy, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
"This is really consistent with the performance of the national and regional economy, where the long-awaited soft landing started to take effect in the third quarter," Dr. Hughes said. "The first and second quarters of 2000 showed explosive growth, which slowed to simply strong growth in the third quarter -- but still a slowdown. So it's not surprising that this economic change was directly reflected in the Manhattan housing market."
In July, the Elliman survey of apartment sales below West 116th Street and East 96th Street reported a record average price of $854,704 in the second quarter. But the Elliman report released last week, for the period ended Sept. 30, indicated an average price of $789,225, a 7.7 percent drop. There were 2,089 sales surveyed for the new report.
Mr. Miller pointed out that even with the decline, the third-quarter figure was up 38.7 percent from the average price of $569,005 at the end of 1999. "The condo market, in particular, spiked during the prior quarters," he said, "and now has resumed a more normal pattern."
Dr. Hughes welcomed the respite. "The double-digit increases that we've had over the past year in Manhattan, if sustained, could ultimately yield a price bubble similar to what we experienced in the late 1980's," he said. "The bursting of that bubble made the ensuing recession the worst downturn in the city since the Great Depression."
According to the second survey, the Corcoran report, which was released this week, the average price for apartments below 125th Street during the third quarter was $759,000, up 5 percent from $723,000 at the end of June and up 24 percent from $614,000 at the end of 1999.
The surveys differ slightly in the neighborhoods they cover and the transactions they record. The Elliman report does not include condominiums, while the Corcoran report does.
"Although the gains are still strong," said Barbara Corcoran, chairwoman of the Corcoran Group, "it's a slower rate than in the first half of the year."
Asked what caused the slower rate, Ms. Corcoran said: "People are exhausted by runaway prices. After looking at a handful of apartments for a lot of money, they are tired of saying: 'Is that all I can get?'
"Also, there's a lot of change in the air: who will be the new president, what's going to happen with the stock market? Whenever there's a lot of change, people take a breath. They are praying that prices stop going up; thinking, 'Enough already.' And when enough people think that, they make it happen."
But there seems to be no brake on the high end of the market.
In what the Corcoran report calls its super-luxury category -- apartments selling for more than $5 million -- the average price in the third quarter was $5,846,000, up 13 percent from $5,180,000 in December 1999. There were 145 super-luxury sales surveyed for the report. "The most coveted apartment in Manhattan today is nine rooms and larger with a $4 million to $5 million price tag," Ms. Corcoran said.
In the Elliman report, the average price of luxury co-ops in the third quarter was $2,621,667, a 12.7 percent increase over $2,325,850 at the end of 1999. The Elliman luxury survey was based on 117 co-op sales (of apartments with two or more bedrooms on Fifth Avenue, Park Avenue and Central Park West) in the third quarter. Neither report analyzed luxury sales on a quarterly basis because, Corcoran and Elliman officials said, the samples are small.
In his assessment of the marketwide trends shown in the Elliman survey, Mr. Miller noted that besides average price, sales volume declined in the third quarter from the year-earlier quarter, dropping 15 percent, to to 2,089 transactions, from 2,447. But he attributed that slip in sales to factors other than lack of buyer interest.
Citing what industry officials call the listing discount -- the difference between the last price listed by the seller and the actual sales price -- Mr. Miller said listing discounts averaged only 1.3 percent in the third quarter, "which means apartments are still selling at just about full price."
"That tells me the decline in volume is attributable to the lack of inventory, not lack of interest," he said.
Most new development in Manhattan has been aimed at the high-end market. "As a result," Mr. Miller said, "a building constructed today might contain 100 very large apartments whereas, if it was constructed in 1986, it might have had 300 units. So we have a lot fewer units coming on the market for entry-level and middle-level buyers. That's a factor in the decline in sales volume.
"We're still seeing bidding wars."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 3, 2000, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The Residential Real Estate column last Friday about two market surveys that showed a cooling in average sales prices for Manhattan apartments referred incorrectly to a sample used in one of them. The survey by the Douglas Elliman company omitted condominium sales in calculating average sales in the luxury apartment category only, not for all apartments in the study.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 349 words

HEADLINE: Unfair Car Loans

 BODY:
Black plaintiffs have sued automobile finance companies because, they say, the companies charged them more for their loans than they charged comparable white borrowers. The lenders reject the accusation that their loans are racially discriminatory, pointing out that they never knew the race of the borrowers. That might seem like an ironclad defense. But the Department of Justice does not think so, and it has properly weighed in on the side of the plaintiffs.
In one lawsuit filed in Nashville two years ago, according to documents pried loose by The Times and ABC News, a black couple purchased a Nissan vehicle with money borrowed from the Nissan Motor Acceptance Corporation. The lender never met the borrowers. Instead the dealer met with the couple and submitted an application to the lender, who set a minimum interest rate based on the couple's credit rating. The dealer then decided how much of a markup to add to that rate. The dealer and lender split the proceeds of the markup, which cost the borrowers thousands of dollars over the loan's life. 
 The plaintiffs maintain that the markups are typically higher for black borrowers than for white borrowers with comparable income, wealth and credit records. That difference, the Justice Department agrees, violates the fair-lending rules even if the lending process took no intentional account of race.
The dealers may not be biased. They presumably set the markups to maximize profits and are able to charge applicants who have few alternative sources of loans -- often blacks -- more than applicants who can easily borrow from banks or family. Blacks may wind up paying more even if the dealers have no discriminatory motives.
The lenders say that if the dealers are responsible for discriminatory markups, sue them. But, Justice argues, the lenders control the loans and are therefore legally responsible. It also makes sense to put liability on the people who can most easily monitor and enforce the fair-lending rules, namely the large lenders. The lenders created the system. They should be compelled to fix it. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Media Giants in Joint Deal for Harcourt

BYLINE: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

 BODY:
The media giants Reed Elsevier and the Thomson Corporation are buying Harcourt General for $4.4 billion in cash and the assumption of $1.2 billion of debt, a lower-than-expected price for one of the largest acquisitions in the publishing business.
The main reason for the low price, analysts said, is that consolidation in the educational and professional publishing businesses -- Harcourt's core -- has progressed so far that there are almost no bidders left. Each of Harcourt's main businesses is dominated by just three or four companies, like McGraw-Hill or Pearson. Almost all potential bidders faced antitrust problems or had balance sheets full from recent acquisitions. 
 "If you look at all the potential acquirers, people are already maxed out," said Gareth Thomas, an analyst at Commerzbank Securities in London.
Under the terms of the joint acquisition, which will require the approval of antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe, Reed Elsevier has agreed to buy all of Harcourt and then sell about 30 percent of it to Thomson for $2.06 billion in cash.
Reed Elsevier, a British-Dutch publisher, pursued the deal primarily for Harcourt's legal, scientific, technical and medical publishing businesses. Reed Elsevier is already the largest company in that market by far.
"The breadth and depth of Harcourt's journals fit well," said Crispin Davis, the chief executive of Reed Elsevier. Harcourt is particularly strong in medical journals, where Reed Elsevier is somewhat weaker, he said.
Reed Elsevier will also retain Harcourt General's elementary and high school publishing business. Harcourt is one of the largest publishers of elementary and high school textbooks in the United States, while Reed Elsevier sells textbooks in other English-speaking countries. At least for the moment, Reed Elsevier will also keep Harcourt's small trade-book publishing operations.
Thomson, which is based in Toronto, will acquire Harcourt's units that provide online training and testing to adults, as well as its higher-education publishing business.
Richard J. Harrington, the chief executive of Thomson, said the acquisition satisfied the company's plans to expand into the online training business, a market growing at a rate of about 25 percent a year.
"The idea of learning after college to improve your wages or your position in business is really driving hard, and businesses are interested in the training and development of their people," he said. Harcourt is the second-largest company in online training, behind Smart Force.
The advent of the online services increased the economies of scale in both higher-education publishing and adult education, he said. As universities customize online curriculums, professors edit their own print-on-demand textbooks and companies contract for online employee testing and training, large educational publishers can spread the costs of the new technology over more products and revenue, he said.
Thomson expects to cut the expenses of the units it is acquiring by $75 million a year within three years. The units have a combined annual revenue of about $750 million.
For Harcourt's chairman, Richard Smith, whose family owns 28 percent of the company's stock, the sale ends a 40-year odyssey through the business world. It began with his father's chain of drive-in movies and included acquisitions in soft-drink bottling, department stores, luxury retailing, insurance, broadcasting and finally publishing. The company acquired the book publisher Harcourt Brace Jovanovich in 1991.
Harcourt General, based in Boston, has since sold or spun off most of its assets, including the spinoff of its General Cinemas theaters as GC Companies in 1993 and the spinoff last year of its Neiman Marcus retail chain. GC filed for bankruptcy protection last month, and Harcourt General was saddled with a $100 million liability because it guaranteed some of the movie theater leases, further lowering the company's price.
Some analysts had expected Harcourt to fetch a price as high as $6 billion, especially if it was sold off in pieces. But for tax reasons, Mr. Smith sought to sell the remaining publishing company as a whole, which made a sale more difficult. The bidding cooled further when the two principal contenders, Reed Elsevier and Thomson, decided to collaborate.

1989 -- Sells bottling division to PepsiCo for $1.88 billion.
1991 -- Acquires Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, a leading educational publisher, for $1.5 billion.
1993 -- Changes name to Harcourt General and spins off General Cinema to shareholders.
1999 -- Spins off most of its controlling interest in The Neiman Marcus Group to shareholders.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Campaign Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE SENATE
 
SUPPORT FOR GOVERNOR'S WIDOW
She is not on the Missouri ballot for the United States Senate. And she has given no indication that she would serve if appointed. But a campaign to put Jean Carnahan in the Senate is nevertheless well under way, with support groups forming, one rally already held, more planned and e-mail messages that promote her flying in every direction.
Mrs. Carnahan is the widow of Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri, a popular Democrat killed this month in a plane crash while campaigning to unseat Senator John Ashcroft, a Republican. His death came too late in the campaign to put a substitute Democrat on the ballot. Should Mr. Carnahan win, and polls taken in the past few days indicate the race is a tossup, the new governor, Roger Wilson, a Democrat and Mr. Carnahan's lieutenant governor, has promised to appoint Mrs. Carnahan to serve for her husband. 
 Mrs. Carnahan says it is too soon to commit to anything, and Missouri Republicans question the legality of the plan. John W. Fountain (NYT)
 
SUDDENLY, TOSSUPS
New polls indicate that the Senate races in Virginia and Michigan, once one-sided, are now tossups.
In Virginia, a Mason-Dixon survey taken this week found the incumbent Democrat, Senator Charles S. Robb, had closed to within three percentage points of his Republican challenger, former Gov. George Allen. For almost two years, Mr. Allen had enjoyed a comfortable lead in the polls over Mr. Robb. But in recent weeks, Mr. Robb has steadily closed the gap, thanks mainly to gains among women.
In Michigan, an EPIC/MRA poll taken this week found that Representative Debbie Stabenow, a Democrat, had pulled even with the Republican incumbent, Spencer Abraham, after trailing him for months. Two weeks ago, an EPIC/MRA poll found her 10 points behind. She and Senator Abraham together have spent more than $16 million on the contest. (NYT)
 
THE DEMOCRATS
 
GORE AND THE RAP STAR
In Vice President Al Gore's latest appeal to young voters, he sat for an interview with Queen Latifah, a rap singer and syndicated talk-show host whose audience is chiefly between 18 and 24, a lot of them generally switched off by politicians.
In the interview, to be broadcast on Wednesday, Queen Latifah, whose real name is Dana E. Owens, gave Mr. Gore a "pop-culture quiz," asking if he had ever worn leather pants.
"I don't think I have," he said. But he had a leather vest for riding his Harley, he said.
Ever been caught speeding?
"I don't think I ever got caught speeding on my motorcycle," Mr. Gore answered. "Certainly I got caught speeding in my car when I was younger. But that wasn't to say I wasn't speeding sometimes on my motorcycle. I look back on those days and I feel like I'm very lucky to have survived."
Then he added: "Once, on a dare, we went double-dating on my motorcycle." At the time, he went on, he was wearing a tuxedo. Did he get pulled over?
"Actually, there was a blue light," Mr. Gore answered. "And I can't say for sure that they were coming after us, but just on the chance that they were, we cut through an alleyway."
And finally: "On a woman, leather or lace?" Mr. Gore mulled for a moment, then answered: "Lace." Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)
 
THE INTEREST GROUPS
 
UNION DOLLARS FOR GORE
The political action committee of New York State's largest health-care union sent a $1 million check to the Democratic National Committee this week to bolster the campaign of Vice President Al Gore.
The contribution, by 1199/S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union, followed an earlier donation of $1 million to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and a $600,000 donation to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.
"We are alarmed about the prospect of having George Bush as the next president and about the impact that will have on the labor movement," said Dennis Rivera, president of 1199, a division of the Service Employees International Union. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
 
THE ISSUES
 
ASSISTED-SUICIDE VOTE
Residents of Maine vote next month on a ballot initiative that would allow very ill patients of sound mind to ask their doctors for medication to help them die. The latest poll on the Oregon-style proposal, conducted last weekend by Strategic Marketing Services, found the electorate evenly divided, 43.5 percent for, 43.5 percent against and the rest undecided. In mid-September, a poll by the same company found that 67 percent of the state's voters supported the initiative.
States like Michigan, where a similar initiative was defeated in 1998, have seen a similar dynamic as Election Day approached. Some analysts say it may be because people support assisted suicide in general, but become troubled by the details of any particular law. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

HEADLINE: Insecurity Once More Casts a Pall in Kosovo

BYLINE: BY CARLOTTA GALL

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Oct. 27

 BODY:
As the West rushed to embrace Vojislav Kostunica's recent emergence as president of Yugoslavia, Kosovo's Albanians -- suppressed for years by the Serbs until NATO intervened last year -- felt threatened once more.
While the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, was in power, the Albanians were confident of support and understanding from the West -- and even sympathy for their goal of independence. 
 But now they are suspicious about Mr. Kostunica and feel a new urgency to resolve the status of Kosovo, which is administered, for now, by the United Nations. International peacekeeping troops have been protecting the Kosovo people since Yugoslav troops withdrew in June 1999 after 78 days of NATO bombing.
The Albanians' concerns remain despite the momentous change that swept through their neighbor and old enemy, Serbia, just weeks ago, bringing Mr. Kostunica in as the new president and fundamentally changing the political world around Kosovo.
At first, the Albanians here ignored what was going on to the north. Since they remain officially part of Yugoslavia, they could have participated in the Yugoslav election that brought Mr. Kostunica to power. But the Albanians boycotted the election, as they have every election organized by Belgrade during the past 10 years, because, they argue, voting would legitimize a rule by Serbs they do not want.
"We are not joining in with the international euphoria over the events in Belgrade, but I understand the euphoria," said Alush Gashi, a senior member of the largest political party, the Democratic League of Kosovo. He said Mr. Kostunica is someone the Albanians can talk to, "and if he is someone who has not committed any crimes, that's good, but he is a man who has not distanced himself from crimes against humanity."
Mr. Kostunica's rise to power has coincided with the first real elections the Albanians have known since Mr. Milosevic stripped them of autonomy in 1989. The balloting on Saturday will be for local councils, but the campaigning, which the Albanians have embraced enthusiastically, has revolved around global issues -- first and foremost, independence for Kosovo.
This week, Mr. Kostunica acknowledged that crimes were committed by Yugoslav forces in Kosovo and has promised to work on freeing Albanian prisoners from Serbian jails as he tries to forge a relationship with the people of Kosovo. His pledge was welcomed by Dr. Bernard Kouchner, head of the United Nations administration in Kosovo.
"If the Albanians are not saying anything, that means they see it as good," Dr. Kouchner told journalists this week. "Kostunica's comments are good, and I think he will be making more. We will face difficulties, but the difficulties will have become positive."
And Richard C. Holbrooke, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said during a visit to Kosovo this week that he was confident that Mr. Kostunica would not pursue Mr. Milosevic's tactic of infiltrating the Serb police and military on covert missions to destabilize Kosovo and intimidate the beleaguered Serb communities left here.
But most ordinary Albanians say they see no difference between Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Kostunica.
"I don't believe he is better -- he was also a paramilitary in Kosovo," said Mihrije Preneqi, an electrician, as she left a political rally in Pristina, the capital. She was referring to a photograph that showed Mr. Kostunica holding an automatic rifle during a visit to Kosovo, and which has been widely published here since he won the presidency.
Ms. Preneqi said she supported independence, but also some dialogue. "If the Serbs are democratic, then we see our future as neighbors," she said.
But speeches at the election rallies this week showed that popular feeling is still violently anti-Serb. Hashim Thaci, the former political leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army, which fought Serbian forces for two years, and now leader of the Democratic Party of Kosovo, draws much of his support from young activists and former fighters.
"The killer Serb army under Milosevic is the same army under Kostunica," Mr. Thaci said. "I want you to be sure that every act of Belgrade will be rejected and condemned, and will get the response it deserves from the Albanians and from the democratic world," he said, to enormous cheers.
Yet, when pushed, the Albanians agree that Mr. Kostunica can only be an improvement on Mr. Milosevic, who disenfranchised them and sent his forces against them and their armed rebellion in Kosovo, culminating in the expulsion of more than a million people from their homes during the NATO bombing campaign. Hundreds of thousands were left homeless and thousands were killed.
Qerim Mulaj, 30, a former guerrilla fighter, now unemployed, said he could see Albanian leaders entering into a dialogue with Mr. Kostunica in due course. "If all the Albanian prisoners are released and the fate of the disappeared solved, then they could. It would be normal," he said as he left the rally.
Political leaders are calling for general elections in Kosovo as soon as possible, arguing that this is the only way that they can have viable, elected leaders who can negotiate their future and deal with Serbia, rather than rely on foreigners to do it for them.
"Independence is not your issue, it is not the West's issue," said Ramush Haradinaj, a former commander of the liberation army and now leader of an alliance of parties, the Alliance for the Future of Kosovo.
"We will work inside the rules," he said, "but I do not need to discuss it with anyone. The West is not the one who decides, and it must respect the will and determination of Kosovars."
Mr. Haradinaj makes it clear he will continue the battle for independence if necessary, even if it has moved into the political arena. "Kostunica is good because a democratic Serbia will be better prepared to accept the reality here," he said.

HEADLINE: Stifling the Source of the Surplus

BYLINE: By David Baltimore; David Baltimore, president of the California Institute of Technology, won the Nobel Prize in medicine in 1975.

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.

 BODY:
As debate rages this season about how to spend the federal budget surplus, no one is discussing the real forces that generated it and how to keep them healthy. Many Americans understand that our unprecedented economic well-being comes from mining the extraordinary vein of basic knowledge laid down by our research universities over the last few decades.
Why, then, do we hear nothing in the campaign about how the Democrats or the Republicans will ensure new discoveries to keep our prosperity going? 
 When I confront a politician with that question, I am told that these issues are too technical and complex for a campaign. I disagree. The issue is straightforward: We must keep replenishing the vein we are mining because, if it runs out, we will have no more of the ore from which technological innovation is created. We must be concerned about both direct financing for basic research projects and maintaining the health of institutions that educate the people who make innovation happen.
Basic research is often considered to be studies done with no practical goal in mind. It may be very abstract. However, years -- even decades -- after its completion and publication, basic knowledge may suddenly have a great commercial impact. Thus, the health of the American basic science enterprise in the 1950's and 60's generated the huge surge of industrial applications in the 70's, 80's and 90's. We have seen this with the fundamental discoveries in microelectronics, biology, information theory, computer science. These basic sciences generated modern telecommunications, biotechnology, the computer industry and now the Internet.
The cold war fueled basic research funding for four decades, as we feared that the Russians might outstrip us in science, giving them an edge in military technologies. Our investment paid off, not only in the most sophisticated military the world has ever known, but in our prosperity.
Were I a politician, I would forcefully state that the vibrancy of the American economy for our children and grandchildren depends on our investment in basic science today. I would insist that the science budgets of the National Science Foundation, NASA, the Department of Energy and the Department of Defense be strengthened. The only budget keeping up with the opportunities is that of the National Institutes of Health, and I would pledge -- as Al Gore did for cancer research -- that the momentum would be continued.
We spend less than half a percent of the gross domestic product on basic science. We should be able to afford to double that amount. Today, the federal government does not even finance the full cost of the research it supports at universities, as a recent RAND study noted, and this forces universities to use their endowment returns to subsidize the research.
On the education side, the political parties have fallen over themselves championing increased support for kindergarten through 12th grade. I certainly support them. It is higher education, however, that produced the people whose intellectual capital has contributed so decisively to today's prosperity.
We need to remember that people in training -- graduate students and postdoctoral fellows -- carry out the bulk of the research. Thus more money for research means more apprenticeship training opportunities to nurture the development of the next generation of scientists and scientific entrepreneurs. It is a system that is self-renewing as long as the commitment to it is maintained.
I am confident that championing scientific accomplishment and higher education would be a vote-winning strategy for Vice President Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. It would be refreshing to see one or both of them adopt it.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
Blacks Stick With Gore Despite Differing Views

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 27

 BODY:
If he were headed to the polls today, Curt Farrison, a real estate broker in the predominantly black neighborhood of South Norwalk, would gladly pull the lever for Al Gore. But Mr. Farrison, whose three children are all grown, said he disagreed with the vice president's opposition to vouchers, which would let poor parents use tax dollars to send their children to private schools.
"Every opportunity to give your children a better life, you take," said Mr. Farrison, who is black. He recalled how nearly 30 years ago he and his wife moved from Norwalk to Danbury so their children could attend better public schools. "That's what the vouchers are," he said. "They are an option. It gives you choice. You can take that voucher and turn that into a decent education for your child." 
 Joseph E. Mann, a Democratic district leader in South Norwalk, is a party loyalist who has never considered voting for George W. Bush. But he disagrees pointedly with Mr. Gore's support for the death penalty. "I happen to not be for it," Mr. Mann said. "I think there are too many problems associated with it, especially for minorities." He added, "I just don't think it's a deterrent and I don't think it's civilized."
In conversations with two dozen black voters in this diverse city of nearly 80,000 people, the death penalty and school vouchers emerged as two issues on which even some of the staunchest Democrats could find reason to disagree with Mr. Gore. And yet, no voters said that a differing view on either of these issues would change their vote -- at least not in the presidential race.
The conversations, with small-business owners and teachers, government employees and social service workers, clergymen and police officers, suggested a Clinton-style compartmentalization of issues and priorities among black middle-class voters here. The voters, mostly Democrats but also some Republicans, said smaller differences could be put aside in favor of larger considerations, especially concerning the economy.
"I think the current administration should go back in, no questions asked," said Harold McCready, 65, a Republican member of Norwalk's City Council and the owner of the Old Post Liquor Store on Cedar Street. "When I put my hand into my right pocket -- that's where I keep my money -- when I feel there are greenbacks there all the time, I don't want that to change. And the stock market has been good to me."
Cassandra Eaton, a private music instructor, said that as a black woman, she might not see eye to eye with Mr. Gore on all issues, but she considered his policies appealing to the middle class. "Right now he is offering more for us in the middle class," she said. "I am looking for someone to identify with. Obviously, the racial thing I can't identify with him. But there is something there, I am hoping. He has that edge for me."
For this reason, Ms. Eaton said she could put aside her differences with Mr. Gore on school vouchers. As a 60-year-old grandmother of two young boys, 7-year-old Eric and 3-year-old Anthony, Ms. Eaton said she would like to see private school available to them. "If I could get them in private school through vouchers, I would," she said. "I would want that option."
The voucher issue is far less crucial in Connecticut, a state that is firmly in the grasp of Mr. Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, than it is in Michigan, a swing state. There, a statewide ballot referendum on vouchers has drawn attention to a philosophical disagreement between Mr. Bush, who supports vouchers, and Michigan's Republican governor, John Engler, who opposes them.
Although the stakes are not so high here, the issue is still sensitive enough that not everyone feels comfortable speaking about it. Ms. Eaton said she was hesitant to discuss the issue because it was so contentious. Opponents, including Mr. Gore, argue that vouchers would drain necessary resources from public schools, hinder public school reform and hurt the majority of poor students who would remain in public school.
"It's a very touchy thing," Ms. Eaton said. "Especially when you want the best for everyone. At the same time, when you look at others who can make it on their own, you want the best for your youngsters as well."
Geraldine Jean-Louis, a Haitian immigrant who recently became a citizen, paused in the ShopRite parking lot to say that she, too, saw vouchers as an opportunity to get the best for her child. "My son goes to public school and enjoys it," she said. "But I'd rather have him in a class with 14 or 15 children instead of being in a class with 40 children."
Robert E. Burgess, the director of Norwalk Economic Opportunity Now, a local nonprofit social service organization, said he was more concerned about the economy and Social Security but that he did agree with Mr. Gore on vouchers. "The majority of kids in this country are in public school, and public school will always be needed," he said. "So the voucher will be counterproductive to helping the majority of the children."
Giving school vouchers to people and saying, "You go where you want to go," he said, would take money from the public schools. "There will be no improvement in the public schools," he said.
At age 57, Mr. Farrison, the real estate broker and a Norwalk resident again, is a satisfied man. He has three grown children: a son in the Marines and two college-graduate daughters now embarked on professional careers. Business is steady at the local real estate brokerage that he owns. And if his mind becomes preoccupied these days, it could well be that he is contemplating his 1-year-old grandson or his next game of golf, making him just the kind of happy voter unlikely to throw an incumbent out of office.
Although he parts ways with Mr. Gore on school vouchers, he says he understands Mr. Gore's criticism of them. "It's a Band-Aid," he said. "But Band-Aids stop bleeding and they stop infection one day at a time. The true battle is about making the school systems equal. The quick fix-'ems are vouchers, obviously busing, etc.
"Those are just Band-Aids and any person worth his or her salt recognizes that," Mr. Farrison said, adding that Mr. Gore has the right long-term idea. "He is saying exactly what I am saying. He is saying, 'Let's not use the Band-Aid, let's fix the system.' "
But he added: "In the absence of having the fix in place, let's go with the vouchers. Let's put vouchers on the table and then once we do that, let's put a solid fix on the system. Let's take out the hammer and the nails."
Mr. Farrison said he did agree with the vice president on the death penalty. "How do we make the punishment so horrible that people don't kill?" he asked. "I do strongly believe in an eye for an eye."
One reason that votes in the presidential race may not hinge on vouchers or the death penalty is that education and criminal justice are largely administered at the state or local level. That point was not lost on Mr. Farrison, who said that despite his support for Mr. Gore, he might not vote for other Democrats running in local races. "In my opinion, the best way to vote is issue by issue, candidate by candidate," he said.
Shelley T. Ragsdale, the owner of the Ragsdale Fuel Oil Company, on West Avenue, said that he had sent one son to public school and the other to private school and recognized the benefits of both systems. But he said that tax dollars should not be made available in the form of vouchers to encourage parents to remove children from public schools. He also said he feared that the poor would not really benefit.
"People of color will not flourish in this system and people of non-color will flourish," he said. Vouchers would barely cover tuition, Mr. Ragsdale said, and many poor parents would not be able to afford to transport their children to the private schools located outside their home neighborhoods. "They rely on the bus system," he said. "They don't have the wherewithal."
Also, he said, the poor children "would feel out of place" in the wealthier private schools."
The Rev. Albert D. Tyson, pastor of Bethel A.M.E. Church, said he agreed with Mr. Gore on vouchers and planned to vote for him because he favored the Democrats' economic proposals. Mr. Tyson, who is 73, said that his vote for Mr. Gore would not be deterred by his passionate disagreement with the vice president on the death penalty. After all, Mr. Tyson and other voters noted, Mr. Bush's home state of Texas has carried out more executions than any other state.
Still, Mr. Tyson said he wished that Mr. Gore had a different view. "Once a person's life is taken, you can't give it back to them if you have made a mistake," he said. "And the justice system is not perfect, and that disturbs me."
Despite such disagreements, the voters interviewed said race relations were better now than they were eight years ago and they suggested that credit belonged to President Clinton. "I think in every respect the record is good, much better than anyone else's as far as involving minorities in government," said Mr. Mann, the local district leader. "I think there is no doubt that Clinton has been good for minorities, anywhere you want to look."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
In Speech, Bush Says It's Time for Leader Who Will Do the People's Business

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech that Gov. George W. Bush delivered at a school in Knoxville, Tenn., on Tuesday as recorded by The New York Times:
I know this is going to be a close election, and one of the reasons I come is not only to ask for your vote but to ask for your help. During the next two weeks -- I know you vote early here in Tennessee. So do we in Texas. Sometimes we vote early and sometimes we vote often. I just want to make sure those folks voting often are for us. But turn out the folks. Don't be afraid to turn to those independent-minded voters or some of those open-minded Democrats, because you know what? Like us, they know we can do better in Washington, D.C. 
 It doesn't have to be that way in Washington where you're pitting one group of people against another, where there's finger pointing and name-calling and bitterness. No, Washington doesn't have to be that way. You see, this country can have a fresh start after a season of cynicism. We can lift this nation's spirit, and we can focus on doing what's right for the people of this country. We can do what's right for America.
There's a lot of talk about the so-called projected surplus. Let me tell you about the surplus. Let me tell you about it. First of all, it is going to exist not because of the ingenuity and the hard work of the federal government. It exists because of the ingenuity and the hard work of the people of America. That's why the surplus exists. And that money -- if you listen to my opponent, he lost some of the lessons he learned here in Tennessee, evidently -- because that money is not the government's money, Mr. Vice President. That money is the people's money. And that is one of the big differences in this campaign, and that's what you've got to tell our fellow independents and Democrats.
This is a man who trusts government, and we trust the people. He trusts the federal government, and I trust the people with your own money to make your own decisions for your family. It's a fundamental difference of opinion, and it's one of the reasons why, when the people go to vote, when we get them out to vote, they're going to come our way on Nov. 7.
Here's what I think we ought to do with the surplus. First I'm going to tell you what we ought not to do with the surplus -- spend it all and more. Listen, I'm running against a man who's going to define the history books about big spending. He's going to be the biggest spender, if he gets elected, in history. He'll be three times bigger than that which President Clinton proposed. His budget proposals, truthfully, are bigger than those of Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined. Now that's saying something, folks. That's a man who trusts Washington. It's a man who wants Washington to have the power over our lives. That's not the way Tennessee thinks, and that's not the way America thinks either. So here's what we ought to do.
We ought to take half of that surplus and set it aside for one purpose: Social Security. We need to be able to say to seniors loud and clear, a promise that this country has made will be a promise that this country will keep. Our seniors are going to get their Social Security checks, and we're not going to let the other side scare them. They're running ads that are trying to scare the seniors, and that's old-style politics. Not this time and not this year. This is the year we're going to say to the seniors: You can trust us. We're going to do what we say we're going to do. . . . We need to let younger workers take some of their own money and put it in the private market to get a better rate of return on their investment dollars.
But they don't want you to do that in Washington. Because they want the government making decisions for everybody. See, I trust people. I want you to have your own assets to call your own, assets you can pass on from one generation to the next, assets that are real assets, not i.o.u.'s. And assets that will get a better rate of return on your money than the paltry 2 percent the federal government is getting on your behalf. No, it's time for new thinking in Washington, D.C., to make sure we save Social Security.
There's some important projects. There's some important things we've got to do with some of that surplus. About a quarter of the surplus needs to go for important priorities. One of them is to rebuild our military to keep the peace. I want to tell the moms and dads and grandparents here that Dick Cheney and I will do what it takes to keep the peace. But I want a strong hand. I want a strong hand when it comes to keeping the peace.
Now you've heard the debates about how our military is the strongest in the world. It is. But the role of a leader is to anticipate. The role of a leader is to be looking down the road and when you see warning signals, do something about it. I worry about the captains leaving our ranks. I worry about the fact that a recent survey showed that a lot of personnel in the military are not going to re-up. I worry about our military trying to be too many things to too many people around the world.
Not only are we going to restore morale by paying our women and men in uniform more money, and house them better, and make sure they're better trained and better equipped. You're going to have a commander in chief who respects the men and women in uniform and a commander in chief who in turn earns the respect of the men and women in uniform.
Education will be a priority, but I assure you I don't want to be the federal superintendent of schools. I believe in local control of schools. I believe we ought to trust parents and teachers and principals to make the right decisions. The people who care more about the children in Knoxville, Tenn., are the citizens of Knoxville, Tenn.
My view of compassionate conservatism says any time we find somebody who cannot help themselves, we will. We're a compassionate nation. People should not go without in America. One of the big concerns in our society today is the fact that some of our seniors are having to choose between prescription drugs and food. And that's not right. That's not our vision for America.
So I've got a plan that says we're going to spend the money necessary to modernize and strengthen Medicare. We're going to have a Medicare system that includes prescription drugs for all. We'll give seniors the choices they need, if they want to have a different plan. We're going to have an immediate helping hand for seniors. That means drugs and money for prescription drugs for poor and moderate-income seniors. This is going to require a leader who brings people together, someone who does not use Medicare as a political issue but someone who sees it as an important priority for our nation.
Now I know you've heard the debate and all the numbers and all the language, but one thing is for certain that they cannot escape. In 1992 they went around the country saying 'we're going to do something about Medicare and prescription drugs.' In 1996, if you think about the echoes from the past, they said the same thing. And here we are now four years later, and they're still saying the same thing. Here's our answer, Mr. Vice President. You had your chance. You have not led, and we will.
It's time for new leadership in Washington. It's time to get somebody up there to get the people's business done. It's time to send power out of Washington for our schools, save and strengthen Social Security, do something once and for all on Medicare, do something about the military so we can make the world more peaceful, keep our promises to our veterans. But let me tell you what else we have an opportunity to do. We have an opportunity to, once we fund our priorities, remember whose money the surplus is, and send some of it back to the people who pay the bills.
They've been telling me all along during the campaign -- the pundits -- the pundits have been saying, you know, that people don't want tax relief. The polls say they don't want tax relief. You know what my answer is? I really don't care what the polls say. I'm standing before you because I do what I think is right. And what I think is right, what I think is right, is to hear the voices of those who work hard to make a living.
I want to tell you the facts: people pay more in federal, state and local taxes than they do for food, clothing and housing combined. Now you think about that load on the people who work for a living. The pundits may not think people want tax reform, but I hear they do all across the country. I hear they do all across the country. We're going to use this moment now in American history, seize this moment, to make our tax code more fair and to give people some of their own money back.
The death tax is unfair. It's unfair to Tennessee farmers, it's unfair to small-business people, and we need to get rid of the death tax. The marriage penalty is unfair; what kind of tax code is it that says if you get married, you'll pay more in taxes than if you're single? It's a bad tax. It's a bad tax.
We're going to drop the top rate to 33 percent for two reasons: one, there ought to be a principle involved. The federal government should take no more than a third of anybody's income. But two, I understand how capitalism works. The role of the federal government is not to create wealth but an environment in which entrepreneurs flourish, in which small businesses can grow to become big businesses. Our economy is strong today not because of Al Gore, I might add, our economy is strong today because we're a land of dreamers and doers, but also because of the tax cuts, Ronald Reagan's tax cuts in the 80's.
We need an insurance policy against an economic downturn by giving people some of their own money back, and I want you to remind our friends who haven't made up their minds yet, that people are paying more as a result of failed leadership in Washington. Those gasoline prices are going up. You know why? There's been no energy plan. They're going up and so are the heating bills, the heating oil bills, up in the Northeast. There's no energy plan. Their own energy secretary got caught, if I might use a Texas phrase, sleeping at the switch. They were caught unaware. We're more dependent than ever before. I think Americans ought to be asking, where's all the capital we earned overseas after defending some of our OPEC nation friends? Where are they?
They're pulling 30 million barrels out of what they call the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Sounds like they're using that as the Strategic Political Reserve. They're trying to cover up the fact that they've had a failed energy policy.
No, our people need tax relief. And therefore, we're going to cut the taxes not on a few, but on everybody who pays taxes. We're going to drop the bottom rate from 15 percent to 10 percent and increase the child credit from $500 to $1,000 per child and here's why. I want you to hear why and tell your friends this. This tax code we have today is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. If you're a single mother in Tennessee, trying to raise two children and making $22,000 a year, one, you're working the hardest job in this state. That's the toughest job. And two, for every additional dollar she earns above the $22,000, because of this tax code, justified by the agents of the status quo in Washington, D.C., she pays a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200,000 a year.
In fact, this nation has put a toll booth right square in the middle of the road to the middle class. If you stand on one side of the toll booth, you pay the rates we've been telling you, and the other side, for those struggling to get ahead, for those working their heart out to put food on the table, you pay a higher marginal rate. And that's not right, folks. You're looking at a man who hears the voices of the entrepreneurs, but our plan also addresses the inequities of the system that hurts the hard-working people at the bottom of the economic ladder.
It's time to knock down that toll booth on the road to the middle class. I've heard all the talk about rich people versus poor people. That's class warfare that Mr. Gore likes to put onto people. That's not how you lead. That's not what this nation needs. This nation needs somebody to bring us together. This nation needs a healer, not a divider. This nation needs somebody, somebody, who's going to stop the bickering and fighting and name-calling in Washington, D.C. . . .

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk
