The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: October 29, 2000

SECTION: Section 7; Page 18; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1317 words

HEADLINE: Clueless in Virginia

BYLINE: By Jacqueline Carey; Jacqueline Carey is the author of "The Other Family," a novel, and "Good Gossip," a collection of stories.

 BODY:

 BLUE RIDGE
 By T. R. Pearson.
 243 pp. New York:
 Viking. $24.95. 
 I wish more mainstream writers turned out the occasional mystery. There are notable exceptions, but most American detective novels are composed with all the verve and originality of the instruction manual that came with your food processor. And thanks to the iron grip of Raymond Chandler, that mystery-cum-manual is probably littered with preposterous metaphors that are better read with your eyes half shut, for your own protection. (English whodunits, on the other hand, are generally worse.)
I can say all this because I am an indefatigable fan of the mystery genre. As such, I was curious to see what T. R. Pearson would do with it in his new book, "Blue Ridge." Pearson is best known for "A Short History of a Small Place," a deceptively folksy, highly ornate exploration of a suicide in a small Southern town. Every long-winded writer who ever set foot south of the Mason-Dixon line has been compared to Faulkner, but there's no getting around it -- A Short History of a Small Place" is definitely Faulknerian. In mystery circles, Faulkner is best known for remaining indisputably himself when he wrote the detective stories in "Knight's Gambit." Pearson, too, remains his neo-Faulknerian self in "Blue Ridge," and the results are delightful.
The book alternates between two crime stories, and -- on the surface, at least -- the conventions are followed. Ray Tatum, a new deputy sheriff in Hogarth, Va., is directed by a couple of hikers to a pile of bare bones just off the Appalachian Trail. The skull is caved in. For the investigation, he is teamed up, buddy-movie style, with a tough black Park Service employee who could be played by Pam Grier. ("Well, well," she says to one man they're questioning, "if it isn't Superfly.")
The other story concerns Ray's cousin Paul, an actuary in Roanoke, who is asked to come to New York to identify the body of his son. Paul has never really been acquainted with the young man (more on that later), but he dutifully goes north and winds up being escorted around Manhattan by various colorful cops and criminals, all of whom are very interested in what exactly happened to this ne'er-do-well.
The two puzzles end in real solutions, with none of the life-will-always-be-unknowable evasions found in many literary expositions of the genre. The solutions are simple and believable, not surprising -- but that isn't the point. Pearson is up to a lot more here.
"Blue Ridge" is much funnier than most mysteries: not too broad, not too dry, effortlessly finding the right tone, time after time. Paul, who can be devastatingly honest about his own haplessness, finds himself in especially ludicrous situations. (On an earlier trip to New York for an actuarial conference, he and a colleague decided to save money and stay in Weehawken, N. J., near the Lincoln Tunnel, in a motel that advertised rooms by the hour. As he recalls the story, the motel manager and a customer abandoned a heated argument and stood in stunned silence when confronted by the two men's request, "helplessly constrained, I have to think now, to imagine me and Lowell engaged together in some manner of middle-aged white-boy sexual congress, 72 prepaid hours of swampy actuarial love.")
The splicing together of the two different plots puzzled me at first. The investigations start off unrelated and remain so throughout the book. (I think I can give that much away.) But gradually it became clear how very shrewd this decision was. Paul's story confounds expectations at every turn, from the moment a local policeman shows up at his insurance firm, obviously bearing bad news. Paul casts his mind over his family tree, trying to figure out which relative has died. When he is told it is his son, he pauses, then says, "Who?" It's a funny line, and quickly explained by the circumstances: the boy was conceived after a casual fling in the early 1970's and his now-deceased mother opted for single parenthood; Paul has seen his offspring only once or twice in over 20 years. But that "Who?" is also indicative of the poison in Paul's personality. He has no feel at all for human ties. His cousin Ray is the more usual solitary detective type: he's divorced; he wanders from job to job. But it's all because of a horrible loss in Ray's past for which he feels responsible. His presence is an implicit criticism of Paul, a character it would be hard to read a whole book about.
After consulting an advice column in the newspaper about ways to ease up on his compulsive tidiness, Paul picks out a dog at the pound. But the dog annoys him, and one night he neglects to let his new pet back in the house. Later, when a neighbor with two kids asks if the dog is his, Paul says, "Never seen him before" and suggests that she keep him. This is the sort of thing heroes of detective novels do before they inexplicably go off and risk death to save the lives of strangers. The idea is that the dog would be better off with the neighbor, so the hero sacrifices his own comfort. You are never supposed to believe the crusty excuses he makes. But in "Blue Ridge," even though you may be laughing at the way Paul tells the story, abandoning a dog turns out to be nothing more than abandoning a dog.
In a comic novel, you'd barely notice Paul's fecklessness. In a detective novel, which depends on an exaggerated sense of responsibility in the hero, Paul's failings are always sneaking up on you. He sees people being threatened, injured and killed, and he doesn't seem to care. The real suspense here is whether this man will ever be roused from his almost sociopathic numbness.
A whole series of parallel situations between Ray's story and Paul's reinforces the contrast between the two men: children lost, sexual favors offered, household furnishings inventoried. Ray even has a neighbor who has obsessively searched for his missing dog for 25 years. If all this sounds too schematic, it is -- a little. (It's also hard to forgive Pearson's use of the word "closure," ironic or not.) But a mystery is defined by its artifice.
Pearson has never been timid about pushing form to its limits, and his splendid prose is also artificial, stunningly so -- high-pitched, evocative, decorative and closer to the human heart than the rictus-grinned pseudorealism of many modern mysteries. For Pearson, aesthetics are the stuff of life. In the beginning of "Blue Ridge," Ray gets thrown out of a motel because his dog barks at the cheesy furnishings. On the other hand, Paul's admiration of the impeccable taste of the criminal who first has him beaten up and then wines and dines him is a failing we cannot forgive.
At one point, a New York detective asks for Paul's help in going through the stuff in his son's apartment and Paul comes across a photograph of the young man's mother:
"She'd grown jowly, and her hair was cropped close and highlighted. She was standing in front of a run of board fencing, alongside a spruce the color of bread mold, was grinning slightly and looked tired to me, looked a trifle disappointed.
" 'How about her?' Doogan had emerged from the closet with a glossy 8 by 10 in hand, a photo of an arrestingly shapely woman in a bikini who cradled a spear gun in her arms.
" 'Ursula Andress,' I told him.
"Doogan flipped the thing over for a closer look. 'Oh.' "
This moment of deflation seems so obvious that I can't believe I haven't come across something similar in the thousands of scenes I've read in which a victim's belongings are examined. Or maybe I have, but it wasn't as beautifully handled. Maybe it didn't demonstrate so pointedly the sad gap between pop-culture crime and real-life crime.
Practitioners and fans of the mystery genre have long used Faulkner to shore up its sometimes shaky reputation. Sooner or later, they'll be doing the same with T. R. Pearson.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1484 words

HEADLINE: Eyewitness Account

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen; Roger Cohen, the Berlin bureau chief of The Times, is the author of "Hearts Grown Brutal: Sagas of Sarajevo."

 BODY:

 History of
 the Present
 Essays, Sketches, and Dispatches
 From Europe in the 1990s.
 By Timothy Garton Ash.
 389 pp. New York:
 Random House. $29.95. 
 With the cold war won and Wall Street on a winning streak, America's interest in Europe has waned. Yet it has been a convulsive decade. Violence took more European lives in the 1990's than in the entire 44-year period of the cold war. Several post-Communist societies muddled their way toward democracy and the market economy. Another, Yugoslavia, fissured in a blood bath. The wars of its destruction may finally have ended with the ouster this month of Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's ruthless leader. Saying goodbye and good riddance to the full exercise of their sovereignty, several West European states created a common currency, the euro. The thinly-veiled political objective behind the money could scarcely have been bolder: the forging, one day, of a United States of Europe.
These are the weighty themes of Timothy Garton Ash's "History of the Present," a collection of essays and dispatches from one the most penetrating observers of Europe's recent transformation. A rather self-conscious introduction announces that the author has sought to combine "the crafts of historian and journalist," an objective that in lesser hands might merely have yielded mediocre illustrations of both. But Garton Ash has the wherewithal for his ambitious genre. His strongest pieces combine a quick eye, a gift for concision and an ability to discern the deep currents of history in the restless waters of the present. Pith, prescience and intellectual passion often coalesce to provide a powerful European portrait.
The essays in Garton Ash's book, most of them previously published, form what he calls a kaleidoscope. At times, the patterns are vivid, the images brilliantly illuminating. At others, the fragments are disjointed or simply repetitive. We hear not once but twice from the anonymous French businessman who comments acidly that expansion of the European Union to include post-Communist central Europe should always be talked about but never considered. The term "demokratura," used to describe an authoritarian regime dressed up in the garb of democracy, returns with irritating frequency to characterize governments as different as Milosevic's murderous Serbia and Vladimir Meciar's messy Slovakia. And the eviction of "innocent" Germans from Eastern Europe after the end of Hitler's terror appears to be something of an obsession.
But when Garton Ash, a fellow of St. Antony's College, Oxford, explores his favorite themes, the results are often formidable. Two of the most important essays are "Catching the Wrong Bus?" and "The Case for Liberal Order." In them, he argues that European leaders made a cardinal error a decade ago by setting monetary union in the western part of the continent as their chief political priority. That priority should have been the swift integration of post-Communist countries into the democratic order of the European Union: "They put Maastricht before Sarajevo," he writes, referring to the Dutch city where the treaty on the euro was agreed to in 1991.
His case is compelling, and impressive for the cogent consistency with which he has argued it since the Berlin Wall fell. No post-Communist state has joined the European Union; dates for entry keep getting postponed. Meanwhile, monetary union -- decided in haste and on high in order to tie a reunited Germany to an integrated Europe -- is suffering from its largely undemocratic conception and from the absence of a coherent, broadly acceptable political project to accompany it. Hence, in part, the weakness of the euro, which has lost 25 percent of its value in 21 months. A European money probably needs a European government to administer it; but not enough Europeans want such a goverment, at least not now.
As a result, Garton Ash is deeply suspicious of what he sees as a drive to push Europeans toward more union than they want. His is a conservative Atlanticism, that of a British intellectual deeply engaged in Europe, enraged by the myopia of so many Little Englanders, but still suspicious of too much centralizing idealism on a Continent so ravaged, still convinced that avoidance of the worst is a worthy goal.
Disaster, he suggests, is not impossible. Germans, who have abandoned the much-loved symbol of their postwar nationhood, the mark, may come to view the euro as another Versailles. A "serious danger" exists that the French-German "magnetic core" of an integrating Europe could come to exert "magnetic repulsion." In a Continent now marked by the rise of populist, rightist politicians like Jorg Haider in Austria, and increasingly wary of the notion of a European "superstate," such warnings are hard to ignore. But the political investment in the euro is probably too great, and the ultimate American interest in a stable Europe too keen, for an implosion to come to pass.
In its southeastern Balkan corner, Europe has already had its share of cataclysms in the past decade. Garton Ash backs into the story in the strangest of ways, with an account of the expulsion of the Serbs by a resurgent Croatian Army in 1995. This is a bit like beginning an account of World War II with the story of those Sudeten Germans ethnically cleansed after 1945. He refers to this expulsion more than once as "the biggest single exodus" of the Bosnian war. In fact, that dubious accolade belongs to the more than 750,000 Muslims driven out by the Serbs as they swept through Bosnia in the first months of the war in 1992. This exodus was also the result of one devastating, coordinated sweep. Yet the Serbian concentration camps through which many of the Muslims were processed merit not a mention.
This lacuna is doubly strange because Garton Ash gets so much right. "Hitler," he writes, "should have been stopped when he remilitarized the Rhineland in 1936; Milosevic at the siege of Vukovar in 1991." Indeed. And his critique of the no-body-bags approach of Bill Clinton and the Pentagon in Bosnia and later Kosovo is superb: "It is a perverted moral code that will allow a million innocent civilians of another race to be made destitute because you are not prepared to risk the life of a single professional soldier of your own." As Garton Ash explains, thousands of ethnic Albanian lives were sacrificed in 1999 because there was no readiness to accompany the NATO bombardment of Kosovo with the deployment of a ground force that could stop the marauding Serbian killers. Years before that, the dismemberment of Bosnia went as far as it did because of similar hesitations. For President Clinton to claim Bosnia as a success story, as he has often done since 1995, is simply extraordinary. Garton Ash now sees little alternative to allowing ethnic separation to be completed in the Balkans, a process that he hopes will eventually open the way for their reintegration. This, he suggests, is the European way; to fight it is to try "to freeze history."
Of course, the United States and its allies are trying to prove him wrong by preserving some semblance of mixed societies in Bosnia and even Kosovo. In Bosnia, they may succeed because they have something to build on; Garton Ash underestimates the reality of a Bosnian identity even among many Serbs there. In Kosovo, however, any meaningful multiethnic project is almost surely doomed at this stage. Meanwhile, with Garton Ash, we are left to rue the painful fact that "the democratization of Yugoslavia, and of Bosnia in particular, would, had it worked, have been a unique example of a part of Europe moving peacefully from a truly multiethnic society under an undemocratic (imperial, then Communist) political roof to such a society within a democratic framework."
It is this sort of perception, and writing, that makes "History of the Present" essential reading. Garton Ash sometimes seems unsure of his role, assuming a highhanded pomposity that makes certain passages read like a "History of My Presence." He is often scathing toward journalists, dismissing their "color," their "cliches" and their "Sarajevo safaris," and suggesting that CNN and Christiane Amanpour play fast and loose with the truth. Yet this is the craft he claims to be practicing, at least in part, and the role of journalists in the Balkans -- not least the discovery of the camps in Bosnia in 1992 -- has surely done more honor to the profession than damage.
At the start of his book, throwing in the towel on his convoluted attempts to define history-cum-journalism, Garton Ash writes that the final test must be this: "Is the result true, important, interesting or moving? If it is, never mind the label. If it isn't, then it's not worth reading anyway." So let us apply the test. True? Most of the time. Important? Sometimes. Interesting? Always. Moving? Surprisingly so.

PUB-DATE: October 29, 2000

SECTION: Section 5; Page 23; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1292 words

HEADLINE: Compris? Coperto? Confused.

BYLINE: By LIBBY LUBIN; LIBBY LUBIN writes frequently about travel.

 BODY:
IN 1521 on a trip from Bruges to Cologne, the German artist Albrecht Durer handled transactions in 18 different currencies that included stuivers, anglots, orrts, and weisspfennigs. His pockets bulging with masses of mismatched coins, he probably never knew how much he was really paying for his rooms at the inn.
Half a millennium later, in a radically transformed Europe, virtual euros have simplified financial transactions to the point of boredom, while credit cards have very nearly eliminated the use of currency. During a recent year abroad, as my husband and I traveled through a Europe rife with cash machines and money changers, paying our bills was simple and straightforward. Tipping was a different matter. 
 You see, we, like many Americans, are intent -- no, obsessed -- with doing the right thing when we travel abroad. We speak quietly in restaurants, we dress tastefully, and we drink local wines. But when it comes to leaving a tip, our savoir-faire abandons us and we become mired in self-doubt. Ten percent? Fifteen percent? Eighteen percent? And what if the service is already included? If we leave too little we'll seem cheap and small-minded, but leave too much and, worse still, we'll be taken for arrogant industrialists, skimming the cream off foreign nations, profiteering from currency imbalances, and flaunting our imperialist economy.
I should confess that even in the United States I do not feel comfortable in the role of Lady Bountiful. I mostly lug my bags through hotel lobbies. "No, please don't worry," I assure distressed porters as I huff and puff, "They're practically empty."
Similarly, my husband, David, a college professor, finds that his ability to calculate simple percentages abandons him the moment his taxi pulls over to the curb. "How much did you tip?" I asked him in New York after a lengthy cab ride from La Guardia airport. David paused for a moment of deep concentration. "About 90 percent," he finally calculated.
But in Europe, the problem goes beyond simple math to issues of self-esteem and intercultural relations. Indeed, we found on our recent sojourn that the symbolism and expectations surrounding tipping were as varied and capricious as the coinage in Durer's time.
Britain, for starters, has so many inconsistencies and variations associated with gratuities that there was actually a bill before Parliament several years ago to try and impose some sort of national norm. The basic confusion arises from a "voluntary tip" that restaurant managers sometimes, but not always, add to bills. In theory you don't have to pay it, but more often people mistake it for some sort of cocktail or dessert and leave yet another tip -- thus increasing the cost of the dinner by about 35 percent. It didn't take long before we were on to this ruse. But that was just the beginning.
"You've got to be kidding," a British friend exclaimed, when David tried to leave the barman an extra pound for our pints of ale. "You don't tip at a pub."
When we explained that we didn't want to seem like ugly Americans, our friend elaborated: "It's like, you know, McDonald's. Surely you don't leave a tip at a burger joint." Instead we simply bought another round.
It is well and good, of course, for our British friend to outline local tipping customs -- "Tip a cabby? Are you out of your mind? They make more than I do" -- but for better or worse Americans travel the world with a national identity: very rich. Never mind that the current rate of exchange on the pound makes most Americans in Britain wince each time they pull out their pocket calculators. A century ago, Americans larded with the wealth of the Gilded Age bought castles with bank drafts. Today, times have changed but the sins of those robber barons will be forever visited upon the sons and daughters of the middle class. Call it, if you will, the national debt.
In Italy, the tipping situation is both byzantine and baroque. There is the puzzling but quaint coperto, or, literally, the place setting, which is the fee charged for the clean napkin and tablecloth that may seem like a bargain to anyone who has paid to have a shirt laundered at an Italian hotel. It also functions as an ad hoc service charge, but this is merely the beginning. My Italian friends tell me to leave an additional 4,000 or 5,000 lire a head if the service hasn't already been added into the bill.
But who without graduate work in cryptography can tell whether the scribbled bill we've been presented includes service, much less if it bears any relationship to the meal we have just consumed? One could ask the waiter for clarification, as we once did, only to learn that, well, yes, a service charge had been added but the manager was going to pocket all of it and, moreover, the waiter himself was very underpaid and had small children at home. And what do you do if the waiter, choosing a different tack, presents a frosty limoncello as offerto dalla casa (on the house)? Surely then you should leave a bit more. Of course, given the instant numbing effects of this Amalfitano potion, one tends in these situations to ignore the bottom line altogether.
Coffee bars? Place 200 lire on the counter to ensure that the barman doesn't scald your milk. (Quite a deal for 10 cents!) Autogrill (a k a service station) restrooms? Tip generously -- even if the matron snarls. A clean facility is priceless.
For the most part we followed our friends' advice, generally more economical than our guidebook recommendations, and hoped that we would appear more Roman. But with our flat vowels and mushy consonants it's more likely that we merely seemed cheap.
The border between France and Italy has traditionally been somewhat fluid. Garibaldi, the father of modern Italy, was actually from Nice, while even today many Milanese prefer crepes and souffles to pasta.
But cross that border and the "coperto" evaporates, "servizio" becomes "service" and the cards are laid out for all to see: it is either "compris," which means no additional charges will be applied, or "non compris," which means a service charge will be added to the bill. In other words, they've taken the guesswork out of settling one's accounts. Or so it would seem.
IN Alsace, after a particularly memorable meal, we paid by credit card. No service charge was added to our substantial bill and, as a truly gracious touch, our waiter had drawn a line through the gratuity space on the credit card slip.
We thanked him profusely and, having noted the "service compris" printed on the bottom of the menu, we left nothing. On the way to our car, ever nervous and perplexed, we asked a French couple whether we had done the right thing.
"The service is compris," the husband explained, "but at a restaurant such as this" -- eyebrows raise and voice lowers -- "we leave something extra." Clearly we had failed.
A day later and several thousand meters higher, we were lunching in Murren, a ski resort in Switzerland.
"Excuse me," David asked a Swiss couple at the next table, "do you tip in Switzerland?" Yes, our insecurities had become clinical.
"We don't tip in our country," the young man explained. "The meals are expensive already, but that's all we pay."
After months of such excruciating postprandial uncertainty, we were overwhelmed with a novel sense of well-being. David paid our waiter who in turn counted the exact change from a well-worn leather pouch strapped to his waist. With no complicated percentages, no existential soul searching and no mental math, we pocketed our delightful Swiss coins and headed back to the slopes.
Never mind the exorbitant sum we'd paid for our chicken and potatoes. The transaction had been as clean and precise as a Swiss watch.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1841 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Droll Dramatist Who's Also a Diva Moves Up a Notch

BYLINE: By DON SHEWEY; Don Shewey is the author of the biography "Sam Shepard" and a theater critic for The Advocate.

 BODY:
FOR Charles Busch, it was the shock of a lifetime. In 1984, he and some friends put on a campy show to entertain themselves for a weekend at a nightclub on Avenue C in the East Village. With Mr. Busch doing a star turn in drag, "Vampire Lesbians of Sodom" won a cult following, moved to the Provincetown Playhouse and ran for five years.
Now this 44-year-old playwright and performer has attained an even higher level of visibility in the theater. When a six-minute sketch he wrote and performed about a disaffected housewife blossomed into a full-length play, Mr. Busch handed over the diva role to the award-winning Broadway veteran Linda Lavin. Result? "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife" was a hit last season in its limited run at the Manhattan Theater Club. Staged by Lynne Meadow, the club's artistic director, the play has now moved to the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Broadway, where it opens on Thursday. 
 Ms. Lavin plays Marjorie Taub, a cultured Upper West Sider having a midlife meltdown. Bereft after the death of her psychiatrist, she seeks a consolation she can't find from her husband, the well-meaning but never-quite-present Ira (Tony Roberts), or her aged mother, Frieda (Shirl Bernheim), who is alarmingly eloquent on the subject of her bowels. Into this troubled nest, salvation arrives in the form of Lee (Michele Lee), a vivacious enigma.
The comedy that ensues did not earn universal rave reviews when it first opened last February. John Lahr, in The New Yorker, called it "conservative folderol," and a number of reviews mentioned the unsatisfactory ending (which has been somewhat reworked for Broadway). Still, largely thanks to Ms. Lavin's bravura performance, most reviewers shared the opinion of Ben Brantley, who wrote in The New York Times that though "Charles Busch's window-rattling comedy" has moments "cut from the synthetic cloth of television comedy," it "earns its wall-to-wall laughs." No less a Broadway authority than Stephen Sondheim said in print that "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife" "may be the funniest evening I've ever had in the theater."
It might be hard for some people to believe that "The Allergist's Wife" comes from the same planet, let alone the same pen, as "Vampire Lesbians of Sodom." On the other hand, those who have followed Mr. Busch's work have a different perspective. Kyle Renick, who produced four of Mr. Busch's plays at the WPA Theater over the last decade, describes the new play as "both a new direction for him and a summation of the work he has been doing for years."
The question is: How did he get here from there?
Mr. Busch, who lives in a West Village studio stuffed with Orientalia and painted "Gigi red," cheerfully admits, "I didn't set out to be a writer at all." Tall and lithe, Mr. Busch has a highly mobile face and expressive eyes that have served him well as a comically androgynous performer. It's a little surprising to encounter him offstage and discover that he shaves his head. He usually wears wigs, as he did for his stint as a double-crossing cross-dresser in the HBO series "Oz."
"Ever since I was in the womb," he said, "I wanted to be on the stage. Growing up in New York City and going to Broadway theater since I was a kid, I had a rather pragmatic view of show biz. In college I realized I was an offbeat type, and the only way I was going to have a career was to create roles for myself."
He started writing material to perform solo, learned the rudiments of style and exposition, and booked himself into gay bars and small theaters around the country. "It was kind of like being in vaudeville for six years," he said.
In the early 1980's, he and the director Kenneth Elliott assembled an informal company of performers who put on shows at an East Village nightclub called the Limbo Lounge. "I wrote according to what would be acceptable in that space," Mr. Busch recalled. "We performed on an empty stage because we had no place to store furniture. And half the audience was standing up drinking beer, so you couldn't do an elaborate two-act piece.
"When we first did 'Vampire Lesbians,' Ken and I thought, 'What would we like to see at midnight in the East Village?' Of course, you'd want something campy and sexy, cute people with not too much on, and a flamboyant drag role for myself. I never thought I was intentionally writing a play. I was just making up lines for us to say, like a vaudeville sketch."
"Vampire Lesbians" wasn't the only sketch Mr. Busch created that had a shelf life beyond one weekend. The film version of "Psycho Beach Party," a spoof of surf movies, which Mr. Busch performed at the Limbo Lounge in 1986, was well received when it came out last summer.
Unlike, say, the late great Charles Ludlam, whose erudition informed the literate travesties of classic dramas he performed (sometimes in drag) with his Ridiculous Theatrical Company, Mr. Busch said he never sat down to write a play because he had an idea. Rather: "It was to create a marvelous role for myself. Wouldn't it be fun to be Stanwyck in a Capra comedy, or a Mary Quant-type fashion designer in London, or have a Sarah Bernhardt-type role in a 19th-century spectacle? Since I was a kid, I've been fascinated with theater history, and Bernhardt was a favorite figure for me. In a certain crazy sense, I modeled myself on her as actress-manager."
Invited by Mr. Renick to do a play at the WPA Theater, Mr. Busch found that he was no longer content simply spoofing movie genres. He wrote "The Lady in Question" (1989), ostensibly a takeoff on World War II movies, as a critique of the New Age philosophy of enlightened selfishness. Another play, "Red Scare on Sunset" (1991), was a comic melodrama set during the McCarthy era with a heroine who spouted a politically incorrect ideology. "As I began creating these vehicles for myself, I gradually, without intending to, became a writer," Mr. Busch said.
He spent the 1990's experimenting with a variety of forms. "There was a war going on between my three roles as playwright, actor and faux diva," he said. "I finally felt that for the writer to grow, I'd have to keep the diva unemployed for the time being."
He wrote a novel ("Whores of Lost Atlantis"), a nightclub act, a musical revue, a play in which he took a male role ("I didn't enjoy that too much," he says now about the 1995 "You Should Be So Lucky"), and the book for the 1997 Rusty Magee musical "The Green Heart," produced by the Manhattan Theater Club.
"Minutes after the disappointing reviews came out," he remembered, "Lynne Meadow said she would commit to doing my next play, whatever it was, which was a lovely gesture of faith in me."
Around the same time, Mr. Busch had written a one-man show in which he played several female characters, one of whom was Miriam Passman, a raging Upper West Side housewife desperately in search of self-expression. "This was one of the few times I'd looked at my own suburban Jewish background and the people I grew up with in Hartsdale and Westchester," he said. "When Lynne invited me to write a play for her, I hoped to develop that character further. But it was hard to come up with a plot that would let Miriam breathe. The various story lines I came up with sounded very sit-commy."
Having seen the Broadway revival of Edward Albee's play "A Delicate Balance," Mr. Busch started thinking, "Wouldn't it be funny to take these Jewish characters and put them in a rather cryptic Albee or Pinter play?" Specifically, the murky relationship between two women and a man in Harold Pinter's "Old Times" provided a blueprint for "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife." "I didn't intend it to be a genre parody," Mr. Busch said, "just a mysterious story line with very un-mysterious characters."
One thing that was clear from the beginning was that Mr. Busch was not going to play any of the female roles in the new play. "I identify with the character of Marjorie Taub, whose dilemma is that she wants to be an intellectual," Mr. Busch said. "I have the same frustrations. But I never thought for a second of playing that role. I'm at my best playing a woman and simultaneously commenting on the history of star acting, and that dual consciousness is not what this play is about."
While the play was gestating in his mind, he happened to see "Death Defying Acts" Off Broadway, which featured Linda Lavin in one-acts by Woody Allen and Elaine May. He ended up writing his play for Ms. Lavin after watching her perform. "Linda is very rare because she's a brilliant comedienne and knows every possibility of getting laughs, physically or through verbal humor," Mr. Busch said. "But she also has enormous emotional resources. She's like a Jewish Anna Magnani. The very moment you're horrified for her, you're also laughing."
For Ms. Meadow, directing the play meant grounding the comedy in emotional reality. "Charles is terribly witty and deeply funny," she said. "But his characters are also very human. This is a play about getting lost in the middle of life and finding one's way. Linda knew she had to go to the high wire for this one, and we agreed we would approach the material as if it were 'Hedda Gabler,' without worrying about being funny. But I have to tell you, it was hard sometimes in the rehearsal room stifling my laughter."
FAR from monopolizing the laughs in "The Allergist's Wife," Ms. Lavin's character has a hardy foil in her mother, Frieda. This character, Mr. Busch said, is a composite of his Aunt Belle, who is 88, and his Aunt Lillian, who died a year ago. "It's wild to hear the audience roaring with laughter at things Aunt Belle said that left us shocked and appalled," he said. "When my sister told her she was planning to take a boat trip down the Rhine, Aunt Belle said, 'I hope you can sleep on pillows filled with Jewish hair.' When she came to see the play at the Manhattan Theater Club, my sisters and I worried that she'd be upset and tried to pretend that it was a portrait of Aunt Lillian. But she recognized everything that came out of her own mouth. And she loved it. She kept saying to the audience members around her, 'That's me!' "
One bittersweet aspect of the play's success is that Aunt Lillian, who brought up Mr. Busch after his mother died when he was 7, didn't live to see it. Talking about her was the only time when Mr. Busch's steady stream of breezy conversation faltered, and tears surged to the surface. "She was a cross between Auntie Mame and the Miracle Worker, he said. "I was a completely frightened child, and she insisted that nothing should get in the way of me pursuing my creative interests. I had 10 years of very difficult struggle before I could make a living in the theater, and she was always there for me.
"It's ironic that the career I had all these years was based on my sexuality and performing in drag, which was a little too weird for a woman of her generation to embrace. And yet it was only because she made me so confident about myself that I was able to have this very odd career."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1976 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO;
The Networks Barely Hear the Latin Boom Outside

BYLINE: By THELMA ADAMS; Thelma Adams is a contributing editor for Us Weekly.

 BODY:
WITH singers like Ricky Martin and Marc Anthony leading a Latin music explosion, and with Jennifer Lopez able to open one of the summer's biggest movies ("The Cell"), can a Hispanic wave on network television be far behind?
Well, yes. 
 While the networks say they are trying to embrace more Latinos -- "The general atmosphere at CBS is one of inclusion" said Josie Thomas, senior vice president for diversity -- a look at their fall schedules tells another story. Cheech Marin, the highest-profile Latino in CBS's prime-time lineup, said: "There are Hispanics on TV? That's news to me."
Mr. Marin, who plays Don Johnson's partner on "Nash Bridges," continued: "It's lonely at the top. It's like the tide. It goes in and out."
He recalled his appearance two years ago as host of the American Latino Media Arts Awards, or Alma Awards, an annual event that honors portrayals of Hispanics in film and television. "Myself, Jimmy Smits, Hector Elizondo, Michael DeLorenzo -- all leads on every network," he said. "We'd reached a high-water mark. Two years later I'm the only guy. It can't get much worse."
Of the 1,477 characters on the four major broadcast networks' prime-time series in the 1999-2000 season, only 41, or 3 percent, were Latino, according to a study by the National Hispanic Foundation for the Arts. And the new season has introduced few new recurring Hispanic characters. On ABC, the Panama-born Ruben Blades is a father confessor figure to the star, Andre Braugher, in the hospital drama "Gideon's Crossing"; CBS added Sara Ramirez to the sitcom "Welcome to New York"; and on Fox, the 19-year-old Mexican-American Jessica Alba plays a sexy superhero in "Dark Angel."
But those gains have been offset by attrition. The cancellations of CBS's "Chicago Hope," NBC's "Jesse" and "Suddenly Susan" and ABC's "Sabrina the Teenage Witch" meant the disappearance of Hector Elizondo, Bruno Campos, Nestor Carbonell and Jon Huertas from the top four networks. Jimmy Smits, Jon Seda and Benjamin Bratt had departed the previous season.
But cable is beginning to take up the slack. Channels like Lifetime and Nickelodeon are providing more roles for Hispanics, and Showtime's new one-hour drama "Resurrection Blvd." is the first television series produced, written and directed by Latinos. The show, set in East Los Angeles, traces the lives of the Santiagos, a multigenerational family.
Why have Hispanics been so scarce in Hollywood, part of a city where they make up nearly 44 percent of the population? Dennis E. Leoni, the producer and creator of "Resurrection Blvd.," identified the problem as "more cronyism than racism."
"People in Hollywood don't necessarily see Latinos as people with interesting lives," he said, "because people who buy programming see Latinos as maids, gardeners and service people."
Alex Nogales, president of the National Hispanic Media Coalition, an advocacy group, had another answer. Referring to network executives, he said: "Because they're foolish. They have let their prejudices and biases get in the way of sound economic reckoning. They've been content to believe that we all are Spanish speaking, watching Spanish-language TV and listening to Spanish-language radio. They've been content to leave the market to Univision and Telemundo."
And now, apparently, to cable, where Latinos are being portrayed as far more than "service people."
In "Resurrection Blvd.," the patriarch of the Santiago family, Roberto (Tony Plana), is a boxing-obsessed mechanic who dreams that one of his three sons (played by Michael DeLorenzo, Mauricio Mendoza and Nicholas Gonzalez) will become a contender, even though his live-in brother is permanently disabled from his fighting career. On the Lifetime cable channel, "Strong Medicine" pairs Rosa Blasi, as a Puerto Rican public health doctor, with Janine Turner, who plays a society gynecologist. In January, Lifetime will present "City Lights," an ensemble cop show set in San Francisco that will feature Lisa Vidal, a Latino, as a detective. (Both Ms. Blasi and Ms. Vidal play single mothers, as does Elizabeth Pena on "Resurrection Blvd.")
Nickelodeon has probably made the greatest strides. "The Brothers Garcia," which had its premiere this summer, is about three school-age siblings growing up in suburban San Antonio. It's a latter-day "Wonder Years," with John Leguizamo assuming the Daniel Stern role of the adult narrator recalling his youth. It has been renewed for another 13 episodes. "Dora the Explorer," an animated show for preschoolers, features a Hispanic star equally at ease in Spanish and English. And Nickelodeon will enter the tween market in January with the half-hour musical series "Taina," about a talented Puerto Rican teenager.
Nickelodeon's president, Herb Scannell, said that incorporating Hispanic characters in its shows was a logical extension of the network's mandate to "put real kids on television." Mr. Scannell, whose mother was Puerto Rican and who "ate more rice and beans as a kid than mashed potatoes," said he saw diversity as a programming opportunity.
"Part of the power in diversity is that there isn't a lot on television," he said. "When you embrace diversity, you make TV that is different from a lot of other things. We set out a net for talent that isn't Nancy Drew."
"Dora the Explorer" was originally about a bunny, but the title character evolved into a Hispanic girl. Now this fluidly bilingual program makes children aware of language without becoming, in Mr. Scannell's words, "a Berlitz tape." Because Viacom owns both Nickelodeon and CBS, "Dora" has joined the CBS Saturday morning line-up along with "Blue's Clues."
This broadening of Hispanic representation is another example of how cable has opened up television to those who have been excluded by the networks, "not necessarily by intent or design but by a system that focused on the mass," said Tim Brooks, a senior vice president at Lifetime and co-author of "The Complete Directory to Prime Time Network and Cable TV Shows."
Mr. Nogales, of the Hispanic Media Coalition, agrees. "Cable has broken barriers that broadcasting has been very hesitant to even touch," he said. "Cable is more segmented, is more targeted. So they've got it all over broadcast, who wants to believe that they have to appeal to everyone.
"It's a small beginning and a beginning that's been long in coming, and it's very little. We deserve a lot more."
The numbers support Mr. Nogales's claim. Composing 12 percent of the population, Hispanics are the fastest-growing minority in the United States, having risen to 32 million from 23 million in a decade. They are expected to overtake African-Americans as the largest minority in the near future. From 1993 to 1999, the number of Latinos in households with televisions grew 27 percent, to 28.3 million. Hispanics' annual buying power should top $440 billion this year, according to federal government estimates.
"In other words," Mr. Nogales said, "a lot of soap. People in the broadcast industry are not doing their jobs by not targeting this segment."
Josie Thomas's post at CBS as vice president for diversity was created last spring as a result of a memorandum of understanding between the network and a coalition of ethnic advocacy groups, including the National Latino Media Council, which is based in Los Angeles. The memorandum grew out of the broadcast networks' earlier agreements with the N.A.A.C.P. to seek ways to promote diversity in hiring and programming. Ms. Thomas, a CBS veteran who had been in the business affairs department and had had no specific experience in diversity matters, said, "We recognize there's a need for significant improvement."
Historically, Hispanics have been television's near-silent minority. "Hispanics have fared even worse than African-Americans in terms of representation," said Mr. Brooks, of Lifetime. As a result, said Mr. Nogales, Hispanics have had little control over how they have been portrayed.
"The dialogue is pretty black and white and doesn't include brown," he said. "That doesn't mean that we are envious of the strides that African-Americans have made. You know they have a small slice of the pie; they're very deserving of that slice. But so are we. We need our slice of the pie."
Early representations of Latinos tended to be comic stereotypes. On "The Jack Benny Show," Mel Blanc had a recurring bit as Cy, who called himself "Si" -- the whole routine resting on confusion about the pronunciation of a Spanish word. Bill Dana created Jose Jiminez, the Mexican immigrant bellhop. Born on "The Steve Allen Show," the character earned his own NBC program ("The Bill Dana Show") from 1963 to 1965.
ABC telecast the swashbuckler "Zorro," starring the non-Hispanic actor Guy Williams, from 1957 to 1959. Ron Simon, a curator at the Museum of Television and Radio in Manhattan, said the series was "one of the most significant of early shows."
"It defined Hispanics to the first generation of TV watchers, and especially children," he said.
A more significant show was never shown by a network. "The Cisco Kid," starring Duncan Renaldo and the Hispanic actor Leo Carrillo, was a popular syndicated western about a hard-riding Mexican adventurer and his sidekick and ran for 156 episodes from 1950 to 1955. The Mexican government consulted on the show with the goal of creating a positive ethnic role model.
Desi Arnaz remains television's most famous Hispanic. Before the debut of "I Love Lucy" in 1951, CBS resisted casting the Cuban crooner opposite his wife, Lucille Ball, but she insisted. Mr. Simon said: "It's very odd for the defining sitcom to have a Hispanic co-star. It was a great formula, the zany housewife playing off the Hispanic straight man. So much of the comedy came from the cultural differences in that relationship."
NEVERTHELESS, an industry that thrives on copycatting never recycled that formula. NBC's mid-1970's hit "Chico and the Man," which paired Jack Albertson and Freddie Prinze as an Anglo and a Chicano co-existing in East Los Angeles, came closest. Lesser known was the short-lived series "a.k.a. Pablo" starring Paul Rodriguez. In the late 80's and 90's came breakthroughs by actors in ensemble casts, like Mr. Smits in "L.A. Law" and Mr. Bratt in "Law and Order."
"Now you have 'Resurrection Blvd.,' " said Mr. Blades. "But I don't see the situation changing in a way where I would say it's over, the fever has receded."
"The fear with which we're seen, seen as a culture that survived and resists assimilation," persists, he said. "Some people find it very threatening and the choice has been to ignore us. Right now here in Los Angeles, there are more Latinos than any other group. For some people that is very disturbing. Basically we have to try and see if we can work out this fear."
Mr. Blades, a Grammy Award winning musician who ran for president of Panama in 1994 and finished third, added: "Many years ago somebody suggested that in order to get better roles in films, I should lose my accent. I don't think it's necessary for a person to lose or gain an accent. That's insulting. We're talking about a cultural background; you're not talking about race. And that is one of the things that has been more threatening in explaining why we're nowhere to be seen for the most part."
At stake is more than grabbing a bigger slice of the pie. It is a struggle for self-determination. Mr. Nogales said: "When I was growing up, TV was almost nonexistent. The family told me who I was, what I was and what my worth was. Now it's very electronic. TV has become a member of our family, and it tells us now who we are, what we are and what we're worth. If you're excluded from creating those images, then the images are going to be made by other people that have no love or knowledge of what we are."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 21; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 932 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 10-29-00;
Pro Pharma

BYLINE: By Andrew Sullivan; Andrew Sullivan, a contributing writer to the magazine, has a new Web site, www.andrewsullivan.com.

 BODY:
Here's an unfashionable romance: I love America's pharmaceutical companies. As a slogan, "Better Living Through Pharmaceuticals" still has a campy, futuristic ring to it, but for me, at least, there's nothing sci-fi about it. Because I have H.I.V., I swallow around 800 pills of prescription drugs a month and around 400 extra pills -- vitamins, antidiarrheic, antinausea pills and the like -- to contain the side effects of the first 800. That's close to 15,000 pills a year. When I first tested positive, I had a dream that I was walking down the street shaking like a baby's rattle because there were so many pills inside me. Eight years later, that shaking has become white noise. I asked my pharmacist the other day to tote up the annual bill (which my insurance mercifully pays): $15,600, easily more than I pay separately for housing, food, travel or clothes.
I'm an extreme case -- along with many others now living relatively normally with chronic illnesses -- but I'm not completely atypical. Over the last decade, as new and better prescription drugs have become our primary form of health care, our common spending on them has soared. In 1999 alone, according to a study conducted by an independent consulting group, overall expenditure on prescription drugs in America rose by 19 percent -- but only 4 percent of that was because of increased prices. We're simply taking advantage of living in the 21st century and medicating ourselves to the gills. 
 This is our country on drugs. You can bash the "big pharmaceutical companies" all you want, but their products are among the most popular around. We can now treat arthritis, balding, impotence, depression, obesity, not to speak of cancer, heart disease, diabetes, in ways that were, only recently, a matter of science fiction. In the last 10 years, with the possible exception of information technology, no industry has more thoroughly transformed our lives. Calculating the economic benefits of this is impossible -- but think of the new antidepressants alone. If you know one person whose life has been overhauled by a stabler supply of serotonin, the "happy" chemical in our brain, then imagine the impact multiplied by millions. Or consider protease inhibitors. Thousands of H.I.V.-positive people are now contributing to the economy who might, without the drugs, be dead, sick or draining resources in hospital care. Perhaps it takes seeing the transformation in your own life to fully appreciate what drugs can do for the society as a whole.
But what is our response to this? We complain about the price. According to polls, the cost of medicine is one of the hottest issues in this election. Vice President Al Gore has warned of price gouging by "powerful forces." In a move intended to lower drug costs at home, Congress has passed a bill that will let anyone reimport American prescription drugs sold more cheaply overseas. Both major candidates have pledged to do something to subsidize or pay for medicines under Medicare. Whoever wins the election, the federal government's bargaining power with major drug companies is almost certainly going to be ratcheted up, forcing prices -- and profits -- down.
What's not to like? Well, as with many other debates in this election, no one wants to point out that there's a trade-off. It would be wonderful if we could make the newest drugs affordable for anyone who needs them and keep the lifesaving research going. But cut prices and you cut profits. Cut profits and you cut research and development. Cut research and you slow new drug innovation. You may get cheaper and more widely available drugs in the short term, but you'll also get worse drugs in the long term, and risk ending the greatest era in research in memory. Don't big pharmaceuticals make enough money to take a hit? Sure, their profitability is slightly higher than some other industries -- but that barely offsets the unique risks the drug industry has to take. Of more than 5,000 potential medicines tested at some point in the lab, on average only 3 get into clinical trials, and only 1 is approved for patient use. In all, only 30 percent of drugs make enough money to recoup the cost of their own research, and the average time it took to bring a new drug to market in the 1990's was close to 15 years, at an average cost, according to Boston Consulting Group, of $500 million.
The only way these risks will be run is if the payoff is big enough. Slap on de facto price controls, squeeze profits to get more short-term access for more people -- and you'll have one sure result. Investment for research will dry up, innovation will slow down and the great gains of the last decade will recede into history. Those gains are not just for the wealthy. Once patents run out and generics compete, the pricey innovations we now encourage lead to cheaper, better drugs for everyone. This is particularly true for the small, high-risk bio-tech companies that have pioneered some of the most substantial breakthroughs of the last few years.
The private sector is now responsible for more than 70 percent of all the pharmaceutical research in this country -- and that share is growing. Whether we like it or not, these private entities have our lives in their hands. And we can either be grown-ups and acknowledge this or be infantile and scapegoat them. They're not "powerful forces," penalizing America's "working families." They're entrepreneurs trying to make money by saving lives. By and large, they succeed in both. Every morning I wake up and feel fine, I'm thankful that they do.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1472 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Living, Working and Playing Near the Train Station

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
A THREE-ACRE lot across Lafayette Avenue from the train station in Morristown that has long been used for parking has become an increasingly rare commodity: a buildable site at the edge of the community's reviving central business district.
To realize its potential, New Jersey Transit, which owns the property and is the overseer of the state's mass transit system, earlier this month selected a partnership between Roseland Property Company of Short Hills and Woodmont Properties of Parsippany to develop the site for apartments, parking and stores. 
 Called Lafayette Commons, the $35 million project is to contain 226 rental units and 8,000 square feet of stores as well as parking for 780 cars. The architecture of the project, to be built over the next two and a half years, will blend with that of the buildings downtown as well as with the historic 1915 Renaissance Revival train station, which the developers will improve.
Lafayette Commons is part of New Jersey's year-old transit village program administered by the state's Department of Transportation and the autonomous transit agency. The program seeks to attract private investment and spur mixed-use development within walking distance of transit hubs, many of which are often at the core of downtowns.
Beyond Morristown, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman selected four other towns for transit village projects, which are in various stages of development near rail stations in Rutherford, South Orange and South Amboy and a bus depot in Pleasantville. All four of these projects are rising or will rise on privately owned land.
Mark W. Gordon, senior director of real estate and economic development at the transit agency, said towns are chosen for the program where local leaders support transit friendly projects and are already involved in or are willing to proceed with such projects. He said the projects also must be within a quarter of a mile of the transit hub so that "that people can live, work and recreate within walking distance of mass transportation." Other towns will be named to the program within the next six months, Mr. Gordon said.
There have been earlier efforts by New Jersey Transit to encourage development around its stations. This program brings together 10 state agencies to help implement the projects, said James Weinstein, who is the commissioner of the Department of Transportation and chairman of New Jersey Transit. Involving the state agencies may help speed the approval process, Mr. Weinstein said.
Under the program, technical assistance is also made available to the participating towns, which are also given priority consideration for certain state and federal financing and grants. In the year since the program started, the State Transportation Department has awarded almost $3 million to the five communities, according to the department.
THE program also reflects the state's efforts to respond to the growing anti-sprawl sentiments of residents in the last few years. Among those efforts is Governor Whitman's program to buy a million acres of open space in the next decade. And it conforms with the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, which encourages growth in areas where roads, utilities and mass transit are in place and discourages it in less developed area.
Developers and towns involved in the program agree with its aims. But some officials and developers said they were unsure of how much it had helped since a pool of specific money is not set aside for the communities to tap. They also said having so many agencies involved could increase, not decrease, governmental red tape.
Stressing the need for the program, Mr. Weinstein said: "We are at a point when we don't have the ability to add three more lanes to highways, so we have to look at ways to better capitalize mass transit. This program takes advantage of the inroads already made in the state's transit system."
Among the transit projects Mr. Weinstein expects to benefit through increased ridership encouraged by the transit village program is the Secaucus Transfer, which will link 11 of New Jersey's 12 commuter rail lines and allow passengers to transfer to trains for direct service to Pennsylvania Station. In doing so, Manhattan-bound commuters will bypass Hoboken, where they now must change to PATH trains, and shave up to 30 minutes from their commute. When completed in 2002, the project will increase the number of commuters using the historic 1898 Rutherford station, which is undergoing a renovation costing more than $1 million.
The program also hopes to enhance ridership of Midtown Direct, a four-year-old express rail service from towns like South Orange and Morristown that also bypasses Hoboken and goes directly into Penn Station.
In South Orange, local officials have been working with New Jersey Transit for five years on projects around the 1916 train station as part of a plan to revive the village's 12-block business district. Among them is the rehabilitation of a string of stores adjoining the Sloane Street Station. The transit agency also built a 275-car parking lot and sold part of the property to South Orange on which to build a planned $9 million arts center.
That investment has led to a second round of projects, including the development of more than 200 residences on several downtown parcels, said John O. Gross, South Orange's administrator. "Without a doubt," he added, "our relationship with New Jersey Transit was instrumental in the downtown's revival."
In Rutherford, a four-story building for the Boiling Spring Savings Bank recently opened on a long-dormant two-acre bank-owned parcel a block and a half from the train station. It is the first phase of a larger project, planned several years ago, that will include 48 rentals, more than 18,000 square feet of medical office space, a day care center and a 510-car garage with 160 spaces for commuters. Construction on those components are to start by the end of the year.
The project, on Orient Way, is at a gateway to the borough and is the cornerstone in its downtown revitalization, said Robert Gorman, Rutherford's administrator. "Being designated a transit village helps a little and we certainly would not turn our back on it," he said, adding that putting more financial resources behind the program would strengthen it.
For the latest project in Morristown, local officials rezoned the parking lot site for its transformation into a transit village, enabling New Jersey Transit to put together a request for proposals to developers that could complement the new zoning. The transit agency will lease the site for 49 years with renewal options to the joint venture between Roseland and Woodmont, whose Lafayette Commons proposal was selected over four others.
THERE are concerns the project will increase traffic in the area, six blocks from Morristown's historic center green. Still, Mayor John J. DeLaney said the project "will bring people, life and vitality to the area and is part of the continued revitalization" of the central business district.
For the developers, having the project, which still must receive its local approvals, be part of the transit program "will be helpful and expedite the pathway to the approvals," said Carl Goldberg, a partner at Roseland. He said the partners also got involved with the project because of Morristown's reviving downtown and its strong rental market.
Construction of Lafayette Commons, which is being designed by the Hillier Group of Princeton, is to start by the end of 2001 and take 14 months. The 226 one- to three-bedroom units with 800 to 1,350 square feet will be contained mostly in the upper floors of three buildings, each four stories high. The ground floors of the buildings, which will sit atop a parking garage, will be for the retail shops.
There will also 10 town-house style rentals on Lafayette Avenue to hide the parking garage and provide a streetscape in keeping with those nearby, Mr. Goldberg said. Also, the design of all the buildings will blend with neighboring structures and incorporate some architectural elements found in them as well as in the historic train station across the street. Monthly rents have not yet been set.
Because the rentals will be so close to the station and adjacent to the eastbound passenger platform, Mr. Goldberg said, "Special windows, insulation, landscaping and construction techniques will be used to buffer the housing from a visual and sound perspective from the trains."
That will help broaden the market of potential renters for the units, said Eric Witmondt, a principal of Woodmont. He said they included young single and married professionals living in the area and working in Manhattan as well as New Yorkers looking for lower rents and a suburban alternative to Manhattan.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Substantial Office Space Being Added to the Market

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the the first building at the 33-acre Reckson Executive Park under construction along the Long Island Expressway just west of Route 110 in Melville will have its official opening in December, no tenants have yet signed leases for its 277,000 square feet of space.
But Mitchell Rechler, the co-chief operating officer of the publicly held Reckson Associates Realty Corporation in Melville, the developer of the 554,162-square-foot project, which ultimately will have twin buildings, did not sound worried. 
 "This is not a disappointment," he said. "We normally anticipate not signing leases before a building is completed because historically on Long Island space is not leased until people can see a finished product. This has nothing to do with the market."
At a time when financial markets are swinging and some companies are reporting disappointing earnings, substantial new space is flowing into the Long Island office market.
In addition to Reckson Executive Park, Reckson has 170,000 square feet available at the Melville Technology Center at 50 Marcus Drive in Melville. The project, which is a renovation of an industrial building to Class A offices --that is, well located office space with quality amenities -- opened earlier this month. Several brokers hinted that a major high-technology company was interested in taking the entire building, but no lease has yet been signed.
The Tritec Real Estate Company of East Setauket, in partnership with Greenfield Partners of Westport, Conn., held a ground-breaking earlier this month of the first phase of a 408,000-square-foot complex, 100 Motor Parkway, to be built on 20 acres at Exit 53 of the Long Island Expressway in Hauppauge. The building will have 170,000 square feet of offices and 60,000 square feet of meeting rooms and other tenant amenities.
Several major conversions of other industrial buildings to Class A space are also under way in the Route 110 corridor.
Long Island's diverse economy, its concentration of high-tech companies and its low vacancy rates are expected to keep the office market stable.
Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Commack-based Long Island Association, a leading regional business group, said that she saw "some risk in all this space coming on line in a short period of time," but that on the plus side Long Island has seen very little new office construction in the last decade because of the reluctance of banks to lend. "So this doesn't mean the new space won't be absorbed," she said.
"The economy is topping out and poised for slower growth ahead and that is what the stock market is telling us," she said. "But even if we have a recession -- and it is not clear that we will -- Long Island has a base of technology that will act as a buffer. Those technologies are needed in bad times as well as in good times."
The companies include Computer Associates International of Islandia, a designer and developer of computer software products, with 21,000 employees; the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Bethpage, one of the nation's leading telecommunications and entertainment companies, with almost 14,000 employees; Arrow Electronics of Melville, a distributor of electronic components and computer products to industrial and commercial customers, with more than 11,200 employees: and Symbol Technologies, a world leader in portable data terminals and bar code scanners, with almost 4,000 employees.
"These are companies that are somewhat insulated from what's happening in the stock market because they are in large markets, with extensive customer bases and evolving new products for customers that rely on them," said Gus P. Nuzzolese, a senior managing director at Sutton & Edwards, a Lake Success brokerage.
Most brokers agree with Raymond A. Ruiz, a vice president at the Garden City office of CB Richard Ellis, the international brokerage, that the influx of new space will, in fact, have a positive effect on the office market. "New construction and redevelopment projects are bringing equilibrium back to a marketplace where tenants were having a very difficult time securing space and landlords were having an equally difficult time trying to accommodate them, especially their existing tenants," he said.
Not counting the new buildings coming on line, vacancies for Class A buildings in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties are at historic lows. Corporate mergers among large financial institutions could have left large blocks of space in existing buildings lingering on the market, but companies whose businesses were growing rushed to fill it, resulting in a 350,000-square-foot net absorption in this year's first nine months. In the same period last year, the net absorption was 307,000 square feet.
"Chase Manhattan Bank left 700,000 square feet and a couple of thousand jobs behind in Jericho," said Paul F. Amoruso, managing partner of Oxford & Simpson, commercial brokers in Jericho. "But before the lights were out, Cablevision occupied both buildings."
THE commercial brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island, which is based in Melville, reported that in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, the direct office vacancy rate -- space available directly from landlords and not including subleases -- was 4.4 percent, the second lowest on record and only slightly higher than the 4.1 percent low reached the year before. The vacancy rate including sublease space stood at 5.9 percent. Annual direct asking rents at the end of the third quarter had risen to $28.88 per square foot from $28.01 per square foot a year earlier. Long Island has 12.8 million square feet of Class A office space, according to Cushman & Wakefield.
"The slowing economy is going to affect everyone, but the good news is we don't have a tremendous amount of space," said Kenneth M. Krasnow, regional managing director of Cushman & Wakefield's Long Island division, which also encompasses Connecticut. "We don't see companies saying, 'Well, maybe we don't need more space.' They are still thinking about where to go because of the growth of their business."
An internal study recently conducted by Insignia/ESG, an international brokerage that has a Syosset office, showed that there was enough demand and anticipated demand based on planned expansions to fill double the space now on the market, said Martin L. Lomazow, a senior managing director at the brokerage company, which is handling the leasing at the Tritec building.
Earlier this year, space at Nassau's first speculative office building in a decade was readily absorbed. When the Tilles Companies of Woodbury completed its 100,000-square-foot 88 Froelich Farm Boulevard building in February, it had no signed leases. But now all but 8,000 square feet are rented "and we have someone about to sign a lease on it," said Roger Tilles, a principal of the company with his brother, Peter.
Over all, the company, which owns three million square feet of office space on Long Island, only has 25,000 square feet vacant, for which it is talking with users wanting 200,000 square feet, Mr. Tilles said. "So we have eight times the amount of users than we have space," he said.
Nevertheless, a 525,000-square-foot office park in Melville just west of the intersection of the Long Island Expressway and Route 110 for which the Tilles Companies has approvals will not be started until leases for most of the space are signed, Mr. Tilles said. "I would do 100,000 square feet on spec today, but not 525,000 square feet," he said.
Reckson Executive Park and 100 Motor Parkway both occupy highly visible sites along the Long Island Expressway. The Reckson building, four stories high, was designed internally by the company's architectural staff. The Tritec building is six stories high, making it one of the tallest in Suffolk. The architects are Mojo Stumer Architects of Roslyn and the Baldassano Architectural Group of Ronkonkoma.
Both buildings are designed with sophisticated technology and backup systems, and both represent the new direction Suffolk is taking in bringing high-quality office space in very large complexes far east of the traditional office hubs of Lake Success, Mitchel Field and Jericho.
Rents in the two buildings are also breaking new ground for Hauppauge and Melville, with asking rents at 100 Motor Parkway scheduled to go from $26 to $27.50 a square foot by the end of the year, and asking rents at the Reckson building at $32 a square foot. Those prices do not include electricity costs of $2.25 a square foot. The average rent for Class A space in the Hauppauge area, according to Cushman & Wakefield, is $25.32 a square foot, including electric, and in Melville it is $28.50 a square foot with electricity.
If anything, the softening market could bring downward pressure on rents but not a downturn in demand, said Mr. Krasnow, the regional manager of Cushman & Wakefield. "The envelope will not continue to be pushed in terms of escalating prices," he said.
Nevertheless, brokers say, for the immediate future it is likely to remain a landlord's market.
When the economy turned soft in the 1980's, Long Island's office inventory had just undergone an unusual growth spurt, said Bruce Nelson, a vice president of the investment property group at CB Richard Ellis in Garden City. "What really hurt us was going from 20 million square feet to 35 million square feet mostly between 1984 and 1988, and that kind of increase creates a lot of problems no matter what state the economy is in," he said. "Today, we are looking at a 3 to 5 percent increase, and that's healthy growth."
Mr. Amoruso of Oxford & Simpson added: "Financing wasn't available for new construction and that's the real reason we won't have the real estate crisis we had before." "Banks lost so much in the 1980's that they avoided lending, and what has happened is they have managed to save developers from themselves."
