HEADLINE: Research Park Leads a Comeback in Philadelphia

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
ANGELIQUE XOCHIME IRVIN did not have to look far for a site for her fledgling software development company when it came time for her to receive her M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School last May.
Ms. Irvin, a 34-year-old entrepreneur, decided to stay in the neighborhood. Her choice for a business home is a new building in the 17-acre University City Science Center research park in West Philadelphia, adjacent to both Penn and Drexel University. The $22 million building -- named the Port of Technology -- at 37th and Market streets offered Ms. Irvin exactly the kind of high-tech amenities she wanted. 
 And Ms. Irvin was exactly the kind of so-called "new economy" tenant the Science Center envisioned when it decided to put up the city's first speculative office building since 1992.
"Philadelphia is trying to hold on to its brain power," said Roger McManimon, a director in the Philadelphia office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company. "We don't want them going to California or Boston."
Unlike Boston's booming real-estate market, Philadelphia stalled during the 1990's as major businesses, including the CoreStates Financial Corporation and Conrail Inc., were swallowed up or dismantled. Such losses dumped hundreds of thousands of square feet on the market. While rental rates in Boston are now as high as $85 a square foot a year, according to Mark Roth, senior director at Cushman & Wakefield's Boston office, the rate for top tier buildings in Philadelphia is $32.50 a square foot.
"Basically, we've climbed back up to where we were in the mid- to late-1980's," said Paul G. Garvey, senior director of Cushman's Philadelphia office.
But the city is rebounding, as evidenced by the leasing activity at the Port of Technology, Mr. Garvey said. The building was 90 percent leased by the time construction was completed in July.
What attracted Ms. Irvin was the building's incubator program. It provides her company, Coviant Inc., which develops software for the fiber-optics market, with access to capital, business contacts and mentoring services. A self-described "techie nerd," Ms. Irvin said she was also impressed with the building's access to "the latest and greatest in fiber to the desktop."
Like many landlords today, the Science Center wants to showcase the fiber in its walls, not its carpet. Real estate agents now pitch buildings as having "robust riser cores," which mean they have large raceways to carry wiring. The brochure phrase "plug and play," is to let tenants know they can be in the game merely by showing up with phones and computers.
To create a smart building, the Science Center enlisted the help of Cisco Systems Inc. of San Jose, Calif. The Port of Technology was built with enough "dark" -- unused -- fiber-optic cable to handle the hungriest bandwidth users, like multimedia Internet broadcasting companies. Bandwidth determines how much data can be sent and received at any time. The building also houses a "co-location provider," Meridian Telesis L.L.C., where internet-based and telecommunications businesses can lease space for their computers and fiber optic cable equipment. These centers, also known as "carrier hotels," "server farms" and "cyber centers" offer customers around-the-clock security, environmental controls and protection against power failure for their communications equipment.
The 144,000-square-foot, eight-story building was outfitted with cutting-edge telephony -- voice-over-I.P. (Internet protocol) -- so tenants can run voice calls on a data network. It is more cost-effective and easier to manage than traditional switch-based telephone networks.
The project's architects, Ueland, Junker, McCauley & Nicholson of Philadelphia, designed the building with dual power service and space for emergency generators.
"I couldn't do what I'm doing competitively in another building," said Ms. Irvin. And she can also take her 13-year-old Norwegian elkhound, Brokk, to the office.
The Science Center's campus is run by a nonprofit organization made up of 30 academic and scientific institutions interested in creating regional wealth. The campus is one of the nation's largest urban research parks, running from 34th to 38th Streets along Market Street. It houses nearly 200 technology and science-related operations that employ nearly 7,000 people.
When it was founded in 1963, the Science Center was one of the first city research campuses in the world. It grew out of a larger initiative spearheaded in the late 1950's by the University of Pennsylvania under Gaylord P. Harnwell, who was its president at the time. The project was an attempt by academic and medical communities to revitalize declining West Philadelphia neighborhoods.
IN the 19th century, the section of West Philadelphia overlooking the Schuylkill that includes the university was home to some of Philadelphia's best families. But by the early 1900's, smokestacks were the backdrop for some photos of Penn buildings.
In 1920, the university considered a proposal to move 22 miles west to a 175-acre estate near Valley Forge National Historical Park, according to a university history co-authored by Martin Meyerson, president emeritus of Penn.
After decades of discussion, trustees decided in the 1950's that the university had an important role to play in revitalizing the neighborhood. But urban renewal plans soon angered residents. The Science Center project meant that hundreds of buildings would be demolished and more than 1,000 people displaced. Students took up the cause in 1969, staging a sit-in at Penn's College Hall, where the university's administrative offices are located, to protest displacement of black residents. They also wanted a halt to military research at the park.
But for young people involved with the Science Center now, that is ancient history.
"It was a different time -- an anti-establishment time," said Gregg W. Garnick, 36, executive director of the incubator program.
Today, under the leadership of Jill R. Felix, the Science Center appears to be living up to the dream of its creators. The center plans to expand to 3.6 million square feet from 2 million square feet in the next decade. The master plan calls for the number of buildings to grow to 18 from the current 14. Each new building site is a Keystone Opportunity Zone, where nearly all city and state taxes are waived until December 2010.
Ms. Felix, who developed the Great Valley Corporate Center in Malvern, Pa., while with Liberty Property Trust (formerly Rouse & Associates), believes the Science Center has a competitive edge because there are 100,000 professors, students and other professionals within walking distance of the park. "In today's world, the biggest challenge is attracting and retaining people," Ms. Felix said.
The City of Philadelphia supported the campus's recent expansion by giving $1 million for Port of Technology's technology infrastructure. Townsend Capital L.L.C., a private real estate investment firm based in Towson, Md., is a partner in the building, mainly providing some financing.
Two of the building's floors have been designated as incubator space. One entire floor is equipped with wet labs, reinforced floors and vent stacks for early-stage life sciences companies. The other, where Ms. Irvin has her company, is for information technology start-ups. It consists of one huge open room with ultramodern modular furniture, giving the appearance of one company, even though there are in fact several startups there.
The other six floors are being leased to more-established technology companies at $23 a square foot a year. CTNY of New York City, which develops software to allow businesses to gain access to data by wireless technologies, took a full floor.
Fledgling companies like Ms. Irvin's Coviant, which has five full-time employees and 10 workers on a contract basis, have to be approved by Port of Technology Inc., a for-profit subsidiary of the Science Center.
Instead of paying rent, the tenants pay a monthly fee of $450 per workstation. In return, they are given access to office equipment, a break room, conference rooms and an on-site support team that includes a lawyer. The incubator companies give the Science Center a 5 percent equity stake in their businesses.
Twenty information technology and biotechnology companies are in the incubator program. The Science Center has another subsidiary raising a pool of $60 million to invest in tenant companies in amounts of $500,000 to $1 million.
"The lure of the building is that it's an urban location, close to public transportation," said James Venturi, chief executive of CTNY. "We didn't want to be in a suburban park -- for our culture, it's not an option."

HEADLINE: Raising the Neighborhood;
A Few Years Into Its Ambitious Plan, Trinity College Sees Results

BYLINE: By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
IT is a street parallel to the playing fields at Trinity College, a corner of the now handsome block that is home to the neighborhood's four newest schools, where Eddie Perez illustrates the progress of an ambitious plan to reinvent a poor neighborhood in the poorest city in the state.
"Four years ago, there was a gang assassination at 2:30 in the afternoon, during a football game," said Mr. Perez, the president of the Southside Institutions Neighborhood Alliance, as he points across the block from the new $110 million school buildings. "Today there are kids in there going to school and it's a corner of hope." 
 There is also a job training center, a Boys and Girls Club and a social service agency, all created in the last three years as Trinity attempts to raise the neighborhood where the college sits. The area, called Barry Square, was once known for its drugs, prostitution and robberies. Now it has become a symbol of renewal and to what one college can do for its community.
"The seeds were there before Evan came," Mr. Perez said, referring to Evan S. Dobelle who was named president of the college in 1995. "But everyone was thinking small. There was no way we thought of building schools. Evan thought big."
The newly hired Mr. Dobelle was able to persuade the trustees of the college and ultimately, (with the help of several politicians, including Kevin Sullivan, the State Senate president pro-tem and an employee of Trinity), the state legislature to back a $175 million plan to improve a 15-block area that included the Barry Square and Frog Hollow neighborhoods with new schools, housing, jobs, recreation and social services.
In addition, he called on his neighbors who were partners in the neighborhood alliance: Hartford Hospital, the Institute of Living, Connecticut Children's Medical Center and Connecticut Public Television and Radio. The city's corporations were also tapped for support. Aetna and the Loctite Corporation gave the first $2 million. The Kellogg Corporation gave a $5.1 million grant to Trinity to support its plans. Hartford Steam Boiler, Fleet, People's and Bank of Boston also contributed.
"If you're a firefighter or a teacher, you can live here and not have to worry about not being able to afford a private school," said Mr. Dobelle, who is 55 and brought a unique background of politics (mayor of Pittsfield, Mass. and chief of protocol in the Carter administration) and education ( he was president of two community colleges).
Those involved in the project attribute its success to pairing two seemingly disparate groups: the power brokers and the people movers. It was the legislature and the corporations that found the money to buy real estate but in at least one case it was knowing the father of one homeowner because he played dominoes with Eddie Perez's uncle that clinched the sale. The Hartford Areas Rally Together Job Center is funded by a pastiche of programs, but it functions because its director, Ana Natal, knows somebody who knows somebody who will hire a woman who has never filled out a resume, but has children to support.
This blend pleases Mr. Dobelle, but he would like to see the plan replicated elsewhere. In a recent interview in his office, he said that a colleague from Williams College just phoned and told him the neighborhood plan was the talk of a recent conference.
"I said, 'Great! Is anyone else doing it?' " The answer was, just one other college, the University of Southern California.
"We wanted the whole community to buy into the idea that their kids can be anything they want," he said. The plan meshed with the college's promotion of community service; some 1,400 of the 1,800 students at the college volunteer, Mr. Dobelle said. Since Mr. Dobelle's arrival on campus, applications to Trinity have increased 77 percent, according to his staff.
The most expensive and ambitious portion of the plan is complete: four public schools arranged around a central green on 16 acres between Broad and Washington streets, next door to the Trinity campus. They are known collectively as "The Learning Corridor." Construction began in 1998 on the $110-milion buildings and the schools opened last month to 800 students. These include: a Montessori school for pre-kindergarten through fifth grade; a city magnet middle school for grades six through eight; a math and science academy, and an arts academy.
The 516,000 square feet of buildings will ultimately serve 1,500 students. The complex also includes a 632-seat community theater. On the first floor beneath the parking garage, retail spaces are for rent. The project partners hope these spaces will house small, community-based businesses. The project was funded by $94 million of state money with neighborhood alliance partners and the city contributing $10.5 million and $6.3 million, respectively.
The Montessori Magnet School is the only public Montessori school in Connecticut and one of just 15 public ones in the nation. The 230 students are grouped by ages rather than grade. Emphasis is placed on experiential learning, including practical life skills and a music program that starts 95 percent of the students in violin at age 5. The school will ultimately serve up to 350 children. It is state-funded and operated by the Connecticut Region Education Council, as are the two high schools.
Each classroom on the first floor of the Montessori school opens to the courtyard, a whimsical space that includes a stream where children can control water flow and gardens.
About half of the children at the school come from Hartford, with 25 percent of those from the neighborhood. The rest hail from 20 participating school districts. A lottery system was used; there were more than 200 applications for the 48 places in the 3- to 5-year-old classes and phone calls keep coming, said Timothy Nee, the principal.
Tonya Dorman, a third-year law student at the University of Connecticut who lives in Windsor and works as a law clerk in Hartford, enrolled her son, Rochayne, 3, because she liked the school's intellectual orientation for pre-schoolers.
"I'm West Indian and it is the closest I could get to the education I received as a child in Jamaica, where I learned to read at 2," she said.
Just across the green is the Hartford Middle Magnet School where doors opened in September to a class of 200 sixth graders, all but 10 from the neighborhood school district. Over the next two years, 400 more seventh and eighth graders will be added. It was built with $27 million of city and state money and $1 million from the neighborhood alliance.
The school emphasizes science, math and the arts. Its principal, James Longo, said the ultimate goal is for the school to be an inter-district magnet. Parents' night, Mr. Longo said, was a full house. The school's library will be stocked in the coming weeks and its swimming pool open.
The middle school is steps away from the Greater Hartford Academy of Mathematics and Science. Built to serve 300 high school students from around the state, it was funded by $46 million of state bonds and donations.
As of September, 148 students from 13 public school districts enrolled in either morning or afternoon math and science classes taught by teachers and researchers and faculty mentors from Trinity College, the University of Connecticut Health Center and the University of Hartford. Among the offerings are courses in robotics and molecular genetics. There is a cell culture laboratory and a computer controlled green house. Jeffrey Osborne, the school director, said "there are no quotas" at the academy. Thirty-two percent of the students are from Hartford. There are more girls than boys, more minorities than whites.
At the Greater Hartford Academy of the Arts next door, students audition or submit portfolios for admission.
Until September, the arts academy was housed for about 12 years in a former funeral home and bar on Wethersfield Avenue in Hartford. Kim Stroud, the school's managing director, said student dancers were reluctant to leap with abandon since the ceilings were so low. The new performance spaces are very different, with many windows and soaring ceilings. Musicians work in modern recording studios. Writers listen to visiting poets while perched on upholstered furniture in a room that overlooks the green. More important, school administrators said, the majority of the teachers are themselves performing artists.
These 260 students leave their home schools in 43 different school districts to attend either morning or afternoon classes at the arts academy. About 21 percent of the students are from Hartford. Students must audition and apply to be considered for the program. Unlike the math and science academy, this school will accept students whose home districts do not participate in the magnet program. Students can pay privately. Sebastien Guidetti, 17, of Glastonbury works summers on a blueberry farm to help earn some of the $3,900 tuition so he can play the vibraphone, percussion and piano in the academy's jazz ensemble.
The school building project is complete and the program to build owner-occupied housing is one-third accomplished. Thus far, 15 houses have either been newly built or rehabilitated; four more are under construction and 10 more properties will be completed, said Mr. Perez, who coordinates the housing effort. Many vacant houses have been torn down. The restored or new homes have been sold to neighborhood residents. Seventy percent of people in the target area are Hispanic. Eighty-five percent of them are renters.
On average, the two family homes are built for $185,000 with city, state and federal subsidies. The neighborhood alliance sells the houses for about $95,000, often with down payment assistance and reduced mortgage rates. The conditions for the buyers are these: They must live in the house for at least three years, 10 percent of the debt is discounted if they stay 10 years or more. They need to take a home ownership training class. People who live or work in the area get top priority, a practice Mr. Dobelle calls "geographic affirmative action."
Mark Hallums is negotiating to buy a big yellow house around the corner from the Learning Corridor. The 34-year-old Bloomfield resident works in the buildings and grounds department at Trinity. He said the offer of home ownership was too good to pass up.
"If this collaboration can put up $200 million in the area," he said, hooking his thumb in the direction of Mr. Perez as a symbol of the neighborhood alliance, "I can put up $100,000."
Mr. Dobelle wasn't the first person to suggest change for the Barry Square and Frog Hollow neighborhoods. His predecessor, Tom Gerety, supported neighborhood groups. The neighborhood alliance is 22-years-old, but was not yet part of a coalition. There was a community newspaper, merchant associations and educational programs. They needed to be galvanized.
The first big thing Mr. Dobelle did was come up with $5.9 million. Hartford Hospital put up another $5 million, legitimizing the project. Experts were hired to examine the 15-block area of the neighborhood. At the same time, Mr. Dobelle and Mr. Perez went into the neighborhood to hear concerns and capitalize on existing community groups such as Hartford Areas Rally Together (HART).
"Kids were their top priority," Mr. Perez said. "Then crime, jobs and housing. People said maybe if we had decent jobs, crime wouldn't be such a big problem."
The police department is focusing on "quality of life" issues in the neighborhood, such as public drinking, noise complaints, an approach used successfully in cities like New York. Statistically, major crime in the Barry Square neighborhood has decreased 33 percent since 1993, according to Hartford Police Sergeant Neil Dryfe, the department's public information officer. Yet he noted there has been an increase of 29 percent from January to August of this year when compared to the same period in 1999.
Across the street from Hartford Hospital is the HART Job Center. It opened in 1996 to train and find work primarily for residents of the neighborhood. Several hundred people are placed each year. The center was the first source for hiring during construction of the Learning Corridor.
The center's director, Ana Natal, and her staff steer people to available jobs, help them learn to type, use a computer and fill out an application. Mr. Perez admitted the center is sometimes more unorthodox than professional, but said that does not hamper its effectiveness. Ms. Natal said the center is a start for people.
"A lot of our people walk in off the street, most of them are Hispanic and don't speak English," she said. "They have nothing and nowhere else to go. We don't turn people away."
New houses and buildings are up, some streets have been improved, but a lot of work remains. On some streets surrounding the school, house after house is abandoned, their yards littered with broken glass.
Mayor Michael Peters did not return telephone calls seeking comment about the Trinity program. Yet when asked about the neighborhood, the first thing residents point out is the Learning Corridor as the most potent symbol of change. Others use different markers. Yolanda Jimenez and her husband own the Roque Market. It is a small, neat-as-a-pin grocery store on Zion Street where the owners estimate half of the customers are on welfare. She expressed guarded optimism when asked about the neighborhood.
"We opened in early January and since then the neighborhood seems more calm than it was," she said. "There were a lot of drugs but I think it's improved."
Last February, the Connecticut Historical Society announced plans to move from its west end location to Zion Street, in the neighborhood known as Behind The Rocks, which borders Trinity. The architect, Frank Gehry, will design the 115,000-square-foot space. Linda Campanella, Trinity senior vice president for operations and planning, said the society's decision was another example of "a nonprofit catalyzing economic renewal in the area." As the neighborhood is restored, Mr. Dobelle said he hopes self-confidence of its residents follows.
" Nonprofit organizations don't pay taxes for a reason, Mr. Dobelle said, adding that these institutions are supposed to give back to their communities. "We're trying to do the right thing. We're sending a signal to other colleges that asks, do you or don't you do the right thing?"

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Coming of Age, but Going Nowhere

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
TOMMY, a 12-year-old Indian boy, born in Canada, searches for a father, rejecting the one he has.
Tina, his 16-year-old cousin who cannot walk, endures the rituals of an arranged marriage in India, eventually giving up whatever she was searching for, and rejecting everything she doesn't have. 
 Somehow, the paths of Tommy and Tina intersect, though not dramatically, in "Rice Boy," a very long night's journey at Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven.
The quest for identity and for love are universalized through specificity, and a playwright can hardly be more culturally specific than Sunil Kuruvilla. Still, the two cousins, not to mention Father, Uncle, Auntie, Granny, and such outsiders as a servant girl, a fish seller, a sari clerk, a kinky umbrella man and a nut seller are grounded in Indian mores .
"Rice Boy" is not transcendent. Although the playwright, a 1999 graduate of Yale Drama School, struggles lugubriously to be charming, the quality of his whimsy is strained. "Eventually you will be unhappy," Auntie, who is Tina's mother, tells her about marriage. "But not at the beginning," she assures her daughter. That's as humorous as it gets.
Oddly, Canada, the playwright's homeland, is shortchanged, even though Tommy's indolent father, a mathematics professor in his own country, now an unemployed pizza maker in his land of exile, says, "I don't know how to be a Canadian father," not that he tries.
"Rice Boy," based on Mr. Kuruvilla's memories of childhood trps to India, does not try to depict a cross section or intertwining of two cultures. Except for its vivid evocations of Indian rites -- the preliminaries for the making of the unleavened bread, nan; the sprinkling of rice powder for kolams, decorative patterns, on the stage floor; talk of cinammon fields and rosewater ice cream -- Mr. Kuruvilla's play is flat and meaningless, down to its last line, a reference to boys without girls.
Liz Diamond, a resident director of the company, appears to have gone round and round to energize it and make it flow. The production is enhanced by ascending and descending screens of many colors, and such lovely effects as snowflakes, which Granny tastes and pronounces sweeter than the rain.
One learns of Auntie's infidelity with the family doctor and of Father's misery with his marriage to Tommy's mother who drowned mysteriously and whom he now loves and misses. One hears fathers incessantly undermining their children; no wonder Tommy looks for, and for a time finds, a new one.
And one listens, captively, to Granny's ravings, never knowing whether they are informational, senile or intended to be poetic. Given her sculpted face, stunningly communicative hands and dancer's grace, Yolande Bavan provides other diversions, mostly of a choreographic sort.
In his truly annoying coming of age, the incessantly demanding Tommy hardly progresses beyond whining, though his all-consuming sadness and premonitions of death remain just an offering for possibilities of depth. Unlike Ms. Bavan, Wayne Kasserman does not possess his own talent to distract. At the end of an hour-long first act, he asks, "Where should I go?" and one wonders, who cares.
A gratuitous, but mercifully shorter second act, winds up with the sort of obligatory narrative provided by a playwright who is compelled to tell us what happens to everybody without quite knowing how to end his own play. At least by then it's really over.
"Rice Boy" Yale Repertory Theater 222 York Street, New Haven. Box office: (203) 432-1234. Performances through Nov. 11.

HEADLINE: Few Lobsters, and Now, Fewer Lobstermen

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
BOB SPONG, 60, has been a lobsterman on Long Island Sound all his life. But last March, when he thought the lobster population might never recover, he decided to get what he calls "the first real job" he's ever held. So now he drives a forklift at the Home Depot store in Commack on the lobster shift -- what else? -- from 10 p.m. to 6:30 a.m.
"The idea was then I could still go fishing during the day," Mr. Spong said. He kept his 1,000 lobster traps in the water through the spring. But instead of hauling in 900 lobsters a day, as he and other lobstermen had when the sound was flush, he rarely brought in more than 40 a day, barely enough to pay for the trip. 
 "I worried about it for months, but I finally made the decision to take the traps out," Mr. Spong said. "There just wasn't enough signs to stay in." He still goes out on his 42-foot boat about once a week to fish for blackfish, but he doesn't expect to make much money from that. He does it just to be out on the water.
Today, of the 20 lobstermen who used to fish out of Northport, Mr. Spong's home port, only five or six are still fishing for lobster regularly, and many of them have also taken part-time jobs to help make ends meet. Some 7,000 lobster traps sit in neat piles at the foot of the old town dump in Huntington, where town officials have allowed lobstermen to store their unused gear. Mr. Spong checks on his traps every now and then and said that the number of lobstermen bringing in their pots grows each week.
Further west in the Sound, in Glen Cove to the south and Greenwich to the north, there are virtually no lobsters left and consequently no fishermen either. The situation steadily improves heading eastward, so that at the easternmost tip of the North Fork, fishermen are reporting that things appear almost normal, state officials said.
So why don't the lobstermen move farther east? The trade has traditionally been very territorial, and a lobsterman who normally fishes out of Glen Cove would not be welcome elsewhere.
Lobstermen and state officials say the good news is that lobsters do not appear to be dying off, as they had been a year ago, but the bad news is that there are many fewer lobsters being caught and virtually no signs of lobsters in the western sound.
The causes of the die-off are being studied. Research has implicated a single-celled protozoan, but other factors may be involved.
Officials in New York and Connecticut do not have statistics showing how hard the lobster industry was hit last year or how the industry is faring now. But officials said that informal surveys of lobsterman suggest that the lobster haul in the central part of the Sound is still off by more than 50 percent and down by about 30 percent as far east as Mattituck.
"It's a stark difference from the way it had been prior to the die-off when there were record-high harvests," said Gordon C. Colvin, the director of marine resources for the New York State Department of Economic Conservation.
According to the latest figures available from the National Marine Fisheries Service, the lobster industry in New York hit a peak in 1996, with 9.4 million pounds caught, worth nearly $33 million, and stayed strong through 1998, with 8.5 million pounds worth $29.8 million.
In Connecticut, the agency said, 1998 was the peak year, with 3.7 million pounds caught, $12.1 million. Preliminary figures from Connecticut show that in 1999, the haul dropped to 2.5 million pounds, worth about $9.2 million. New York State did not have comparable figures.
"The only thing that's encouraging is that we have not heard that they're dying in the central sound this fall, and most lobsters seem to be healthy," Mr. Colvin said. "But it's difficult to forecast what might happen, especially in the western sound where there are no young lobsters at all."
Lobstermen and officials agree that given the current circumstances, it will take at least four to five years -- the time it takes for young lobsters to grow to one-pound size, the minimum for legal harvesting -- for the lobster industry in Long Island Sound to recover.
But if what happened to the scallop industry in the Peconic Bay is any indication, the lobstermen have little to look forward to. The scallops there were decimated in 1985 when a sudden bloom of algae known as brown tide starved and killed them. The industry has yet to recover fully. Scallops rebounded briefly in 1994, but another bloom of brown tide hit the following year. And despite years of surveys and research, state officials have been unable to determine what causes brown tide to appear or how to control it.
It's unclear how many fewer lobster fishermen there are plying the waters this year. The number of licenses issued is down by 20 percent in New York, from 746 in 1999 to only 587 this year, and down by 8 percent in Connecticut, from 419 in 1999 to 386 this year. But officials in both states suspect that many fishermen have kept their licenses but are not actively fishing.
"The people who have stayed seem to be fishing less gear," said Eric M. Smith, the assistant director of marine fisheries for the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection. "The number of lobster pots out there has been down." Connecticut and New York officials estimated there were more than 500,000 lobster traps in the sound last year, but they will not know how many there are this year until fisherman submit their tallies in December.
Lobstermen are very close-mouthed about how much they make. But when Mr. Spong and his friends reminisce about the days of good lobstering, they talk about bringing in 900 to 1,500 pounds a day, which translates, roughly, to $3,000 to $5,000.
"It was a tough but nice way to earn a living," said Larry Eberhardt, a good friend of Mr. Spong's who now works at Home Depot, too. He said the months of April and May would be busy, followed by a slow June when lobsters shed their shells, and then followed by two or three busy months. "The rest of the time, you could vacation when you wanted and if you didn't feel like going out one day, you just didn't," he said.
Marcel Cormier, one of the few fishermen still tending lobster traps out of Northport, estimated that his lobstering income this year would drop by 90 percent. There have been days when he has checked 400 of his 1,000 traps, only to come back with only 30 lobsters. The only way for a lobsterman to survive this year, he said, is "to have a wife with a good job." (His wife, Susan, is a jeweler in Northport.)
With last year's catastrophic die-off in the western sound, the federal government has approved $3.6 million to compensate lobstermen in New York for their losses and another $3.6 million for Connecticut lobstermen, but the money has yet to be distributed, and state officials do not know how much longer it will take.
Officials from both states also are preparing to divide up $6.6 million in federal research dollars to study causes of the lobster deaths. A research team at the University of Connecticut found last November that a parasite had killed the lobsters but has been awaiting further financing for research to determine what might have weakened the lobsters' immune systems enough to make them susceptible to the parasite. The parasite in question is a paramoeba, a tiny, one-celled protozoan that targets the lobster's nervous system and destroys nerve tissue.
Many lobstermen have a different view. Blaming the die-off on last year's pesticide spraying to kill mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus, about 1,100 lobsterman from Long Island Sound have filed a lawsuit against five pesticide manufacturers, seeking $125 million in damages. But researchers have been skeptical of the pesticide theory, noting that while the lobster die-off peaked last fall, it began last summer, before pesticide spraying began.
Other possible causes include last year's unusually warm water temperatures, which were generated by tropical storms that moved through the area and brought in large amounts of warm freshwater, the large lobster populations in previous years may have made it possible for a disease to spread rapidly.
The State University of New York at Stony Brook recently received $1 million in state money to create a pathology laboratory so lobsters will no longer have to be shipped to Connecticut, Virginia and Arizona for autopsies.
Jack Mattice, the director of the New York Sea Grant program, which will coordinate the research with Connecticut Sea Grant and other agencies from both states, said that because there were likely multiple causes for the die-off, the federally financed research would try to cover all possibilities. The research money also will be used to study the causes of shell disease, which has struck mainly in the waters off of Montauk and Fishers Island. Shell disease does not kill lobsters but leaves their shells eroded and pitted, making them unappealing at the table.
Mr. Mattice also said that some of the research money would be used to pay lobstermen to set traps to bring in a sampling of lobsters for study.
But for older fishermen like Mr. Spong, the fruits of the research may come too late.
"The lobsters won't be back in my lifetime," Mr. Spong said with resignation.
Mr. Spong and his friend Mr. Eberhardt often scour the ads in magazines for commercial fishermen, looking for a boat with a license for offshore lobster fishing. But these bigger, more powerful boats cost $400,000 to $500,000, significantly more than the $50,000 to $150,000 that a fisherman in the sound normally spends for a boat.
"We dream," Mr. Spong said, "but we don't know if we have what it takes at this stage of the game. Offshore fishing is a young man's game, because you're far out there, and you've got to fight the sea."
Mr. Eberhardt said he often wonders what to call himself these days, considering that he spends 40 hours a week moving stock at Home Depot.
"I don't know what I'm supposed to be anymore," he said. " Am I still a fisherman? I don't know. I never thought I'd have to start new at age 53, but I guess that's life."

HEADLINE: Suggestions Offered on Cutting Energy Costs

BYLINE: By SAM LUBELL

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
STRONGER conservation programs, aggressive use of alternative energy sources and public control of the electricity supply were among the ideas proposed last week at a forum here on rising energy prices.
The forum was sponsored by County Executive Andrew J. Spano, and many who attended acknowledged that most factors affecting energy prices are out of local control, like unrest in the Middle East, weather and federal energy policies. The discussion instead focused on what could be done on the local level. 
 "We have to free ourselves from the inability of the federal government and the state to move things along," Mr. Spano said.
State Assemblyman Ronald C. Tocci, a Democrat, proposed that the county's Public Utility Service Agency, which already buys power in bulk for county facilities, do the same for residential customers. This would mean "divorcing from Con Ed" to help fight what he characterized as the company's price inflation.
"It has to do with a corporate structure that has as its premise make money at the expense of the rate payer," he said of Con Ed. He said that the Public Utility Service Agency would do everything possible to help give consumers economic advantages, and proposed a referendum to empower the agency.
"There's nothing that Con Edison does that we couldn't do ourselves," he said.
Mr. Tocci and others also complained that Westchester citizens were forced to bear the burden of the company's costs in New York City.
A Con Edison spokesman, James O'Toole, responded that it was the market, not the company, that set the prices for energy, and that Con Ed was doing everything possible to keep rates down.
"We always look for the best energy deals in the marketplace for our customers, but, despite our best efforts, prices have increased," he said.
Edward Smeloff, Director of the Pace Energy Project and commissioner of the county's Public Utility Agency, proposed improved control and monitoring of consumers' energy use via technology like programmable thermostats and the internet.
Mr. Spano suggested that monitoring could eventually be made possible by linking electric, oil and gas meters to the county's developing high-speed network, Westchester Telecom, to give consumers immediate information on energy consumption. Such technology, Mr. Smeloff said, could increase energy efficiency. While the meeting was meant to draw the opinions of experts, many residents expressed their concerns.
"Seniors especially are caught up like yo-yo's on a string," said Helen Henderson, a former outreach worker from Mount Vernon who worked primarily with the elderly. She said she had helped people who were forced to choose between keeping their heat on or having enough medicine and food, and she called on local authorities to closely scrutinize and regulate energy costs.
Mr. Spano asked most residents who testified to speak with representatives on hand to work out short-term help for their problems.
"What we're trying to do is free ourselves from being hostage to federal policies by creating a whole bunch of solutions that cumulatively would have a big effect," Mr. Spano said. "I think we got some excellent feedback, and we can now see more clearly that there are things that can be done."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Turning Brownfields Into Fairways and Greens

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J.

 BODY:
THE view is terrific, even if it's from the top of a massive trash heap. The wide swath of the Hudson River and the breathtaking skyline of Manhattan are to the east, and the rolling hills of northern New Jersey march north and west.
If current plans are carried out, this moonscape of construction debris and industrial waste rising from the watery flats known as the Meadowlands will be covered in grassland and bushes and become the home to as many as four golf courses. The project, which would involve more than 900 acres, would be one of the largest reuses in the state of a brownfield, the term for land that has been environmentally contaminated and often abandoned as a result. 
 Brownfield redevelopment is taking place all over New Jersey, a state whose industrial history has left it with an abundance of contaminated land. Real estate executives say intense demand for sites for retail, commercial and recreational activities -- along with a more realistic attitude on the part of state lawmakers and regulators -- is pushing developers to consider places they would have avoided in the past.
"Brownfields are becoming a major force in the real estate market," said Ira L. Whitman, who heads an environmental consulting company in East Brunswick. He noted that more than 3,000 people attended a recent conference in Atlantic City just to discuss brownfield issues.
"The demand for industrial land is particularly strong," said Paul D. Cohen, an executive vice president of SBWE Inc, a New Jersey-based real estate brokerage. "There are three million square feet under construction or about to start at Exit 8A," he said, referring to the exit of the New Jersey Turnpike in South Brunswick Township that is about 60 miles southwest of New York.
"And that's a second choice for most of them, since they would rather be closer to the city," he added.
The Jersey Gardens outlet mall in Elizabeth is probably the best known brownfield redevelopment in the state. The 225-store mall sits on the site of the old Elizabeth town dump, which was covered with clean dirt and equipped with drainage pipes to prepare for the new structure. Now the company that did the mall site, OENJ-Cherokee, is filling in another old dump, this one in Bayonne, to prepare it for an 18-hole public golf course. It is also attempting to develop land to the east of the mall with 700,000 square feet of modern office space and a ferry link to Manhattan.
Some of these projects are tied to the Port of New York and New Jersey, which is concentrated along the waterfront of the cities of Newark and Elizabeth. Both the Meadowlands and Bayonne golf course projects are based on using material dredged from the harbor to cap the contaminated land.
And as the dredging deepens the port so that it can receive the new generation of large container ships, traffic planners are looking to develop brownfields near the docks to house facilities to handle the larger volumes of cargo. Then, they envision value-added distribution operations that would generate needed jobs in the poorer, urban areas near the port.
In addition to the pressure of the market, real estate executives and consultants say, activity is being generated by developers, financiers and government officials who have become more sophisticated about brownfields in recent years. In particular, they have recognized that a lightly polluted brownfield is different from a heavily contaminated Superfund site, one that has been designated by the Environmental Protection Agency as one of the most dangerous in the nation.
UNDER Superfund rules, a broad range of companies associated with a site -- owners, concerns that operated plants and companies that dumped waste -- can be made responsible for the entire cost of the cleanup. Thus, developers have been reluctant to get involved with them because of the unknown cost of making a site acceptable, and lenders have often refused to provide financing, because a builder's default might make them the owner of the property -- with the consequent legal and financial responsibility for its cleanup.
The increasing attractiveness of brownfields in New Jersey is in part a result of legislation passed in 1998 under which the state provides financial incentives to promote the reuse of brownfields and does not insist that they be cleaned to a uniform standard. If a site is to remain industrial and is distant from residences, it might have only to be capped with clean material, leaving the contamination enclosed at the site.
Sites that could pose a danger to human health, such as as those near housing or schools, would have to meet a much stiffer standard.
Attitudes toward brownfields vary from state to state. In New York, some planners and architects complain that a law requiring sites to be cleaned to a pristine standard is preventing economic development in places like the South Bronx and Brooklyn.
Ronald Shiffman, director of Pratt Institute's Center for Community and Environmental Development, said such a regulatory climate drives development toward sites in suburban and rural areas that have never been used by industry, bypassing economically needy urban locations.
The Pratt center is part of a group known as the Brownfields Coalition, which proposed legislation that would encourage the establishment of cleanup standards based on how the property would be used and incentives for voluntary cleanups. The bill was not acted upon by the Legislature in Albany, with the result, according to a coalition statement, that "New York is hemorrhaging businesses, jobs and tax revenues to states who have changed the way they do business to encourage private investment in their brownfield sites."
Mr. Shiffman said: "We have prime real estate along the Hudson River and in Greenpoint, Williamsburg and Red Hook that are in need of infrastructure investment and work force training, but it is not happening."
There are few tracts of land in the metropolitan region that have been treated as badly as the New Jersey Meadowlands. Before the value of wetlands as wildlife habitat, flood control systems and water filters was recognized, the Meadowlands were treated as useless swamps, a place to dump unwanted garbage and trash.
The 32-square mile area in Bergen and Hudson Counties is now represented by the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, which has planning and zoning jurisdiction over towns within its borders.
The commission has a tentative agreement with EnCap Golf of Tampa, Fla., to lease the land for 99 years for the golf development in the Meadowlands, which may also include a hotel, time-share condominiums and other development. The company would pay to properly cap old landfills on the site that are leaching contaminated liquid into nearby waterways and emitting methane gas as a result of the decomposition of organic matter. Some of the landfills are considered "orphans" because the towns and private companies that once used them have either disappeared or declined financial responsibility.
"All these landfills were abandoned in the 1970's," said Alan J. Steinberg, executive director of the commission. "Golf is a means of having the private sector pay for closure and to enhance the quality of the Hackensack River watershed." He added that the project would help to improve the appearance of sections of the Meadowlands that are clearly visible from the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike and would help to reduce ocean pollution by providing an upland site for the disposal of mud dredged from New York harbor as part of the deepening project.
Although heavily developed, the Meadowlands remain that most unusual of locations, an "urban wilderness," Mr. Steinberg said. Some 3,600 acres of the 19,000 acres in the tract remain as open space and most are still wetlands. Commission officials say the remaining wetlands are a vital feeding and resting area for migratory birds passing though the area.
Even on the areas that have long since been despoiled, like the landfills, the Meadowlands' proximity to Manhattan is a big part of its appeal as a recreation area. "EnCap people speak about 'experience tourism,' " Mr. Steinberg said. He said the opportunity to play golf with the Manhattan skyline in the background of the 120 foot high landfill is expected to attract visitors who might also be persuaded to do some eco-touring in the wetlands.
The Meadowlands golf proposal is an indication of the state's increasingly activist approach to brownfield redevelopment, said Jane M. Kenny, New Jersey's commissioner of community affairs and chairwoman of the state's Brownfields Task Force. "We were overly cautious in the past, but now we are more aggressive," she said.
Development of urban brownfields is tied directly to the effort to preserve open space in the densely crowded state, she said. "We have a goal of preserving one million acres of open space, so the question becomes, where do you grow," Ms. Kenny said. "So brownfields become the flip side of preserving open space." State and local efforts to preserve open space by subjecting developers' plans in rural areas to intense scrutiny can nudge them to look more favorably at brownfields, said Mr. Whitman, the environmental consultant. "Once a developer has financing, timing is important," he said. "If he is facing a 24 month approval time in a suburb versus a 12 month approval in an urban area, he is likely to choose the latter."
Brownfield development nationally is being aided by more sophisticated regulation, said Ronald B. Bruder, president of Brookhill Group, which specializes in developing contaminated properties.
Rather than insisting that all of such a site be cleaned to a pristine standard, he said, regulators are now willing to use devices like deed restrictions to prevent public contact with polluted land.
Nevertheless, he said, redevelopment will always be more difficult than an initial development on a greenfield. "These deals are complicated," he said. "It can take as long as two years to figure out how to deal with a site."
Because of that difficulty, he said, brownfield development is more sensitive to the state of the economy than the rest of the industry. "If the real estate market starts to cool, the brownfield market will cool off a lot faster," Mr. Bruder said.
Mr. Steinberg, the Meadowlands official, said economic development in the Meadowlands is intended to finance preservation of the remaining open space and wetlands. "If a wetland is functional, we are opposed to developing one square inch of it," he said. "If an area is degraded and there is no funding for restoration, we will consider development of a smaller portion of the tract if the developer will mitigate the larger portion."
The first, 36 hole, phase of the golf course plan is intended to close three "orphan" landfills in an environmentally secure manner plus one that is currently in operation.
The second phase would add 36 more holes of golf and include the towering site in North Arlington, where the commission currently operates a landfill accepting construction debris and nontoxic industrial waste. "We are totally self-funded, but we would be happy to get out of the solid waste business and collect lease payments," he said.
William Gauger, the president of EnCap, said the company planned to begin construction of the first Meadowlands golf course next July, with completion expected in July 2005. The expected cost is $70 million to $75 million, he said.
The second phase might be built in parallel with the first, with the second golf course opening in 2007. At least one of the courses will be open to the public, Mr. Gauger said. The project includes a hotel with 500 to 600 rooms, which that would open in 2007, and a marina on the Hackensack.
EnCap Golf is an offshoot of Environmental Capital International, which specializes in supplying capital to environmental concerns. Mr. Gauger said putting golf courses on top of old dumps is a common reuse of such sites, with more than 60 already in operation. One of the oldest is the Marine Park course in Brooklyn, which was built in the early 1960's.
One advantage of putting golf courses, rather than buildings, on old landfills is that there is little danger of damage if the ground subsides. Mr. Gauger said a golf course built on top of 350 feet of garbage in the Los Angeles area has subsided 50 feet in the last 15 years.
Developing golf courses on top of landfills is a way of turning eyesores into assets and increasing the value of adjacent land, Mr. Gauger said. He said the group hoped to do additional development near its golf projects, including office properties.
Brownfield development of a different sort is on the minds of officials of the North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority. Glancing out the window of its offices on the 17th floor of One Newark Center at the industrial tracts to the east in Hudson and Union Counties one day recently, John V. Hummer, the agency's special projects manager, said, "That's all brownfields out there."
The agency, he said, is anticipating a large increase in containerized freight from the Far East as dredging, first to 45 feet and ultimately to 50 feet, allows the ports in Newark and Elizabeth to accommodate a new generation of larger ships. The problem will be moving all that traffic through an already congested area. But there is also an opportunity to capture some economic advantage by doing some processing of that cargo before it leaves the region.
"The projections for traffic growth in the port are astonishing," he said. "It is expected to double in 10 years, and we are already up to the level expected in 2004." In addition to seagoing freight, the adjacent Newark Airport is expected to become one of the nation's air cargo centers.
THE agency, a federally funded planning organization that is affiliated with New Jersey Institute of Technology, has a mandate to develop plans to move freight through the region by locating facilities on brownfields.
One of the proposals the agency is studying calls for building a special road, called the Portway, for trucks moving containers from the docks to nearby warehouses and processing centers. This is intended to reduce some of the pressure on the northern stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike, which often resembles a race track for trucks, and to ease congestion on local roads.
Another is to direct more of the traffic, particularly freight traveling long distances, off the highways and onto trains. "The issue is railyard and rail capacity," Mr. Hummer said. When Conrail was operating the freight system in the Northeast, it shrunk capacity to cut costs, he said. As a result, a rail system in the northern part of New Jersey that could accommodate 250 freight trains a day in 1960 can handle only 70 trains a day at present.
And this is at a time of increased demand for passenger rail service that competes for time and space on the same track system.
The economics of transportation are such that railroads make money only on hauls of over 400 miles, so local distribution will continue to be based on trucks.
This presents an opportunity for brownfield development, Mr. Hummer said. Shippers in the Far East, he said, use the entire capacity of containers "without concern for weight restriction." But, he said "we have weight restrictions, so the containers have to be unpacked and loaded in multiple containers."
As long as the containers are being unpacked, he said, some light processing of the cargo can be done, such as sewing labels on clothing or adding bar codes and labels to goods before they are repacked for transit. "We have an opportunity to add value," he said, "and jobs beyond the usual ones in a warehouse, at locations near the terminal."
Regardless of the final use, brownfield developments have to make sense as real estate deals before the environmental costs are added in, said Andrew W. Savitz, an environmental specialist at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. "If the real estate does not work, the deal is not going to work," he said. "But if it does, it's good for both the environment and the developer."

HEADLINE: Saving the Shore

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: VENTNOR

 BODY:
MARC MILLER'S ocean view from the dining room of his modest Cape just footsteps from the beach -- is a painter's dream. On summer days, beachgoers make their way across the several hundred yards of sand that separate the Atlantic Ocean from his floor-to-ceiling windows. The scene is often frenetic, not serene, but that's the way Mr. Miller likes it.
"This beach is for everyone," said Mr. Miller one recent day. "I love it. Visitors love it. It is there day after day and year after year. And it should stay that way, untouched." 
 But that could change under a plan being drawn up by the Army Corps of Engineers to safeguard Mr. Miller's dining room -- though perhaps not his picture-window view. The project, referred to by the corps as the Absecon Island Shore Protection Project, would add 100 more feet of beach through Ventnor and the neighboring island towns. Moreover, the widened beach would be reinforced with a 10-foot-high dune.
After the work is done, what Mr. Miller -- and all his beachfront neighbors, for that matter -- would see would not be frolicking children or greased-up sunbathers but, as he puts it, "just a large, unneeded mountain of sand."
And the project, which could ultimately cost as much as $600 million over the next 50 years, doesn't stop at this swath of shoreline.
The Corps has essentially decided that constructing dunes and rebuilding beaches in front of them is the most sensible way to protect development along the state's barrier islands as well as other stretches of the 127-mile-long coastline.
But the 71-year-old Mr. Miller, a retired insurance salesman, and the group to which he belongs -- Don't Upset the Natural Environment, or DUNE -- have drawn their own line in the sand, insisting that this kind of government spending is wasteful. "We have one of the most beautiful beaches in the world," he said. "When you build one continuous dune you destroy the beach."
Mr. Miller and his members of his organization have not come up with an alternative plan, but at the least would like to have other options to consider.
As the Corps views it, Congress has given it a mandate to protect the infrastructure that is the lifeblood of tourist and beach economies, though it is not the Corps' job to make better beaches for recreation. In addition to the projects on the boards for this state, the corps has similar plans for much of the Atlantic seaboard.
"While you can debate whether we should have built up these islands and beach areas, the fact is that there are now streets and buildings and boardwalks worth billions of dollars there," said Susan Scott-Lucas, chief of the Army Corps Coastal Planning Section in Philadelphia, which oversees the state's coastline from Manasquan Inlet to Cape May. "The main reason for this whole beach replenishment project is to protect those investments. It is only the secondary purpose that are the recreation benefits."
But what DUNE and other opponents of beach replenishment see is one long dune casting a shadow over their little slice of heaven -- a ridgeline running the length of the state blocking ocean views, making it a bit more difficult to get to the beach, blowing sand into nearby streets and houses and serving no particular purpose other than to make work for the Army Corps of Engineers.
So far, opponents of the replenishment project have delayed the first leg of the journey: the 8.1-mile, $60 million Absecon Island project, which would run through Atlantic City, Ventnor, Margate and Longport. The federal government is to bear 65 percent of the cost, while the state will take on most of the other 35 percent with the towns assuming the rest. Work is now scheduled to begin in Atlantic City in the spring and to progress down the island, finishing in Longport late next year.
Along Absecon Island alone, the project would dredge 6.2 million cubic yards of sand from the ocean floor near the Absecon Inlet on the north end of the island and construct a 200-foot-wide extension to the beach in Atlantic City and a 100-foot-wide beach in the other three towns.
In addition, the dunes -- four feet above boardwalk level in Atlantic City to a foot above in Ventnor -- would be built and reinforced with dune grass.
And the widening of the beach and building of the dune would only be the beginning. Over the next 50 years -- at a cost of $540 million -- the corps plans to pour as much as 1.67 million cubic yards of sand along those same beaches every three years to keep them stable, with the possibility of emergency reinforcements after particularly devastating storms.
Glenn Klotz is unmoved by the corps' arguments that his beloved Margate beach needs any help. Mr. Klotz, a 51-year-old computer engineer, lives several blocks from the beach -- and has for much of his life -- so it is not the ocean view he is afraid of losing. He simply regards the project as futile and wasteful.
"The sand is moving, not staying anywhere," said Mr. Klotz. "If there is a river of sand moving down the beach and you dump sand into it, it won't work. You are throwing the taxpayers' money into the ocean. And someone is making a lot of money pushing that sand around."
But Stewart Farrell, a professor of marine science and geology and director of the Coastal Research Center at Richard Stockton College of New Jersey, like most experts on the subject, disagrees with opponents of the replenishment project.
"If the argument is that we are messing with Mother Nature, well, we messed with her long ago when we built there," Professor Farrell said. "If nothing is done now, those houses will wash away and they will certainly wash away sooner without the project than with it. That is guaranteed in stone. We could make the choice to let that happen, but the politicians and the banks certainly won't like it. The fact is that beach nourishment on a large scale is the only way to keep the wolf from the door as long as sea level is rising."
SCIENTIFIC disagreement notwithstanding, Mr. Klotz, a leader of DUNE, says he and other opponents of the project feel beach replenishment is a political football, noting that although the Clinton Administration has been against the project, the Republican-controlled Congress has continued to finance the corps' proposals.
President Clinton vetoed the Energy and Water Development Appropriations Act of 2001, which included funds for future beach replenishment projects, saying that the legislation passed by Congress included too much federal money for all Army Corps projects. Indeed, officials from the Federal Emergency Management Agency testified that the projects were too expensive and, if undertaken at all, should be done by individual communities.
"You can imagine the pressure on local politicians to go along," he said. "They must think, 'What if a storm comes and I don't build this dune? Will I ever be elected again?' Fortunately, some of the political people are showing some courage."
After about 750 people -- most of them opposed to the project -- attended three informational meetings held by the Corps of Engineers over the past several months, elected officials in Ventnor, Margate and Longport said they wanted to wait until they had more information before they signed onto the project.
"That will probably, at the very least, delay work," said Ms. Scott-Lucas. "And the project will not happen unless every town along the beach wants in."
This is dismaying to Mayor James Whelan of Atlantic City, which is by far the largest city on Absecon Island.
"It's a very frustrating issue for us," said Mayor Whelan. "We have done anything the feds and the state have asked us to do, and our neighbors on the island have not. If you live on barrier islands, you need to pump sand. That's the fact. We can pump them now or we can do it 10 or 20 years from now after we've had a devastating storm. You can't wait for unanimous support on every issue. We need to do this before a disaster happens."
But Ms. Scott-Lucas explained the need to have every town on the island on board this way: You can't have a dune for several miles, then have no dune and expect the dunes to be stable. It would be a waste of time to do that kind of partial project.
In general, the scientific community favors the construction of dunes to save the beaches as an environmentally benign approach to beach preservation.
Moreover, Professor Farrell said that the arguments against building the dunes were flawed. "People say it is a big pile of dirt," Professor Farrell said, "but they go on that other side of the dune and that dirt is what they love to call a beach.
"They say dunes collect trash, but they don't," he continued. "People do that and municipalities are forced to clean it up, which they generally do. Then they talk about bugs, rats and muggers. Muggers can find better hideouts. Rats can't find food there. And, bugs, all right, they have bugs, but there are probably bugs in everyone's house at the beach."
For his part, Mr. Klotz dismissed Mr. Farrell's advocacy of beach replenishment, saying he was a mouthpiece for the corps. On the other hand, he said that people who own beach property should not not be reimbursed -- either through insurance or legislation -- should their homes be washed away.
"The land moves," he said. "Back in the beginning of the 1900's, part of Longport detached and ended up as the north part of Ocean City. That's only natural, and we who live here on the island understand that. We are prepared to live with that and, certainly, we don't think people in Cherry Hill, or Ohio for that matter, should be paying for filling our beaches."
Interestingly, that is the objection an otherwise sympathetic scientist, Norbert P. Psuty, a professor of marine and coastal sciences at Cook College, Rutgers University.
"I have always been in favor of dunes, whether artificially or naturally made," said Professor Psuty. "They are there not to prevent the shore from eroding, but to prevent the storm surge inland. From a natural kind of process perspective, it more closely duplicates the natural system.
"My attitude on beach fill is that I am antagonistic on the way it is paid for," he added. "Locals should pay a larger share. I am philosophically opposed to state and federal taxpayers paying for local costs. Those who go to the beach are paying a fee going into the town coffers. I don't see why that can't be used to pay for beach fill.
Beach fill and dune reconstruction is a relatively new way of preserving beaches. In the early 20th century, towns often constructed groins -- long, rocky piers into the ocean -- to divert sand to their beaches or to keep sand from washing away. Eventually some towns, like Sea Girt in northern Monmouth County, ended up with virtually no beach, and a sea wall was built there to stop the ocean from washing onto the adjacent buildings and roads.
Or there are places like Wildwood, where the beach has filled in from both the north and the south -- largely because of jetties that the corps erected years ago at Cape May Inlet -- to such an extent that it can actually fit another city block or two on some stretches and still have a substantial surf. Because of that, Five Mile Island in Wildwood is the only barrier island in the state where no dunes or beach replenishment projects are planned.
Whatever the outcome of the proposed project on Absecon Island and other beaches along the state's coastline through 2005, real estate firms are unconcerned about the potential effect on the market for beachfront property.
"The public may right now have difficulty with the federal government trying to push this through," said Michael Zitomer, vice president of Zitomer Real Estate, which has offices in Margate and Longport. "But I think you have to sacrifice for the 'what if.' What if that big storm really hits? People just need to receive the right information and then, I think, they will realize that everyone will benefit. And, let's face it, people will build second-floor decks and they'll have their views and property values won't be affected."
Farther south, Seven Mile Island stands to be next in line for the dune project, or perhaps the first late next year if the towns on Absecon Island balk. And the more upscale and less densely populated towns of Avalon and Stone Harbor that make up Seven Mile Island appear to welcome the beach fill.
Both towns have financed their own smaller projects over the last few years -- Avalon on the north end of the island and in Stone Harbor between 98th and 110th Streets. Since each individual project undertaken by the Corps of Engineers requires Congressional approval, the financing for Seven Mile Island has not yet been authorized, though it seems to be taken as a matter of course there.
"When they built the dunes from 98th Street, maybe you could no longer see the ocean from the sidewalk, but I didn't hear anyone complain," said Bob Sellers of Diller-Fisher Real Estate in Stone Harbor. "Maybe it will actually enhance property values, even if it is only the appearance of safety. Besides, now people seem to build with, say, guest rooms and storage downstairs and the master bedroom and kitchen with big windows on the second floor, higher than the dunes."
JUST how the beach replenishment projects will affect flood insurance rates is an open question, at least according to Sam Wierman, who owns the Ide Insurance Agency in Stone Harbor.
"It's a complicated formula that the federal agencies that underwrite the insurance use, but having dunes will factor into it and certainly can't hurt, Mr. Wierman said. "Still, in 20 years, I can count on two hands the claims I have gotten from flooding on the beach. Ironically enough, it may be the bay that is the problem."
For all the controversy about the dunes and the beach widening, said Professor Psuty of Rutgers, it is indeed the bay side of all these islands that probably needs some more attention.
"Sea level in New Jersey has come up a foot over the last century, and it is estimated that it could come up two more feet this century," he said. "At the same time, development has leveled some of the islands by two, or as many as six feet.
"So what has happened," he added, "is that on the bay side of the island, some of the buildings are now only a foot above sea level. The streets flood regularly. And with global warming and continued development, it only projects to be worse. You can put up 20-foot dunes and it's not going to help the bay side. People may well be fighting the wrong fight."
Such talk only inflames Mr. Miller of DUNE.
"What we really need is more and more information, not just putting up a dune because the Army Corps say it's the way to go," he said. "Mother Nature is going to govern in the end, though. I'm willing to leave it to her and take my chances."

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Poised to Raise Real Jersey Tomatoes, Year Round

BYLINE: By Karen DeMasters

 BODY:
Just as home gardeners are putting away the tomato cages, those at the experimental agriculture station greenhouse in Bordentown operated by Cook College of Rutgers University are preparing to harvest their first tomatoes of the season. The workers there not only hope to produce a steady stream of tomatoes to be sold to King's Supermarkets in northern New Jersey throughout the winter, but they also hope the tomatoes will be as good as any that are picked in the Jersey fields at the peak of summer. The greenhouse, next to the landfill at the Burlington County Resource Center, is in the middle of its third year of operation. Dr. Harry Janes, a research professor and director of the greenhouse, which is next to the landfill at the Burlington Country Resource Center, talked recently about the operation.
Q. How is your tomato greenhouse different from others? 
 A. The tomato seeds are planted in a small block of spun rock that looks like fiberglass and they are placed on tables that are on rollers and easily moveable. The plants are kept to about four feet in height. They are watered regularly with water that is enriched with controlled amounts of fertilizer. The heat for the building is made from methane gas that is siphoned off of the landfill. This not only provides an economical source of heat but it uses a greenhouse gas that can harm the ozone, so we are helping the environment. Now we are trying to find ways to reduce the cost of lighting, which can be 30 percent of the cost of running a greenhouse.
Q. What is the ultimate goal?
A. We know we can grow tomatoes that are as good as ones grown in the field in New Jersey in the summertime. What we are trying to do now is to grow tomatoes of that same quality in a greenhouse economically enough so that farmers can do it and make a profit. The reason other greenhouse tomatoes in the supermarkets in the wintertime are not as good is because they are bred to have thicker walls and less gel so they can be shipped long distances. They are picked before they are ripe, and much of the sugar is absorbed into the tomato from the plant just as they are ripening. We can leave them on the vine longer. But we have to be able to produce a steady flow of tomatoes throughout the winter or a supermarket is not going to be interested in buying them. We want to be able to go to the farmers and say, "This is how you do it to make a reasonable profit." In the past, greenhouse production was not economical because tomatoes could not be produced consistently. We have a grant from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration because they want to know what can be grown in the least amount of space.
Q. Why use moveable trays?
A. One of the biggest costs is labor. In most greenhouses you have floor-to-ceiling plants and the workers have to move among them. The plants can be damaged and the workers cannot be properly supervised. With moveable trays, the plants can be much closer together and they are brought to the workers. We plant seeds every week, so there are tomatoes ripening all winter long. We can have four times as many plants per acre and one fourth as many workers. Our workers are all mentally or emotionally handicapped people. When the plants can be moved to the people, it is easy to provide the guidance the workers need.
Q. Is the greenhouse used to raise anything other than tomatoes?
A. This greenhouse is the only one of its kind. We have the graduate students preparing proposals to use the 2.5 feet of space beneath the tables for growing ornamental fish. We don't know if it can be done or if you can make a profit doing it. We think we might be able to use the nitrogen waste from the fish as fertilizer. We'll experiment to try to find those things out. KAREN DeMASTERS
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 9; Page 13; Column 2; Society Desk

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
