HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Warning From One President To the Next

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:

To: My Successor
From: Bill Clinton
Date: Nov. 8, 2000
Congratulations on your victory. My bequest to you is the best economy that any of us has ever known, a testament either to the righteousness of my policies or my exquisitely fortuitous timing. (We'll let history sort that one out.) 
 In any case, here's your first top-secret briefing as president-elect: The good times probably won't last.
I'm not trying to put a damper on your celebration. But let's face it: no winning streak goes on forever, and even with Alan Greenspan working his magic, this expansion is vulnerable on a number of fronts.
So if you don't want to be a one-term president, you had better start thinking about where the economic danger will lurk during your watch.
Here are three topics that, however arcane they sound, may soon be keeping you awake at night: the current account deficit, the possibility that the long boom in capital spending will come to a halt, and the likelihood that the current budget surpluses will give way to another era of deficits.
The current account -- a broad measure of the balance of trade and the flow of capital across borders -- is running a huge deficit. This year, it has been more than 4 percent of the gross domestic product, the largest by far among the big industrial countries and well above its last peak of 3.4 percent during the mid-1980's.
In a sense, the current account deficit is an indicator of strength. The economy is expanding faster than those of our major trading partners, so imports are surging while export growth has been sluggish. Moreover, capital has cascaded into the United States because rates of return here have been high, both from the stock market and from direct investments like the acquisition of companies or the construction of new factories.
In this new, productivity-enhanced economy, no one knows how big the current account deficit can grow before the United States encounters trouble. But at some point the deficit will become unsustainable.
Here's the possibility that generates sweaty palms at Treasury and the Fed: Foreign investors judge the United States to be losing its economic edge. They suddenly become nervous about the current account and cut off the flow of new money into the country. The dollar plummets, inflation accelerates and the Fed responds by pushing up interest rates, choking off growth.
How do we address the problem? By encouraging more robust growth in Japan and Europe, and by shoring up our own national balance sheet through continued reduction of the national debt and increased levels of private savings. As you'll soon find out, those things are easier said than done.
Perhaps the most important characteristic of this expansion has been the high rate of growth in capital spending. The growth reflects the successful drive by corporations to squeeze out costs and improve productivity, and accounts for a substantial chunk of total demand in the economy.
Companies have enjoyed high rates of return on capital spending because they have been able to borrow money cheaply. But now interest rates for corporate borrowers are rising. At the same time, profit growth is slowing, as is overall economic growth.
Many forces, including global competition, are still pressuring companies to continue to invest in new equipment, but it is now clear that the rate of increase is slowing. A continued slowdown could have outsized effects on economic growth, and on the outlook for corporate profits and for Wall Street.
Through its effects "on productivity growth and ultimately on the level of stock prices, the capital spending boom has been responsible for a significant part of the growth in consumer spending in recent years," said a recent study by Ed McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs.
"In short, if the boom were to end," the study added, "this could undermine the virtuous cycle that has driven U.S. growth over the past decade."
The economy's recent strength has been underpinned by big budget surpluses and reduction of the national debt. But guess what? The surplus is shrinking already, and that's not even the real problem.
Even if all the positive forces that have generated surpluses for the last few years remain intact for another decade, the government's fiscal condition is going to take a wrenching turn for the worse starting around 2015, as we confront the bill from the aging of the baby-boom generation. The prospect of huge budget deficits lies just over the horizon.
I'm heading off into early retirement myself. Do me a favor and help me make it a prosperous and secure dotage.

HEADLINE: Taking On the Corporate Goliaths

BYLINE: By GRAHAM GORI

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
WHEN Mexico's antitrust agency decided to break up the nation's airline monopoly in early October, the move was seen as a bold show of aggressiveness. It also sent a strong signal that with the government about to change hands, Mexico might be prepared to guarantee competitors greater access to markets now dominated by single companies.
Telefonos de Mexico, known as Telmex, dominates telecommunications, Cintra owns the skies, the state-run Petroleos de Mexico, known as Pemex, controls oil and Bimbo rules the bread market. These companies have benefited greatly from decades of weak or nonexistent regulation, coupled with a tight relationship between big business and big government. 
 Vicente Fox Quesada, who takes office in a little more than a month, has said that to accomplish his economic goals, he will need to strengthen existing antitrust and regulatory commissions. He wants to ensure that they are more powerful than the beasts they were devised to tame, giving competitors greater access to markets previously closed to them.
The most important is the Federal Antitrust Commission, headed by Francisco Sanchez Ugarte. In its seven years of existence, it has tackled some of the nation's most powerful companies. Two years ago, it ruled that Telmex, run by one of Latin America's richest men, Carlos Slim, was a monopoly, a decision that should have resulted in major reductions on the leviathan's grip on the telecommunications market. Telmex's share of the long-distance market has rebounded to 81 percent after falling to about 70 percent, and the company still provides more than 95 percent of local service.
But through appeals, Telmex has tied up the issue in the judicial system, raised the prospect of a telecommunications trade battle with the United States and illustrated the weakness of antitrust enforcement.
All of this begs a question: What good is it to have an antitrust agency if its ability to enforce decisions depends on the good will of the companies it is regulating?
"We need to give regulators the teeth that they don't have currently," said Emilio Goicoechea, a congressman from Mr. Fox's National Action Party. "The regulators simply can't enforce their decisions."
Mr. Fox's economic advisers plan to present a proposal to Congress that would eliminate the "judicial uncertainty" of antitrust decisions. The law would limit the appeals process and allow the agency to put regulations into effect immediately, even if they are challenged in court.
Damian Fraser, a Latin American equity strategist for UBS Warburg, agreed with proposals to beef up regulatory agencies as a way to lower costs and increase efficiency.
"The government's role should be to allow competition in the market," he said. "I think it's a lot easier to take on monopolies in the new Mexico than in the past. What you had was a cozy, de facto, unwritten agreement between large companies and the PRI," the longtime ruling party.
"The companies would support the PRI, if the PRI in turn would support the companies and help them maintain a dominant market share," he added.
BUT even before Mr. Fox's plans are debated in Congress, the antitrust agency has begun acting more forcefully. A few weeks ago, it ruled against Cintra, calling for it to sell its two largest carriers, Mexicana and Aeromexico, as separate and competing entities.
Mr. Fox's economic team withheld comment on the recent Cintra deal, but said it was committed to a strong regulatory agency.
The opposing argument is that Mexican companies need monopolistic power to compete with overseas rivals, especially under the North American Free Trade Agreement. In the wake of the Cintra decision, union leaders have led protests against what they see as any action that would "jeopardize the future of this country's aviation," said Jaime Luis Gonzalez, general director of the Airline Pilots Association of Mexico.
Mr. Gonzalez has threatened strikes and shutdowns if the airlines are split. He would view a breakup as an open invitation for foreign competitors to muscle into Mexico's air travel market, which could lead to layoffs of airline employees.
Cintra officials also balked at the decision, arguing that a unified airline industry could better compete globally. They boast that after taking over the near-bankrupt airlines in 1995, Cintra grew to become Latin America's largest and most lucrative airline company. If it is split, they say, the separate airlines could not hold their own against United States carriers like United or Delta.
The unfriendly reception, however, has not slowed the antitrust commission. It ruled recently that Pemex's gas stations would have to sell lubricants made by competitors of Lubmex, in which Pemex has 49 percent ownership.
Last week, Mr. Sanchez announced that the commission was investigating the selling practices of Coca-Cola in Mexico. Next in line, he said, are the selling practices of two dominant beer manufacturers, Grupo Modelo and Grupo Moctezuma Cuauhtemoc.
If Mr. Fox succeeds in creating regulatory agencies capable of enforcing their rulings, the United States government would welcome the news. Richard W. Fisher, the deputy United States trade representative, recently came to Mexico to argue that its government had not done enough to prevent Telmex from denying competitors entry into Mexico's telecommunications market. AT&T and WorldCom have complained about the interconnection fees that Telmex charges competitors to connect into its network, arguing that the practice violates World Trade Organization agreements.
Although Mexico's federal regulators ordered Telmex this month to slash its interconnection rates by 63 percent, it remains to be seen if the order will be enforced. Telmex could seek another injunction. "We will be looking to see whether or not these decisions by very earnest regulators will be implemented and enforced," Mr. Fisher said. "I think the signal this will send is critical to the success of the Fox administration."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Treacherous Stretch For a Busing Leader

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Ontario

 BODY:
NO company buses more people around North America than Laidlaw Inc. Its 40,000 school buses transport more than two million students in cities like Rochester, and its 3,800 Greyhound coaches form by far the largest network in the United States. Laidlaw also operates 240 municipal transit services -- including those carrying commuters in Orange County, Calif., and the disabled in Boston -- as well as ambulance services.
What many of its passengers may not know, however, is that Laidlaw, based here, about an hour west of Toronto but doing 90 percent of its business in the United States, is struggling to survive. 
 Its bus businesses make money, but not enough to cover the interest on $3.3 billion of mostly public debt amassed in failed growth plans during the 1990's. The company is already in default, having paid no interest on the debt since mid-May. Last week, it reached an agreement with its creditors, enabling it to borrow as much as an additional $350 million.
With that agreement, Laidlaw's operating units can now keep going for several months. But by next spring, Laidlaw faces the risk that school boards will refuse to keep doing business with a company whose future is uncertain.
John R. Grainger, 51, who joined Laidlaw a decade ago and became president and chief executive in December, faces a company-imposed deadline of next March 31 for bankers, bondholders and shareholders to agree on a reorganization. Stephen Cooper of Zolfo Cooper, a New York firm specializing in turnarounds, joined Laidlaw as vice chairman in mid-July to supervise the restructuring and sell the idea to investors.
If creditors and shareholders refuse to sign on, Mr. Grainger says, the company could be forced into bankruptcy and sold off in pieces.
Laidlaw took several wrong turns to arrive at a destination that Mr. Grainger bluntly calls "our disaster." Aggressive expansion into ambulance service proved to be a sinkhole, and the company's foray into the waste management business also proved worthless.
In the quarter ended May 31, Laidlaw had a loss of $227 million on sales of $1.08 billion. That compared with a profit of $168 million on sales of $896 million in the year-earlier period.
To improve the company's finances, creditors would have to exchange a big chunk of their debt for equity. Stockholders would see their share of the company greatly diluted. (The stock, which reached $20.25 on the New York Stock Exchange in February 1991, closed on Friday at 25 cents.)
Mr. Grainger said in an interview at the Laidlaw headquarters that he was trying to determine how much debt the bus and ambulance businesses could support, and which investors would end up with how much of the company. "How that value -- in debt, equity and cash -- will be split up among the stakeholders will be negotiated between now and March 31," he said.
Kam Hon, a transportation analyst at Dominion Bond Rating Service in Toronto, cited two factors that might make a reorganization succeed. One is that the school transportation and Greyhound divisions continue to be profitable. The other is that Laidlaw is in such a deep hole that selling off the company in pieces would yield scant returns for anyone with a financial stake. "It doesn't serve anybody's interest to put the company under when its assets are nowhere near its liabilities," Mr. Hon said.
For much of its history, Laidlaw had steady and orderly growth. Established as a trucking company in 1924, it was bought in 1959 by Michael DeGroote, a businessman in Hamilton, Ontario. Mr. DeGroote added industrial waste disposal and school bus companies in Canada and the United States, then sold the trucking division. The company was listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange in 1969 and on the Nasdaq in 1983. It moved from Nasdaq to the New York Stock Exchange in 1990, when Mr. DeGroote retired.
During the 1990's, while the company continued to buy school bus companies, Laidlaw executives decided that their logistical skills could be applied to consolidating another area of transportation: ambulance services. It made sense at the time, said Mr. Grainger, who was then running the bus division. "In retrospect, it should have been done more slowly, but when you're consolidating, speed is part of the strategy."
With the purchase of MedTrans in 1993, CareLine in 1995 and American Medical Response in 1997, Laidlaw became the biggest transporter of the sick and injured in the United States. But about that time, the government began a far-reaching inquiry into reports of false Medicare charges and overcharges, including those related to ambulance services. Neither Laidlaw nor any other ambulance company was ultimately accused of wrongdoing. Like other ambulance companies, however, Laidlaw had to return some government payments as a result of the inquiry, while new rules led to delays in subsequent payments. Losses began to mount in the ambulance division.
LAIDLAW, meanwhile, sought to expand in the business of transporting industrial waste. In 1997, it bought Rollins Environmental, to merge with its own waste management unit. A year later, Laidlaw made a successful hostile bid for control of Safety-Kleen, an industrial waste processor based in Columbia, S.C.; after consolidating its own various waste holdings into Safety-Kleen, Laidlaw ended up with a 44 percent stake in the company.
Laidlaw added intercity buses in 1997 with the acquisition of Greyhound Canada, followed by the 1999 purchase of Greyhound Lines Inc. in the United States. Recently reorganized, Greyhound remained heavily in debt when Laidlaw bought it for $816 million and assumed its $416 million in debt.
Feeling its own debt squeeze, Laidlaw decided in September 1999 to sell its ambulance operations and Safety-Kleen stake for an anticipated $2 billion. The cash, it said at the time, would be used to reduce debt and to buy more buses.
The sale of Safety-Kleen was expected to be routine until employees of the company raised questions about dubious accounting practices. A board-ordered audit uncovered improprieties and, although no charges resulted, Safety-Kleen filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June of this year. Laidlaw has written off an investment once valued at more than $1 billion. Some Safety-Kleen creditors have threatened to seek recovery of a $200 million payment that Laidlaw received from Safety-Kleen in August 1999 that creditors say should go to them instead. Laidlaw, which says the payment was part of the sale of its own waste company to Safety-Kleen and therefore was appropriate, will have to settle any claims before its own restructuring can proceed.
The ambulance business, still unprofitable, is also unsold. "We're receiving distress kinds of offers, below what we think are appropriate values," Mr. Grainger said. He now says the company may keep the ambulance operations, whose results have improved recently.
The new bank loans ensure that the school bus, Greyhound and ambulance divisions will have enough cash in the near term. If he can hold the company together, Mr. Grainger said, it will have a good foundation on which to build. School bus contracts provide healthy profit margins, and the school bus division accounted for $72 million of the company's $99.2 million in operating profit for the latest quarter. Two-thirds of the school buses in North America are run by private companies that Laidlaw might want to acquire.
Margins are thinner at Greyhound, but passenger loads have been rising and, as a low-cost travel option, the company may stand to benefit from an economic downturn.
Mr. Grainger's mission is to work on longer-range plans, even as he rushes to strike a deal.
"Our job is to keep value in the company, while recognizing the constraints we're under," he said. "I tell our operating people to consider this as a race, but it's a marathon -- it's going to be long and tough, but we're doing it at a measured pace. The negotiating team -- they're in a sprint."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Shifting Rules Add Luster to Trusts

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
THE long bull market has left some people with more wealth than they -- and their children -- will ever need. But barring some extreme act of profligacy by their immediate heirs, the super-rich face the prospect of having that money whittled away again and again by estate taxes with each passing generation.
There is an alternative, though, for those who are concerned about their financial legacies to distant descendants. Called a "dynasty trust," it provides -- as most trusts do -- substantial tax savings for the person setting it up. And the money is never again subject to estate taxes. 
 The trusts are still available only in some states, but anyone can travel to those states to set one up.
"Dynasty trusts are tremendously attractive, because wealth builds up quickly when it can be passed on without paying estate taxes at each successive generation," said Gideon Rothschild, a partner at Moses & Singer, a law firm in New York.
If a dynasty trust of roughly $1 million was established today, Mr. Rothschild figured, it would be worth $867.7 million after four generations, assuming that it grew 7 percent a year and nothing was spent. By contrast, it would be worth $35.6 million if the property was given outright to future generations and was subject each time to an estate tax of up to 55 percent.
For a century, wealthy families like the Rockefellers have created intergenerational trusts called family trusts. In 1986, Congress capped tax-free contributions at $1 million, indexed for inflation to $1.03 million this year, and most states limit trusts to roughly 100 years by adopting a version of the 16th-century British common-law doctrine called the rule against perpetuities.
The rule was devised by kings who feared that land given in return for service to the crown would be left to people who had no obligation for such service. Under the rule, a trust had to terminate 21 years after the death of a specified person living at the time the trust is created.
So far, 13 states have eliminated rules against perpetuities, making dynasty trusts possible. South Dakota, Wisconsin and Idaho were first, in 1983. Other states followed suit starting in 1996 -- most recently New Jersey in 1999 and Rhode Island this year. Starting in 2001, Floridians will be able to create 360-year trusts. New York and Missouri, among others, are debating similar moves.
Critics say dynasty trusts will further increase the concentration of wealth, can benefit people estranged from the donor and encourage litigation over the right to money from the fund and over how it is invested.
Alan Halpern, an estate tax specialist at Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, says that if the estate tax is repealed or limited to billionaires, heirs of those who create dynasty trusts may be unhappy. "Can you imagine if there is no estate tax and all this wealth is tied up in perpetuity?" he said.
The tax savings can be considerable. No federal gift taxes are owed when the trust is set up with assets valued at the amount protected by the one-time "federal unified credit," now $675,000 a person. The assets are not taxed in the donor's estate and can be free from state income taxes, depending on where the trust is set up. (South Dakota and Delaware, among others, generally levy no tax.) Finally, the trust can be structured so that assets are free from creditors' claims, ex-spouses or lawsuits against beneficiaries.
Dynasty trusts are often established as "defective grantor trusts," in which income is taxed not to the trust but to the person who created it. By paying the tax, the trust creator makes additional tax-free gifts. But Mr. Rothschild advises giving the trustee power to convert it to a nongrantor trust, to allow the trust creator to opt out of paying taxes.
Because dynasty trusts are long term, the trust document should include provisions to adjust for changing family circumstances and to allow modification or termination of the trust if the estate tax is repealed. Most important, but often neglected, is a statement of why the trust was created, said Laura H. Peebles, director in the Washington national tax office of Deloitte & Touche.
"What your kids, grandchildren and great-grandchildren will do with the money is more important than what Uncle Sam will do with his share," Ms. Peebles said. Often, the creator of a trust outlines his or her philosophy in a separate document, to avoid having it construed as legally binding. Some people want a trust used for education expenses, while others direct trustees to distribute income only when heirs fall below a certain standard of living.
The cost of setting up a dynasty trust varies. A simple lifetime trust established outside the home state of the trust creator costs $5,000 to $7,500 or more, depending on the complexity.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Michael J. Donnelly and Mark S. Kopiniski;
American Century Emerging Markets Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
MICHAEL J. DONNELLY, a manager of the $110 million American Century Emerging Markets fund, speaks Spanish, French and a smattering of Russian. Mark S. Kopinski, the other manager, speaks fluent Japanese. Collectively, the 14 American Century international analysts speak 13 languages, including Ukrainian, Cantonese and Afrikaans.
But the fund speaks to its investors in a different language: It returned 3.9 percent in the 12 months ended Oct. 26, compared with a loss of 2.6 percent for its peers in the diversified emerging markets category, according to Morningstar Inc. Over three years, a generally rough period for the emerging markets, the fund returned 2.5 percent a year, on average, versus a loss of 8.0 percent for the average fund in the category. 
 Mr. Kopinski, 44, and Mr. Donnelly, 35, called the market sell-off of September and October overdone.
"The emerging markets have been beaten up past a point that's reasonable," Mr. Donnelly said. "I think they're due for a considerable rally soon."
In picking stocks, the managers study 1,500 companies in 35 countries around the world. They use computer screens in their research -- though such filtering can be difficult for companies in some markets. "Our database is built around quarterly reporting, which isn't available in many emerging-markets countries," Mr. Kopinski said.
They look for companies with annual earnings growth of at least 20 percent, but they may raise or lower that bar depending on the industry and the countries where they operate. For example, earnings in countries that have devalued their currency may not be sustainable, Mr. Kopinski explained.
The portfolio's earnings growth rate averages 27 percent, versus 17 percent for the Morgan Stanley Capital International Emerging Markets Free Index.
The earnings test pares down their universe to about 300 companies, from which they eventually choose 100 to 125 stocks for the fund.
When working in their New York offices, the two men meet at 9 a.m. daily with the international analysts for the American Century fund family, sharing information about earnings announcements as well as global, country and industry trends.
"The global perspective gives us context for our investment decisions," Mr. Donnelly said. In the cellular phone industry, he added, "we were scratching around early in the emerging markets because we saw the trend developing in Europe."
Their work also requires an understanding of both corporate and national cultures, the managers said.
The managers often sell shares after one disappointing earnings report. "If a good company stumbles, it tends to take time to get back on its feet again," Mr. Kopinski said.
One favorite is Tubos de Acero de Mexico, a maker of pipes used for oil and gas transportation and drilling; the company trades as American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The company operates in a quasi-oligopolistic market around the world," Mr. Kopinski said. "Now that the price of oil is increasing, it will be a direct beneficiary of equipment purchasing by the major international oil companies."
Sales volume is on the rise despite quarterly price increases of 4 to 5 percent. Most sales are priced in American dollars, providing a hedge against weakness in the Mexican peso, Mr. Kopinski added.
The fund bought shares in September 1999 at $14.80. On Friday, they closed at $13.95, or 6.31 times the consensus earnings estimate of $2.21 a share for this year.
THEY also like Folli-Follie, a Greek retailer of midpriced fashion jewelry sold in rented space in department stores in about a dozen countries worldwide.
A visit to the company in May confirmed that operations were strong, Mr. Donnelly said. He expects annual earnings growth of 40 percent through 2002. "They're gaining market share in Japan," he said, "and moving into shops in the larger department stores, even though the Japanese economy is slow."
Growth in same-store sales, those at stores open at least a year, has doubled in the last three years. The company has opened stores in the United States and France and plans to expand into duty-free shops in Asia, Mr. Donnelly added.
The managers bought shares in May 1998 at 7,390 drachmas. The stock closed on Friday at 7,610 drachmas, or 59 times analysts' earnings estimates of 129 drachmas a share for this year.
Another holding is China Mobile (Hong Kong). The company is the largest cellular provider in China, Mr. Kopinski said; its acquisitions of regional mobile phone operators have resulted in a network running the length of China's eastern seaboard. The company has modernized the billing systems of its acquired companies, improved networks and pursued business users aggressively, he said, resulting in "a lot of upside in the subscriber base and earnings of the acquired companies."
Vodofone recently acquired a small stake in the company, Mr. Kopinski said, a move that will help it become part of a global network.
The managers bought the stock in June 1999 at $52 (Hong Kong); it now trades at $52.75, or 41.5 times consensus 2000 earnings estimates of $1.27 a share.

HEADLINE: Poised to Take Merrill by the Horns

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
OPENING his mail several months ago, E. Stanley O'Neal got a real blast from his past. An instructor from graduate school had sent him a card that Harvard Business School professors had used to track Mr. O'Neal's class participation. Affixed to it was a picture of him in full mid-70's flower, with a bushy Afro, long mustache and dark-tinted glasses.
"Would you want this man running your company?" said a note attached by the sender. 
 That joke elicited a burst of baritone laughter from Mr. O'Neal as he recounted it recently. Weeks earlier, he had been chosen to run the brokerage operations of Merrill Lynch & Company, a job generally considered a steppingstone to the chief executive's chair.
"I hadn't seen that picture in almost 25 years," said Mr. O'Neal, now 49 and known to all as Stan. The picture was snapped in a photo booth during a break from work as a foreman at an auto plant outside Atlanta, and Mr. O'Neal took particular note of his factory-issued shirt of "some unnatural blend" involving polyester.
Today, Mr. O'Neal looks every bit the polished Wall Street master, starched and trim in pinstriped suits and French-cuffed shirts made of nothing but fine cotton. Typical, except for one essential detail: Mr. O'Neal is an African-American, still a rarity in the executive suites of the biggest investment banks and brokerage firms.
When Merrill Lynch promoted him in February from chief financial officer to president of what the firm calls its U.S. Private Client Group, he became the first black person ever to run the nation's biggest brokerage business. He is also the first person to hold that job who never worked as a stockbroker, probably is the first who had ever labored in an auto factory, and almost certainly is the first who had picked cotton for spending money as a boy.
Now, he spends his days in corporate jets and conference rooms, deciding how Merrill's 15,000 brokers should provide financial advice to the millionaires and multimillionaires he says should be Merrill's main target. He took the reins at a crucial time for the brokers, who account for less than half of the firm's profit but who are still considered crown jewels. Merrill and other major brokerage firms are under attack from all manner of new competitors that have much lower costs and can charge less for stock trades and other services delivered mostly electronically.
The Charles Schwab Corporation, once dismissed on Wall Street as a low-budget discount broker, has swiftly shrunk Merrill's lead as the nation's biggest broker by consistently attracting more new customers and assets than Merrill. To stem the flow of accounts to Schwab and others, Merrill has slashed some prices, cut 2,000 jobs and, belatedly, embraced the Internet.
After a decade of concentrating on gathering customer assets without keeping a sharp on eye on costs, Merrill is under pressure from shareholders to show that its brokerage business can slim down and become more profitable. That is where Mr. O'Neal, with his background as a financial manager, comes in.
He has pledged to raise the pretax profit margin of the brokerage unit by three to four percentage points within four years. "He's got to do that," said Richard Strauss, an analyst at the Goldman Sachs Group. "That's the bare minimum, not a home run."
Even then, the business would be keeping, before paying taxes, less than 18 cents of every dollar in revenue. Mr. Strauss said pretax returns from a dominant financial services franchise should be higher than 20 percent, as they are at Schwab and some mutual fund and trust companies.
If Mr. O'Neal knocks the cover off the ball in his first crack at running one of Merrill's main businesses solo, he could cinch the chance to succeed David H. Komansky, Merrill's popular chief and chairman. No major firm on Wall Street has ever had a black chief executive.
Mr. Komansky, the expansive former broker who has been chief since late 1996 and chairman since 1997, is scheduled to retire in 2004. He has promised that by January 2002, he will help the board select a successor to serve as president and C.E.O.-in-waiting for two years. Mr. Komansky has said that there are four or five internal candidates who could succeed him, and speculation within Merrill has focused on Thomas W. Davis, who oversees trading and investment banking; Jeffrey M. Peek, who manages the mutual fund business; and, after his promotion to run the brokerage, Mr. O'Neal.
The promotion of Mr. O'Neal came as a surprise to most of the brokers he now manages, and even to some other Merrill executives. Most had learned little about him during his first dozen years at the firm -- few knew that his first initial stood for Ernest -- and many had considered him out of contention for a top job after he was selected as chief financial officer in 1998.
"I've been relatively anonymous for a long time, which has been perfectly fine with me," he said.
Outside Merrill, Mr. O'Neal has maintained an even lower profile. He is a director of one charitable organization, the Ronald McDonald House near his Park Avenue apartment in Manhattan, but is not involved with any major service organizations. When the National Urban League, which has tried for years to have Mr. O'Neal join its board, presents an award next month to Merrill Lynch, Mr. Komansky will accept it.
Hugh B. Price, the league's chief executive, said he still hoped to reel in Mr. O'Neal at some point.
"His success at Merrill Lynch and on Merrill Lynch's terms is what's of most significance to us as a people," Mr. Price said.
Mr. O'Neal is off to a fast start. During the summer, he cut 2,000 support jobs in the brokerage division while adding about 500 brokers, and started flattening the hierarchy that had built up over the years. Those and other expense reductions contributed heavily to Merrill's surprisingly strong earnings in the third quarter, which were 53 percent higher than in the third quarter of 1999.
Still, the contribution from the brokerage operations lags well behind that of Merrill's investment bank. The firm's businesses that cater to corporate and institutional clients earned $3.1 billion before taxes in the first nine months of 2000, about two and a half times as much as the brokerage business earned.
 THE early gains from the brokerage business have added to Mr. Komansky's affinity for Mr. O'Neal. The chairman dismissed the most common criticism of Mr. O'Neal as a leader: that he is too guarded, too tightly wound, that, in short, he is nothing like Mr. Komansky.
"We both came from fairly atypical backgrounds for where we ended up," said Mr. Komansky, a Bronx native whose father was a postal worker. "Stan didn't have the easiest trip in the world." Mr. O'Neal may not be the gregarious back-slapper that he is, Mr. Komansky said, but "superficial characteristics of a leader are less important than what that person is made of."
Mr. O'Neal's journey to Wall Street started in rural eastern Alabama, where his grandfather, who Mr. O'Neal said was born a slave, had settled to raise timber and cotton. He refused to sharecrop on a white man's land and managed to borrow enough money to buy his own, said Mr. O'Neal's father, Ernest O'Neal, who is 70.
The oldest of four children, Mr. O'Neal was born in 1951, and lived as a child in a house built by his father and uncles. The house had no indoor plumbing, Mr. O'Neal said, and he walked to a one-room schoolhouse. He recalled taking breaks to gather wood for the stove that heated the school.
His grandmother, mother and aunts picked cotton, and he sometimes worked in the fields alongside them. "They were not totally unpleasant chores, because I was with my family and I used to listen to all the talk and the gossip," he said. "I didn't like the sense of being poor, though."
Ernest O'Neal remembers his oldest son as a quiet boy who read a lot and kept to himself.
Hard times on the farm drove Ernest O'Neal to move his family to a federal housing project in Atlanta when Stan was 13. In 1964, the father landed a job at the General Motors assembly plant in Doraville, northeast of Atlanta, just as the factory's work force was being integrated.
An indifferent student in high school, Mr. O'Neal enrolled in the General Motors Institute, a cooperative college run by the automaker in Flint, Mich., after it held an open house at the Georgia factory. He earned a bachelor's degree in industrial administration by taking classes in Michigan for six weeks at a time, then driving the 640 miles back to Atlanta to work in the Doraville plant for six weeks.
After failing two classes in his second year at G.M.I, now known as Kettering Institute, Mr. O'Neal said he made a concentrated effort to excel. That led him, after a two-year stint as a foreman at Doraville, to the Harvard Business School, where he was an honor student. Upon earning his M.B.A., he joined General Motors' treasury office in New York, a breeding ground for executives. Among his contemporaries was Richard Waggoner, now chief executive of G.M.
Tony Hain, who taught at G.M.I. and later worked with Mr. O'Neal at G.M., remembered him as being able to read people and win them over. "His interpersonal radar is probably as good as anyone I have known," said Mr. Hain, now the dean of Kettering's graduate school.
JOHN FINNEGAN, G.M.'s acting chief financial officer, said that at G.M., "Stan was a star right away in the office." Recalling him as smart and focused, Mr. Finnegan added that he "seemed to have a great dislike for useless work."
Mr. O'Neal worked on some of G.M.'s biggest financial deals in the 1980's, including the issuance of tracking stocks for its fast-growing Hughes Electronics and Electronic Data Systems divisions, but he became restless as the company's competitive position sagged. Having come in frequent contact with investment bankers, Mr. O'Neal began to consider making the leap to Wall Street, as had one of his G.M. bosses, Courtney F. Jones.
Mr. Jones, who had been treasurer, left in 1985 to be Merrill's chief financial officer and tried to persuade Mr. O'Neal to follow him.
But Mr. O'Neal had decided that if he was going to Wall Street, he would not go as a financial manager but rather into a job where his contribution could be measured in the only way that counts there: in revenue brought to the firm. Leaving G.M. entailed big career risks and Mr. O'Neal sought a big potential reward, the sort of huge annual bonus that investment bankers took home.
Mr. O'Neal considered Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley before deciding in 1987 that he would be more comfortable at Merrill.
G.M. tried hard to stop him, summoning Mr. O'Neal to its Detroit headquarters for meetings with the chief executive and other officials who told him that he had a bright future at the company.
Mr. O'Neal's wife, Nancy Garvey, an economist who worked with him in the treasurer's office, said her husband labored over the decision long and hard. "We spent a lot of time talking about it," said Ms. Garvey, who went on to be the controller of Allied-Signal, but resigned in 1997 to raise the couple's twins, who are now 9 years old.
"It was a gutsy move," said Robert Scully, a vice chairman of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and a close friend of Mr. O'Neal's. "On Wall Street, eventually you have to do business, you have to write some tickets."
After joining Merrill, Mr. O'Neal made his mark by pushing the firm to be more competitive in the market for high-yield, or junk, bonds. By persuading companies with weak credit ratings to pay hefty fees to Merrill to sell their bonds, Mr. O'Neal led the firm to a top ranking among junk-bond underwriters in the early 1990's.
That success earned him the top job in the junk-bond department and put him on the path to loftier positions. When Herbert M. Allison was appointed to the No. 2 position at Merrill in April 1997, Mr. O'Neal was promoted to be one of his replacements as co-manager of all of the firm's trading and investment banking operations.
Brian Hehir, a senior Merrill investment banker who then reported to Mr. O'Neal, remembers taking frequent calls from his boss, who always had a list of questions about Mr. Hehir's business. Mr. O'Neal was "inquisitive" and "voracious" for information, but never imperious, Mr. Hehir said. "I had a very strong feeling that he had an extreme sense of fairness," he said.
MR. O'NEAL'S ascent since then has been speedy but far from linear. In less than a year, Mr. Komansky persuaded him to become chief financial officer, a role that people at investment banks generally see as thankless, and one that Mr. O'Neal accepted grudgingly. That stint lasted less than two years. But one of them was 1998, a wrenching year for Merrill.
The firm was rocked by the devastation that the Russian financial crisis wrought on global bond markets. Merrill, which had taken pride in being one of the biggest players in every segment of the bond market, got caught owning a huge amount of bonds whose value sank so fast that they were nearly impossible to unload. Then came the implosion of Long-Term Capital Management, a giant hedge fund that Merrill had to help keep afloat. In October 1998, when its competitors were already rebounding from the chaos of late summer, Merrill reorganized its bond department and laid off 3,400 full-time and 900 part-time employees. The $430 million cost of the revamping caused Merrill to lose $173 million in the third quarter of 1998.
Mr. O'Neal had the unpleasant task of delivering the stunningly bad news to investors through conference calls with analysts. Some of them pointed out that as a former head of the capital markets business, Mr. O'Neal had a hand in the buildup that led to the blow-up.
HOW Mr. O'Neal managed to survive with his reputation intact as a first-rate financial manager remains something of a mystery, some analysts and current and former Merrill employees said. None of them wanted to be identified as critics of a man who may run Merrill someday, and none had a negative word to say about Mr. O'Neal as a person. But they voiced doubts about how he would fare in his first try at running a major line of business by himself.
Those sentiments do not completely surprise Mr. O'Neal, who says he has often been saddled with low expectations, largely because of his race. Before his latest promotion, he said, when he met people socially and they asked him what he did for a living, he would say he worked at Merrill.
"And what do you do there?" they would ask. When he said he was the chief financial officer, he said, there inevitably would be a pause, followed about 75 percent of the time by: "Of the whole company?"
Mr. O'Neal shrugs off such reactions, saying, "It's not malicious at all, but there's an unspoken expectation that's embedded in that exchange.
I've been able to find ways of dealing with most of this stuff," he continued. "I've chosen to conduct my career and compete, as much as I could, on ability and performance."

HEADLINE: Worker Housing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The connection between property ownership and economic development in Peru as elucidated by the economist Hernando de Soto is clearly visible in the history of American home ownership (Editorial Observer, Oct. 26). 
 In the late 19th century, immigrant workers here were more likely to own homes than were middle-class Americans. Workers often used their houses as collateral for loans. But this did not necessarily provide for upward mobility; in many cases those loans were used to get through difficult economic times and to buttress wages that were too low to support a family.
Easy access to property titles may have helped to start industrial capitalism, but that's in part because home ownership allowed workers to survive on relatively low wages. The solution to poverty here and in the developing world is access to both loans and higher wages.
 
MARGARET GARB
New York, Oct. 26, 2000
 
The writer is adjunct professor of history, City College of New York.

HEADLINE: The World;
Working Nuclear Blackmail

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

 BODY:
WHY the difference between American policy toward Cuba, a renegade Communist backwater whose dictator is scorned by the United States, and toward North Korea, a renegade Communist backwater whose dictator was feted last week with Californian wines carried by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright?
One obvious reason is the political importance of fiercely anti-Castro Cubans in Florida. But there is another, more fundamental reason: weaponry. 
 Cuba built roads, schools and a conventional army. North Korea built nuclear weapons and missiles that can soar across most or all the Pacific and threaten the United States in the coming years.
So Washington, after decades of isolating North Korea much as it isolated Cuba, has been forced by this variant of gunboat diplomacy to change its stance.
In 1994, for example, the United States agreed to help construct billions of dollars worth of new nuclear plants for North Korea, if it abandoned atomic weapons development. From the North's perspective, the crowning achievement of its policy will come this fall, if President Clinton goes ahead with a contemplated trip to meet Kim Jong Il, North Korea's longtime "Dear Leader," more recently its "Great Leader," also known to his people as "the greatest of great men produced by heaven."
Nuclear blackmail, in short, pays pretty well.
Secretary Albright's visit to the North Korean capital of Pyongyang, the world's last Stalinist redoubt, put the issue in sharp perspective. She unwillingly boosted the legitimacy of Mr. Kim when she sat with him and watched a grand gymnastic spectacle in which the multitudes used cards to spell out in huge Korean letters: "Greatest glory to the great leader comrade Kim Jong Il."
The Chosun Ilbo, one of South Korea's leading newspapers, harrumphed: "Are We Paying Again for North Korea's Giving Up Its Missiles?" The answer is probably yes, if a price can be agreed upon. And that price will set the benchmark against which North Korea will then be able to negotiate further payoffs for giving up what intelligence experts believe are its considerable stockpiles of sarin nerve gas, mustard gas and various biological weapons, possibly including smallpox.
All this suggests that Kim Jong Il may be a shrewder leader than many people realize. For more than a decade, he has been portrayed largely as a buffoon, a playboy, a sadist, a maniac and a demented terrorist. Intelligence officials have talked about how he raced cars, attended to a harem of Scandinavian blondes, accumulated thousands of Western videos, executed aides and developed a bouffant hairstyle to add an inch or two to his 5-foot, 2-inch stature. He also repeatedly changed his name -- from the Russian name Yura, which he used in his youth, to Jong Il (meaning Jong the First), to a homonym Jong Il (meaning Jong the Sun). But for a supposed buffoon presiding over a famine-stricken land, Mr. Kim has done remarkably well in high-stakes international poker.
"They have played a weak hand very well," said Mitchell B. Reiss, a North Korea expert who is dean of international studies at the College of William and Mary.
Yet it is not that Americans have played badly. Rather, their cards were never very appealing.
In 1994, the United States pressed North Korea hard to abandon its nuclear program, threatening a naval blockade if it did not. At the time, North Korea warned that it could turn the South Korean capital of Seoul into "a sea of flames." Many military officials now say that the United States and North Korea came perilously close to war, much closer than was generally realized at the time. And while the United States clearly would have won, North Korea in its tormented death throes might have killed vast numbers of civilians in South Korea.
In the end a war was averted, thanks to the intervention of former President Jimmy Carter. The United States grumpily agreed to help build nuclear reactors for North Korea and supply it with fuel oil, arguably an unprincipled payoff, which most believe was preferable to a principled war.
That was nuclear blackmail. Today, instead, it's missile blackmail. In 1998 North Korea developed a new missile, the Taepodong, and sent it arching over Japan for a splashdown in the Pacific. The Taepodong is exceptionally inaccurate and for that reason not very useful militarily, but it still makes a valuable poker chip.
Once again, while everyone chafes at the idea of payoffs, blackmail and bribes, many diplomats believe that the alternatives are worse. As Walter Slocombe, a former under secretary of defense, once put it, leaving North Korea to its own devices would allow it to begin "turning out plutonium like sausages."
In a new book "North Korea: Through the Looking Glass" (Brookings Institution, 2000), Kongdan Oh and Ralph C. Hassig review the policy options, underscore their flaws, and then cite John Kenneth Galbraith's letter to President Kennedy in 1962: "Politics is not the art of the possible. It consists in choosing between the disastrous and the unpalatable."
Ms. Oh and Mr. Hassig say that some payoffs, regrettably, are probably necessary in the short run, and they add with equal regret that the only carrots that will lead the Dear Leader to change his behavior are those that will strengthen his dictatorship. "So the problem," they write, "is this: the kind of rewards that might reduce the Kim regime's hostility will strengthen that regime and will therefore prove unpopular among democratic donor states."
PROFESSOR REISS noted that while the rewards for North Korea have been unusual in scale, there is a long history of the United States offering "inducements" to other countries in similar situations. This began with President Dwight D. Eisenhower's "Atoms for Peace" program. Even today, United States policy toward countries like Pakistan and Iran rewards them economically, with trade, investments and loans from international organizations, if they steer away from nuclear weapons.
"Is this a bad example?" Professor Reiss asked of American policy toward North Korea. "Are other countries going to develop nuclear weapons programs so that they can trade them for economic development?" His answer is probably not, but if that were to happen, it might not be so awful to buy them out as well.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: The Car Is King;
Mass Transit Riders Are Pawns

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IT lasted 32 days and left half a million people stranded without their usual means of transportation. Maids and nannies struggled to find new ways from East Los Angeles to Beverly Hills, office workers carpooled and were chronically late and the notoriously bad traffic on freeways and surface streets was, if anything, worse.
Yet, somehow, most of Los Angeles hardly seemed to notice the monthlong bus and subway strike against the county's sprawling Metropolitan Transportation Authority that finally ended 10 days ago. For most of its duration, the strike rarely made the local television news. Politicians and union members faced little public pressure to reach a settlement. Only the intercession of a famous outside mediator, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, finally ended the walkout. 
 After all, this is the place where you are your car. It's not unusual for commuters to drive 100 miles round trip each day, or 45 minutes to eat dinner with friends. More than 8 in 10 Los Angeles area households have at least one car, and even the poorest residents tend to know somebody who knows somebody who has one in which they can share a ride. In a county with a population of 9.4 million, buses and subways move about 450,000 people any given day; there are 5.9 million registered cars and trucks.
But here's the paradox: greater Los Angeles grew up in the sprawling pattern the world knows today not because of the automobile but because of mass transit, the streetcars and rail lines of a century ago, that allowed a collection of interconnected communities and garden suburbs to flourish in contrast to the denser, traditional cities of the East and Midwest. The explosion of car culture only accelerated that trend -- as did the subsequent decline of mass transit.
Now, with more freeways more crowded than ever and literally no room left to build many new ones, Los Angeles County (an area three-fifths the size of Connecticut) is more dependent than ever on mass transit for the survival of its service economy. Two-career middle-class couples can go off to work in no small measure because of an interconnected system (mostly bus lines) that deposits cheap and reliable household help near their doors each day.
What's more, current projections call for the region to grow by six million people, or two Chicagos, over the next 20 to 25 years. That means even affluent Angelenos will have to look for new ways to avoid the daily agonies of driving clogged freeways, or make their peace with living in denser neighborhoods closer to their jobs -- or both.
"This strike shouldn't have happened and we should have been able to avoid it through negotiation," said Zev Yaroslavsky, a Los Angeles County Supervisor and M.T.A. board member, who like his colleagues took a hard line in the standoff with the agency's 4,300 drivers. "But we have to position this agency for the long term, to expand the quality and quantity of service to this increasingly transit dependent region."
The transit agency was under intense pressure to cut costs because of the huge price tag of its last big idea: a subway serving a relatively small part of the central city that wound up costing $4.5 billion for just over 17 miles of track. Plans for a grander system fell victim to construction delays, cost overruns and political infighting. Meanwhile, with so much money going to the subway, bus service declined and fares rose, so ridership fell overall. Now, the focus is on expanding the overcrowded bus system with new express routes and technology that keeps traffic lights green to speed the buses down major arteries.
To be sure, the challenges of building a workable system are enormous in a region where, in the words of Peter Gordon, a professor of urban and regional planning at the University of Southern California, "origins and destinations are ubiquitous." That means commuters are just as likely to be traveling from one suburb to another as from the suburbs to an urban core, so models like New York or Boston make little sense. Which is why it may be tempting to draw the wrong lesson from the strike -- that since the city did not grind to a halt, mass transit does not matter here.
"It may be that some of the seeming non-impact is that the impacts are diffuse and hard to quantify," said Eric H. Monkkonen, a professor of urban history and policy studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. It's one thing to measure the lost income of people who couldn't get to work. But what about the lost services for people whose workers didn't show up? Or whose secretaries were late because they were driving their sisters to work? Is a missed doctor's appointment for someone with a chronic illness a minor inconvenience?
"Just as Los Angeles is a spread-out city, it doesn't depend on any one network," Professor Monkkonen added. In the Northridge earthquake, for example, when the Santa Monica Freeway was closed because a bridge collapsed, affluent workers still managed to find ways to drive into downtown Los Angeles on surface streets. In fact, Los Angeles has a certain resilience precisely because it has no one center of action, but is instead a sprawling collection of "edge cities."
INDEED, the municipal bus systems of cities-within-the-city, like Santa Monica, kept operating and, in some cases, expanded service to relieve the strain of the M.T.A. strike. And Angelenos mostly managed to limp along, in car pools, gypsy cabs, on bicycles and on foot.
In this city, owning a car remains the most reliable mark of upward mobility, and immigrants aspire to own a used Toyota here the way they might learn the subway map in New York. But in a place where it's getting harder and harder for everyone to drive, there's reason to think the fire next time could be worse.

HEADLINE: October 22-28;
Now It's Time To Play Geography

BYLINE: By Peter Marks

 BODY:
Put aside, for the moment, thorny subjects like economic policy and national security. The 2000 presidential campaign is down to a question of geography. Eighteen states are in play, political strategists say, and in a startling reversal of received political wisdom, the number of tossup states is actually growing as the days to election day dwindle down to a few.
The candidates spent the week in a frenzied game of musical media markets, setting their campaign planes down long enough in advertising battlefields like Milwaukee and Pittsburgh and Tampa to speak above the roar of the jet engines and the crowds. 
 Gov. George W. Bush sent 28 of his fellow Republican governors in teams into the battleground states.
Vice President Al Gore, seeking to reassure those who are leaning to the Green Party candidate, Ralph Nader -- whose support in swing states like Oregon and Wisconsin could be decisive -- reaffirmed his commitment to the environment before a throng of 30,000 in Madison, home of the University of Wisconsin.
"For 24 years, I have never backed down or given up on the environment, and I never will in my whole life," boomed the author of "Earth in the Balance."
The balance of the campaign, no doubt, will be even more frenetic: the polls seem to seesaw daily between the nominees. For both of them, the enemy is not merely the opposing party, but also time. Peter Marks

HEADLINE: The World: Why Things Fall Apart;
A Slow, Preventable March Into Crisis

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
WITH its running tableau of disasters, both man-made and natural, Africa in the 1990's has shown an unerring knack for inspiring hand-wringing in the outside world and increasing self-doubt among Africans themselves about the waste and futility of half a century of independence.
Now, like an exclamation mark, the century may be closing on the descent into chaos of what has long been one of Africa's brightest corners, the former French West African country where a deeply flawed election last week produced rampaging mobs and ethnically motivated lynching, not democratic rule. By week's end, negotiations among the power seekers had begun, and an uneasy calm had taken hold. Still, the death toll was well over 100. 
 The trouble in Ivory Coast could be seen coming for at least five years, visible on the horizon like the darkness of a gathering storm. But as predictable as the disputed vote and the killings may seem, they were never inevitable.
Ivory Coast's crisis has its roots in the usual cynicism and blind ambition of politicians, but just as surely in the indifference of an onlooking world. Where Africa is concerned, it seems, extinguishing fires before they can get out of hand is scarcely ever tried.
For most Americans, the name of this country with 17 million inhabitants means nothing. In fact, there are few places in Africa today that could give the world more reason to care. For a stretch of countries from Mauritania to Nigeria, Ivory Coast, despite its modest size, has been something akin to what the United States has often been to Latin America. It has absorbed many far poorer neighbors -- more than 25 percent of the population is now foreign. With its huge exports of cocoa and coffee, sizable industrial base, good roads and working electricity and telephones (such things are not taken for granted in Africa, even today), Ivory Coast has served as the region's employer, its breadbasket, its banker, its educator and its hub.
For years, foreigners there have repeated the joke about loving to live in the capital, Abidjan, "because it's so convenient to Africa." More important, though, this was one of those rare African places that had a large and worldly middle class.
If Ivory Coast's slide goes unchecked, all that will vanish. One need only visit Liberia next door, with its skyscrapers full of squatters, to see what a gutted capital looks like, and to realize that what took generations to build can burn in a blink.
Emulation has always worked powerfully in Africa politics. In the 1960's, an often well-intentioned but ultimately disastrous socialism was in vogue. In the 1970's and 1980's, leaders began naming themselves president for life. In the mid-1990's, with the Rwandan crisis, deadly mobilization along openly ethnic lines reared its head, spreading quickly through much of East and Central Africa.
EVEN in faraway West Africa, Rwandization has become a familiar verb. For several years now, as in Rwanda, politicians have been playing to their ethnic bases, with the result that Ivory Coast is now seriously divided into three regions of roughly equal size: a Muslim north with cultural links to Mali and Burkina Faso, a Christian southeast, which has dominated the country's history, and a Christian and animist southwest with strong ancestral ties to Liberia and Guinea.
If this sounds familiar, it should. Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, broke down along almost identical lines, leading to the Biafran War in 1967. The fear of many Africa watchers is that even worse than the regional economic disaster it would occasion, an ethnic explosion of Ivory Coast would set a pattern for the region for years to come. In fact, Nigeria is facing a resurgence of ethnic violence now.
"An Ivory Coast set ablaze by ethnic hatred will light a fire clear across this region," said one Western diplomat with longtime experience in West Africa. "The only way to prevent it is for the world to engage all of the parties there and press them to respect some basic principles, especially the principle of compromise."
Many Africans have been waiting for France to lead an international effort to pressure Ivory Coast's factions to negotiate. But the wait has been in vain. The United States has condemned many of the worst abuses in Ivory Coast, where its interests are few. But France, without whose help the former colony's economy cannot run, has remained largely silent , providing support and justification for leaders even as their abuses have grown more flagrant.
While Communism was falling in Eastern Europe a decade ago, much of Africa was experiencing popular revolutions of its own. In Mali, Benin, Congo and elsewhere, citizens who organized to demand democracy were overthrowing corrupt dictators.
With little special outside help or attention, many of these early experiments in African democracy quickly foundered. But France, the only former colonial power to have maintained strong ties to its ex-possessions, worried that the end of personalized power under long-ruling dictators would open the region up to influence from others, notably the United States, and upset its interests in everything from oil fields to military bases.
Early in the 1990's, Paris decided to stem its losses by backstopping corrupt regimes in Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Gabon, resource-rich states that provided handsome returns. With the implicit backing of the French President Jacques Chirac, who had already said that Africa was "not ready for democracy," Henri Konan Bedie, the Ivory Coast leader who took power after the death of the country's founder, set out to eliminate his most important rival, a former prime minister named Alassane Ouattara.
From 1995 until the end of last year, when he was overthrown in the country's first coup, Mr. Bedie ceaselessly improvised at eliminating his rival, a former deputy director of the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Bedie invented a bogus ideology, called Ivoirite, which sought to distinguish purebred citizens, mostly deemed to be his own southern Christians, from supposed latecomers, especially northern Muslims like Mr. Ouattara.
This played on long-standing, latent hatreds. Mr. Bedie's southeastern Akan group had enjoyed the fruits of education and ultimately the power that grew out of their early contact with French colonizers. The Akan, who saw themselves as natural rulers, thought of the Muslim northerners as a "dirty" people. The southwesterners were disparaged as hotheaded near-savages.
France never seemed to tire of Mr. Bedie, but the Ivorian people did. Last Christmas Eve he was overthrown in an army coup that seemed intended to right his wrongs. That is, until the new president, Gen. Robert Guei discovered the intoxicating effect of ethnic exclusionism. Soon, he, too, was changing the rules to keep Mr. Ouattara out.
General Guei eliminated over a dozen rival candidates for the presidency, including those of the two largest parties, making a sham of this month's election. Having barred them from the race, the unpopular general was surprised to be soundly defeated in a low turnout by Laurent Gbagbo, a pioneer of the country's democracy movement.
AFTER the stunned general sought to proclaim himself president anyway, his military government was literally chased from office by tens of thousands of supporters of Mr. Gbagbo, who now claimed power. But in a country badly divided along ethnic lines, this left two-thirds of the population dangerously disgruntled and unrepresented, setting up the terrifying street confrontations between supporters of Mr. Gbagbo and Mr. Ouattara.
While much of the world, from Kofi Annan and the State Department to the South African President Thabo Mbeki and the Organization of African Unity called for new, free elections, the French government, which has always seemed more preoccupied with African power than with process, rushed to back Mr. Gbagbo.
"Don't expect comments from us that could resemble a show of paternalism or lesson-giving," said a government spokesman responding to criticism by the French press for backing the winner of a bogus election out of pure expediency. "It is not the French role."

HEADLINE: The World: Snapshot of Despair;
The Deathly Glamour of Martyrdom

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

DATELINE: GAZA

 BODY:
RABAH EL-LOH, 23, stood one afternoon in front of the shallow pit where the body of his brother, Raid, killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers, had just been set down. The funeral had taken all morning and thousands of angry mourners milled around the barren cemetery in Gaza.
"Goodbye brother," he said. "Say hello to the other martyrs." 
 Gaza is a derelict collection of boxy concrete structures, a slum of about one million people on a flat, dry piece of land about twice the size of Washington D.C. A haze of grit and dust hovers in air fouled by untreated sewage, and the young men, many of whom are unemployed, loiter in groups in the streets.
Everywhere, the walls of Gaza are plastered with poster-size photographs of those who have died in the recent clashes. Many are pictured holding a weapon in front of the gold-topped Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem.
The odd thing is that these are studio shots, like a bizarre version of a high school yearbook photo, taken long before the current unrest.
The gun is a prop, the glittering mosque is a large photograph. What was real, apparently, was the desire of these young men to fight against Israel and for a Palestinian state, and to invite death in the process. And now, at least until the pictures fade or peel away, the young men will have their deed recognized.
The decision by Raid to become a martyr was a conscious one, based, his family said, on despair of life in the Gaza Strip, hatred for Israel and a belief that not to sacrifice himself was to dishonor those who had gone before. "He spoke only of this, of being a martyr for the last four or five days," said his mother, Fatma. "I asked him not to go. But once his younger brother was wounded, he felt that it was his duty. When he left I said God be with you. I knew he would never come back."
In Gaza, those who die fighting Israel are carried on a stretcher through the streets, their bodies covered in Palestinian flags. Impassioned crowds of people swarm around the pallbearers chanting, waving flags and vowing to follow the example of the dead. Bereaved parents sit under white canopies in the blocked-off streets and serve bitter coffee and dates to lines of visitors, including uniformed members of Mr. Arafat's Palestinian police.
"Tell the man what you want to be," said Hyam Temraz to her 2-year-old son Abed, as she peeped out of the slit of a black veil.
"A martyr," the child answered.
 "We were in Jordan when my son Baraa was 4," she said. "He saw a Jordanian soldier and ran and hugged him. He asked him if it was he who would liberate Palestine. He has always told me that he would be a martyr and that one day I would dig his grave."
Nezar Rayyan, 42, a theology professor at Islamic University, is a large man with a thick black beard and the quiet gravitas of someone who has spent much of his life reading. On the walls of his office are black and white photographs that illustrate the history of Palestinians over the last five decades. They show lines of trucks carrying refugees from their villages in 1948, after the United Nations formally created Israel and the new state was attacked by its Arab neighbors. They show the hovels of new refugee camps after the 1967 war. And they show the gutted remains of Palestinian villages in what are now Israel.
Mr. Rayyan's grandfather and great-uncle were killed in the 1948 war. His grandmother died after she and Mr. Rayyan's father were forced from their village near Ashkelon. His father, who eventually settled in the Jabalya refugee camp in Gaza, was passed between relatives and grew up with the bitterness of the dispossessed.
It was a bitterness the father passed on to the son and the son has assiduously passed on to the grandchildren. "There was not a single night that we did not think and talk about Palestine," Mr. Rayyan said, his eyes moist. "We were taught that our lives must be devoted to reclaiming our land."
MR. RAYYAN spent 12 years in an Israeli jail for his pursuit of that end. His brother-in-law was a suicide bomber who blew up an Israeli bus in 1998. His brother was shot dead by Israelis in street protests seven years ago. Another brother was expelled to Lebanon and several more were wounded in clashes.
Today, his three sons -- ages 12, 15 and 16 -- daily join the youths who throw rocks at Israeli checkpoints. All, he said, yearn to be one thing -- martyrs for Palestine.
"I pray only that God will choose them," he said.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
There'll Be a Quiz On This Tomorrow

BYLINE: By KATE ZERNIKE

 BODY:
Using materials found in your home, design assignments that will allow schools in the United States to keep up with those in other countries, allow parents to keep up with the Joneses, but will not keep students up at night. In your answer, you should consider the influence of the Horatio Alger narratives on American society and the impact of longer working hours on the average American family. Parents should be involved, but not too involved. Remember to factor in time for soccer, piano lessons, family togetherness, and a healthy dose of childhood exploration and fun (your answer should define healthy). Those who do not ultimately secure a good job will receive a failing mark. Extra credit for those who gain admission to a college in the U.S. News and World Report Top 20.
STUMPED? Don't feel bad. Homework isn't really about doing work. It's about what homework stands for. 
 Reviled and even banned as recently as 50 years ago, homework has become what one author calls a "virtual icon of our culture," a culture that admires long hours as the way to the American dream. But that admiration has always been undercut by the question: Is all the work worth it?
This conflict was on display earlier this year, when the school board in Piscataway, N.J., limited nightly assignments and prohibited teachers from grading homework. Parents across the country phoned the district's superintendent to applaud him for his sanity. Others, though, railed at the decline of standards in America.
The homework pendulum has swung back and forth over the last 150 years. Public health advocates declared homework "child labor" in the 1930's, when it was banned in some cities and limited by state law in California.
Then, in 1957, the Soviets launched Sputnik, creating fear that America would lose the "space race" because its kids weren't getting a good science education. Yet another shock hit in 1983, when "A Nation at Risk," a report by the National Commission on Excellence in Education, warned that a "rising tide of mediocrity" was threatening the nation's preeminence in industry, business, and technology. In both cases, homework was seen as a way to improve schools and safeguard the nation.
To this day, said Brian Gill, a researcher at the RAND Corporation and co-author of a 1996 article titled " 'A Sin Against Childhood': Progressive Education and the Crusade to Abolish Homework, 1897-1941," there is a widespread feeling that the educational system is in crisis. One response has been to triple the average homework load of the youngest students since 1981.
But although some studies suggest that homework improves student test scores, others don't. The broadest of transnational studies, the Third International Math and Science Study in 1995, found no link between homework and achievement. For example, Japanese eighth graders got less homework than their American counterparts, but far outperformed them.
One reason Americans hold so tightly to homework is that it is wedded to two cherished national myths. It is the cauldron in which immigrants melt into the melting pot. And it is the ladder that anyone who works hard can climb to the top.
"For some parents homework is about 'You are in second grade and I want you on that Ivy League track, and one of the ways I can do that is to make sure that you are busy,' " said Jeffrey M. Young, superintendent of schools in Newton, Mass.
Homework becomes a status symbol, proof that a school and a child are of a certain caliber. Outlining the 10 purposes of homework, Joyce L. Epstein, director of the Center on School, Family and Community Partnerships at Johns Hopkins University, identifies one as public relations. Schools are judged, she said, by how much homework they give. Juliet B. Schor, a Harvard professor and author of "The Overworked American," and "The Overspent American," recently overheard one parent boast that her child attended the better of two schools in town because it assigned more homework in kindergarten.
But what of those parents, in Piscataway and elsewhere, who complain of too much homework? Mr. Young and other superintendents say they are as numerous as the parents demanding more work.
A recent by the Public Agenda Foundation, a nonprofit research group, showed that a mere 10 percent of parents think their children have too much homework, and 64 percent say they receive about the right amount. Last year, another of the group's surveys found that 50 percent of parents had had a serious argument over homework and 34 percent identified it as a "source of struggle and stress."
The two findings are not inconsistent, said Deborah Wadsworth, president of Public Agenda. Rather they indicate the conflict most parents feel. They hate the stress and struggle of homework, but also want their children to do well.
Maybe that anxiety is what homework stands for.
