HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE GREEN PARTY;
At an Iowa Rally, Nader's Supporters Stand Their Ground

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 28

 BODY:
At every mention of the word "spoiler," the crowd groaned.
The students and others who packed a hall at the University of Iowa on Friday night to hear Ralph Nader, the Green Party's presidential candidate, justify his campaign simply did not want to hear any more about the possibility that they would throw the election to Gov. George W. Bush. They were so upset at being confronted with the evil of two lesser candidates, they said, that they refused to vote again for the lesser of two evils. 
 "This year the choice is between George W. Bush and a Democrat who is to the right of Bill Clinton," complained Ed Fallon, a Democratic state representative who introduced Mr. Nader. "I don't begrudge my friends and constituents who plan to vote for Al Gore. I understand their fear of George W. Bush. But voting against somebody isn't enough anymore. If I had three hands maybe I could hold my nose, my gut and my mouth and vote for Al Gore. But in good conscience, I can't, I won't, and you shouldn't either."
Democrats were certainly nervous about the possibility: the party dispatched the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the comedian Al Franken to address students at the university, which is in Iowa City, that same afternoon.
Mr. Nader himself was unsparing in his criticism of the Democrats, attacking them more often and more harshly than he did the Republicans. In an interview after the speech, he explained that he did not feel the need to go after Mr. Bush because the problems of a Bush presidency were more readily apparent.
"Bush is a corporation running for president disguised as a person," he said, "Whereas Gore touts his environmental record, says he can match it against anyone, even me. And that's an invitation."
Others said that to wean national politics from its dependence on big business, and to give a voice to people against the death penalty, the war on drugs, genetically altered crops, economic sanctions in Iraq and a host of other causes that the people here felt deeply about, radical change was necessary.
Simply put, they said, things may have to get worse before they get better. One labor leader used the analogy of a strike: the workers would be willing to endure "short-term pain" to win long-term reforms and benefits.
Mr. Nader used another analogy, pointing out President Reagan's appointment of James Watt as the Interior Secretary, which so infuriated environmentally minded Americans that the rolls of watchdog groups doubled. "He was a provocateur," Mr. Nader said, explaining that a more palatable appointment might have been an "anesthetizer" that would have left those people complacent. "Sometimes people need a provocateur," he said.
Late in the evening, a woman asked Mr. Nader whether by voting for him she would be electing Mr. Bush and endangering the right to abortions. Mr. Nader told her that it would not necessarily happen, noting that conservative presidents have appointed liberal judges to the Supreme Court and vice versa.
The evening showed why the Nader campaign has been a political phenomenon. Not only did he fill a hall with nearly a thousand students, but many who came donated $3.50 for the privilege.
Unlike the major candidates, who speak about issues like Social Security and Medicare that are aimed at elderly voters, and issues like education that are aimed at parents, Mr. Nader tailored his message to the young.
"If you don't 'turn on' to politics," he warned, "politics will turn on you."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS BACKING PROJECTS AT HOME AT A RECORD PACE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
A few years back, the people of Toledo, Ohio, began building a new four-lane boulevard linking the northern edge of town to Interstate 280. But the money ran out before they could put on the finishing touches.
So earlier this month, Representative Marcy Kaptur, a nine-term Democrat from Toledo, set out to fix that. As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, she tucked $250,000 into a transportation spending bill to line the otherwise barren twin ribbons of asphalt with two miles of trees, shrubs and flower beds. 
 "It needed major landscaping," said Ms. Kaptur, a former city planner who justified the federal money because the spur, the Greenbelt Parkway, connects to a federal highway.
Democrats may be in the minority in Congress and may be complaining about the death of many of their legislative priorities, but when it comes to securing pet projects back home, from the most senior and secure lawmakers, like Ms. Kaptur, to the most junior and insecure members, Democrats hold their own with Republican rivals.
As lawmakers struggle to adjourn for the year, Democratic leaders are taking special care to funnel heaping helpings of pork to their most vulnerable incumbents, including Rush D. Holt of New Jersey and Joseph M. Hoeffel of Pennsylvania. "From our point of view, most of them have been very well taken care of," one senior House Democratic aide said.
Pork-barrel politics is nothing new and lawmakers from both parties engage in it. Fueled by a fat economy, budget surpluses and an election-year eagerness to shower favors on voters, Congress is on pace to set a record this year in steering taxpayer money to projects like sunflower research in North Dakota, reindeer herders in Alaska and mapping chicken genes in Michigan.
There's so much pork that one Republican House candidate, Derek Smith of Utah, is not even in Congress, but Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, had $5 million set aside for water and land-related projects in Mr. Smith's district.
"It's an embarrassment of pork riches," said Tom Schatz, president of Citizens Against Government Waste, an organization dedicated to eliminating pork, or the billions of dollars steered to projects back home that are not requested by the White House or reviewed by a Congressional committee.
It will be several weeks before the organization can tally all the pet projects included in final spending bills, but Mr. Schatz said Congress is likely to break the record, $17.7 billion, set last year.
Take just one bill, for example. In a $107.3 billion measure to finance housing, veterans and environmental projects, lawmakers earmarked 1,183 research, water and economic development initiatives. The combined value of the pet projects was just under $1.1 billion, or slightly more than what the bill provides for helping the homeless.
Of course, one man's pork is another man's prime cut. "You can probably get a good column written once in a while about pork-barrel spending and all that kind of stuff, but when you go down these items, these items are important to the constituencies in those states," Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said on the Senate floor last week.
There is no definitive breakdown between Democratic and Republican pork, but each party has its master purveyors of pet projects. Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee, had included in an Interior Department spending bill $1.25 million to repair a church in the Aleutian Islands and $176,000 for the Reindeer Herders' Association.
Democrats have their own earmarking legends, notably Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, his party's senior member on the Appropriations Committee. Among other projects, Mr. Byrd included $4.6 million in an Interior Department spending bill to help restore a downtown section of Wheeling, W. Va.
"When you have Stevens and Byrd, very persuasive chairmen who take home so much for their states, there's no credence if they say no to anyone else," Mr. Schatz said.
Endangered incumbents are typically first in line for help. Republican leaders ensured that $102 million in road and bridge projects were earmarked for Representative Jay Dickey's district in Arkansas.
Top aides to Representative Richard A. Gephardt, of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, collected a wish list from their half-dozen most vulnerable incumbents and had Mr. Gephardt tell senior Democrats on the Appropriations Committee that "there was no higher priority than theirs."
(Mr. Gephardt did not ignore his own district's needs, securing $950,000 for a local sewer project and $2 million for a traveling exhibition of documents and artifacts related to the Lewis and Clark expedition.)
Mr. Holt, a New Jersey freshman who faces a stiff re-election fight, is one of the beneficiaries, securing more than $18 million in road, dredging and bike path projects in his district.
"I try to ask for as much as I can without asking for too much," Mr. Holt said. "It's age-old politics."
Mr. Hoeffel gained $29 million in roads projects from party elders looking out for him and, like Mr. Holt, from working his own contacts among colleagues. But Mr. Hoeffel had another perhaps unlikely ally: Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican on the Appropriations Committee, but more important, a fellow Pennsylvanian.
"Let's face it, he comes from a state with a Republican senator on Appropriations whom we've worked closely with," said Frank X. Custer, Mr. Hoeffel's spokesman. "Unlike a lot of people in Washington, we've tried to work across party lines."
Perhaps the best way for Democrats or Republicans to guarantee a pet project is not just to know someone on the Appropriations Committee, but sit on the coveted panel itself.
Representative Robert E. Cramer, an Alabama Democrat on the committee, proudly announced in a news release on his Web site that in an agriculture spending bill, he had secured $725,000 for red snapper research, $600,000 for catfish-disease research and $500,000 for peanut-allergy research.
An article on pork-barrel spending would be incomplete without mentioning $500,000 that Representative David E. Price, a North Carolina Democrat on the panel, won for additional study at North Carolina State University on managing and using hog manure. "It's a severe problem in North Carolina, and this program turns waste into fertilizer pellets that don't smell," said Thomas Bates, a spokesman for Mr. Price.
Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a New York Democrat on the committee, had $100,000 set aside to help an apple-packing plant in New Paltz, N.Y., ride out a bad year, marked by low apple prices, hail storms and tornadoes. "No one has ever given us this kind of support," said Charles M. Andola, secretary of the Consolidated Fruit Packers, the plant operator.
Lawmakers from small states band together to back favorite projects. North Dakota's three-man Congressional delegation -- all Democrats -- united behind a $300,000 grant to hire a geneticist to study sunflowers at a federal laboratory in Fargo, N.D. North Dakota grows 85 percent of the nation's sunflowers.
"This is the kind of crop research we're proud of," said Laurie Boeder, spokeswoman for Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota. "Scientists are looking for ways to make sunflowers more drought-resistant, more disease-resistant and more productive to feed more people on less land."

HEADLINE: Testing Bonds in Midst of Jerusalem's Clashes

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 28

 BODY:
With crowns of leaves encircling their heads, Shmuel Mantinband and Imam Tibi tried to decide on which vacant couch to settle their toga-clad bodies. Lute music echoed forlornly through their cavernous Roman-themed banquet hall in an Old City devoid of tourists.
"Wherever you want, you're the Caesar," Mr. Tibi said to Mr. Mantinband, who indeed is the Caesar. It's on his business card. 
 For three years, Mr. Mantinband, an American-born Israeli, and Mr. Tibi, a Palestinian, have worked side by side in the Cardo Culinaria restaurant in the Jewish Quarter of the divided Old City. Mr. Mantinband, the boss, lived through Mr. Tibi's divorce, and Mr. Tibi, the manager, through the death of his employer's mother.
Together, hundreds of times, they have delivered a historic spiel to guests, peeled their grapes, washed their feet and dried between their toes. Working together in the ancient past was a bonding experience, they said. But in all that time, they avoided the present, or at least religion and politics. Then, their world exploded in a wave of violence that quickly unraveled most dreams of coexistence for Israelis and Palestinians. It also killed their business.
Yet Mr. Mantinband, 46, and Mr. Tibi, 30, kept coming to their empty restaurant. With days to fill, they talked and talked, and discovered how completely differently they saw everything that was happening.
"He saw black, I saw white," Mr. Mantinband said, adjusting the wreath encircling his knitted skullcap. "I saw black, he saw white. It could make your jaw drop."
There are not many pairs like them, Israeli-Palestinian colleagues or friends who have established a solid enough base on which to walk together through the minefields of their disagreements. But they do exist, in a smattering of tourism businesses, industrial ventures, schools and human rights organizations. And their bonds, like their joint enterprises, are being challenged.
Mr. Mantinband, for instance, asked his friend point-blank why Palestinians were putting children in the midst of clashes to be killed.
"The way it stands in the Arab street, it's jihad now," or holy war, Mr. Tibi said. "In jihad situation, the rules are off. Kids don't ask their father and wives don't need the permission of their husband. Listen, we have direct orders from God. We are fighting for our freedom."
Swigging some lemonade with mint, Mr. Mantinband looked glum. That explanation did not make things any clearer, he said.
In a previous discussion, Mr. Tibi had demanded to know why the Israelis could not control rock-throwing Palestinian crowds without shooting. "What Israeli would go face the Arabs without a gun?" Mr. Mantinband said was the first thought that crossed his mind. But he acknowledges that he then contemplated whether the cycle of violence could have been prevented if in the very beginning the Jerusalem police had used milder riot control techniques -- as they would at Jewish demonstrations.
"Shmuel needs the explanation of my side, for sure," Mr. Tibi said, crossing his legs beneath a knee-length tunic. "He knows how Israelis see things, but he doesn't know how Arabs see things. I have a better view into the Israelis. I speak Hebrew, I work in the Jewish Quarter."
The grandson of a rabbi active in the American civil rights movement, Mr. Mantinband sees himself as someone conditioned to "see people as people." A soft-spoken man who is quite enthused by his restaurant's gimmicks, he admits that when he bought the Cardo, he asked the seller if he should watch his back around the Palestinian workers. The seller, a Jew, laughed at him, he said, "and rightly so."
Now, he says proudly, he leaves Mr. Tibi blank signed checks when he goes away.
His public relations agent suggested recently that the Cardo staff, most of whom are Palestinian, deliver food to Israeli soldiers hunkered down in Gilo, a Jerusalem suburb, firing back at shooting from a Palestinian village.
"I knew it would be great publicity, with all those cameras there," said Mr. Mantinband, who grew up in St. Louis. "But I couldn't do that to Tibi and the others." Mr. Tibi looked down at the marble table before them, his face impassive.
Open and gregarious, Mr. Tibi lives on the Mount of Olives in East Jerusalem. As a youth, he had studied at the Muslim school at Al Aksa Mosque in the heart of the Old City. "It was like a yeshiva," he told his boss. "They tell you everything here is yours." He barely set foot in West Jerusalem until his late teens.
All those years, he said, "I wanted so much for the opportunity to understand who is this enemy of mine."
He learned the restaurant business in the Old City. Over 10 years that taught him an easy collegiality around "this enemy," the Israelis, he advanced swiftly into management in a way that gave him a stake in Jewish-Arab economic cooperation. With Mr. Mantinband, he oversaw the opening of a second Cardo Culinaria at a Hyatt near the Dead Sea. And he grew out of his marriage, and out of his neighborhood, although he still lives there. He developed several close friendships with Israeli Jews. And, to great scandal, he divorced his Palestinian wife, marrying a Danish woman who used to work as a waitress at the restaurant.
"Think about that, I met my wife at a restaurant, too, when I was waiting tables at Grossinger's" in the Catskills, Mr. Mantinband exclaimed. "That's another thing we have in common."
But if Mr. Tibi has expanded his world, he still sees through the nationalist and religious lenses with which he was fitted as a young boy. Similarly, Mr. Mantinband, who is not a rigid ideologue and has swung back and forth politically, voting for Labor and Likud party leaders, still sees the situation just as the Israeli government puts it forth.
Mr. Mantinband believes that the violence began on Sept. 27, when two bombs exploded beside an army-escorted settlers' convoy in the Gaza Strip, killing an Israeli soldier.
Mr. Tibi believes that it began the following day, when Ariel Sharon, the Israeli rightist, made a politicized, heavily guarded visit to the area near Al Aksa Mosque.
Mr. Mantinband can't "see the big deal" of Mr. Sharon's visit. Mr. Tibi, who let those words hang in the air an extra beat before responding, can't see how it can't be seen.
"According to Islam, as I understand, anyone is welcome there," Mr. Mantinband said. "I went and had no problem."
Mr. Tibi answered, "Shmuel, did you announce it in advance, your visit? Did you arrive with 1,500 soldiers? I have my doubts about whether he was really so interested in what there was to see."
Mr. Mantinband: "It was a political game. Sharon just wanted publicity."
Mr. Tibi: "Well, he shouldn't have played a political game on one of our most holy spots on this earth. That step has been very costly. If it had been Rabin, O.K. I would have smiled. I cried on his grave. I put his picture on my wall. But Sharon had a history, really, with blood on his hands," he said, alluding to Mr. Sharon's leading role in the Israeli incursion into Lebanon in 1982.
Both men say the deterioration in Israeli-Palestinian relations has disturbed them deeply. Mr. Tibi said that when he saw the pictures of the mob murders of two Israeli soldiers in Ramallah, he wished he could have been there. "I would have defended them with my body," he said. "I have to hang my head just thinking about it."
Softened by that, Mr. Mantinband reminded him that they both think diplomacy is the only solution.
But then he suggested that the explosive issue of Jerusalem's sovereignty be put aside for "like 99 years." Mr. Tibi gently but firmly said that he did not think the Arab world's demand for sovereignty over Al Aksa could be postponed that long.
"Until this mosque is free, there's no peace to talk about," he said.
There was nothing to do but turn back to the oil lamps, urns, trumpets and helmets inside their restaurant. "It's embarrassing to be pragmatic in a situation like this," Mr. Mantinband said. "But we were really doing a very nice business here."
Mr. Tibi added: "We will, again, I hope. But we will have to make it through many more months of this, I am afraid."

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: Truth in 2 Forms: Clinton and Lazio Both Right on Upstate

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
If there is one place that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio have butted heads -- figuratively, of course -- it is in upstate New York. To judge by their schedules (and the television images), the barnstorming candidates have attended every parade, pancake breakfast and preschool pageant north of Peekskill.
Their views on the upstate economy could hardly be more different. Mrs. Clinton sees upstate as deeply distressed, left out of the boom that has transformed New York City. Mr. Lazio contends that it has turned the corner economically, although he acknowledges that more needs to be done. She calls him an ostrich; he calls her a gloom-monger. 
 But if you travel around the state, reading the newspapers, eating in diners, talking to businesspeople and firefighters and lacrosse moms -- behaving, in short, like a candidate without the cameras -- you can discover something rather odd: both would-be senators are right.
Not about the name-calling. About the economy.
The upstate economy is certainly not in free fall the way it was just a few years ago, and in some places it has gotten a whole lot better. But the economic climate upstate does not seem nearly as vibrant as it does in the Hudson Valley, on Long Island or in New York City. Things are up upstate, but from a very depressed base.
H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and a likely Democratic candidate for governor in 2002, agrees with Mrs. Clinton, a fellow Democrat. More surprisingly, he also agrees with Mr. Lazio, her Republican opponent. "One candidate has been more critical, which is helpful, and one has been more optimistic," he said. "I think they are both right." How can that be? The employment numbers upstate have improved, he said, but upstate residents "kind of expected to catch the boom downstate they hear so much about, and they know they are not doing as well."
Any understanding of upstate New York requires knowledge of things that may at first seem far afield from economics: history, geography, technology, psychology. And it must take into account one of the most unusual aspects of upstate: its steep population loss.
But getting a grip on upstate is not easy, in part because the place is so big and diverse. Drive north from New York City to Albany, 144 miles, and you will not even be halfway to the northern tip of the state. Hang a left for Dunkirk, and you are in for at least a five-hour drive. (It's 320 miles to the west.)
Blue-collar Buffalo, the state's second-largest city, has a not-so-friendly rivalry with white-collar Rochester, 70 miles away, and neither of them has too much in common with the Capital Region. Every upstate city or town seems to have not only its own favorite food, but also its own favorite sausages, from tiny-tinies in Troy to red hots in Lockport and white hot dogs in between (a Rochester specialty).
Economic conditions vary just as widely. In Buffalo, the number of jobs has edged up just 0.3 percent in the 12 months that ended in September, according to the State Department of Labor. Meanwhile, the average increase nationally was 2 percent, and in New York City the number of jobs rose by 2.5 percent. No wonder Buffalo citizens say they are dubious about the boom.
Head east to Glens Falls, north of Albany, and it is a different story. Jobs are growing there even faster than in New York City, by 2.7 percent. Unemployment is less than 3 percent, meaning that, basically, everybody who wants a job can get one.
Companies in the Glens Falls area, especially those that make medical equipment, are expanding rapidly, said Maury Thompson, the business reporter for The Post-Star in Glens Falls. "Every week I'm writing about 20 new jobs here, 15 new jobs there," he said.
But whether people are satisfied depends a lot on whom you ask. Mr. Thompson said he was also writing about the woes of workers who until recently made $12 or $14 an hour at pulp or packaging plants that are now closed. They found new jobs quickly, but for less than $10 an hour, so they feel as if they are struggling to get by.
Manufacturing has been declining for decades across America, so some of upstate's troubles are not unique. In some places, like Syracuse, manufacturing employment has actually been climbing, slowly, since 1997. In fact, overall employment has been rising there since 1993.
So why do some people there, and across New York State, describe their cities and towns in apocalyptic terms? The short answer is population loss.
Losing population can have a profound effect on a place. A city's tax collections shrink, but the same number of roads have to be plowed, and services like garbage collection and firefighting still have to be provided. Politicians, fighting over a shrinking pie, become even less cooperative. (Many parts of upstate are famous for their ferocious partisan politics.)
True, unemployment rates are low, but it is not because jobs are plentiful; it is just that workers are scarce. Big companies are often reluctant to move to a place with a shrinking population, for fear that they will not be able to fill future jobs.
And it is all too easy for communities to become insular; there are towns in New York where it seems as if every resident was born at the local hospital. Nostalgia for the glory days can have a tight grip, even if the last great time was when the Erie Canal opened in 1825.
For the worst case, look at Buffalo. From 1950 to 1990, a quarter of a million people -- 43 percent of the population -- moved away. Of course, twice as many left New York City, but they accounted for less than 10 percent of the population.
Since then, the population trends of the state's two biggest cities have diverged. Because of foreign immigration, downstate has been growing. According to federal census estimates, New York City and Long Island have gained 246,000 residents since 1990, but the total gain statewide is only 206,000. That means the upstate population has continued to dwindle, by about 40,000 residents.
The city of Buffalo now has fewer than 300,000 residents and has lost more than 30,000 people in the last decade, according to Census Bureau estimates. Some of them moved only to the suburbs, but the population of the whole metropolitan area fell by 4 percent from 1990 to 1999. Rochester shrank, too, as did Syracuse, Binghamton, Jamestown and Elmira.
Utica and Rome, two small and neighboring cities near the heart of New York State, lost more than 7 percent of their population, almost 24,000 people, from 1990 to 1999, according to new data from the Census Bureau. The only metropolitan area that fared worse was Grand Forks, N.D.
Like Syracuse and other places around the state, Utica now finds itself with far too much housing, some of it abandoned, said Kevin M. Kelly, a self-described "social activist of the genteel sort" and president of a retail lumber company in New Hartford, just south of Utica.
Given the nature of his business, Mr. Kelly might be expected to press for people to repair those abandoned homes, which he estimates account for 10 percent of the housing stock. But, he contends, there are just not enough people to fill them; he wants them torn down. "The sooner these buildings are gone," he said, "the better we will feel."
Many people upstate are not waiting for the federal government to solve their problems. They are taking matters into their own hands and trying different approaches.
Buffalo finally abandoned its infighting to start a strong regional advertising effort. In Rochester, small entrepreneurs are picking up the slack left by layoffs at Kodak, Xerox and Bausch & Lomb. In tiny Clyde, retirees have returned home to try to improve the tourism trade. Syracuse is knocking down its abandoned housing, Troy is improving its waterfront, and Ogdensburg, far to the north, is experimenting with industrial recruitment efforts.
But drawing attention to the strengths of upstate may be the most important way that any federal politician can help the region.
Outsiders who travel there are often struck by the beauty of the countryside, the wonderful old houses, the charming downtowns, even the number of golf courses, which, along with the decreasing number of people, make it easy to get a tee time.
Of course, you have to "like the four seasons": upstate-speak for "it snows here." But it snows in Colorado, too, and Colorado is booming.
So as the candidates make their final swings through upstate, a central question remains: "How do you bring back the skilled people who you lost in the calamity of the early 1990's?" asked Marc Goloven, an ebullient economist for Chase Manhattan Bank who sees upstate as a hot growth area. "The major challenge now is to ensure that people follow the jobs now being created."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TURNOUT;
Big Push Starts To Lift Turnout Of Black Vote

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 28

 BODY:
On black radio stations and in newspapers, from pulpits to mailboxes to answering machines, Democrats and civil rights organizations have begun an effort of unprecedented size to increase the turnout of black voters in next month's presidential election. In several close states, Vice President Al Gore's chances may hinge on the effort's effectiveness.
Advertisements proclaiming "Lift every voice and vote!" have been placed on the screens of Magic Johnson Theaters before movies, and on Black Entertainment Television. Students at black colleges are being urged by entertainers to vote, and congregants at thousands of black churches will hear the same message on the Sunday before Nov. 7. Organizers for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have even registered more than 11,000 prisoners at county jails around the South. 
 One of the most promising tactics gets under way this week, when telephones in black neighborhoods will begin ringing with a recorded message from President Clinton, urging a vote for Mr. Gore. Similar calls by the president in 1998 on behalf of Democratic candidates in Georgia were considered an important reason black voters represented 29 percent of the total turnout, up from 19 percent in 1994.
"We got a lot of comments on those calls in 1998, and now everyone's doing it," said David Worley, chairman of the Georgia Democratic Party. "People especially love it when their answering machine picks up his call, and then they can play it for their friends."
The voter drive comes at a moment when both sides in the narrowly divided presidential race are frantically skipping from one contested state to another, many of which -- Michigan, Ohio, Missouri, Illinois and Florida, for example -- have large black populations that could decide the outcome. Although the turnout of black voters has usually lagged behind their percentage of the population, efforts in several states have shown that the turnout can be greatly stimulated by a combination of effective candidates and marketing.
Because the race is so close, turnout could be decisive. In Missouri, for example, where polls show the race to be dead even, the voting-age population is 10 percent black, but blacks generally constitute only 5 to 8 percent of the electoral turnout. If the turnout drive can boost black participation to 10 percent or more while the white vote remains steady, those extra two or three points could be enough to swing the state.
In the battleground state of Michigan, a concerted effort in 1998 resulted in black voters making up 19 percent of the total turnout, even though they represent only 13 percent of the state's voting population.
The drive has both a partisan wing, run by the Gore campaign and the Democratic Party, and an ostensibly nonpartisan wing, run by the N.A.A.C.P. in conjunction with several other civil rights organizations. But both are clearly drawing on the tradition that about 90 percent of black voters usually support Democrats, and they hope to transfer Mr. Clinton's enormous support among African-Americans to Mr. Gore. With enough money and enthusiasm, experts say they may break some records this year.
David Bositis, an expert on black voting with the nonpartisan Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, says this year's effort is by far the largest and most expensive ever made to generate black turnout, with at least 10 times as much money being spent as in 1996. If it succeeds, Mr. Bositis said, the percentage of this year's vote cast by blacks may for the first time equal that of blacks in the nation's voting-age population, which is 12 percent.
"In 1992, blacks were 8 percent of voters, and in 1996 and '98 they were 10 percent," he said. "If this effort succeeds and the vote gets up to 12 percent, blacks will be decisive in the outcome of the election."
To help reach that goal, the N.A.A.C.P. is spending $9 million -- from a handful of large donations -- on an enormous effort, known as Operation Big Vote, to boost black turnout in a dozen swing states, buying advertising and conducting bus tours with prominent political and entertainment figures urging people to vote. The tours are for the most part hitting the states the Gore campaign needs to win. Rural areas are not being neglected either; the nonpartisan Black Leadership Forum is distributing handbills in hundreds of barbershops and salons in small black communities.
But the campaign by the N.A.A.C.P. and related groups, which is not supposed to be partisan, has at times veered toward such strong criticism of the Republican nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, that it has drawn fire for its tone.
One television commercial features Renee Mullins, the daughter of James Byrd, the man who was dragged to death in Jasper, Tex., in 1998. In the commercial, Ms. Mullins says that when Mr. Bush refused to support a hate crimes law after her father was killed, "it was like my father was killed all over again."
(Texas does have a hate crimes law, but Mr. Bush did not support a bill increasing the penalties for crimes based on race or sexual orientation.)
Representative J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, a black Republican, said the advertisement was out of bounds in suggesting an equivalency between Mr. Bush and Mr. Byrd's killers, and predicted it would backfire.
Another advertisement, which the organization placed in The Atlanta Daily World and other black newspapers, urges voters to call Mr. Bush to complain that he has not sufficiently supported the prohibition of racial profiling.
Andrea Pringle, communications director of the N.A.A.C.P. National Voter Fund, which was established in July, said the advertisements were not intended to promote Mr. Gore. "The intent is to raise the issue of hate crimes legislation, which is an important subject," she said. "In examining any issue, people want to know where the candidates stand on issues, the same reason you have debates and such. This is an important time, an important election cycle where you have an opportunity to elect both a pro-civil rights president and a pro-civil rights Congress, which is very important to the N.A.A.C.P."
But many Republicans say the group's drive is the equivalent of soft-money advertising for Mr. Gore and the Democrats. The Republican National Committee is also beginning an unusual advertising campaign on black radio stations, urging listeners to consider the party's position on education and taxes, but the attempt is not considered likely to change the overwhelming preference of African-Americans for Democratic candidates.
The larger efforts by the Democrats and the N.A.A.C.P. are based on previous attempts to increase black turnout in carefully selected states, in some cases the same ones that have become battlegrounds in this year's contest. In Michigan, for example, black turnout increased from 9 percent of the total in 1992 to 13 percent in 1996 to 19 percent in 1998, according to a study by the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies. In Illinois, it rose from 14 percent in 1992 to 17 percent in 1996.
One of the largest increases occurred in Georgia, now a model for much of this year's national efforts. Georgia's turnout was 19 percent black in 1994, with that figure rising to 25 percent in 1996 and 29 percent in the midterm elections of 1998, an overall increase of more than 50 percent. Many blacks turned out to support Gov. Roy E. Barnes and two black candidates on the statewide ballot, and to vote against an unpopular candidate for lieutenant governor who had been making overtly race-based appeals to whites.
But the Democrats also used several effective marketing techniques: mailing tailored literature to black registered voters, placing ads on black radio stations and placing recorded telephone calls by Mr. Clinton and prominent black leaders to black households, urging them to vote. This technique is easier in the nine Southern states (and parts of seven others) covered by the federal Voting Rights Act, where registered voters must record their race, but it can also be used elsewhere.
"The idea was to get 50 hits per black registered voter," said Mr. Bositis of the Joint Center. "In other words, 50 times where a black voter would get a phone call or a letter, or encounter an ad on a radio station or in a black newspaper. They met their goals in Georgia, and it worked."
Georgia, where Mr. Bush has consistently been several points ahead in the polls, is not considered a battleground this year, and neither candidate is running television ads here. But the techniques used here and in other states in 1998 are being used in this election's most contested states. Late last week, Mr. Clinton began recording telephone messages that make points on behalf of Mr. Gore similar to the points he had made on behalf of Democrats candidate two years ago.
Mr. Clinton was also scheduled to conduct a telephone conference call with several hundred black pastors today, in which he will suggest points they can make in their Sunday sermons leading up to the election.
Not everyone is convinced the methods will be as effective as they were in 1998, however. Georgia State Representative Bob Holmes, who is also director of the Southern Center for Studies in Public Policy at Clark Atlanta University, said sophisticated marketing was often not as important as the nature of the candidates.
"The thing that really energizes black voters is the presence of a candidate who is seen as adversely affecting their interest," said Mr. Holmes, a Democrat who teaches political science at the historically black college. "This year, we don't seem to have the same sort of demon or enemy on the ballot. Bush comes across superficially as a good guy, so many people aren't bothering to look closely at his record."

HEADLINE: Struggling Nassau Republicans Bench Elephant in State Senate Races

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y.

 BODY:
In the solidly Republican precincts of Nassau County, G.O.P. candidates have literally shed their political colors, a visible sign of their rush to abandon the county's once vaunted Republican machine.
The candidates have dropped the electric blue and orange that had come to symbolize both Nassau County and its reigning party. The new colors are soothing pastels and earth tones, a switch that is by no means inconsequential. 
 Nassau Republicans, particularly the county's five state senators, have been forced to reinvent themselves in a tough election year. They have expunged nearly all mention of their county party affiliation from advertisements, mailings and other campaign material, keenly aware that the county's near fiscal collapse helped propelDemocrats to power in the County Legislature for the first time in decades last November. Even the Republicans' longtime logo, a bald eagle, has vanished from some billboards.
The stakes are high, not only for local Republicans but also for the statewide party. Republicans are locked in a fierce struggle to maintain control of the State Senate, and they see the prospect of losing even a few races in Nassau as a grave threat.
The party's leaders in Albany need to win Nassau so much that they have instructed their candidates to steer clear of partisan appeals and run campaigns stressing cheerful nonpartisan themes: making college affordable, improving schools, cleaning up the environment, fighting consumer fraud and providing health coverage for the poor.
Michael A. L. Balboni, a Republican senator from Mineola, summed up the strategy by saying: "Nassau County is changing, and people here are less interested in party affiliation than they used to be. They are more interested in what you've accomplished. That's why I am trying to build a base of support that is truly nonpolitical."
Republicans still outnumber Democrats three to two, and service in Nassau has begun the careers of some of the state's most influential politicians, including Ralph M. Marino, the former majority leader of the State Senate, and Alfonse M. D'Amato, the three-term United States senator who anointed George E. Pataki as the Republican candidate for governor in 1994.
But this year, Nassau County is one of the most interesting -- and highly unpredictable -- places in the state politically. Its Republican base still poses a battle for Democrats, who are trying to unseat all five of the county's Republican senators.
At the same time, Republicans are expressing concern that the voter uprising of last November will continue on Election Day and sweep some Republican incumbents from power, along with one of the nation's last great political machines. The county is still facing the prospect of a state takeover as local leaders grapple with huge deficits projected over the next few years.
"Nassau Republicans are desperately trying to distance themselves from the county organization that gave birth to most of their careers," said Senator Eric T. Schneiderman of Manhattan, who heads the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee. "But the Democrats of Nassau County are not going to let them fool voters that way."
The county's fiscal problems are creating headaches for Republicans outside the county as well. Democrats have unleashed a series of campaign advertisements attacking Republican senators in New York City and upstate for voting to approve a $100 million state bailout for Nassau County. Their strategy is simple enough: stir up resentment against Republicans for bailing out one of the richest counties in the nation.
Democrats, too, are running campaigns that make little mention of their own agenda. Instead they try to portray the five Republican senators as pawns of Nassau County's Republican leadership, particularly the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, who has been widely blamed for the mismanagement.
For example, one Democratic television commercial shows a man crouching under a desk as the narrator accuses Republican senators of doing Mr. Gulotta's bidding in the State Capitol. "Our state senators can't hide from their records as members of the Nassau Republican machine," the narrator says. "We need state senators who will put our needs first, not their party's."
Democrats have been particularly emboldened by the returns of last year's county races showing how poorly the Republican line did in the districts held by Nassau's five Republican state senators: Carl L. Marcellino, Kemp Hannon, Mr. Balboni, Dean G. Skelos and Charles J. Fuschillo. Over all, the Republican line received 36 percent of the vote in Mr. Marcellino's district, 41 percent in Mr. Hannon's district, 36 percent in Mr. Balboni's district, 40 percent in Mr. Skelos's district and 39 percent in Mr. Fuschillo's district.
Democrats say these figures spell potential trouble for the Republican Party when taken together with recent internal polls showing lingering voter resentment over the county's fiscal mismanagement under Republican rule. "Nassau County is a total wild card," said Martin Connor, the Democratic minority leader in the Senate.
But Republicans say that Democrats are drawing the wrong conclusion from last year's results, noting that Republican senators are far more popular and better known in their districts than are county legislators, and have records that distinguish them from local officeholders. That said, the five Republican senators have sought to distance themselves from their local colleagues, asserting that the county's problems are not the fault of the state. They have chosen to run campaigns that feature warm, almost apolitical themes that make a direct appeal to women and elderly voters.
In the Fifth Senate District near Oyster Bay, Mr. Marcellino's campaign is blanketing neighborhoods with glossy brochures and pamphlets that underscore the overall strategy. One pamphlet features a photograph of two boys playing in a pile of bright orange and red leaves and then lists the senator's work on behalf of improving schools and cleaning up the environment. "No one is fighting harder for our children than Senator Carl Marcellino," the pamphlet reads.
The pitch is almost identical -- in tone, at least -- in the Ninth Senate District here in the Rockville Centre area, where Mr. Skelos's political operation is circulating fliers reminiscent of Ronald Reagan's 1984 "Morning In America" advertisements. They feature a photo of the sun rising over water with a hopeful message: "Cutting taxes, creating jobs, a growing economy. A brighter future made possible because of Senator Dean Skelos's leadership."
On the campaign trail, the senators maintain the same buoyant tone and message. The other day, for example, Mr. Skelos visited a center for the elderly here in his district, where he delivered a stump speech laying out Albany's accomplishments this year: prescription drug coverage for the elderly, additional restrictions on gun owners, new penalties for hate crimes and financial assistance for college students.
Then Mr. Skelos noted, with some relish, that Washington could not make good on such an ambitious agenda. "This has been a remarkable year in Albany," he said, drawing applause. "I like to kid my federal friends that we accomplished in Albany what Washington is still talking about."
But for all the cheery talk, Democrats are working hard to remind Nassau voters that their state senators are creations of the Republican machine that brought the county close to financial ruin. Larry Silverman, a lawyer who is Mr. Marcellino's Democratic challenger, poked fun at the fact that Nassau Republicans are so desperate to soften their image and distance themselves from their own party that they are beginning to sound like Democrats.
"If one did not know Mr. Marcellino was a Republican, one would think he was a Democrat, based on the issues," Mr. Silverman said. "He is running on a Democratic record, not his own." But Mr. Silverman vowed not to let voters forget his challenger's political roots.
"Marcellino is the handpicked successor to Ralph Marino," he said, referring to the former majority leader, who came from Oyster Bay. "He is the product of the Nassau Republican machine. He has marched lock step with the party from the start."

HEADLINE: Make Terrorists Pay a Real Price

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"U.S. Military Placed on Highest Alert in Several Hot Spots" (news article, Oct. 24) is an ominous reminder of the changing face of war. Never again will an Arab country or terrorist confront the strength of the United States military. Rather, individual terrorists, financed by various countries and groups, will strike at our Achilles' heel: public support. 
How many lost American lives will the public endure before it calls for withdrawal of American forces from the Middle East? The argument that oil justifies our presence there is no longer valid; with or without our soldiers there, oil prices will remain high, to the detriment of the American economy.
The interesting question is whether the United States is willing to lose lives for defending democracy and regional stability. If so, then why are we not in Central Asia and Africa?
 
JAMES WINDLE
Bellevue, Wash., Oct. 24, 2000

HEADLINE: When 'Just Sit Tight' Is the Wrong Advice

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
AT first it sounds like a grimly humorous way to describe what you suffered on your last airline flight, when you were wedged for hours in a tight seat and the tray table slammed into your belly like a karate chop after the passenger in front of you decided to recline for a snooze.
But "economy-class syndrome" is a real term given to what some medical experts claim is a more serious consequence of long airplane trips: a circulatory problem known as deep-vein thrombosis, which is essentially a blood clot. Economy-class syndrome turned up in headlines last week after a 28-year-old British woman collapsed and died at London's Heathrow Airport following a 20-hour, 10,000-mile flight from Australia (with a single stop in Singapore). An autopsy attributed her death to a deep-vein thrombosis. 
 Deep-vein thromboses caused by immobility, a condition first widely diagnosed among Londoners jammed into air-raid shelters during World War II, has been increasingly reported among air travelers in recent years as airplane seating became more cramped on ever-longer domestic and international flights.
How serious a threat is it? While there are disputes about the numbers of documented cases, the potential for circulatory problems caused by immobility is serious enough that airlines "have given extensive attention to this issue in the United States and will continue to do so," said Michael Wascom, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, which represents the domestic airline industry.
Mr. Wascom said that his group, in affiliation with the Aerospace Medical Association, publishes a booklet for passengers called "Useful Tips for Air Travelers," which he said "covers a variety of cabin-environment issues, including recommended practices to prevent leg compression and blood pooling" on long flights.
British advocates of strengthened governmental oversight on issues like cramped airline seating and the possible transmission of infectious diseases in poorly ventilated cabins made widely reported claims last week that in Britain alone, 30,000 air travelers experienced deep-vein thromboses after flying last year. But aviation-medicine experts in the United States say these numbers are wildly exaggerated.
"If there was that kind of an epidemic, the aerospace medical world would be very active" in sounding an alarm, said Russell B. Rayman, a physician who is executive director of the Aerospace Medical Association, a group that represents professionals involved in clinical and research work in the aviation industry.
Reports tying the blood clots to air travel have intensified in recent years, after airlines began cramming more seats into their planes. A decade ago, the space between seats in a typical airline economy-class cabin was about 35 inches. Now it is 31 inches on most planes (American Airlines gives a little more), and among frequent fliers complaints about cramped space rank second only to those about delays.
While there are disputes about the numbers of cases, airlines are supporting medical studies of deep-vein thrombosis, and some are defending themselves against lawsuits filed by passengers who claim cramped seating caused deep-vein thrombosis conditions.
On its Web site, British Airways has a health advisory that addresses deep-vein thrombosis. "It has also been referred to as 'economy class syndrome,' " the site says, adding: "This is misleading, because individuals seated in theaters, cars, trucks, buses etc. may all be at risk." And the blood clots "have been reported in travelers in premium cabins as well as economy," the site says. "It seems to be the immobility rather than the environment which is a factor."
Over all, about five million Americans a year suffer from the condition, which accounts for about 800,000 hospitalizations annually, according to the DuPont Pharmaceuticals Company, which sells a blood-thinning drug, Innopehn, used to treat the condition. Most susceptible to the ailment are people who have recently had surgery, people with cancer, heart disease or diabetes, and "those who are immobile for a prolonged period," DuPont said.
"Certainly crowding and especially immobility increase the risk" of deep-vein thrombosis in air travel and in any other situation where physical motion is constricted, said Dr. Rayman. He added that when he took an 18-hour flight home from Asia last week, in business class, he made sure to leave his seat regularly.
"I get up and wander around every hour or so," on a long flight, he said. Even if it means disturbing other passengers to climb out across a row of seats, passengers should force themselves to stretch their legs, he suggested.
The disputed claim that air travel accounted for 30,000 deep-vein thrombosis cases in Britain was made by a group in Oxford, England, called the Aviation Health Institute.
"The shock to us is we've found it can happen to anyone," said Farrol Kahn, the director of the organization. 'We'd done research on people over age 50 because that's where you tend to find pre-existing circulatory problems, but we're now seeing it in fit people in their 30's and younger."

An article last Sunday about a circulatory problem that can afflict airline passengers and others who remain immobile for extended periods misidentified a blood-thinning drug that is used to treat it. The drug, manufactured by the DuPont Pharmaceuticals Company, is Innohep, not Innopehn.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Calculating One Kind of Middle Class

BYLINE: By TOM ZELLER

 BODY:
COURTING the middle class, as presidential candidates are wont to do, requires no great political calculus: most Americans -- nearly 70 percent by one count -- reckon that the siren song is directed at them. And while it's true that some wealthier folk are comfortable with the label of upper-middle class, and a good quarter of industrious citizens will tag themselves working class, stark categories like "upper class" and "lower class" remain unpopular.
 Self-selecting one's station, however, is a luxury afforded only by polls, while defining the actual middle class has kept economists, politicians and sociologists busy for decades. 
 No official definition exists.
 Some experts advocate an equation of poverty-rate-times-three. Others prefer to pinpoint the median income for all households (currently around $40,000) and find some range above and below it. And every formula is flawed to the extent that it fails to accurately measure the debts, expenses and investments that inform day-to-day life for most people.
 Still, there is a range of household income, and somewhere in that, there's a middle. The following is one way of defining the nation's bourgeois, and it may be surprising to learn that this middle class, the mathematical middle, isn't quite so well-heeled as the middle class Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George Bush are romancing.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

 CORRECTION:
A chart last Sunday illustrating definitions of the middle class referred incorrectly to families' average spending on fuel. The $737 expense for fuel oil is annual, not monthly. The $50 monthly item was for natural gas, not gasoline.
